And because the universe enjoys layering its irritants like a sadistic pastry chef, somewhere nearby a celebration has switched on its speakers, and the bass is marching through my closed doors and windows as if low frequency has diplomatic immunity; I can’t even record it properly on my phone because the microphone obediently listens to mid and high frequencies—polite citizens—and largely ignores the subterranean thump that travels through walls, bones, and teeth, the way a rumor travels through a family without ever appearing in writing. The physics is straightforward and therefore insulting: long wavelengths wrap around obstacles, they don’t need a line of sight, they don’t care about your expensive window seals; the body is an accidental antenna, and my skull, it turns out, is a decent resonator at someone else’s preferred tempo. *Congratulations*, I tell myself, *you’ve become a percussion instrument.*

I get headaches from bass, the kind that feel less like pain and more like being slowly edited—some invisible intern deleting your ability to think in full sentences—while the backhoe conducts a parallel seminar in air pollution, tossing particulate matter into the lane as if the atmosphere is an infinite bin. I’ve watched neighborhood cats pause mid-prowl, mouths slightly open, that faint panicky gulp that says the air is no longer a background, it’s a negotiation; watching an animal struggle to breathe is a moral argument delivered without words, which is convenient, because words are dangerous here when you refuse to perform the usual gestures of reverence.

People say “noise” as if it’s just sound with bad manners, but noise is a physical force and also a political one—noise is what you produce when you don’t have to care who is hearing it. There’s a small, bleak insight hiding inside that sentence: the loudest people are often the ones least forced to imagine other minds, which is why my fantasies sometimes get petty and anatomical. I catch myself wishing I could become one of those blessedly uncomplicated creatures—overconfident, incurious, impervious to evidence—because ignorance is not merely a lack, it’s an insulation, a thermal blanket for the brain, and I am cold with awareness. Then I remember I’ve read too many books, and there’s no unreading, no voluntary lobotomy package on offer, no “return to factory settings” for a life that has tasted clarity.

And then there are the podgy female shrill studio anchors—studio hippos in psychedelic fluorescent jackets, bobbing in climate-controlled tanks of light—bellowing made-up “breaking” nonsense with the practiced fury of people paid by the syllable, as if shouting were verification and urgency were evidence; the graphics strobe, the tickers crawl, the producers feed them outrage pellets, and they inflate every rumor into a national emergency because silence would reveal the emptiness, because in this economy decibels are treated as content and confidence as truth, and I can hear the same garbage news playing in neighbors’ houses in accidental stereo and some cursed 8D surround—one TV a fraction of a second behind another, voices phasing like a cheap echo effect—because winter air carries sound better, the colder, denser atmosphere acting like a faithful transmission medium, a bitch that doesn’t discriminate between Bach and propaganda, between a lullaby and a lie.

When I was young in old North Calcutta, the lane had its own rough logic, its own limits; the street vendors knew where to stand, the rickshaw bells had a rhythm, the neighborhood, the *para*, could be irritating and intimate in the same breath, and yes there was noise then too, but it had gaps, pauses, pockets of accidental quiet. Now the city behaves like a badly maintained sound system: every knob is stuck at maximum, the equalizer is set by a drunk, and the person holding the remote is convinced loudness is the same thing as joy. The celebration music isn’t even music anymore, not in the human sense; it’s a low-frequency occupancy claim, a sonic flag planted into the air—this is ours, this hour is ours, your skull is ours too, don’t pretend you have boundaries.

I try to think about the engineering, because engineering at least has the decency to be falsifiable. Why does the phone miss the bass? Because tiny microphones are designed with high-pass filtering to reduce handling noise and wind rumble; because dynamic range is finite; because designers assume you want speech intelligibility, not the seismic autobiography of your neighborhood DJ. Why does bass penetrate? Because the wavelength at, say, 50 Hz is several meters long, and your window is not a fortress, it’s a suggestion. Why does this all feel like a personal attack? Because the brain is a pattern machine, and it hates randomness; it keeps trying to assign intention to what is merely structural failure.

And then the backhoe yanks me out of acoustics and into civics, because the road is being “fixed” again, which in India can mean anything from legitimate maintenance to a tender being “utilized” to keep a chain of petty patronage fed, and the trouble is that both look identical from the balcony: dust, noise, a man in a reflective vest pretending to supervise reality. We have built a society where the visible work is often theater, and the invisible work—planning, inspection, accountability—is a rumor told only in brochures.

There’s a colonial ghost in this too, as there is in almost everything we touch here, including the very idea of a “proper road.” The city’s arteries were widened and straightened for commerce and control, for moving goods and troops, for making bodies legible to administration; the British loved a line you could draw with a ruler, and we inherited the fetish for visible order without inheriting the ethics that might sustain it. Postcolonial pride then arrives like a belligerent cousin at a wedding—loud, easily offended, ready to interpret criticism as treason—and suddenly a complaint about particulate matter becomes an insult to the nation, as if the nation is a fragile god who must be protected from data.

Speaking of gods: there’s a special local superstition that if you slap enough mythology onto a problem, it becomes sacred and therefore exempt from improvement. Air is bad? Must be karma. Roads collapse? Must be fate. People suffer? Must be a test. This is not spirituality; it’s intellectual tax evasion. The old patriarchal trick—wrap the mess in metaphysics, then scold anyone who asks for a receipt. I’m allergic to it, and allergies, inconveniently, involve breathing. At some point, as the bass continues thumping like a lazy heartbeat and the road continues being amputated in sections, my mind wanders into etymology, because that’s what it does when it’s cornered: it tries to build little museum displays inside the skull, as if labeling a thing makes it survivable.

I admit, I’ve been cheated by my own romanticism too. I came back to India with that NRI sheen still on my eyes—the belief that if you bring skills and sincerity, the world will meet you halfway—and the country greeted me like a street magician: smile, patter, flourish, now your wallet is gone and you’re somehow applauding. The damage isn’t only financial; it’s neurological, a slow erosion of trust until even simple interactions feel like hostile negotiations. Somewhere in there I learned a cowardly wisdom: tell the truth too directly and you invite consequences; bluntness is treated as aggression, rationality as arrogance, and the demand for evidence as an insult to someone’s ancestral pride. So I’ve become careful in the ugliest way—careful not because I respect others, but because I don’t trust them.

And then there’s my mother, which is where the essay stops being an essay and becomes a daily manual. I don’t have the luxury of grand ambitions anymore; the remaining ambition is mechanical: keep a set of lungs working, keep oxygen moving in and out, keep infections away, keep panic from becoming physiology, because she is enfeebled by that inexorable label of time we call age, and she needs the financial support to still exist — and if she doesn't I have nothing else to look forward to. This is the part people don’t put in patriotic speeches—the part where “family values” are not slogans but unpaid respiratory labor. I had bought her and myself an RO purifier last year, which is its own small satire: clean water as a consumer upgrade, like a streaming subscription, while the city outside treats air as an ashtray. The RO sits there, humming softly, a tiny private infrastructure, the domestic equivalent of building your own moon because the sky has been outsourced to incompetence. Just recently many people died in Indore, it happened somewhere else, elsewhere is a license to be cavalier in India, so I hide our insignificant lives behind a RO. 

<Yt src="https://youtu.be/5pagAmRUo_g?si=dfiKJNomhTmTVwrS" />

Sometimes I wonder if this is what modern citizenship is: you pay for your own micro-safety while the macro-system rots, and then you’re told you’re ungrateful for noticing. The post-leftist in me is tired of slogans; the rationalist in me is tired of magical thinking; the *bhadralok* in me—God help me—still wants to believe that education should produce a gentler society rather than a better-armed one. But education here is often ornamental, a certificate nailed to the wall like a dead butterfly, while the real social currency is volume: volume of voice, volume of faith, volume of certainty, volume of music. The subwoofer becomes a political model.

There’s a philosophy-of-mind angle hiding in the bass too, because of course there is. The brain is a prediction engine; it tries to reduce surprise by modeling the world. In a stable environment, prediction becomes wisdom. In an unstable one, prediction becomes anxiety. You can’t settle into thought when the sensory stream is constant assault—noise spikes, dust, honks, sudden shouting, the backhoe’s metal teeth—so your mind becomes reactive, twitchy, short-horizon, and then the same society that shattered your attention mocks you for lacking calm. We create a landscape that punishes cognition, then reward the people best adapted to cognitive shortcuts, then pretend it’s virtue.

So yes, I sometimes fantasize about becoming stupider—not morally worse, just simpler, buffered, less permeable. It would be efficient. But the problem with knowing how things work is that you start seeing the joinery everywhere: the way low-frequency sound bypasses your walls, the way PM2.5 bypasses your cilia, the way corruption bypasses accountability, the way mythology bypasses causality, the way nationalism bypasses shame. Knowledge is a flashlight you can’t switch off, and once it’s on, you see the dust dancing in the beam.

Around dusk the construction slows for a moment—never stops, just pauses like a predator licking its lips—and I take that pause as if it were a gift from a reluctant universe. I rinse a glass from the RO, hold it up, watch the water catch the light; it looks clean in that narrow sense, transparent and obedient, and it’s absurd that such a small clarity feels like a victory. Outside, the bass continues, indifferent, and a thin film of gray settles on the window ledge again, as if the day has been gently powdered with ash.

I wipe the ledge with a damp cloth, once, slowly, not because it matters, not because the cloth will defeat a city, but because my hands need to do something that has a beginning and an end.

The cloth comes away dark, and the speakers thump on, and that’s the whole thesis.


# File: src/lib/posts/benfords-fucking-law-india.md

---
title: "Benford's Fucking Law and the Great Indian Cover-Up"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251129-WA0003.jpg"
date: 2026-01-11
description: "A foul-mouthed Bengali man rants about India's statistical masturbation, cooked government numbers, and the mathematical fuckery they forgot to hide."
category: 'math'
published: true
color: "green"
---

<script>
    import BenfordVisualizer from '$lib/components/viz/BenfordVisualizer.svelte';
</script>

<Pi src="IMG-20251129-WA0003.jpg" />



The smell, right, let’s start with the smell—because it *always* fucking starts with the smell in this country, doesn’t it?—like someone boiled a thousand election affidavits in cow piss, threw in some rotting sarson ka saag, stirred with a broom previously used to beat a Dalit voter unconscious, and let it ferment in a cracked municipal drain for three Lok Sabha terms. That’s the stench that hit me as I opened the morning paper—no, not *read* it, I mean physically opened the thing, because it was still wet with printing ink and statistical diarrhea—and the top headline, in its usual syphilitic optimism, screamed “INDIA FASTEST GROWING ECONOMY IN THE WORLD.” In font size so large it looked like the number of unemployed graduates in Bihar.

And I thought: here we fucking go again.

Every fucking quarter, like a drunken uncle showing up at your door with a new business plan involving turmeric pills and WhatsApp forwards, the Government of India lurches out of the shadows with another goddamn “revised” GDP estimate, some “unexpected” fiscal surplus, some suspiciously round number of houses built, jobs created, toilets summoned into existence like caste-neutral mushrooms from the rectum of Modi’s economic miracle.

They *can’t* help themselves. These oily bureaucratic cocksuckers fiddle with numbers like perverts at a wet sari contest. They rub and rub the digits until they glisten, smooth, photo-ready—until that surplus deficit curve looks less like a bar chart and more like Shah Rukh Khan’s abs in a dimly lit, poorly regulated factory.

And what do they think? That we’ll just swallow it? That every fucking round number is divine revelation? No variance, no edge-case, no oddball first digit? Just neat, pre-chewed, saffron-tinted bullshit?

Except—*EXCEPT*—there’s this beautiful little motherfucker called **Benford’s Law**.

Oh yes. Let me introduce you to the thing they forgot to Photoshop.

Benford’s Law, named after some boring American nerd who probably died virginal but satisfied, is the statistical equivalent of a snitch. A narc for numbers. It says—listen up, you spreadsheet-tweaking sons of bitches—that in real-world data sets, the *first digit* of most numbers isn’t evenly distributed. It’s not a casino. It’s rigged by nature, physics, and entropy. You *expect* 1s. Loads of ‘em. Then 2s. Then fewer 3s. By the time you get to 9, it’s like finding a functioning ATM in Behala during demonetization—rare, suspicious, possibly a trap.

And here’s the kicker: when data is *fake*—massaged, adjusted, enhanced like an aging actor’s headshot—it breaks the Benford pattern. It sniffs of human intervention. It's *too* smooth, *too* pretty. Like GDP numbers that magically round off to 8.0% three months before elections. Or tax revenue growth rates that jump from 4.3% to 7.9% in a single quarter with no fucking explanation besides “robust reforms.”

Reforms, my hairy, overboiled Bengali ass. That’s not reform. That’s statistical necrophilia. That’s dragging the corpse of a failed policy across the screen and faking a moan.

And I know, I *know*, some chucklefuck will say, “But all governments lie.” Sure, sure. America lies with PowerPoints. China lies with ghost cities. But India—India lies like a municipal contractor: sloppily, smugly, and with chai-stained fingers that leave fingerprints all over the Excel sheet. They forget the details. They forget that digits, like bodies in a canal, float weirdly when tampered with.

Let me tell you something. In a real economy, with real transactions, the digits are messy. You get weird spikes. 1001. 342. 7882. But when these Number Bhakts cook the books, they pick numbers like they’re decorating a fucking cake: 500,000 beneficiaries. 10,000 new startups. 8.0% growth. 1,000,000 new toilets. Always zeroes at the end. Zeroes like the future of this fucking country if we keep letting chartered accountants dictate reality.

And here’s the fun part—*Benford’s Law doesn’t care about your nationalism*. It doesn’t bend for Vande Mataram. It just crunches. You run it on the Election Commission's expense reports, or the PM CARES disbursements, or the Ujjwala LPG connections—and you’ll see the lie. A gentle slope becomes a clumsy staircase. That 1 should’ve appeared 30% of the time, but here it is, at 8%, wheezing like a retired sarkari babu in a lift.

Because *truth* has a fingerprint. And so does bullshit.

The real tragedy? No one in the country gives a wet fart anymore. Not the journalists, who’d rather review South Indian masala blockbusters than dig through dusty PDFs from the Ministry of Fuck-All. Not the economists, most of whom are too busy consulting for the same ministries they used to critique. And not the public, god bless their WhatsApp-forwarded brains, who think GDP is a kind of paratha and fiscal deficit means you’re not praying hard enough.

Meanwhile I’m sitting here, surrounded by fungus, cockroach wings, and newspaper clippings, trying to remember if I’ve paid my electricity bill or if that was just a hallucination brought on by the smell of the neighbor’s incense sticks, which might actually be burning tax documents from the Panchayat office.

Oh, and let’s not forget *every* budget season, when the finance minister—some stone-faced, menopause-stung ex-banker with a haircut sharp enough to cut interest rates—comes on TV and reads out numbers like a GPS glitching in Sanskrit. And everyone claps. Claps! Like schoolboys watching a monkey dance, not realizing the monkey has their pension fund in his anus.

I remember this one time—I kid you not—I tried to run a Benford analysis on the rural employment data released post-COVID. And the fuckers had already “pre-aggregated” the data into percentiles. No raw numbers. Just vibes. It was like trying to reverse-engineer a turd back into a salad.

No error margins. No footnotes. Just bold-face digits and an image of a tribal woman smiling under a plastic banner, as if that smile wasn’t Photoshopped in a Gurgaon basement by a kid named Deepak being paid in Maggi and performance pressure.

It’s not that they’re hiding the truth.

They *are* the lie.

The entire fucking apparatus is like a numbers-themed haunted house—meant to disorient, distract, and if possible, make you shit your pants before you reach the exits. And most of us? We just shuffle along, clutching our ration cards, hoping the lights stay on long enough to cook the rice.

I once had a friend—statistician, paranoid, probably correct—who said if you really wanted to prove malfeasance, just publish a Benford analysis of campaign expenditures across five states. But he didn’t. He died. Or disappeared. Or got a government fellowship, which is the same thing.

Anyway.

Benford would be proud.

No—Benford would be *fucking furious*. But what does it matter?

The last honest digit in India died in a ration queue in 2016.

<BenfordVisualizer />

And here's the bit that really puts chilli powder on the chapped asshole of this whole spectacle: if you ask a fucking computer as above, to generate numbers—just blindly, randomly, like a digital toddler flinging digits out its silicon asshole—they still follow Benford’s Law. Why? Because even so-called pseudorandomness isn’t truly random, it’s math underneath, beautiful cruel math—multiplicative cascades and modular congruences and other such abstract foreplay—which means it accidentally stumbles into the same curved frequency distribution that nature, markets, populations, and entropy follow. The math doesn’t cheat. The math is dumb but honest. It doesn’t care about elections or headline GDP or some sweaty babu’s appraisal. Meanwhile, our government’s idea of randomness is “how many toilets should we say we built this week?” followed by an office boy spinning a fucking chakra wheel labeled 1000, 2000, 5000, and Jai Hind.


# File: src/lib/posts/bengalis-eat-birds.md

---
title: "Bengalis Eat Birds: A Love Story in Feathers and Grease"
date: "2025-04-05"
description: "In Calcutta, the city where time ferments like leftover ilish, we eat birds with such enthusiasm it makes even the most carnivorous of colonials look like lactose-intolerant Quakers."
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251214-WA0013.jpg"
category: "personal"
color: "red"
published: true
---


<Pi
    src="IMG-20251214-WA0013.jpg" 
    caption="Winged poems, once tweeting now stewing."
/>

Bengalis eat birds. Yes. Yes, my friend. Birds. Not *bird food*. Not sunflower seeds and safflower dreams and millet melancholia. Not peck-peck vegetarianism with beaky restraint. No. We eat birds, actual flappity-flaps, winged poems, once tweeting now stewing.

Some cultures fly birds. Some cage them. Some revere them as messengers of God or metaphors in corporate PowerPoints. We marinate them in mustard, grind their bones into paste for *jhol*, and chew on cartilage with the same spiritual solemnity the Vatican reserves for wafers.

Because in Calcutta, the city where time ferments like leftover *ilish*, we eat birds with such enthusiasm it makes even the most carnivorous of colonials look like lactose-intolerant Quakers.

# The Poultry Hierarchy

Start with the humble chicken. *Gallus gallus domesticus*. Sanskrit for “seriously, again?” The British brought it and we turned it into "murgir jhol"—a bowl of poultry grief where dead chicken floats in turmeric regret, bobbing with potatoes that never stood a chance. Not to mention "rezala"—the Mughal orgasm of cashew-cumin soaked ghost flesh—where the bird has been slow-seduced in yogurt until its soul leaves via the fenugreek fumes.

Then comes the duck. *Haansh*. No, not “honk honk cute Donald” but a beast that’s been simmered till its fat bleeds history. We stew them in whole spices like we’re extracting confessions from an 18th-century traitor. One does not simply "cook" duck in Bengal. One holds it hostage over low heat with cinnamon threats and cardamom bribery.

Pigeon? *Parabotar jhol*. Absolutely. As if colonial trauma wasn’t enough, we added airborne rodents to our protein portfolio. Pigeons—those poo-artists of modern architecture—are rendered noble in a Bengali kitchen, dunked into pressure cookers of post-partition nostalgia and served with rice you never remember finishing.

Quail? You better believe it. The elusive *bater dim*—quail eggs—are considered aphrodisiacs, which is both hilarious and telling because nothing says “I want to bang you” like popping five miniature embryos with cumin salt and calling it foreplay.

# Wings of Desire

What’s with Bengalis and birds? Is it because we secretly want to fly but can’t get our sweet-loving asses off the ground? Is it because fish—our real spirit animal—got boring and bony and we wanted revenge on another branch of the animal kingdom? Or is it just that when we see feathers, we think “what would this taste like in mustard oil and existential crisis?”

Historically? Sure. Blame it on famine. Blame it on partition. Blame it on rice inflation or ancestral trauma. Birds were plentiful, stupid, and fly into traps like ideas into WhatsApp forwards. And we, with our post-colonial passive-aggressive digestive systems, needed something to butter with guilt.

Etymologically? Even the words sound delicious. *Murgi*—which probably comes from Persian *murgh*, and before that possibly from some Proto-Indo-European root meaning “to die tastily”. *Haansh*—almost like a laugh, but wetter. *Bater dim*—a phrase that sounds like someone stubbing their toe on a rural egg.

# Chewing on the Past

But here’s the real kicker—this is not even about birds. It’s about Bengali identity. About consuming what once was free. About romanticizing rural poverty into urban Sunday brunch. About eating not just to live, but to re-live—the village, the partition, the train ride, the mother’s sigh, the grandfather’s cough, the tin roof, the aluminum plate, the red dot of chilli oil swirling in nostalgia.

Because we are not a people who merely digest. We remember. We ruminate. We chew on the past like gizzard, stubborn and rubbery. We eat birds because they are metaphors for everything that escaped.

And we cooked them.


# File: src/lib/posts/biology-of-avoidance.md

---
title: The Biology of Avoidance
description: Dust, dandruff, and the AQI—three forms of the same small humiliation. A reflection on the particles that invade our lives and the psychology of looking away.
date: '2025-12-29'
thumbnail : "/images/IMG-20251207-WA0029.jpg" 
category: "personal" 
color : "orange" 
published: true
---

<Yc />

<Pi
src="IMG-20251207-WA0029.jpg" 
caption ="I sat up" 
/>

This morning my pillow looked like it had hosted a small, private blizzard—white flecks, grey grit, the occasional black comma of something that might be dandruff or might be the soot from yesterday’s city, which has learned to crawl indoors the way certain relatives do: without invitation, with entitlement, and with a long memory for corners you forgot existed.

<Yt src="https://youtu.be/JLFIdQHQK4E?si=ldvH77jiDUh5DpWF" />

I sat up and the light did that Calcutta thing where it pretends to be sunlight but is really an argument—hazy, particulate, morally undecided—and when I scratched my scalp (not dramatically, not in some operatic “woe is me” fashion, just the ordinary scratch of a man trying to locate his own body in the morning) a few more flakes let go and floated down with the slow dignity of ash after a riot.

In my old North Calcutta room, dust had a job description. It arrived from the street, it settled on books, it made the almirah look older than it was, and once a week someone would wipe it with a cloth that quickly became the same color as the dust, which felt like a philosophical joke: you cannot defeat the enemy without becoming him.

And yet—every morning, for a few minutes, that same enemy would turn theatrical.

Sunlight would come in through the French window panes as if it had been rehearsing, not the general daylight that simply *is*, but the kind that enters like a guest with opinions: a clean, angled blade of brightness slicing the cramped room into “lit” and “not yet.” We were four bodies in that rectangle—my sister, my mother, my father, and I—stacked among furniture the way lesser-known books are stacked in a secondhand shop: too close, too earnest, and all waiting to be opened.

That beam would hit the air and—this is the part that still feels like a trick—suddenly the air would confess it wasn’t empty. The dust would glitter. Not metaphorically. Literally: a slow snowfall of tiny specks turning gold, then silver, then disappearing as they drifted out of the angle, as if the room had briefly developed its own astronomy. *Dhulo* became constellations. Poverty became planetarium.

What you’re seeing there is not the dust “glowing” the way devotional posters claim certain holy men glow (always in suspiciously marketable hues). It’s physics doing its blunt, unsentimental miracle: light scattering.

Light, when it moves through clean air, is annoyingly well-behaved. It goes straight. It minds its business. Which is why you can’t normally see a beam of sunlight as a beam—you only see the bright patch where it lands. But put *stuff* in the air—dust, smoke, tiny droplets, the invisible confetti of living—and the beam becomes visible, because those particles intercept the light and throw some of it sideways into your eyes. It’s the same reason you can see headlights in fog. Fog isn’t “bright.” Fog is a million tiny mirrors with no coordination.

<Yt src="https://youtu.be/r7lgn8vmJ1c?si=KQzQUi-_f2pbwa56" />

# Tyndall effect 

That sideways-throwing is the heart of what people loosely call the Tyndall effect. Historically, John Tyndall was poking at the way “clear” media weren’t always optically clear, and he showed that colloids—tiny suspended particles—make light paths visible. In school we’re told, dutifully, “Tyndall effect: scattering by colloids,” and then we’re shown a flashlight through milk-water like it’s a magic trick performed by the chemistry teacher who secretly hates us. But in real life, the city gives you the demonstration for free, every morning, along with existential dread and noise.

Strictly speaking, the dust in a room spans sizes. Some particles are small enough that they behave like Rayleigh scattering (the kind that makes the sky blue—shorter wavelengths scatter more). Many are larger, and then you’re in the messy domain of Mie scattering, where the math stops being cute and starts being “numerical methods and despair.” The practical takeaway is simple and wonderfully humiliating: particles in the air redirect light. The beam becomes visible because the beam is being vandalized.

So why the glitter, specifically? Why not just a uniform haze?

Because those particles aren’t identical, and the light isn’t hitting them evenly, and your eyes are not passive cameras—they’re hungry pattern-machines. A speck tumbles, catches the beam at just the right angle, flashes bright for a fraction of a second, and then it’s gone. It’s not “sparkle” like a diamond; it’s more like the flashing of tiny, indifferent fish scales in a river you cannot enter. The glitter is a statistical accident you interpret as beauty because you are a primate with a brain that evolved to notice shiny things and then overthink them into meaning.

At most times of day the room is lit fairly evenly. Light is coming in from many directions (window + sky + reflections off walls), so the scattering from dust is smeared into a general brightness. The dust is still there, still scattering, but it doesn’t stand out as a distinct shaft.

When the sun hits a certain angle—low-ish, slanting in—it does three useful (for visibility) things at once:

It makes a *collimated-ish* sheet of light. Direct sunlight is relatively directional compared to diffuse skylight. Through window panes it becomes a cleaner, narrower “slab” of light cutting through the room.

It creates *high contrast*. The rest of the room is in shade, so you have “bright beam” against “dark background.” Scattered light from the dust inside that bright slab pops, like chalk dust in a projector beam in a dark classroom.

It aligns the scatter with your line of sight. Dust scatters light in many directions, but not equally for all particle sizes—there’s often a strong “forward scatter” tendency (especially for bigger particles). When the sunbeam, the dust, and your eyes are arranged so that a good fraction of that scattered light is headed toward you, the beam looks thicker and more dramatic. Change the angle a bit and the same dust scatters light, just not into *your* eyes as effectively.

Why “glitter,” specifically: because the particles are drifting and tumbling. Each speck briefly enters the brightest part of the beam and, for a moment, sends a little flash toward you. The sun angle that makes the beam most directional and the background darkest makes those flashes look like sparkles instead of a bland haze.

# Those French windows 

<Pi 
src ="/Photos/IMG-20251229-WA0017.jpg" 
caption = "Tyndall effect" 
/>

There’s also the choreography of the room itself. Those French window panes—how grand that sounds for a lower-middle-class North Calcutta box where four people lived, ate, argued, and tried not to become each other’s worst destinies—created a certain geometry. The panes broke the light into strips. The curtains softened it. The almirah and bed made shadows like solid objects. And inside that geometry, the dust performed: rising when someone walked, settling when the ceiling fan slowed, erupting when my mother snapped a bedsheet as if she were trying to whip the day into cleanliness.

My father would cough sometimes, not dramatically, just the ordinary cough of a man who had lived long enough in a city that burns and builds and pretends it isn’t doing either. My mother would scold the dust as if dust had ears. My sister would sit with her own private impatience, the kind children have when they’re forced to share space and oxygen and attention. And I—overeducated even then in the way only certain Bengali households can manage, where a child is fed words the way other children are fed protein—would stare at the glitter and feel, without knowing how to say it, that the world has two layers: the visible one you’re supposed to talk about, and the invisible one that is actually running the show.

That’s what the Tyndall effect teaches, if you don’t ruin it by turning it into a definition. It’s an existential lesson in optics: the beam is always there, but you only see it when the impurities confess it.

And there’s a small, nasty irony in that, because the dust that made my childhood mornings look briefly enchanted wasn’t a benevolent fairy powder. It was skin. Cloth fiber. Road grit. Cooking smoke. Pollen. Bits of our own lives breaking down into particles and joining the air like a union you never applied to. What glittered was decomposition, made pretty by the angle of the sun.

Even now, when I see a beam of light in a room, I have that reflex—half tenderness, half suspicion—because the sight is beautiful, yes, but it is also evidence. A visible beam is a diagnostic. It’s the universe pointing at your air and saying, politely, *look what you’re inhaling.*

In that North Calcutta room, the beam would drift across the spines of books, across my mother’s folded saris, across the edge of my father’s newspaper, across my sister’s hair, and for a moment everything looked dusted with gold, as if poverty itself had been gilded by a careless god.

Then someone would move, the particles would swirl, the glitter would break apart, and the air would go back to pretending it was nothing at all.

Now in South Calcutta’s unfashionable fringes—where the buses come grudgingly, where the new buildings stand like freshly minted lies—the dust is less quaint. It has gone corporate. It comes with metrics.

AQI: three letters that make air sound like a quarterly report.

I checked the phone the way modern people check omens. The app showed a number—high enough to qualify as a personality trait—and a color that looked like it belonged on a caution tape, or perhaps on the face of a government spokesperson explaining that everything is under control, which is the universal phrase meaning: nothing is under control, but please don’t ask for receipts.

The problem with numbers is that they soothe even when they indict. “Very Unhealthy,” the app said, and my mind—trained by exams, rank lists, and the gospel of marks—did the old obedient thing: Ah yes, a category. Now I know where I stand. As if breathing were another board exam. As if your lungs could be graded and then scolded for not writing answers in the proper format.

Dust, dandruff, AQI—three forms of the same small humiliation. Dust is the world arriving uninvited on your shelves. Dandruff is your body producing its own dust, a private weather system of dissatisfaction. AQI is the state and the market agreeing, for once, on a shared fiction: that if you measure the poison precisely enough, it becomes information rather than poison.

The science is straightforward in a way our politics never is. Particles. Tiny bits of stuff suspended in air, floating around like gossip in a *para*, except gossip at least has the decency to be audible. PM10, PM2.5—names that sound like exam papers from a sadistic institution: “You have three hours. Inhale quietly. No calculators.” The smaller ones are nastier, not because they are morally corrupt (molecules don’t do sin) but because they slip deeper into you. Your nose hairs—the ancient, underfunded border security of the body—can catch the larger intruders. The smaller ones stroll in wearing a blazer and carrying a laminated ID card.

And what are these particles made of? The romance dies quickly: vehicle exhaust, road dust, construction debris, industrial emissions, biomass burning, the occasional festive bonfire of collective stupidity. There is no single villain with a moustache you can twirl. The air is a committee decision.

*Dhulo*, my grandmother used to say—dust, as if naming it made it domestic. There’s a Bengali intimacy to certain nuisances. We don’t just have dust; we have *dhulo-moyla* (dust-and-filth), a compound word that admits reality is rarely solitary. The room is never merely dusty. It is dust plus something else: neglect, time, the residue of living.

Dandruff too has its folk mythology. Someone will tell you it’s because you ate too much *tel* (oil), someone else will prescribe a neem paste, someone will whisper about “heat in the body” as if you are a defective pressure cooker. The body, in our household cosmology, is always a kitchen appliance. But dandruff is usually simpler: your scalp sheds skin cells, sometimes more than usual, sometimes because of a yeast that lives on us like a quiet tenant. The horror is not that a fungus exists—fungi are everywhere, and frankly they have better architectural instincts than we do. The horror is that your body is an ecosystem and you are not the landlord. You are the entire apartment building, arguing with itself.

I know this, and still I scratch. Knowledge does not abolish itch. Knowledge simply adds narration. Ah, you say to yourself, this is seborrheic dermatitis, the inflammation of the scalp associated with *Malassezia*— and your fingers keep doing the ancient animal thing because your nervous system did not attend your education.

Education, in fact, is part of the trouble. We were trained to treat air as nothing. It is the blank page on which life writes itself. You don’t think about it until it becomes legible as harm. In school, “pollution” was a chapter—some diagrams, some moralizing, a poster competition where the most talented child drew a sad fish floating belly-up in a river, and we all clapped, and then we went home and burned plastic because the garbage van didn’t come.

If air had been taught properly, it would have been taught like a crime scene. Not dramatic—just meticulous. You would begin with the fact that air is not one thing. It is a mixture, like society. Mostly nitrogen, some oxygen, argon, carbon dioxide, water vapor—then the trace villains, the chemicals that matter precisely because they’re small, because they operate in the shadows. The lesson would not end with “keep the environment clean,” that sanctimonious sentence which is the civic equivalent of telling a poor man to “be confident.” The lesson would end with the actual machinery: combustion chemistry, how burning fuel produces nitrogen oxides, sulfur compounds, particulates; how sunlight drives reactions to form ozone at ground level; how temperature inversions trap pollutants close to the earth like a lid on a pot that nobody is watching.

But our syllabi love the shape of knowledge more than its function. We produce students who can define “AQI” without noticing the sky looks like a long exhale from a dying engine.

Also, the air has become a stage for spiritual branding, which is our national hobby: take a real problem, sprinkle it with a mantra, sell it back as salvation. I have seen “healing pranayama” classes advertised as if lungs are a mood you can adjust with the right playlist. Breathing exercises can be useful, yes—your nervous system responds to slow exhalations, your stress can soften—but a calm inhale of poison is still poison. You cannot *om* your way around particulate matter. The universe is not that sentimental.

Colonial history drifts in here, uninvited, like the dust. The British did not “give” us railways and sanitation out of philanthropic ardor; they built infrastructure to extract, to move goods, to administer. Cities like Calcutta were shaped as interfaces—ports, warehouses, bureaucracy. The air of empire was smoke: coal, ship engines, jute mills. The romance of “heritage” often forgets that heritage is frequently a byproduct of industrial coughing. We inherit architecture, yes, but we also inherit the habit of treating the city as a machine that must run regardless of what it does to bodies.

Postcolonial life did not abolish that habit. We simply localized the arrogance. Now we do development with devotional fervor, as if flyovers are temples and GDP is the deity. You can question anything here except the religion of growth. *Bikash*—development—becomes a word you must chant, and if you ask, gently, whether the growth is poisoning the air, you are told you are anti-national, anti-progress, anti-aspiration, possibly anti-everything except your own depressing books.

This is where I contradict myself, because I like comfort too. I enjoy the conveniences of modern life in the way a man enjoys the fan in May—without wanting to think about the power plant. I complain about cars while using rideshare when I’m tired. I mock consumerism while ordering another book that will sit, accusingly, under a layer of dust. My principles, like my scalp, shed.

The AQI number on my phone has a strange psychological effect: it transforms the air into a moral scoreboard. On bad days, I feel I am breathing wrong, as if my lungs are failing a test. On good days—when the number drops because the wind changed or the rain came—I feel a small, childish relief, as if the world has pardoned me. This is nonsense, but it is a very modern nonsense. We have replaced gods with dashboards. Same hunger for certainty, improved typography.

There’s also the small comedy of domestication. Dust is the most democratic substance on earth. It settles on Marx and on the Bhagavad Gita with equal indifference. It sits on your framed certificates, quietly suggesting they will someday be indistinguishable from old newspapers. Dust is time made visible, which is why it irritates us. We can tolerate aging as an abstract; we cannot tolerate it on the surface of our table.

Dandruff is the same message, delivered by your own body in a more personal font. Your skin is constantly renewing, sloughing off the old. It is a reminder that you are not a stable object. You are a process. This should be liberating, philosophically, but in practice it means your shirt collar looks like it belongs to a man who has been using chalk to solve imaginary equations all night, which is not the glamorous image of “intellectual labor” we were promised.

I once heard someone claim that “dandruff” comes from “dandy” plus “rough,” as if it were a fashionable man’s problem. It’s charmingly wrong. Folk etymology loves this kind of pun because it makes language feel like a clever friend. Real etymology is less cute and more like dust itself: a slow accumulation of history. “Dandruff” likely comes from an older word for scurf—flakes of skin—mixed with sound changes and the ordinary mess of speech. Words evolve the way cities do: without a master plan, through small acts of use, neglect, and improvisation.

AQI, by contrast, is a designed word. It is a technocratic label with no poetry, which is why it fits our age so well. It is the sort of acronym that can be printed on a billboard without blushing. It gives the illusion that the chaos of air can be summarized the way you summarize a child’s report card.

And yet—annoyingly—metrics do matter. The very thing I distrust, the number, is also a flashlight. Without measurement, we are left with vibes. And vibes are how power likes you: squinting, uncertain, arguing about whether the sky is “really that bad” while the particulate matter continues its quiet invasion.

So the rationalist in me keeps the app. The misanthrope in me resents needing it. The depressive in me notes that none of this will be fixed quickly because it would require collective discipline, and we are not good at that unless someone can monetize it or mythologize it. The hypomanic part of me briefly imagines a city where every child learns air chemistry the way they learn multiplication, where buses are clean, where construction is regulated, where waste is managed, where the sky is not an ongoing apology—then that part gets tired and sits down.

I brush my shoulders. More flakes. Tiny, ridiculous, intimate evidence that I am both the victim and the generator of dust.

Outside, someone is drilling into concrete, that sacred sound of “progress,” the whine of a machine biting stone, producing the very particles that will later appear on my books like an unsolicited footnote. A scooter passes, leaving behind a faint stink of fuel, and for a moment the air smells like a garage and a kitchen and a funeral pyre, all layered together—the city’s true perfume, not the imported nonsense sold in glass bottles.

I open the window anyway, because the room is stale, because the fan is moving the same tired molecules in circles, because I am human and I keep choosing imperfect options and pretending they are decisions.

<Pi src="IMG-20251208-WA0001.jpg" caption="mermaid with bones" />

# Biology of Avoidance

A thin beam of light falls across my desk. In it, the dust floats—slow, glittering, almost beautiful, like a galaxy of small mistakes suspended in air.

Congratulations, I think, you are breathing the universe’s filing system.


# File: src/lib/posts/bipolar-hut-in-slow-shitcity.md

---
title: "Bipolar Hut in Slow Shitcity"  
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251212-WA0005.jpg"  
date: 2026-01-16  
description: "A foulmouthed philosophical rant from a chemically-unstable Bengali bastard hiding in slow suburbia, wrestling with bipolar disorder, the violence of meds, and the unbearable slowness of not going mad."  
category: 'personal'  
published: true  
color: "orange"  
---

<Pi src="IMG-20251212-WA0005.jpg" />



It begins with the sound of my own piss ricocheting off the rusted inner wall of the aluminum bucket I use because the goddamn flush doesn’t work, hasn’t worked in months, and every plumber I call looks at me with that Kolkata-smirk of condescension mixed with faint horror—because I’m a lone, angry, brown middle-aged fart-snorting man who speaks too precisely and always sounds like he’s going to punch someone for using the word “chakna”—and they disappear after the first inspection, probably assuming I molest cats or hoard biscuits or collect the fingernails of electricians.

Anyway.

That piss—let’s not forget it, that symphony of yellow urgency and reluctant dribble—is the *only* sound I have full control over most days.

There’s this rhythm to it now. Wake up. Wonder who I am. Drink the tap water that tastes faintly like metallic goat farts and arsenic-soaked chalk. Sit on the bucket like an emperor of decay. Eat stale peanuts. Try not to scream at the trees. Avoid WhatsApp. Whisper to the tea pan. And somewhere, if I’ve taken the fucking meds, sleep again. 

I do not say this for pity.

I say it because I am still alive, and that is not fucking nothing.

Let me clarify, for the cocksuckers in the back: *bipolar medications are a form of biochemical rape.* Yes, that’s right, wrap your little TED-Talk brains around that. They assault the sovereign bastard who is *you*, and not in a sexy way. Not in a “take me you lithium daddy” way. No. They go into your skull like a colonizer, stake flags in your serotonin valleys, piss on your dopamine lakes, and build mind-dams where there used to be waterfalls of fantasy, rage, sexual hallucination, and strange euphoria that made sense only to trees and broken photocopiers. They level your interior like a bad mall. 

And before you say, “But they save lives!”—yes, of course they do. They *save* you the same way a padded cell does. They don’t fix a goddamn thing. They just keep you from jumping off balconies or punching your reflection during the fourth sleepless night of talking to your own thoughts with the hunger of a junkie philosopher. 

I’m telling you, slow helps.

This slow shithole of a city, this nowhere Calcutta suburb where buses fart old diesel onto goats and air conditioners cry milky tears of iron oxide onto old women’s umbrellas—this *slowness* is medicinal. It’s the best sedative I’ve ever known. You want to *stay alive* with bipolar disorder? Move somewhere where *nothing* happens. Ever. No stimulation. No temptation. No dicks to suck and no pussies to chase and no project deadlines or festivals or women with jasmine in their hair asking you to dance. 

Just… cow dung, municipal silence, bad signal, dust, and one uncle with undiagnosed neurosyphilis yelling about Modi while squatting beside a dead cat.

My nervous system fucking thanks me. 

Let me explain with fake science.

Imagine your brain is a tub of sour yogurt with a pissed-off fly in it. That’s untreated bipolar. Now imagine some Swedish shrink decides the solution is to *freeze* the whole goddamn tub until the fly just becomes a vague protein smear. That’s meds. But here’s where this gutter of a city helps—it doesn’t freeze you, it just... evaporates urgency. Like a drunk ex removing herself from the party. It bores you out of mania. It delays psychosis. It stretches your panic into boredom until the scream becomes a nap.

I used to dream of cities with speed and chrome and infinite coffee shops and baristas with septum rings who'd quote Camus while handing you your oatmilk cappuccino. 

Now I wake up next to a gecko with three toes and a fungus-covered light switch. 

And I’m safer here.

You wouldn’t understand unless your neurons have tried to fucking *murder you* from the inside, unless you’ve shat while crying from joy and dread *at the same time*, unless you’ve sent 142 messages to a friend who no longer exists and then apologized to a traffic light. 

The brain is a cunt. 

No. Strike that. The *mind* is the cunt. The brain is just the meat radio, the grey shrimp with spark plugs. The *mind*, though—that bastard is the bad roommate who throws piss bottles at your guests and accuses you of microaggressions while masturbating to old Doordarshan weather reports. 

Sometimes I think the only sane thing to do is give it no audience.

Feed it oats, deny it spectacle, remove caffeine, embrace cabbage. Listen to ceiling fans like they’re philosophers. Sleep next to electrical wires because the faint hum is better than poetry. 

Slowness, my love, my whore, my sponge bath from God.

I haven’t had a proper erection in months. Not one that didn’t feel either chemically forced or emotionally fraudulent. But I’ll take that over mania. I’ll take this flaccid peace over the carnivorous joy of grandiosity, because grandiosity eats you from the top down. You go from “maybe I’ll write a poem” to “maybe I’ll convert to Jainism and start a traveling sex cult for narcoleptics” in three nights and one extra Bournvita overdose. 

Fuck the glamour. 

You think Van Gogh was glamorous? He stank like ass, cut his ear off, and bled alone while hallucinating Christ in a bowl of absinthe. Sylvia Plath’s oven. Cobain’s shotgun. Robin Williams hanging like a broken piñata of joy. *We don’t survive brilliance. We survive boredom.*

And that’s why I live here. In this broken shanty with barely 300 square feet of cracked cement, boxers that haven’t seen detergent since Diwali, one rice cooker, one pan, one cracked mirror that makes my face look like a Picasso farted, and one weak WiFi router that blinks like a dying firefly with erectile dysfunction. 

I could move. I could work again. I could chase the dreams. 

But I don’t trust dreams.

Dreams are manic erections in the pants of fate.

Dreams got me institutionalized.

Dreams make me walk seven kilometers at midnight believing I’m the reincarnation of Ramanujan with a mission to decipher the piss trails of stray dogs as sacred geometric codes.

No.

Now I dream of sleep.

I dream of pooping on time. Of tea that doesn’t taste like rust and cigarette ash. Of neighbors who don’t bang like methed-up goats every Thursday night. Of not seeing Jesus in the water stains.

I dream of decibels staying low, and dopamine staying polite.

Because the only thing more dangerous than *being* bipolar is *remembering* who you were during the high. 

That motherfucker was beautiful.

And I don’t miss him.

But sometimes, on Wednesday mornings when the street dogs don’t bark and the sky looks like undercooked mutton, I feel him twitch. Like a fart waiting to bloom.

And I remember he had better posture.


# File: src/lib/posts/black-hole-up-my-arse.md

---
title: "Black Hole Up My Arse"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251221-WA0106.jpg"
date: 2026-01-11
description: "A foul-mouthed Bengali bastard obsesses over rogue black holes, cosmic annihilation, and the slow, stupid, shitting death of everything while trying not to die on his own toilet."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "orange"
---

<Pi src="IMG-20251221-WA0106.jpg" />



I was shitting when the thought occurred.

And I don’t mean one of those slippery, banana-peel soft-dumps that slither out like a loyal worker clocking out at 5:01. I mean a **lumpy, semi-tumescent fucking asshole-ripper**, the kind of turd that makes you sweat before you even squat. The kind that teaches you humility. Makes you negotiate with your gods, your rectum, and the **interstellar fucking void**, because while your anus is splitting into Morse code blisters, your brain—mine, in this case—starts whispering: *what if it’s already here? what if the fucking black hole is already sniffing at our corner of the galaxy like some interstellar rapist raccoon, invisible, hungry, inevitable?*

This is not a metaphor.

I mean a literal rogue black hole, those ungravitationally leashed motherfuckers that got booted from their original galaxy like a drunk twat at a wedding and now just **wander**, **drift**, **slurp**, **consume** like a cocksucker with no gag reflex and a fetish for planets. No spin. No warning. No cosmic courtesy tap.

We could die tonight and not even know it.

And I’d die on the shitter, pants around ankles, still trying to pinch off a reluctant turd that’s now fossilizing inside my traitor colon, while a silent sphere of infinite gravity and zero fucks **unzips reality like a prolapsed anus in reverse**.

Let me tell you something about wandering black holes. First: they exist. Second: they are **undetectable unless they’re feeding**. And third: *statistically*, one of them should've passed within 100 light-years of us by now. Maybe it already did. Maybe it *is*. Maybe that's why I can't get an erection without a Ted Chiang story playing in the background and a third-world oil massage.

You think I’m exaggerating?

Of course you do, because you're a fucking optimist. Because your body doesn't hurt yet. Or if it does, you’re still stupid enough to think you can *fix* it—yoga, turmeric, kombucha, vitamin D enemas, whatever shiny rectal placebo you rub on your mortality.

Me, I’ve got sciatica, cracked heel, bile reflux, and the faint lingering suspicion that my left kidney's playing *fuck-you* jazz solos when I sleep. Every morning is a fresh audition for the role of "Coughing Fuck About to Die of Minor Infection."

We’ll get back to the black holes, I promise, but first—since I brought it up—**have you ever noticed how utterly useless the human body is** in the face of cosmic risk?

I mean, let’s say some snub-nosed, non-accreting stellar-mass black hole just waltzes into the solar system on a vector out of Buttfuck Sagittarius. Do you know what our response would be? Some 27-year-old white boy with a nose piercing at NASA would tweet *“we’re monitoring the situation”* and **that would be the last thing posted** before your dick sublimated into neutrinos and your spine did a 4D origami collapse through your own cockhole.

And meanwhile your phone would still be auto-updating.

I read somewhere—we don’t know how many rogue black holes are out there because most of them don’t eat. They're celibate. And the only way we spot them is by watching stars *lensing*—warping light as they pass behind a gravitational field. Some tiny tug on a pixel. Blink, and your star does a little jiggle. That’s it. That’s the sign. That’s the **death knell**.

A shimmer.

And if you're old like me and your eyes have floaters, you might just blink back at the end of all things, thinking it was an eyelash. *Whoops.*

Science always gives you two options: dignity or despair. But either way, you’re going to shit yourself.

Now let’s talk about trajectories. These bastards are **not tethered**. They roam like horny gods with no followers. A supernova farts wrong, and boom, the neutron star gets ejected like an angry hemorrhoid across the galaxy. Black holes form when a big star dies dramatically, shitting its own gravitational pants so hard that even light says *fuck this, I’m out*.

Then they wander. No accountability. No insurance. No goddamn headlights.

You think death will come from war or water or some fucking spreadsheet virus made by an autistic finance bro with a genocide fetish?

No, motherfucker. *Death will come from silence.* A nothing so perfect it can’t be detected. Not even with your fancy LIGO, not even with your web telescopes and global warming hashtags.

You won’t *see* your death. You’ll *feel* it. In the blood. In your balls. In the way your soup gets slightly too thick one night and your ears ring differently and you just *know*—somehow—that **space itself has shifted**, and it’s coming. For you. For everyone.

Do you know what happens when one of these things gets close?

Tidal disruption.

Which sounds like a spa treatment but is actually **being stretched like spaghetti through your own nipples while time has a seizure around your ankles**. Earth would quake, your magnetic field would puke, tectonic plates would do drunk bhangra, and you'd find yourself flung into the void like a cumshot in a vacuum.

But first: your cat would stare at a wall for a second too long.

That's the only warning you're gonna get.

Anyway, the shit finally came out. It hurt. It burned like a poem by Bukowski stapled to your perineum. And in that moment of clarity, when the toilet bowl looked like a Jackson Pollock tribute to IBS and the exhaust fan squealed like a dying space probe, I thought: maybe that’s all we are.

Not stardust.

**Shit. And the fear of a cosmic butthole.**

I wiped with two-ply that felt like 19th-century colonial parchment, probably bleached with some carcinogenic chemical banned in Europe, probably made by a child working in a factory near a dried-up lake. My left hand was trembling—might be Parkinson’s, might just be guilt.

Went to the kitchen, made tea. Milk gone bad. Fuck it. Drank it anyway. I mean what’s the worst that could happen, I already lived through enough.

Still tasted better than the air in my room today.

And now I’m sitting here, typing with a hunchback spine and an oily keyboard that smells faintly of sambar and despair, wondering—not if—but **when**. Because it's not *if*.

One of these motherfuckers is already on its way. And when it comes, there will be no movie, no Morgan Freeman, no elegy, no girl to kiss, no planet to save. There will be **a flicker**.

And maybe, if we’re lucky—

someone will be mid-shit when it hits.

Just like I was.

And that, my friend, is the closest thing we’ll ever get to universal justice.



# File: src/lib/posts/body-mass-index.md

---
title: "BMI"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20260105-WA0000.jpg"
date: '2026-01-05'
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "blue" 
---



<Pi
    src="IMG-20260105-WA0000.jpg" 
    caption="a fatty"
/>

I drew it on my Samsung S9 Ultra tab in Sketchbook, using that slightly apologetic digital charcoal brush that always looks like it wants to be a real pencil when it grows up, and I wrote, in the top margin with my best imitation of certainty: “INDIAN BMI is exponential.” The woman beneath the words is sweating, ballooned, staring up at the ceiling as if the ceiling might offer a dividend or a diagnosis, and when I finished, I just sat there for a while with the stylus hovering, not because I was proud of the drawing—this isn’t the Sistine Chapel, it’s my rented room with a fan that wheezes like an elderly bureaucrat—but because the sentence felt true in that irritating way truths do, the way an EMI feels true when it arrives every month whether you’re in the mood for arithmetic or not.

Exponential, yes. That’s the word we use when we want to sound mathematical about a phenomenon that feels like it’s getting away from us—like EMI. Monthly installments. The polite, middle-class leash around your ankle. You buy a refrigerator, you buy a scooter, you buy a little rectangle of “future security,” and then the future arrives as a bill with compound interest and a smile. BMI, in this telling, is the body’s EMI: you don’t exactly *choose* it so much as you sign up for a lifestyle, a food environment, a work rhythm, a stress chemistry, and then discover that the payments are due in flesh.

I remember—annoyingly, sentimentally—that in my childhood the neighborhood had many things, including hunger, but not much visible bulk. Men were wiry. Women were compact and fast, like they had been designed by some Bengali engineer who hated wasted material. If an uncle had a protruding belly, it was notable, like a new building suddenly blocking the winter sun. The elephant and hippo sightings—those crude zoological metaphors we used when we were young and unkind—were rare enough to become characters, and Kolkata loves characters the way it loves traffic jams: it will create a story out of anything that won’t move.

Now I stand in a line at a pharmacy—fluorescent light, overworked pharmacist, a queue of people with that patient, defeated expression Indians perfect early—and I can’t help noticing how many bodies look like they’ve been quietly renegotiated by the last twenty years. Not necessarily heavier in a dramatic, tabloid way. Something subtler and more ominous. More soft mass around the waist, more puffiness around the face, the tired posture of metabolic debt. The city has acquired a new silhouette.

And before I get too righteous—before I climb onto my little soapbox made of second-hand books and moral superiority—I should confess: my own body is not a steel girder of self-control. I have lived on tea and biscuits. I have eaten late at night because the mind was whirring and the stomach was the only thing that could be bribed into silence. I have used food the way this country uses committees: not to solve the problem, but to create the sensation that a problem is being handled.

The trouble is that “fatness” (let’s use a word that doesn’t spit on people) is not a single moral failure you can scold away with inspirational posters and military metaphors. It’s a system. It’s biology meeting economics in a dark alley and exchanging envelopes.

BMI itself is a hilariously blunt instrument for such a complex situation. A ratio—weight divided by height squared—pretending to be a verdict. The square is not even poetic; it’s a compromise from the nineteenth century, like a colonial railway timetable. Bodies aren’t squares. Bodies are history. Bodies are hormones, sleep, muscle, poverty, trauma, starch, celebration, office chairs, and the strange modern miracle of never being truly hungry while still being undernourished.

Also, Indians have a special talent for confounding neat Western categories. There’s that now-common observation—half clinical, half insulting—that we can be “thin-fat”: not necessarily large by the old visual standards, yet carrying dangerous fat in the belly, around the organs, the stealth kind that doesn’t announce itself until the blood tests do. The body can look “acceptable” and still be quietly smoldering. A nation of respectable-looking volcanoes.

So why does it feel exponential? Because the forces feeding it compound.

Start with food, since we always start with food—India can argue about anything except lunch. We have moved from food as a local negotiation (seasonal, perishable, limited by what the bazaar had that day) to food as an industrial product (shelf-stable, aggressively marketed, engineered to be hard to stop eating). This is not some romantic myth of the past where everyone ate simple grains and danced gracefully through sunsets. We ate sugar then too. We fried things then too. We had ghee and mishti and *telebhaja* and the holy trinity of Bengali self-destruction: rice, potatoes, and the belief that walking to the bus stop counts as exercise.

But the new thing is scale. The new thing is precision. The new thing is that somewhere a team of professionals has tuned the salt-fat-sugar triangle the way a sound engineer tunes a pop song: not too much, not too little, exactly enough to make your brain say, *one more,* even when your stomach is filing a formal complaint.

And then—because the universe loves to add insult with a spreadsheet—there is stress. Not the dramatic stress of famine, which is at least honest, but the modern stress of job insecurity, debt, noise, screens, sleep that isn’t sleep. Stress is not just a mood; it’s chemistry. Cortisol doesn’t care about your political views. Your body reacts to threat the way it did when threats had teeth. Now the threats arrive as emails.

Poor sleep, more hunger hormones. More hunger hormones, more snacking. More snacking, more insulin spikes. More insulin spikes, more fat storage. And fat itself is not inert, not a passive suitcase of calories, but a loud endocrine organ sending signals—leptin, inflammatory markers, all of it—so the whole system becomes a feedback loop, a circular argument you can’t win by shouting.

Exponential is what feedback looks like when it’s wearing a sari.

There’s also a linguistic joke hiding here, which my brain cannot resist. People invent folk etymologies with great confidence—confident nonsense is our national renewable resource. I once heard someone claim “obese” comes from “obey,” as in “you obey your appetite,” which is charmingly moralistic and completely wrong. The actual root is Latin: *obesus*, from *edere*, “to eat,” with an intensifier stuck in front—essentially “having eaten too much.” It’s brutally literal, like a bureaucratic file note. No poetry. Just consumption and consequence.

But if you really want poetry, you don’t need Latin. You can take the Bengali word *pet*—belly—and notice how it sits at the center of our idioms. *Pet-bharā* (full-bellied) as a kind of basic success. *Pet khārāp* (bad stomach) as shorthand for general misery. A good life, in the most ordinary sense, is still measured by whether the belly has been satisfied. We are a civilization that knows hunger, and that memory doesn’t vanish just because delivery apps arrive with promo codes and the promise of frictionless excess.

America enters here—not as a villain twirling a mustache, but as an export system. Not jazz, not science, not the gorgeous rebelliousness of real American art, but the industrial American idea that food is not culture, it is a commodity, and commodities must scale, and scaling means making ingredients cheaper, flavors louder, portions bigger, and marketing more shameless. That template travels beautifully. It doesn’t need a passport. It only needs aspirational anxiety.

And India, always eager to learn the worst lessons quickly, has adapted the template with local genius. We can deep-fry anything, yes, but now we can deep-fry it *and* wrap it in plastic *and* sell it as “energy.” We can take the ancient comfort of snacks and turn them into a daily habit rather than an occasional joy. We can take sugar—once an expensive colonial luxury, then a proud symbol of modern plenty—and make it the default background radiation of life.

Meanwhile, we have redesigned the day. Children sit. Adults sit. Old men sit and give political speeches to no one in particular. Movement has been outsourced. The body has been demoted from “tool of living” to “transport for the head.” We have created a society where the most physically demanding act in many lives is lifting a water bottle to the mouth.

And then, because irony is a reliable landlord, we moralize the outcome. We treat weight like a character flaw. We turn bodies into punchlines. We do this even while knowing—if we’re honest for five seconds—that most of this is not about individual willpower in some heroic vacuum. It’s about the environment we built, the incentives we allowed, the cheap calories we subsidized with our collective indifference.

I look again at my sweating figure under that smug mathematical word, and she doesn’t feel like a joke anymore. She looks exhausted in a way that feels uncomfortably familiar: the exhaustion of carrying not just flesh but expectation—be productive, be modern, be cheerful, be “fit,” be thin, be successful, be grateful, pay your EMI, pay your BMI, and don’t complain too loudly because someone will always remind you that worse things exist.

Outside my window the Joynogorer Moya vendor calls out, the sound stretching thin through the damp air, sweet and insistent, and I think of numbers the way we think of gods: as if naming them makes them manageable.

The stylus is still on the table.

The ceiling is still blank.

The body, as usual, is the only ledger that never forgets.


# File: src/lib/posts/burnt-mouth-lonely-fuck.md

---
title: "Burnt Mouth, Lonely Fuck"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20260116-WA0007.jpg"
