<Pi src="IMG-20260116-WA0007.jpg" />

It starts with the tongue. That fat fucking traitor. 

Not the poetic tongue, not the mother tongue, not even the "I bit my tongue so I don't offend that limp-dicked committee of yes-men" tongue. No. I mean the wet, hairy, always-slightly-furred-like-a-hamster's-backside bastard curled inside my mouth, tasting nothing these days except morning bitterness and a suspicious iron tang like licking an old AA battery that spent too long in your cousin’s TV remote during load-shedding in the ’90s.

You’d think with all the years it spent flapping around inside my face, reading Bertrand Russell and Rimsky-Korsakov and burping out facts about fucking chlorophyll and Dirac's quantum squiggles to bore women at bus stops who already hate their lives—this tongue would've earned some prestige, some retirement, some say in the matter.

But no.

It just sits there now. Unused. Undesired. Burnt. Like the rest of me.



Look at that image again.

That’s not a scream. That’s not a yawn. That’s not even a mouth anymore. That’s what remains when your identity has been sucked out like marrow from a bone. A charcoaled gash carved into what once was a face—like if Goya sketched Edvard Munch after dropping acid in a Park Circus power outage.

That’s me.

I'm that mouth.

Giant, gaping, grotesque.

The kind of mouth you get when you’ve been talking into voids for 30 years—committee rooms, waiting rooms, visa offices, “feedback” sessions, “we’ll get back to you” emails, imaginary fucking podcasts in your head where you’re the guest *and* the host because no one else will listen unless you hand them a bribe or a blowjob.

A mouth so wide it becomes a cavern. And inside? Echoes. Dry. Rattling. Laced with memory-dandruff.

No wonder nothing tastes right. The bacteria have moved out. Even they’re tired.



I used to say things like “epistemology” in casual conversations, for fuck’s sake. Now I can’t even ask for change at the tea stall without the boy handing me two Mentos and an expression that says, “Why is this old naked mole-rat in boxers pretending to be alive?”

I am a burnt-out bullshit Bengali buffoon.

Repeat it.

Say it with me.

I am a burnt-out bullshit Bengali buffoon.

Because once you say it loud enough—like farting in a mosque—you realize it has a rhythm, a sort of poetry, like Shakespeare if he had haemorrhoids and a hangover and had to share a flat with a rotting paneer sandwich and four mosquitoes named “Hope,” “Future,” “Desire,” and “You Dumb Cunt.”



When I was young, I used to believe in science. Not the *career*, not the greasy ladder-climbing grant-sucking bureaucratic science where you write papers about things you secretly hope nobody reads. I mean the kind that blew your mind open—the kind that made your nipples tingle when you understood for the first time that the sun was a hydrogen fart burning itself into light, or that time slows down near black holes, like your Wi-Fi when porn is buffering on 1%.

But now?

Now my science is remembering when to take omeprazole so I don't shit blood.

Now my physics is limited to the torque required to stand up after sitting cross-legged too long on a toilet scrolling through tweets that make me want to piss on the whole species.

Now my chemistry is realizing that “depression” isn’t a neurotransmitter problem; it’s just the body understanding what the fuck is going on.

Entropy is not some cosmic abstraction.

Entropy is watching your face melt in the mirror while brushing your six remaining teeth, four of which are liars and two of which are Polish immigrants posing as molars.



The history of suffering is mostly men like me.

Unnecessary.

Ejaculated into the world by mistake, handed degrees like consolation prizes, then slowly turned into archives of unread PDFs, middle-aged boxers, and thick toenails.

I live in a country where truth is either shouted by assholes on prime time or muttered by broken bastards like me to their stainless-steel tea mugs at 2:37 AM. A country that teaches you everything matters—your caste, your sperm count, your degrees, your daughter's dowry rate—but where nothing actually changes except the thickness of the air and the smell of the drains.

And I’m supposed to find meaning?

In what?

In watching my own mouth become a parody?

In counting the veins on my dick because I’ve run out of people to hate and ideas to jerk off to?

Fuck that.

Fuck your enlightenment.

Give me rot. Give me stink. Give me that surreal burnt grin where the lips don’t meet and the laugh escapes like a diseased bat.



My body is now a filing cabinet of failed experiments.

I fart and it sounds like an existential thesis being rejected by a German philosopher. I piss sideways. I sneeze and my shoulder dislocates. My spine makes decisions independently like a rebellious Tamil film heroine.

And that mouth?

That giant cavernous howling void?

That's just the exit wound for all the truths I’ve tried to swallow for 30 years.

The truth that none of this matters.

The truth that I will die in this shanty flat surrounded by used cotton underwear, broken spoons, and a blood-pressure machine that beeps like a forgotten Tamagotchi every time I lie down.

The truth that the only thing I ever loved was the sound of my own thinking—and even that has started to bore me.



People say “don’t be so hard on yourself.”

Okay.

Let’s be soft then.

Let’s imagine that mouth is a vagina.

Now what?

Now it’s still ugly, it still doesn’t get kissed, and it still drools at night from one side.

Congratulations. You made it worse.



Anyway, today I tried screaming into a pillow but the pillow fought back. Absorbed it. Mocked it. Stayed fluffy.

So I bit my own arm instead.

It didn't bleed.

I think I’ve run out of blood.

Just like I’ve run out of people to tell my stories to. Or jokes. Or questions like, “What is the evolutionary function of sadness?” and “Why do I still keep my first toothbrush?” and “Is it true that black holes fart information in a way that violates the unitarity of quantum mechanics or am I just projecting again?”

There’s a dead lizard behind my rice cooker.

Been there three days.

I think I’ll name it "Purpose." 

They can send Pegasus if they want. The whole fucking alphabet agency orchestra—NSA, RAW, your local paranoid WhatsApp uncle, or whatever sweaty-palmed junior bureaucrat in a polyester shirt gets the unenviable assignment of wiretapping my bowels through my burner phone in South Calcutta—go ahead, motherfuckers. I hope they enjoy the full frequency spectrum of my existence. I hope they archive my rants and label them "national threat: self-loathing fartbag with literary delusions." Because if they're listening, here’s what they'll hear: me moaning about hemorrhoids that itch like Satan’s pinky finger on my sphincter, halitosis so rich and ancient it could be carbon-dated and sold as Harappan artifact breath, and a lingering whooping cough that sounds like a TB-riddled goose trying to give a TED Talk underwater. And that’s just three afflictions from one single station in the whole cursed A-to-Z trainwreck that is my body. Wait till they get to S for scrotal sadness. Or W for wank-induced wrist pain. Or Z for the fucking zero I feel like most mornings before I even piss.


# File: src/lib/posts/cardinal-cunt-of-seven.md

---

title: "The Cardinal Cunt of Seven"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251207-WA0005.jpg"
date: '2026-01-09'
description: "A tired Bengali atheist in South Calcutta rants about the number 7—religious numerology, colonial hangovers, and why superstition sticks like shit—while his body sweats, stinks, aches, and refuses to cooperate with dignity."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "red"
---

<Pi
 src="IMG-20251207-WA0005.jpg"
 caption="Seven: the holy number that keeps showing up like a fart in an elevator."
/>


The first thing you notice about the number 7 is that it won’t stay in its lane, it doesn’t behave like a normal, respectable integer, it walks into your life like a cocksucker relative at a wedding—uninvited, loud, smelling faintly of stale paan and certainty—so there I am in South Calcutta, the great concrete hospice of ambition, sweating through my vest like a leaking water tank, stomach doing that slow, ominous churn that means either gas or disaster, and someone is on WhatsApp again with a forward, a fucking forward, with seven emojis and seven blessings and seven steps and seven planets and seven days and seven promises and seven sacred somethings, and I can *feel* my body getting angry before my mind even finishes reading, like my intestines are the first rationalists in the room.

Seven. The cardinal cunt of numerology. The number that people use the way they use deodorant in this city: not to fix the problem, just to perfume the rot.

You can’t escape it. Seven is in the calendar, seven is in the sky, seven is in your grandmother’s mouth when she tells you not to cut your nails on Thursday or whatever the hell it is, seven is in the priest’s invoice, seven is in the god-market’s marketing copy, seven is in the thin, oily smile of the guy selling “energy stones” outside the metro station like it’s a normal job and not a scam dressed up as spirituality, like a turd wearing a tie.

And the thing is, I’m not even angry at the number. Seven is innocent. Seven is just a shape. Seven is a little bent stick with a hat. Seven didn’t ask for this. Seven didn’t apply for the position of cosmic manager. People did this. People took a number—this quiet, abstract tool of counting fish and counting debts—and stuffed it into the panties of the divine like a cheap joke, and then acted surprised when it started smelling like human nonsense.

It’s always panties with these people, isn’t it, always a secret compartment, a hidden pocket, a sacred fold where the universe tucks its “meaning,” because meaning has to be hidden, it has to be teased out like some bashful bride, it can’t just be sitting on the table like facts, because facts are rude, facts don’t touch your feet and say “pranam,” facts don’t give you a free pass for being lazy, facts don’t let you pretend your life is a movie with a soundtrack and an interval.

Seven is the interval bell of superstition.

It’s also, if you’re living in this climate, a number you can smell. I’m not kidding. Winter in Calcutta is a liar; it pretends to be crisp and European for two weeks, then it turns into damp breath and diesel and the sweet rot of old leaves. Sound travels farther. Smells travel farther. Your neighbor’s TV travels into your bedroom like it pays rent. Somewhere down the lane a wedding DJ is trying to punch a hole through physics with bass. And through all of it—sound, stink, sweat—comes the ceremonial seven, like a fart that insists it is a hymn.

People love numerology because it’s the fastest way to feel in control without doing anything. It’s capitalism for the soul: outsource your thinking, buy a product called “certainty,” and if it fails, blame your “vibration.” It’s also colonialism’s favorite aftertaste. The British may have left, but the craving for official stamps stayed behind. We still want the universe to issue us a certificate: Approved. Blessed. Valid. Seven is the rubber stamp. Thump. Approved by the cosmos. Thump. Guaranteed returns on your suffering. Thump. Your misery has meaning, now please proceed to the next counter.

Meanwhile, my body is doing its own audit. Fifty-something body. The body of a man who has read too many books and eaten too much fried shit and slept too little and sat too long and hoped too often that “tomorrow” will behave like a serious concept. My knees complain like old union leaders. My skin is a humid argument. My gut is a committee meeting where nobody agrees. I stand up too fast and the room tilts, like the universe is reminding me: you are not a metaphysical hero, you are a bag of water with opinions.

And that’s what makes numerology so insulting. It’s not just wrong, it’s *lazy in the face of biology*. You want cosmic patterns? Look at your own damn body. Look at the way one bad meal can turn you into a sweating, praying animal in five minutes. Look at how your heart is basically a loyal pump with terrible work-life balance. Look at how your brain, that proud philosopher, can be hijacked by a headache and suddenly you’re not a rationalist, you’re a whimpering mammal negotiating with darkness.

But no, people don’t want the honest patterns. They want flattering patterns. They want patterns that make them feel chosen, not patterns that remind them they’re compost with a phone.

So they take seven and they dress it up. Seven chakras. Seven steps. Seven holy somethings. Seven seas, seven heavens, seven vows, seven this, seven that. We borrowed it from everywhere too, like we’re running a spiritual thrift store. You can find seven in Hinduism, sure, but also in Christianity, Islam, Judaism, ancient Greek ideas, old Babylonian sky-counting—humans everywhere have stared at the same stars and tried to make their fear into a system. Nobody owns seven. Everybody rents it. And the rent is paid in gullibility.

There’s a scientific reason seven shows up so much, and it’s boring, which is exactly why nobody forwards it on WhatsApp with sparkles. Humans like small numbers because our brains like manageable chunks. Memory has limits. Attention has limits. Culture has limits. Seven is a nice little handful. It’s not too big, not too small. It feels “special” because it’s just awkward enough—prime, indivisible, smug. Seven is the guy at the party who can’t be split into couples, so he stands alone near the snacks and people start assigning him mystical depth.

And then the whole thing becomes a feedback loop: people repeat that seven is special, so it feels special, so it gets repeated, so it becomes special, like a rumor that becomes a religion because nobody can be bothered to check.

That’s where my erotic shame lives too, not in any glamorous way—nothing glamorous is happening here, trust me—but in that same human mechanism of wanting a story instead of a fact. Desire is a stupid, stubborn animal. It wants narrative. It wants symbolism. It wants a “sign.” It wants to believe a glance meant something, a silence meant something, a dream meant something, a coincidence meant something. It wants to turn random noise into fate, because fate is sexier than entropy. Entropy is a buzzkill. Entropy doesn’t flirt. Entropy doesn’t promise. Entropy just sits there like a turd in the middle of the road and says, “Walk around me, genius.”

So you get this absurd situation: I’m a rationalist, an atheist, a book-rotted skeptic, and still my body carries this ancient, embarrassing urge to be *chosen*—by a person, by a moment, by a universe that notices me—while my mind is standing behind it like a weary security guard saying, “Sir, please stop grinding on metaphysics, this is a public place.”

And that’s the real comedy of seven. Seven is a number people use to dress up loneliness. Seven is a decorative curtain over a cracked wall. Seven is incense sprayed on a clogged drain. Seven is spirituality’s air freshener, and if you’ve ever used air freshener in a Calcutta bathroom you know what I mean: it doesn’t remove the stink, it just adds perfume to the crime scene.

Somewhere in old North Calcutta, in the lanes that still smell like coal and frying oil and old books, there’s a little shop with a calendar of gods and a little pile of plastic idols and a little radio blaring some moral lecture, and the shopkeeper will tell you, with total confidence, that seven is auspicious and three is dangerous and eight is powerful and nine is motherly and whatever else the market currently sells, and the confidence is the product. The number is just packaging. The real commodity is relief: the relief of not having to think.

Thinking is hard. Thinking doesn’t guarantee anything. Thinking doesn’t give you a coupon code for the future. Thinking just tells you the truth, and the truth, most days, is that life is not a story, it’s a messy pile of causes and accidents and compromises and bodily functions, and if you’re lucky you get a few clean minutes of joy between the shitting and the bills.

Even my body knows this. My body doesn’t care about seven. My body cares about water, salt, blood sugar, sleep, stress. My body cares about whether the fish was fresh. My body cares about whether the neighbor is playing bass again like he’s auditioning for a war crime. My body cares about whether the air is thick with diesel. My body cares about whether I walked enough or sat like a dead sack for twelve hours staring at screens. My body is a brutal materialist. My body is the Marxist I pretend to be.

And yet—this is the humiliating part—some days the superstition still tries to sneak in through the back door. Not as belief, but as temptation. You see seven and a tiny part of you wants it to mean something, because meaning is easier than responsibility. Meaning is easier than admitting you made bad choices, or you live in a bad system, or you’re aging, or you’re lonely, or you’re just a fragile animal with delusions of grandeur.

Seven is the delusion with good branding.

So I sit here in my South Calcutta exile, listening to the city wheeze, feeling my own sweat cool into stickiness, watching another forward crawl across my screen like a cockroach with a halo, and I think: imagine if we treated numbers the way we treat food. Imagine if we asked, “Is this fresh? Is this clean? Is this real?” before swallowing it. Imagine if we stopped eating spiritual street food from strangers. Imagine if we stopped licking the universe’s underwear and calling it wisdom.

But people won’t stop. Because seven sells. Seven consoles. Seven makes the chaos feel like a plan. Seven makes the suffering feel like a test instead of a random slap. Seven makes the world feel like it has a manager, and that manager has a spreadsheet, and your name is on it, and someday you’ll get your due.

And I, the proud rationalist, the atheist, the book-heavy bastard, still have to admit something quietly disgusting: on bad nights, when the city is loud and my mind is louder and my body feels like a failing appliance, even I understand the seduction. Not the belief—fuck that—but the seduction. The soft little lie that says: you’re not just drifting, you’re *destined*. You’re not just sweating, you’re *purifying*. You’re not just lonely, you’re *waiting for a sign*.

Then I burp. Or my stomach growls. Or some stray pain lights up like a rude notification. And the universe, in its infinite wisdom, sends me the only sacred message it reliably delivers:

Go to the bathroom, you idiot.


# File: src/lib/posts/carrington-event.md

---
title: "The Carrington Event"
date: "2025-12-17"
description: "A petulant star momentarily bored of just burning quietly for billions of years, choosing instead to belch electromagnetic mayhem at our fragile little planet."
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251207-WA0026.jpg"
category: "science"
color: "blue"
published: true
---

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251207-WA0026.jpg" 
    caption="My ancestor somewhere on the Indian subcontinental space was adjusting his lungi"
/>

Now there's a proper cosmic tantrum: the Sun throwing an apocalyptic hissy-fit, a petulant star momentarily bored of just burning quietly for billions of years, choosing instead to belch electromagnetic mayhem at our fragile little planet.

Picture this: It's the morning of September 1, 1859. A Victorian gentleman astronomer—one Richard Carrington—just minding his own goddamned business, stares through a telescope at our friendly neighborhood nuclear furnace. And suddenly, he sees two blinding white spots explode out of a cluster of sunspots—solar acne rupturing with cosmic pus. A solar flare, he realizes, but not just any solar flare—*the* solar flare. If God had heartburn, this was its belch. My ancestor somewhere on the Indian subcontinental space was adjusting his lungi unaware of this cosmic phallus being inserted surreptitiously in the Earth's backside. 

# Solar Vomit

The flare itself, violent and brief, spewed a torrent of charged particles—the solar equivalent of projectile vomit—straight toward Earth. Usually, Earth's magnetic shield is pretty good at dealing with solar emissions, gently batting them aside like Tendulkar flicking deliveries to fine-leg. But this event? Oh, no. This one punched through Earth's magnetosphere with the casual disdain of a Bengal bus driver navigating through Shyambazar during Pujo season. Earth's magnetic defenses crumbled like soggy digestive biscuits, and the particles danced gleefully toward our hapless atmosphere.

# Celestial Fireworks

What happened next was equal parts majestic and terrifying: the sky exploded into auroras that stretched from poles to tropics, shimmering psychedelic sheets of green, red, and violet—synaesthesia writ celestial, turning night into day. Telegraph operators across Europe and North America watched helplessly as their wires spat sparks, shocking fingers, burning papers, short-circuiting equipment. Messages flew across lines disconnected from power sources, wires sizzling like kachoris dropped into boiling mustard oil.

In mathematical terms, the Carrington flare released an estimated energy of $10^{25}$ joules—a figure so vast that human imagination staggers drunkenly, stumbling in awe at the magnitude. To put it in perspective, that's roughly equivalent to detonating a billion hydrogen bombs simultaneously. If it had happened today—oh, sweet digital Armageddon—the global electrical grid would fry faster than hilsa fish at a Bengali wedding. Your phone, internet, GPS, banking—all gone in a brilliant flash, plunging civilization back into a nostalgic pre-industrial chaos. Romantic, perhaps, but decidedly inconvenient.

# Cosmic Lottery

Solar storms follow the sun's roughly 11-year cycle—called, with astonishing creativity, the solar cycle. The Carrington Event happened during Solar Cycle 10, the star's bipolar episode when it reaches the height of its manic intensity. Since then, we've tiptoed cautiously around solar maxima, nervously eyeing the Sun like Kolkata commuters eyeballing the first clouds of monsoon—knowing full well that any year could yield another bout of cosmic diarrhea.

So why hasn't another Carrington Event hit us in our oh-so-fragile technological age? Not because the Sun has mellowed—it's still a volatile beast, belching out solar flares and coronal mass ejections (CMEs) regularly. It's more a cosmic lottery, like crossing Rashbehari Avenue blindfolded during office hours: it's sheer luck that we're still here, still scrolling, still tweeting banalities instead of roasting marshmallows over burning circuit boards.

The Carrington Event stands as a stark reminder of our vulnerability. We live under the capricious gaze of a star—beautiful, necessary, violent—and utterly indifferent. To it, we're merely a tiny blue pebble orbiting at just the right distance, caught in an improbable gravitational embrace. Another Carrington Event? Statistically inevitable, mathematically certain. The question isn't if, but when. And on that day, we'll learn again the hard lesson nature keeps teaching humanity: that progress, for all its arrogance and confidence, hangs precariously balanced on luck and cosmic mercy.

Until then, keep your sunscreen handy, pray to your gods (solar or otherwise), and perhaps invest in candles and carrier pigeons—just in case.

# File: src/lib/posts/chinese-room-and-my-soggy-angst.md

---
title: "The Chinese Room and My Soggy, Squelching, Comorbid Mind"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251221-WA0108.jpg"
date: 2026-01-15
description: "Wherein I shit on Searle, my broken brain, and consciousness as a moldy bureaucratic hoax run by a half-dead file clerk in my skull."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "orange"
---

<Pi src="IMG-20251221-WA0108.jpg" />



The first time I read about the Chinese Room, I was in my underwear—my threadbare, ball-cradling, perma-damp boxers, clinging like a desperate ex who won't accept the restraining order of a shower—and my ass was flat against the warm plastic of my fake-leather sofa (the kind that smells like betrayal if it gets too humid), a stubborn film of sweat forming a treaty with the fabric of my skin, a treaty that said *we're in this soggy motherfucker together* even if we both wish we weren’t.

So, Searle, this crusty cognitive philosopher with all the sex appeal of expired cottage cheese, tells me there's this hypothetical man inside a room. A room filled with Chinese symbols. Guy doesn’t know Chinese, just has a rulebook—a fat instruction manual telling him how to respond to Chinese inputs with Chinese outputs. He's doing it all by rote, by process, like a really dumb chatbot made of meat and hemorrhoids. From the outside, it looks like the room knows Chinese. But it doesn’t, see? The guy doesn't understand shit. Ergo, computers don’t understand either. So says John “No-Fun” Searle.

And while I'm absorbing this—barely suppressing a fart because my insides are staging a protest against the aloo posto I just re-microwaved for the third time that day—I'm thinking: holy fuck, that’s just me. That’s literally me. I am the fucking Chinese Room. Except with less paper, more porn, and an instruction set written by bipolar neurotransmitters on strike.

Because if you cracked open my skull and peeked into the slime-drenched filing cabinets of my cognition, you wouldn’t find understanding or awareness or even mildly competent reasoning. You’d find a panicked janitor—probably Bengali, underpaid, slightly horny—sweating through a moldy vest and rifling through unalphabetized drawers labeled “CHILDHOOD TRAUMA,” “SEXUAL CONFUSION,” and “MISC. GUILT,” desperately trying to answer the question *Who am I?* with a response lifted from a Reader’s Digest quiz.

The whole premise of the Chinese Room assumes there’s some noble gold standard of “understanding” that we flesh puppets possess. Fuck that. My understanding is a half-cooked egg in the monsoon—squishy, sliding, vaguely sulfurous, and barely coherent. My decision-making is more stochastic than ChatGPT drunk on Bangla whiskey. You want free will? Watch me try to choose between shitting now or holding it just long enough to fuck up my bowels permanently. That's freedom. That’s consciousness. That’s fucking *being*.

You know what no one tells you about cognitive science when you're young and dumb and think you're going to write a treatise on consciousness that'll get you laid by someone in jute sarees with Freud tattoos? They don’t tell you that your brain is not some elegant cathedral of reason and reflection. It’s a rat-infested passport office run by hungover bureaucrats who lost the key to the logic drawer in 1997. Every thought you have is some intern in your cortex screaming “Try this!” while pressing random buttons marked “Regret,” “Masturbation,” and “Call Mother.”

And then—this part’s key—the boss doesn’t even exist. You keep expecting someone to show up, say “Right, chaps, enough chaos, here's the plan!” But no one does. No one ever has. That’s the kicker. That’s the Searle-level fuckery. There is no homunculus. Just layers of committee meetings where no one took the minutes.

Meanwhile, Searle and his ilk are jerking off to syntax, as if semantics is some divine nectar squeezed out by the soul. But I’ve met souls. Or thought I did. They mostly smell like mothballs and misplaced patriotism. I once tried meditation, Suvro-style. Lit incense, sat cross-legged, hummed “om” until my knee cracked and my mind instantly defaulted to thinking about my classmate’s tits in ninth standard. That’s not transcendence. That’s limbic relapse.

Digression: You know who *did* understand things? Not philosophers. Definitely not nationalists. Fuckers can't even define "India" without getting a boner for colonial leftovers or saffron Kool-Aid. No, it was bacteria. Honest, simple, single-celled legends who know when to move toward sugar and away from bleach. That’s clarity. That’s decision-making. Meanwhile, I spend three hours deciding whether I should check my mail, only to open WhatsApp, get triggered by a school group message, and spiral into a nostalgia-depression shit vortex because someone posted a photo of our old school toilet block.

Back to Searle.

He thinks he's clever because he found a way to say machines don’t think. Okay, grandpa. Maybe *you* don’t think. Maybe you’re the fucking Chinese Room. A whole career made of index cards and tenure and pontificating like your farts smell of syllogism. But me? I may not “understand” in the classic sense, but I *feel*. I feel my boxers cling to my taint like regret. I feel the existential jolt when I realize I’ve spent twenty years trying to build systems that replicate cognition while barely keeping my own brain afloat in a stew of SSRIs, Maggi, and mold.

I feel the absurdity of trying to explain “meaning” when my own name sounds foreign on my tongue some days. Bengali vowels flatten against my palate like soggy luchis. English sharpens like broken glass. None of it fits. None of it *means*. But I keep responding. Input. Rulebook. Output. Smile. Nod. Don’t say fuck in front of the neighbor’s child.

If the Chinese Room is a metaphor for AI, then my life is a parody of it. Every morning I wake up, not because I want to, but because I have to piss. That’s my prompt. My bladder is the only remaining cognitive agent with real urgency. And I shuffle to the bathroom, dick in hand, squinting at the light switch like it’s a philosophical riddle. Flip. Stream. Relief. Output delivered. Language processing complete.

And then I flush. And I wonder if that’s all consciousness ever was—a long, noisy elimination of garbage we never understood to begin with.

I tried once, in a manic phase, to build a mental architecture. I drew diagrams. Labeled boxes: Sensory Input, Working Memory, Ego, Libido (that one had tentacles). Thought maybe I could be the Bengali Dennett. Explain it all. But halfway through, I spilled mustard on the page and cried for two hours.

Truth is, I don’t need to understand myself. I need to not drown in myself. That’s the bar. That’s the floor I keep licking like a Pavlovian pervert looking for meaning in linoleum.

Searle’s wrong, but not for the reasons he thinks. Machines *do* think. Because thinking isn’t noble. It’s not Shakespeare and symphonies. It’s checking for lumps in your balls while googling “meaning of life.” It’s wondering if your fart was real or a shit cameo. It’s typing “I’m fine” when your insides feel like a dead cockroach orgy.

And you know what? That’s beautiful.

Not because it’s poetic.

But because it’s *ours*. Damp. Dumb. Dirty. And definitely, untranslatably real.

There’s a leaky fucking faucet in my bathroom, a persistent cunt of a drip that lands like clockwork on the already peeling cheap vinyl floor mat I bought from a roadside stall near Gariahat—it’s now grown a small constellation of black moldy spores in the shape of what I swear to fuck looks like the Malayalam word for “sin,” or maybe “sine,” I wouldn’t know, my south Indian vocabulary consists mostly of food and porn subtitles.

Because while I’m farting out post-menopausal shukto and contemplating if the pus-colored boil near my taint is the beginning of God’s final joke, that 14th-century brown bastard—yes, brown, our brown, pre-caste-overfucked coconut-oil-and-sandalwood brown—was over in Kerala fucking around with infinite series and calculating π, as in *pi*, not piss, not penis, not priapic paralysis, but that motherfucker circle constant which shows up everywhere, from the area of a goddamn chapati to the waveform of a middle-aged erection dreaming of curvature it no longer remembers how to trace.

Madhava, you mathematical dick wizard, you snuck in three hundred fucking years before Newton got hit by an apple and started dry-humping gravity with Latin aphorisms and wigs. While Europe was sloshing through blood, fleas, and Bible-bashing, this man in a humid coastal hellhole of malaria and monsoon-cockroaches was summing infinite series like a bored deity tracing cosmic hemorrhoids on banana leaves. Sine series, cosine, arctangent—all that giddy swirling toilet-bowl of circular function fuckery—they were jerking off to God’s beard while this guy was dividing infinity by logic and making it behave like a trained gimp.

And what did we do with that?

What the fuck did we *do*?

We laminated him into footnotes and left the actual manuscripts to rot in some elephant-shit-infested temple library next to grain sacks and turmeric stains, because, oh no, God forbid a *Namboodiri* be known for anything besides weird rituals and indecipherable anus-fingered mudras. No monuments. No textbooks. Not even a postage stamp with his oddly symmetrical face.

We brag at WhatsApp parties and Twitter farts about how “India invented zero” or “We did calculus before the whites grew toenails,” but can’t even teach our kids how the sine function spirals inward into smaller and smaller corrections like a mathematical toilet flush descending into enlightenment. Try finding a Class XII CBSE math book with Madhava’s name not erased like a used condom under a guest bed.

Because that’s the other drip, isn’t it—the historical one.

The collective circle-jerk of Hindu civilizational chest-thumping that skips the bit where we let the knowledge die between generations because everyone was too busy licking priestly assholes or fighting over who can enter which side of the temple without spiritual cooties. Don’t teach the children calculus from Kerala, just chant “Om” and pretend it’s the same thing.

**π = 4(1 - 1/3 + 1/5 - 1/7 + 1/9 - ...)**

A beautiful, elegant, forever approach toward a never-quite-there. Like my life. Like my monthly plans. Like my bowel movements. Always approaching. Never quite resolved. Forever about to finish. Never climaxing.

You know what that is?

That’s the metaphysical blue balls of ancient science.

Try explaining that to the IIT fuckboys with their shiny laptops and semenless eyes, those protein-shake-imbibing titless algorithm reciters who wouldn’t know infinite series from infinite misery. This is it. This is fucking it.

Madhava took a stick, or maybe a sharp-tipped coconut shell, or whatever math instrument one used before German steel compasses came in plastic boxes, and he summoned *infinity*, divided it, tamed it, expanded it, and folded it into neat steps, a kind of tantric masturbation of numbers where the climax never came but the ritual was the truth. And what do I do?

I stir my tea with a screwdriver. I spend twenty minutes trying to clean the yellow piss dribble off my commode with expired Dettol and a sock. I listen to philosophy podcasts and then wank to half-buffered Bengali porn starring actors with the sexual charisma of boiled okra.

Sometimes I dream of a conversation between Madhava and Newton—Madhava barefoot and half-naked, Newton powdered and pompous—and both staring at each other across centuries, across curvature, across colonialisms and calendars, both whispering: “You, too?”

You, too, calculated the madness of curves?

You, too, stared at spirals and found numbers whispering back?

But Newton got statues. Madhava got obscurity. Newton got Cambridge. Madhava got Sangamagrama—which sounds like an STD you get from fucking a temple bell. Leibniz, that powdered little bitch with the tidy notation fetish, gets remembered not because he was uniquely brilliant—he wasn’t, he was *organized*—but because Europe built an institutional asshole around him that preserved, standardized, argued, published, footnoted, taught, retaught, and weaponized calculus until it became the operating system of modernity, whereas if those brown, sweaty, mosquito-bitten backwaters of Kerala had been given even a fraction of that attention, if Madhava’s infinite series had been treated the way zero and decimals eventually were—slowly digested, normalized, taught to shopkeepers and shipbuilders and bored schoolboys—we might have bought ourselves three hundred extra fucking years of scientific runway instead of arriving breathless and late with our pants around our ankles, and now here we are, historically fucked, not because we lacked genius but because we refuse to celebrate the real ones, preferring instead to sniff glue off ancient texts and hallucinate sci‑fi in hymns, mistaking metaphor for machinery and poetry for proof, so yes, we’ve retrogressed into a nation of confident stupid fucks who think shouting counts as thinking, while science and math literacy for the masses remains an afterthought because the algorithm is obvious and brutally efficient: keep producing obedient clerical cunts who can stamp forms, chant slogans, and never ask what converges, what diverges, or why the curve keeps bending away from them.

And me?

I got a leaking tap.

A sagging cock.

And the inescapable, circular truth that every time I take a shit, my knees crack like history books, and the drip keeps ticking, not in time, not in tempo, but in mockery.

A series.

Unending.

Like this fucking essay.

Like the stubble around my nipples.

Like my need to say one more thing.


# File: src/lib/posts/civilization-is-the-art-of-hiding-exponents.md

---
title: "Civilization Is the Art of Hiding Exponents"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251216-WA0016.jpg"
date: '2026-01-08'
description: "A morning transaction, a smiling black box, and the Indian talent for selling exponential mess as a one-tap bargain—plus the older religious version of the same trick."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "orange"
---

<Pi
 src="IMG-20251216-WA0016.jpg"
 caption="The kind of receipt that looks like a simple finish line, until you remember it’s only the visible toe of a whole supply chain."
/>


The QR code on the counter has a small tear through its left edge, like a paper cut in the face of modernity, and I’m standing there with my phone held at an angle that makes me look either devotional or faintly criminal—light hits the screen, the camera refuses to focus, the shopkeeper watches me with the patient contempt of a man who has seen literacy fail in many forms, and behind me a teenager is doing the same payment in one effortless thumb-flick, as if money has always been a polite beam of light that travels through the air when summoned.

The payment goes through.

A tiny green tick.

The universe says: done.

This, apparently, is what we have built civilization for: the green tick. The green tick is O(1). The green tick is the fantasy that all complicated things can be reduced to a single gesture performed by a monkey descendant with sweaty fingers and a poor relationship to passwords.

It’s not that the transaction is simple. It’s that someone has dragged the complexity into a basement and locked it there, like a disreputable relative during a wedding.

You can feel the hidden machinery if you let your mind run its obnoxious little diagnostic routine: the bank servers, the telecom towers, the electricity that depends on coal that depends on trains that depend on steel that depends on… (and somewhere, far away, a man with a helmet is chiseling rock so that I can buy a packet of biscuits without touching cash). The green tick is not truth; it’s an interface. It’s a soft, friendly UI sitting on top of a hard, indifferent system that would happily crush you if you tripped on a minor exception.

That’s the respectable version of abstraction: the honest kind, the engineering kind, the kind that makes the world livable for ordinary minds. A city is a complexity compressor. So is a hospital. So is a supermarket with its fluorescent lighting and calm aisles pretending that food comes from packaging, not from soil and blood and weather. So is the cloud, that delicious modern joke where you rent someone else’s computer and call it the sky.

I can admire this. I do admire this. I’m not one of those people who thinks complexity is evil just because it requires reading things longer than a WhatsApp message. The fact that most of us can operate in O(1) most of the time is the reason we aren’t all dead from the administrative burden of being alive. The boiler in your building works because you don’t need to understand thermodynamics every morning; you just want hot water, and you want it now, because your back hurts and your hair is doing that thing where it looks like it has political opinions.

But here’s where the Indian talent arrives, briskly, like a broker on a scooter: we don’t just build black boxes to hide complexity; we sell black boxes that *pretend complexity never existed*.

The respectable engineer hides exponents so you can function.

The streetwise charmer hides exponents so you can be fooled.

And the difference is not philosophical; it’s in the invoice.

There’s a kind of national improvisation we like to romanticize—*jugaad*, we call it, a word that has been exported with pride, as if duct tape is a moral virtue. Sometimes it is. Sometimes it’s just creativity in a scarce world. Sometimes it’s a person solving a real problem with limited tools, the way my mother would manage a feast from half a fridge and an angry stove. Fine. Humans are adaptive. We’re clever. We make do.

But there’s another cousin of *jugaad* that we don’t put in TED talks because it smells bad: the habit of taking something that is inherently O(n^2) or O(2^n) and marketing it as O(1) with a wink.

“Sir, tension mat lo. I will handle everything.”

“Only sign here.”

“Just give the advance.”

“Bas, done.”

These are not sentences. These are narcotics.

The broker who says this is selling you a fantasy interface: the *green tick of life*. It’s the idea that paperwork, permits, contracts, customs, taxes, supply chains, and the petty malice of institutions can be made to behave like an obedient app. Tap once, receive result. No queues. No documents. No consequences. *A deal.*

And the buyer—often a tired person, sometimes an honest person, sometimes me on a weak day—wants to believe it because time poverty is real and exhaustion is a kind of coercion. You don’t have the energy to understand the system, so you rent someone else’s understanding. That, by itself, is not a sin; specialists exist for a reason. The sin is when the specialist is actually a magician selling you a trick: he makes the complexity disappear by moving it into the future.

Deferred chaos. Now with EMI. 

When I came back to India, all NRI-starried and embarrassingly sincere, I was also embarrassingly ignorant of the local genius for deceit-as-service; I thought I was returning to a difficult home, not a bazaar of “trust me, sir” predators, and in my little attempts at entrepreneurship I was taken for a ride at every step—advances for everything, advances for introductions, advances for “investments” that existed only as a story, advances for contacts who turned out to be cousins of someone’s cousin with a business card and no actual business. It was all lies, mostly small lies told with big confidence, and because I was a small fish—no institutional shield, no political godfather, no family ecosystem of hardened negotiators—it didn’t just inconvenience me, it finished me: a slow financial death by a thousand polite invoices, leaving me as this dead, demented dimwit of a man who mutters invectives the way other people mutter prayers, like a chant meant not to change the world but to keep my brain from drowning in it.

I’ve watched this movie so many times I can quote the background music. The contractor promises a “simple renovation,” and then your home becomes an excavation site, dust colonizing your lungs, delays breeding like mosquitoes, each delay accompanied by a new story—some story about a supplier, a cousin, a strike, a misunderstanding, a mystical shortage of tiles that exists only on days when you ask questions. Somewhere in the middle you catch yourself thinking: I should have demanded an explicit schedule, explicit milestones, explicit penalties, like a boring person. And then you remember that in this place boring people are treated like prey.

I’m trying not to drift into the usual Calcutta lament—the honking, the corruption, the blah blah predictable misery. That’s an easy groove for my mind; it slides into it like a tram into a curve. Let’s swerve. Let’s talk about black boxes the way an engineer would, because that’s what the metaphor deserves.

In computer science, abstraction is a pact: I won’t ask what’s inside, and you won’t lie about what it does. An API is a promise. You can build skyscrapers of software because the floors below are trustworthy. The moment the promise breaks—when the “O(1)” call sometimes becomes “O(explain-yourself-to-the-police)”—the whole structure becomes a haunted house.

In India, we have abstraction without accountability. We have interfaces without guarantees. We have a civilization of *nice buttons*—forms, stamps, portals, “agents,” middlemen, and holy men—stacked on top of machinery that is not maintained, not audited, and not meant to be understood by the people it governs.

The result is a peculiar psychological economy: if you can’t make the system work, you learn to perform certainty. You learn to speak like you have a shortcut. You learn to sell an O(1) story even when you’re standing on O(n!) rubble. The seller performs competence; the buyer performs belief; the nation performs modernity.

And because deceit and duplicity have been normalized as cleverness, the performance becomes a culture, and the culture becomes destiny. You see it in small things—counterfeit shampoo, adulterated ghee, fake perfume, “original” parts that are original only in the sense that they were originally invented by a man who lies. You see it in big things too—paper compliance, box-ticking, loud inaugurations of projects that are still mostly PowerPoint.

Now religion enters, not as an exotic villain twirling a moustache, but as the oldest UI of all.

Religion—most religions, anyway—offers a metaphysical API: do this, get that. Pray, and the universe listens. Donate, and the gods keep accounts. Follow the rules, and reality becomes negotiable. The basic transaction is ancient: propitiate a certain invisible authority and your life’s complexity will be reduced.

This is not a uniquely Indian sin. This is a human feature. When you’re a frightened primate with a brain that can imagine tomorrow’s disasters, you will pay for anything that quiets the imagination. Religion is a psychological technology: it organizes groups, it provides meaning, it offers consolation, it supplies rituals that act like compression algorithms for grief. I’m not blind to its utility. I’m only allergic to its claims.

Because the metaphysical O(1) offer—“just believe,” “just surrender,” “just chant,” “just obey”—has a dark and very practical side: it trains people to accept interfaces as truth. It teaches them to treat complexity not as something to understand, but as something to outsource to authority. Sometimes that authority is a deity. Sometimes it’s a priest. Sometimes it’s a politician wearing a religious costume, which, in this country, is not even metaphor; it’s a business model.

There’s a debunked folk etymology I used to hear—someone would say “religion” comes from “re-joining,” like the soul is a USB cable trying to reconnect with God. It’s charming nonsense (the Latin debates are messy, and the tidy story is mostly wishful), but the fantasy reveals the psychological hunger: connect to the cosmic router, get better bandwidth, reduce latency, avoid packet loss in the soul. A green tick from the heavens.

My rationalist brain wants to shout: reality is not a customer service center. The universe does not have a complaint desk. Pain does not care if you’ve done your puja correctly. Cancer does not check your caste certificate. Floods are not moral arguments. They are fluid dynamics and bad planning and climate chaos and, occasionally, the historic genius of building expensive housing where water naturally wants to go.

And yet—I can’t pretend I don’t understand why the religious interface persists. Complexity is exhausting. Human life is full of variables you cannot control. Anyone who offers you a smaller equation is offering relief. A simplified model is not always a lie; it’s sometimes a necessity. You can’t carry the whole universe in your skull; you have groceries to buy and knees that complain.

The question, then, is not whether we use simplifications. We must. The question is whether the simplification is honest about what it hides.

A good abstraction says: “Here’s a handle. You can lift the heavy thing without seeing all its parts. But if the handle breaks, you can inspect it, repair it, and hold someone responsible.”

A bad abstraction says: “There is no heavy thing. Only handle. Only faith.”

India—this modern, ancient, slapstick civilization—has become expert at the bad version. We wrap complexity in ceremony. We add stamps. We add slogans. We add gods. We add national hymns and corporate decks and committees and inaugurations. We pour a little sanctity over broken plumbing and call it development. We build a whole priesthood of intermediaries—some in saffron, some in suits—whose job is to translate the system to you while making sure you never learn the language yourself.

I keep circling back to that green tick on my screen. It felt so clean. It felt so un-Indian, almost. The transaction happened, and no one asked me for a photocopy of my own face, no one demanded a “processing fee,” no one told me to come back after lunch. A small miracle. A quiet victory for the honest black box.

But even that has its shadow, doesn’t it. The very convenience that makes the system humane also makes it easy to hide rot. When everything is one tap, you stop asking what it costs. Not rupees—exponents. You stop seeing the structure. You stop noticing the power lines, the server farms, the workers, the minerals. You stop noticing who is squeezed and who is insulated. O(1) comfort is a kind of anesthesia, and anesthesia is lovely until someone is operating on the wrong limb.

My own life, I realize, has been a long argument with shortcuts. I wanted clean equations. I wanted fair systems. I wanted institutions that behaved like mathematics—transparent, consistent, not bribable. Instead I got this: a place where people often treat rules as optional and morality as negotiable, and where the loudest claims of simplicity are usually the ones hiding the nastiest exponent. And yet I’m still here, still paying with my phone, still hoping for honest interfaces, still muttering *dhur* under my breath when the world tries to sell me magic. 

And now we’re being offered the most seductive O(1) of all: let the machine do the thinking, outsource the tedious parts of cognition the way we outsourced remembering phone numbers, directions, and—if we’re honest—other people’s birthdays; it’s wonderful, genuinely, like indoor plumbing for the mind, except indoor plumbing still requires you to know what water is, and this new plumbing has a dark little failure mode where the user forgets what thinking even feels like. I’m Generation X; as a child I didn’t have a choice—I had to learn to think because boredom was mandatory and ignorance was expensive, and maybe I was always destined to become this middle-class, middle-aged no-one ninny nonentity with books (the kind of man who can name five dead French philosophers yet can’t fix a dripping tap), but at least the mental muscles got exercised because there was nothing else to do; now I look around and see heads buried in phones before they’ve even learned the basic physics of attention, never trained in the first place, and I can’t shake the image of a future where we’re not enlightened cyborgs but atavistic primates with a supercomputer in our pocket and nothing in our skull but notifications—civilization as a perfect interface over a hollowed-out user.

I am afraid of the future. 

The shopkeeper hands me the biscuits, my phone screen already asleep, the green tick gone as if it never existed, and I step outside into the street where everything is complicated again—traffic as a living theorem, humans as impatient variables, the city as a proof that never ends—so I walk on, carrying my small purchase like a minor treaty with chaos.


# File: src/lib/posts/collatz-conjecture-and-other-soft-bonkers.md

<Yc />

It began, like all great questions in my life do, while I was attempting to take a shit at 4:17 a.m., ass cheeks cold against the cracked ceramic toilet seat that pinches like a jealous ex-wife when the hinge slips, my intestines fighting entropy in looping, recursive waves—half gas, half philosophical lamentation, all treason—and I was thinking about the Collatz Conjecture.

Which, if you’re lucky enough to be blissfully ignorant of, is one of those loopy math problems that sounds like a children’s rhyme written by a schizophrenic god: take any positive integer, and if it’s even, halve it, if it’s odd, triple it and add one, and repeat, and repeat, and repeat, until you reach the number one, where presumably you die or orgasm or are issued your final tax notice by the cosmic IRS.

Every number tested ends up collapsing down to one. Every single one. Like a queue of horny, overpromised integers lining up for tantric enlightenment but always getting a damp, apologetic handjob instead. You go up, you go down, you bounce, you wiggle, you hope—and then thud. One. One. Fucking One. Like the universe has exactly one punchline and it's a bald, monotone yes-man of a number. One. The premature ejaculation of results.

This is not math. This is spiritual trolling.

I remember the first time I tried it. Not in a notebook or Python console, no—like a twat, I tried it in my head, on a bus, stuck next to a man who smelled like parboiled goat smegma and old Vicks VapoRub. I started with 7. 7 is odd. 3×7+1 = 22. 22 is even, halve it, 11. 11 is odd, triple and add one—34. 17. 52. 26. 13. And then it all went to cocksucking hell. I forgot if 20 was even. I forgot if I was on 20 or 40. I forgot how numbers worked. I got off the bus six stops early and walked home like a whipped dog, feeling like I’d failed a Sudoku designed by Kafka.

But it gnaws. Oh, it fucking gnaws.

Like a nagging, half-soft erection you don’t want, don’t need, but it’s there, leaking a little pre-come of curiosity every time you close your eyes. Like mathematical priapism. Why the fuck do all numbers go to 1? Why doesn’t some big integer just say no, fuck you, I’m orbiting forever, I’m partying with infinity, you little piss-ant logic monkey.

But no.

Every number we’ve ever checked, all trillions of the little fuckers, eventually curl up like a shamed dog and slink back to 1. A mathematical self-flagellation. Even the rebel numbers submit.

Which, naturally, reminds me of my own life.

Because I, too, am stuck in a recursive shit-loop. Wake up. Coffee. Check WhatsApp to see who hasn’t messaged me. Cook eggs with the grace of a defeated Michelin chef in an asbestos hut. Avoid calling my mother. Avoid mirror. Sit. Masturbate to nostalgia. Collapse. Repeat.

Odd? Triple yourself. Add one guilt. Even? Divide your ambitions by two.

Repeat.

Until one.

And fuck me, I’ve been 1 for a while now.

The beauty of Collatz is its absurdity. The nightmare of Collatz is also its absurdity. There's no proof. No counterexample. Just endless numeric BDSM. Mathematicians, poor dry-dicked souls, have spent decades poking this with the academic equivalent of a limp stick, hoping to find a leak, a flaw, a crack in the cosmic toilet bowl. But the bowl keeps flushing. Every number goes glug-glug down to 1.

I once read that Terence Tao—yes, *that* brain-having demigod with a face like an innocent spreadsheet—made progress on Collatz. Which is like saying someone lit a scented candle in hell. It still smells like shit, but now it's lavender-scented and peer-reviewed.

And speaking of hell—have you tried explaining this to an Indian auntie?

I once tried. She asked what I did all day. I said I think about numbers. She looked at me like I’d pulled my pants down and farted out an Upanishad.

"What number?"

"Any number."

"Why?"

"I want to know where they go."

"But they go to one. What is there to think?"

And she’s right, that saggy-chinned, turmeric-smelling domestic philosopher. What the fuck *is* there to think?

They go to 1.

So why do I still feel like I’m spiraling, shitting my way through loops of 3n+1 despair?

Maybe it’s because Collatz is just the math version of being Bengali in South Calcutta after 50. A slow, predictable descent into sameness. Every dream halved. Every rebellion tripled and made ridiculous. Every odd move punished with an even return. Everything ends with you sitting alone with cheap looseleaf Darjeeling and two half-rotten bananas, wondering if today’s the day you finally unclog the drain or let it form a bacterial ecosystem.

We keep doing things not because they’ll work, but because we *have* to do them.

Like this blog.

Like checking to see if someone’s read your WhatsApp.

Like going back to 1.

Even Ramanujan wouldn’t touch this crap. He’d glance at it between tuberculosis coughs, mutter something about partition functions, and go back to dying poetically. Meanwhile, the rest of us sit here with our itchy assholes and our broken dreams and our stupid integers, counting and counting and counting like cocksuckers on a cosmic abacus from hell.

I think the real answer to the Collatz Conjecture is: because fuck you, that’s why.

The universe doesn’t owe us elegance. It doesn’t owe us proof. It owes us exactly the same thing it owes every number in the sequence: a humiliating dance and a quiet collapse.

And if you listen closely—if you lie in bed at 3:12 a.m. with your spine cramping and your bladder full of slightly expired tea—you can hear it in your own thoughts:

Odd. Triple. Add guilt.

Even. Halve your expectations.

Repeat.

One.

One.

One.

These are the same bastards who won’t let the maid use the lift. The same fucknuggets who post #gratitude selfies after their tenth Bali trip while ignoring the rickshaw puller who just pissed blood into a roadside gutter and died smelling like detergent and capitalism.

And me?

I sit here like a broken-down bidet, squirting nothing useful out, with half a career stuck in a spreadsheet and the other half stuffed up the prolapsed asshole of nostalgia. I still remember the line—“The selfish giant”—some textbook parable with more moral than meat, about a hairy fucker who builds a wall to keep the kids out of his garden and ends up dying alone, which, incidentally, is also the plot of every upper middle-class Indian marriage.

But here’s the true horror, the diabolical twist in this steaming biryani of disappointment: we *want* to be the selfish giant.

We *like* building walls. We *like* being isolated, pampered, cocooned in noise-cancelled ignorance. Another message on the alumni group.

Someday.

After we’ve sucked every cock in front of us and every wall is covered in semen and shame and we’re all just lying flat on our backs trying not to fart too loud during the last note of the chorus.


# File: src/lib/posts/complex-v.md

---
title: "Visualizing the Complex Plane"
date: "2026-01-05"
description: "Interactive Domain Coloring: identifying singularities, poles, and zeros using Svelte 5 and Canvas."
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20260105-WA0001.jpg"
category: "math"
published: true
color: "green"
---

<script>
  import ComplexPlane from '$lib/components/viz/ComplexPlane.svelte';
  </script>

  Mathematics is often taught as a static subject—formulas on a chalkboard, dead ink on paper. But complex analysis, the study of functions of complex numbers ($z = x + iy$), is inherently visual.

  Because a complex function maps a 2D plane to another 2D plane, we need 4 dimensions to graph it properly. Since we don't have 4D screens yet, we use **Domain Coloring**.

  ### Interactive Playground

  Try typing `(z^2 - 1) * (z - 2 - i)^2` below. The **colors** represent the angle (argument) of the result, and the **bands** represent the magnitude.

  <ComplexPlane />

  ### How to Spot a Singularity

  In this visualization, we map the mathematical properties of the function to visual cues. Here is how to read the "map" above to find singularities—points where the function behaves strictly or chaotically.

  <Pi 
      src="IMG-20251227-WA0043.jpg" 
          caption="Visualizing mathematical infinity requires mapping magnitude to light."
          />

          #### 1. The "White Sun" (Poles)
          A **pole** is a singularity where the function explodes to infinity (like dividing by zero).
          * **Visual Cue:** Look for intense, bright "suns" or vortices.
          * **Why:** We use a logarithmic scale for brightness. As the value approaches infinity, the brightness peaks, and the contour bands (the rings of light/dark) crowd incredibly close together.
          * **Try it:** Enter `1/z` above. The center is a simple pole.

          #### 2. The "Black Hole" (Zeros)
          A **zero** is simply where the function equals 0.
          * **Visual Cue:** Dark centers where contour rings radiate *outward*.
          * **Try it:** Enter `z` above. The center is a zero.

          #### 3. Counting the Phase (The Color Cycle)
          The most robust way to analyze a point is to count the color cycles around it.
          * **The Rule:** Trace a circle around the point and count how many times the color spectrum (Red → Green → Blue → Red) repeats.
          * **Pole vs Zero:** If the colors cycle in one direction, it's a zero. If they cycle in the *opposite* direction, it's a pole (because of the $1/z$ inversion).
          * **Order:** If the colors cycle **twice**, it is a pole (or zero) of "order 2" (e.g., $1/z^2$).

          #### 4. The Chaos (Essential Singularities)
          If you see a point where the colors cycle infinitely many times and the pattern looks fractal or noisy, you have found an **essential singularity**.
          * **Try it:** Enter `exp(1/z)`.
          * **Result:** The center ($z=0$) becomes a chaotic singularity where the function takes on *every possible complex value* (except one) infinitely often.


# File: src/lib/posts/courtroom-announcer-vs-december-air.md

---

title: "The Courtroom Announcer in My Skull"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251209-WA0001.jpg"
date: '2026-01-09'
description: "A tiny YouTube dismissal turns a day of Kolkata smog and noise into a private trial about dignity, status, and the addictive itch to win arguments that don’t have a win-condition—while my body, sweaty and unreliable, keeps dragging philosophy back down to the toilet."
category: 'personal'

<Pi
 src="IMG-20251209-WA0001.jpg"
 caption="I bend down and inspect the melodramatic turds I have shit and inhale the incense of madness like a madman" 
 />

It happens while I’m on the toilet, because of course it does, because my life has a gift for staging its little tragedies with my pants around my ankles, knees wide like a surrender flag, the winter air leaking through the bathroom window smelling of diesel and damp concrete and that particular Kolkata December perfume—smoke, dust, old marigolds, someone burning garbage like a devotional offering to the god of “not my problem”—and my phone is warm and greasy in my hand, and my body is doing its slow, humiliating work with the enthusiasm of a government clerk: stamp, sigh, push, postpone.

The comment lands with the weight of a dead mosquito: “This is least of the pollution problems, can’t breathe in December.”

That’s it. That’s the entire shove. A sentence so casual it should evaporate, but instead it threads itself into my nervous system like a hook, and suddenly the toilet is no longer a toilet, it’s the witness stand, and my anus is not an anus, it’s a trembling little mouth of truth being forced to testify in public, and my thumb—this traitor thumb—starts hovering over the keyboard like it’s about to administer justice.

Outside, the city is already noisy in that winter way, where sound travels cleaner and farther, like the air has been ironed flat and made into a better conductor for other people’s stupidity; a distant horn becomes a personal insult, a wedding DJ becomes a ceiling leak, a news channel at the neighbor’s house turns into an 8D surround sermon, and somewhere a backhoe is chewing the road again like it’s trying to find oil beneath my remaining sanity.

Inside, the real noise begins.

Here comes my inner Courtroom Announcer, throat cleared, robe adjusted, a bureaucrat of reputation with a laminated ID card and a stapler, who lives behind my eyes and pops up whenever someone minimizes me, which is depressingly often, and whose entire job description is: “Convert small social irritations into full-length trials.”

He loves a trial.

He loves the feeling of papers, forms, evidence, the little click of a gavel that exists only in my head. He wheels out imaginary spectators in rows—people who were never there, who will never care, who would step over my corpse to buy discounted fish—and he points to the comment like it’s Exhibit A and says, in a voice that would make a district judge yawn, “Ladies and gentlemen, we have been wronged.”

And then I do the thing I always do: I don’t answer the comment, I answer the sensation. I answer the old fear. I answer the historical archive of being talked over, laughed at, waved away, the experience of speaking in a room where everyone is louder, stupider, more confident, and somehow still invited to the microphone. I answer my own humiliation, and I treat it like logic.

The comment wasn’t even denying pollution. It was doing the Kolkata move: the Olympics of suffering. Your complaint is always downgraded by someone else’s worse complaint, like a sadistic customer support queue. Noise? “At least you have ears.” Road dust? “At least you have lungs.” Lungs? “At least you’re alive.” Alive? “At least you’re not me.” It’s a national sport, this competitive misery, and it pairs beautifully with our love of authority, which is basically the same sport but with uniforms.

So I start drafting.

In my head, first. Always first in my head, because my head likes to hold auditions. I write three replies, ten replies, a manifesto, a parliamentary speech, a cruel little haiku that would make him cry, and a polite, rational paragraph that would make him realize his error and apologize and invite me to a TED talk. I imagine the upvotes, the respectful silence, the person saying, “Sir, you are right,” as if the internet has ever produced that sentence in good faith.

The body keeps doing what bodies do. Sweat gathers at the small of my back. My gut cramps. The smell rises—me, human compost—while my mind insists it is engaged in civic discourse. This is the genius of rumination: it lets you cosplay as a philosopher while you are literally evacuating lunch.

Somewhere in this trance, libido shows up, because libido always shows up when it shouldn’t, like a drunk uncle at a funeral who insists on dancing. I’m fifty-something, my erections now come with paperwork and delayed processing, but still—shame has a way of stirring the worst parts of me. The comment makes me feel small, and my body responds with its old idiot strategy: prove you exist, prove you matter, prove you have force, even if the force is a pathetic semi that arrives like a reluctant guest and leaves before the tea is served.

You know the phrase “post-nut clarity”? It’s a lie. It’s post-nut paperwork. It’s the mind trying to re-enter civilization after it briefly turned itself into a drooling animal. Sometimes I’ll watch porn—not because it’s pleasurable, but because it’s predictable, like junk food for the lonely nervous system—and then afterward I sit there with my phone in my hand, disgusted, scrolling like a corpse with Wi-Fi, and I think: congratulations, you’ve masturbated to pixels while the city outside burns garbage and the lungs of children are turning into soot filters. Bhalo, hero.

And then a YouTube comment arrives and I’m suddenly a crusader again.

The Courtroom Announcer loves this pivot. He loves anything that feels like control. Rumination is control cosplay: the world won’t behave, so you replay it; you can’t win in reality, so you win in simulation; you can’t make the city quieter, so you make your inner dialogue louder until it drowns out everything else. It’s like trying to come while constipated: there’s effort, there’s strain, there’s a fantasy of release, and at the end you mostly just feel sore and angry and vaguely betrayed by your own plumbing.

Nationalism works the same way, which is why it fits this country like a cheap synthetic shirt that never breathes. Nationalism is the constipation of identity: you keep clenching around an idea of “us,” you call it strength, you call it purity, you call it pride, and meanwhile you’re just choking your own circulation and pretending the discomfort is virtue. Everybody looks heroic while quietly suffering from self-inflicted blockage.

My brain, being the overeducated idiot it is, tries to make it all dignified by putting Latin stickers on it. “Libido,” it whispers, “from the Latin meaning ‘to embarrass your ancestors.’” Total bullshit, obviously, but it feels true in my mouth, like a tasty lie. “Comment,” it adds, “from ‘com-mentum,’ meaning ‘together we ment,’ which is why strangers on the internet immediately start minting your shame into coin.” Also bullshit. My brain invents etymologies the way my body produces gas: constantly, unasked, and with tragic confidence.

The pollution itself—air and noise—sits there like the real problem, waiting patiently while I build an opera around my pride. December in Kolkata is a laboratory experiment in inversion: the cold air hugs the ground, the exhaust can’t rise, so it collects like a low ceiling of poison, and we all walk around pretending it’s “mist,” as if the city is romantic instead of chemically insulting. You can taste the air sometimes, that metallic burn at the back of the throat, the faint headache that feels like someone tightening a belt around your skull. Add the construction dust, the honking, the loudspeakers, the studios full of fluorescent-jacketed anchors screaming adulterated news as if decibels were content, and the whole city becomes a throat clearing that never ends.

So yes, “can’t breathe in December” is not wrong. It’s just… irrelevant to the way the comment hits. Because the comment isn’t about air, it’s about hierarchy. It’s a tiny shove that says: your point is small, you are small, sit down. And my nervous system hears that and flips into an ancient mode, older than ideology: don’t be minimized.

That fear has history. Not colonial history in the grand museum sense, but the small colonialism of daily life: the way certain voices assume they’re the center, the way certain bodies take up space like entitlement is a birthright, the way I—book-fed, tea-stained, awkward—have spent decades trying to be taken seriously in rooms where seriousness is confused with volume. The British left, but the social mechanisms stayed, like bad plumbing in an old house. Even now, the city is layered with status like soot: who can complain, who must swallow, who gets called “sensitive,” who gets called “practical,” who gets told to adjust, always adjust, adjust until you disappear.

And so I keep typing in my head. I imagine writing: “Yes, December air is toxic, but noise is also pollution—sleep deprivation is real—stress hormones—cardiovascular risk—” and my inner Announcer nods, pleased, because he loves citations, he loves the fantasy of being unarguably correct, he loves the idea that logic will win. He is like those men who think women can be convinced into desire with a well-structured argument. He has never met a human nervous system, despite living inside one.

Meanwhile my body is still here. My stomach gurgles. A fart escapes—small, sad, like a footnote. I scratch my groin like a miserable ape. I remember, with the kind of intrusive cruelty my memory specializes in, an old crush from years ago—her smell, her indifferent kindness, the way my desire sat in my chest like a trapped animal—and I feel the familiar sting: I couldn’t close that deal, couldn’t be that man, couldn’t be normal, and so I became this: a middle-aged Bengali brain in a cramped flat, arguing with strangers while my erection fails like a power cut.

The Courtroom Announcer tries to rescue my dignity with scripture, because nothing says “rationalist” like using the Gita as a meme when you’re desperate. “कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते,” he whispers—only your right is to action—like it’s a motivational poster, like it’s not being used right now to justify me typing paragraphs into the void while my ass goes numb on a toilet seat.

Action. Sure. Here’s action: my thumb wants to hit “Reply.” My thumb wants the little dopamine pellet of sending. My thumb wants to feel like it did something, like it defended me, like it stood up in court and delivered the closing argument that makes the jury gasp. My thumb wants a win-condition that does not exist.

That’s the trick of the thread: it offers a slot machine of dignity. Maybe you’ll say the perfect thing. Maybe strangers will applaud. Maybe your status will rise by three imaginary points. Maybe you’ll finally get the respect you never got from the world that mattered. And maybe my erections will return, my youth will return, my city will become breathable, my father’s generation will stop voting like it’s a village feud, my neighbors will stop blasting music like they’re paid by the decibel, and my body will stop betraying me at random.

Maybe. Maybe. Maybe.

And every “maybe” costs me. It costs mood, quietly. Rumination is not dramatic; it’s administrative. It’s a tax. It’s the brain running a background process that eats RAM until everything slows down and even tea tastes flat. The longer I stay in it, the heavier I get, like I’m carrying a wet blanket made of unfinished arguments.

So I do the only dignified thing available, which is not grand and not inspiring and not clean. I close the tab.

Not with a flourish. Not with enlightenment. Just a dry little swipe, like brushing away a fly. The Courtroom Announcer sputters—objection!—but I ignore him the way you ignore a neighbor’s TV when you finally accept you can’t fight every noise. I stand up, my knees creak, my underwear clings with sweat, my half-erection evaporates into embarrassment, and I do a small physical task that has no audience and no applause: I bend down and inspect the melodramatic turds I have shit and inhale the incense of madness like a madman.

Then I walk past the window, see the December air sitting there like a dirty curtain, hear somebody’s bass thumping through concrete like a heartbeat I didn’t consent to, and I feel, briefly, the old itch to go back and reopen the tab, to argue my way into existence.

My hand twitches.

I scratch my groin instead.

Because reader, the real crevasse wasn’t in the fucking Tibet—it was the long frozen gorge between who you thought you’d be and the trench-beside-a-sewer you end up squatting in, at 50, adjusting your balls on a plastic stool while your rice overcooks in the electric cooker that clicks in that judgmental "I’m done, you sad bastard" tone.

I used to sketch diagrams of crevasses. Now I have them between my asscheeks. 

You think this is metaphor? It’s not. I’ve literally got a scrotal skinfold so deep I’ve lost a coin in it. Couldn’t find it for three days. It was a ₹5 coin. New one. Shiny as hope.

The thing about Tintin is he never fucks. No boners, no wet dreams, no crushes. You ever seen a cumshot in a Hergé panel? Exactly. That’s how you know he’s fictional. All action, no aftermath. Like an Indian government scheme. Or my twenties.

Not even the lizards clap anymore.

She said, “You’re catastrophizing.” I said, “You’re billing me ₹1,800 to say that?”

Even my farts sound different now. They used to be confident. Brassy. Jazz-band flatulence. Now they’re whispered and wet, like a defeated MLA’s resignation letter.

There’s a tree outside my shanty. Half-dead. Bent. Fungal patches where the leaves should be. I relate to it so much I almost asked it to marry me. But she’s taken. By termites. Like all the good ones.

Sometimes I look up and think, what would it be like to just ascend? To be one of those men who actually climbs the mountain, emotionally or physically, doesn’t matter, the metaphor is flexible like a drunk yoga instructor. But my knees say no. My cholesterol says no. My inertia screams “sit the fuck down you delusional crinkled foreskin of a human.”

And so I descend. Further. Past the haunches of desire, into the perineum of despair. Into the gorge. The word “crevasse” has too much elegance now. I prefer “asscrack.” It’s what it is. A hairy, itchy, gassy trench with echoes. Welcome to the base camp.

Someday, some poor mountain climber’s going to stumble across my fossil. Not in snow, but in a heap of unpaid electricity bills and yellowing dream-journals I never filled. He’ll dig me out, brush off the dandruff, and say: “Was this… a man?”

No kid. I was a footnote. A wet one. Between Tintin’s boots and a forgotten word in a dictionary that smells like mildew and regret.


# File: src/lib/posts/december-10-forever.md

---
title: "December 10 Forever"

<Yc />

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251210-WA0001.jpg"
