While marriages aren't made in heaven, the fact is that they are indeed made, or made up. That should be a consternation to anyone who can think, but happily, we live in a time where thinking is gladly unpopular.

<Yt src="https://youtu.be/TEzVLLbwAdY?si=e-Rt-DxJkctj4X7T" />

Marriage is a sort of mutual domestication, a necessary compromise after the agricultural revolution that diverted hunter-gatherers into monogamy as it proffered advantage in survival and inheritance; otherwise, romance of the biological sort that defines intimacy is due to nerve growth factors that don't subscribe to the lived happily ever after, it can't, familiarity wears it off.

So it is a good bit of something that was a really a sad cheap trick the cave-men hit on to enslave the feral females and later promulgate the perverted hypocrisy of religious, well, jibber-jabber jibberish, can't think of a good word ever—nonsense to make it seem like an inevitable but permanent bond designed in the clouds; and like religious institutions, marriage never can, give people the sort of peace that happily-lived-ever-after; until or unless the protagonists are both dead, of course, which is why dead people are happily married; they look so cute side by side, sitting stiffly, black and white, in a photo frame.

Most iconoclasts have a lopsided view of marriage, a misguided romantic one, or, perniciously and problematically, a fictional spaghetti of their own making. I, as an iconoclast, would not make a good writer of such fiction, even though in my vision of the world, I tend to lean heavily on my misanthropic lens, which is beauty in its pathological strangeness, romantic in a roundabout way as my madness sees it. But I believe that in the near distant future, when we look back at marriage as one archaic term good as a catch all for bygone, primitive oxymorons, someone will remember that women, often having given up on the actual merits of a marriage, value the memory of the inferior pair on their recollection of a date as the last redeemable quality; that date for me was today, I should tell you, the tenth of December, and posterity should note that I am indeed good in that trivial sense. Except now I have to qualify the tense with "used to be", it's good that she moved on from what must have been an incorrigible nightmare and I am happy she has a different date to remember and remind fondly. But I'll lurk in the background of forgotten items, hiding in the drizzle and haze of the everyday ordinary, in the small things that life decides to throw at unexpected moments, and the remembrances of our shared past, the good or the bad, will all come flooding back to her, like hard to contain emotions.

<Yt src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/cJT3de5BOik" />

But what I feel is that the biology that was carved into us through the innumerable permutations of genes through evolution is what this shoehorn of social paraphernalia has accomplished to distort, disturbingly. People are animals, not the best kind to be with either, especially for life, and whether the level of vasopressin makes a claim for us being monogamous is debatable and a veritable bone of contention for a lived life of many more years that science may bestow in the future to come. At least we do oscillate between the horny bonobos and the occasionally doting chimpanzees in our marital escapades and duties, and it is the biological imperative that makes the males and females do what they ought to do based on algorithms that are now anachronistic for this ape with a smartphone.

Similarly, I point out that social forms of collective affirmation can never be a placeholder for the feeling you have about a person, and soon we will invent the technology to broadcast the vacillations. Most of my dreams still feature my past life more than the present, and the characters in the brain disregard with frothy disdain any of the features of prohibition that are looked down upon in the waking bengali reality or its physics. I've always been the offending partner in social parlance, but it befits the way that is imprinted in the biology of Homo sapiens.

All the square things that people say about themselves to fit into the rectangular aspirational picture frame are hollow, like the social customs themselves—the chanting around a ritual fire, the tribal feeding frenzy of the occasion. All the rites of passage culminate as an uncaring, thick layer of dust made from apathy, makes the cherished frame an antique or rubbish and the honeymoon pair get thrown away without impunity or concern. I can't do that when I am still alive and even though I sit alone in the said frame, that is only for those who draw comfort in such things. You may be born alone, but you rarely die alone, you die with all the characters married to you in your head, one way or the other.

We are what we are in the cheesecake suspended inside a dark room; all actors on a strange stage we contrive to call our lives are the hallucinations of neurons. My neurons were thrown off more by the overreacting list of the polypharmacy, than with the pathology of bipolarity for which they were prescribed. I'm thankful only to myself for having had the stamina to live through the harrowing ordeals of antipsychotics, dopamine-agonists, benzodiazapine and ambien, hellish drugs and cocktails that some still don't know are what they are, a trip that can be a seductive slippery slope to a trippy and excruciatingly excoriating end to the thin patina on the skin called reality. This pharmacologically induced distortion came at the time when I was trying on the shoes of a healthcare entrepreneur in a country that didn't want me. Indian proclivities are reliant on the thoughts of its leaders, who will sell their own mother without scruples and don't care about healthcare even a bit or anything that's of any real benefit to its citizens, except for keeping their own malevolent chair, but I desist—this isn't the place or paragraph.

But I can only say my better half wasn't the bitter half, nor was she in any way the partner who caused the upheavals in my timeline. This is what I must say to a time traveler, and I want to make it clear now that I can lucidly put words together and I am still alive. I can only hope that good things happen to her, for all the reasons point clearly towards a well deserved life. I was an anomaly for her, as I would be for anyone else. I am better off on my own, that way harm is minimized. My aspirations are too lofty and my depressions too deep for a flat lander to understand.

I also think expectations from monogamy are an affliction akin to prayers being answered by a bearded hairy misogynistic crusty old scrote on a cloud; you, even the normal people who do not count in the blacklisted twisted minds like me, have limited ways to prevent multiple partners in your mind where it matters. People or things for that matter, or abstractions, love them or hate them, or have these feelings coexist or flutter like the wings of a cockroach. The people or objects in our winged perception of reality can't matter, nor can what we think of them as real, when the "I" we hold so dear is itself a rotten construct of the mind. It doesn't exist, and I don't have to have a split brain to tell you that if the person who is thinking these thoughts is itself on such loose gravel, what can we expect of its tenacity to relate to the world? Being bipolar has that advantage, and I can speak for myself. It's a strange world your children (not mine; I don't have any; my gene ends with the sordidness in me) will inhabit in the next few hundred years, when we will be the first to taste how ultraviolet feels, the color of habareno pepper, or the aroma of a happy marriage as felt on the wedding night. Synesthesia will be the rule, not the exception, and people will know what it is to be bipolar and the depths of the affliction, both in the high and especially in the low.

I am aware that being mad makes little sense to most people, but that's quite alright. I think it's just that I know I have communicated what I wanted to say so that I can come clean as an examined life, albeit of little consequence.


# File: src/lib/posts/diarrhea-of-ideas-in-a-powerpoint-world.md

title: "power tools, soft bellies"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251207-WA0007.jpg"
date: 2026-01-10
description: "A filthy meditation on AI, entrepreneurship, bodily fear, fake optimism, real materials, and the humiliations of flesh when ideas pretend they’re weightless."

<Pi src="IMG-20251207-WA0007.jpg" 
  caption="soft ideas, hard floors" 
  />

It starts the way everything honest starts, which is to say with my gut making threats it can absolutely carry out, a low wet mutter like a municipal pump failing at 3 a.m., that exact moment when you realize this isn’t a fart you can negotiate with, this is a full-blown hostile takeover, and I’m standing there with my phone in one hand, pants already halfway down like a defeated flag, reading another one of those chirpy AI optimism screeds while my asshole is drafting its own manifesto about leverage, urgency, and irreversible timelines.

The shit comes fast, hot, opinionated, a real thought leader, splattering the bowl with the confidence of a TED speaker who’s just discovered metaphors, and in that precise moment—legs trembling, knees doing that cowardly knock—I think, yes, this is the correct bodily response to most things people say about the future: immediate evacuation.

Because everyone talks about AI like it’s either the messiah or a cunt with a scythe, and both camps have the same smell, that stale air of people who haven’t lifted anything heavier than a latte since the Clinton administration, and I’m there leaking fluids, very aware that no intelligence, artificial or otherwise, has yet figured out how to deal with a human body that eats street food, ages badly, and refuses to behave like a clean abstraction.

Entrepreneurship, they say, is about hunting leverage, and my bowels nod enthusiastically, hunting gravity, hunting the lowest possible point, because that’s where truth pools, not in decks or demos or those masturbatory flowcharts where arrows fuck boxes and everyone pretends electrons are vibes. You want leverage, try standing up too fast after a bad bout of diarrhea and see how quickly your brain negotiates with physics, see how suddenly blood pressure becomes the only KPI that matters.

AI as a power tool. Fine. So is a lathe. So is a drill press. So is the sharp end of hunger. Tools don’t save you; they just make your mistakes faster and louder. I’ve watched men with expensive tools and zero understanding remove fingers with great confidence. I’ve watched others with nothing but patience and a tolerance for boredom build things that actually stay built. The tool is never the hero. The asshole holding it is.

They talk about symbiosis, humans plus AI, and I’m wiping my ass thinking about actual symbiosis, the kind with bacteria doing unpaid labor in my colon, an invisible workforce that keeps me alive until it doesn’t, until one bad decision—too much oil, too much spice, one optimistic samosa—and suddenly the whole system is staging a coup. That’s embodiment. That’s skin in the game. No model hallucination compares to the very real hallucination that you might not make it back to bed without humiliating yourself further.

Everyone wants AI to understand the world, but the world is a cunt, and understanding it means dealing with dust that gets into bearings, heat that turns clever tolerances into jokes, power cuts that don’t care about your roadmap, and people—beautiful unpredictable idiots—who forget to tighten bolts or steal copper or just decide they’re done for the day because the tea ran out. Until an intelligence has had to beg a transformer to come back online while sweating through its shirt and worrying about rent, it’s still a brain in a jar with good autocomplete.

Industry 4.0, they say, and my asshole clenches at the thought of more numbers pretending to be eras. Machines talking to machines, fine, but machines don’t wipe their asses, machines don’t get hemorrhoids, machines don’t lie awake at night replaying one stupid meeting where everyone nodded and nothing happened. Machines don’t have the special Indian skill of optimism layered over dysfunction like cheap laminate. Machines don’t know the smell of overheated insulation or the sound of a bearing that’s about to ruin your month.

Code is the nervous system, minerals are the skeleton and blood, and here I am, a mineral-rich idiot leaking fluids, acutely aware that without boring ugly stuff—copper, graphite, steel, piss-resistant flooring—nothing runs. You can’t eat a slide deck. You can’t cool a data center with enthusiasm. You can’t fuck a PowerPoint no matter how hard you try, though many have tried and produced entire consulting firms as evidence.

Entrepreneurs are told not to be scared, but fear is just information with bad PR. I’m scared of slipping in my own sweat. I’m scared of promises that don’t have invoices. I’m scared of men who say “interesting” and mean “never.” That fear keeps me from believing that AI is going to float free of the physical world like some smug god. Everything real has weight. Even this shit has weight. Especially this shit.

They say AI electrifies everything, and electricity is a petty tyrant, demanding copper, demanding discipline, demanding you respect load and heat and resistance or it burns your house down. You don’t negotiate with electrons. You don’t manifest amperage. You design for it or you suffer. That’s the part everyone skips, the part between the idea and the thing, where dreams go to die or get reinforced with rebar.

Networking, persuading, getting the right humans in a room. I’ve been in those rooms. They smell like cologne and fear. Everyone hard, everyone soft, everyone pretending their dick still works the way it did when optimism was cheaper. The real heroes are outside, loading trucks, signing papers, testing samples, swearing quietly when something fails for the third time. They don’t talk about disruption. They talk about lead times and customs and why the fuck the voltage keeps sagging at noon.

Paper is cheap; freight isn’t. My stomach knows this. Ideas move fast; bodies don’t. Promises are weightless; toilets are not. There is no cloud for diarrhea. There is only gravity and regret and that moment when you realize the roll is almost empty and this is how civilizations collapse, not with a bang but with an urgent waddle.

Chase constraints, they say, and constraints chase me, right up the spine, reminding me that purity is measured, timelines slip, compliance is a motherfucker, and truth lives where things break. You want proof, look at the stains. Look at the wear. Look at the man who’s been doing the same narrow job for years, not because he’s entitled, but because someone has to keep the lights on while others play futurist with clean hands.

Be ruthless about attention. Yes. I don’t have the calories for enthusiasm-only people. I have hours for those who can move mass, sign names, and admit when something smells like bullshit. Reality rewards boring follow-through the way my gut rewards plain rice: not with joy, but with survivability.

The flush finally works. The room quiets. I stand there, weak-legged, phone buzzing with another alert about intelligence scaling, while my body feels like a prototype that passed just enough tests to ship. Outside, the world is still heavy, still mineral, still indifferent.

Later, much later, on a crowded bus, a stupid thought tries to rise—hope, maybe—and my body responds by producing a half-hearted, pointless erection, trapped in cheap underwear, pressing against nothing, a soft reminder that even desire now is assistive augmentation at best, and I spend the rest of the ride adjusting myself like a man managing a failing subsystem, praying no one notices, knowing full well they never cared in the first place.

It begins with the smell, as all truly national tragedies must—the distinct double-whammy of temple cow diarrhea layered over a drain-choked gutter of half-fermented government idli—**a nose-fisting fog of fermented piss and cumin-tinted neglect** that wraps around your ankles like a nationalist uncle trying to bless your feet with turmeric and caste anxiety, while somewhere nearby, a man named Chintu is shitting behind a broken Ambedkar statue, his turds slow-cooked by the ambient 47°C heatwave and the vague hum of a nearby LED-lit Ram Mandir playing Bluetooth bhajans off a Chinese speaker made from parts stolen from a failed Chandrayaan lander.

No matter where you stand in this slum-tier Marvel Cinematic Universe of performative piety and panopticon populism, India—my mother, my matriarchal cunt of a country—has somehow managed to get herself spitroasted by the two most prolific dicks in our cultural arsenal: god and government. A **double penetration so gory, so moist, so spiritually prolapsed**, that even the Kamasutra would’ve tapped out and asked for a safe word. Which, in our case, is "secularism," but the safeword's been co-opted by upper-caste podcast hosts with expensive mics and zero shame.

And you know what the fuck of it is? I still live here. Still queue up for ration rice next to illiterate fuckwits who think WhatsApp forwards count as evidence in court. I still watch the same mustachioed morons with seven gold rings and saffron tilaks ramble about ancient science as if Rishi Vatsayana invented the WiFi before Newton figured out gravity by huffing a mango lassi and slipping on his own ejaculate.

I know the science. I know the fucking history. I know what British opium and Brahminical revisionism and the delightful flavor of bureaucratic shit-fuckery have done to this ancient termite mound of a nation. But my knowing doesn’t stop the priests from installing CCTV in my foreskin while the Home Ministry whispers that I'm the problem.

And I was born here. In a city that once produced Satyajit Ray and now vomits out YouTube astrologers who yell at Saturn as if it's an ex-girlfriend who left them on read. I grew up under fans that squeaked like rats fucking and studied under teachers whose greatest contribution to knowledge was not dying mid-lecture. I watched as democracy got sodomized, missionary-style, by a ruling party so proud of their erection they forgot they had to actually fuck the people, not just thrust at them from a podium. And meanwhile, the Opposition sits like a flaccid dick in a cold shower, trying to form a coalition while adjusting their silk lungis and checking for erectile dysfunction in their moral compass.

And let’s talk about the god bit. Oh, the god bit.

I’m an atheist, yes, but not the sexy Richard Dawkins kind, more like the bitter, bloated, Bengali-brand of book-bred disillusionment that comes from being raised in a household that feared poverty more than purgatory. I prayed once, I think—when I was ten and had a fever of 104—and my mother rubbed mustard oil on my chest while whispering mantras and Marxist slogans in the same breath. I recovered and took that as proof of hydration, not Hanuman.

But this country? It never stopped praying. It **prayed so hard it broke its own spine bending backwards to suck off every fucking deity in a ten-mile radius.** We pray to Shiva for stock tips, to Durga for beating our wives with divine license, to Sai Baba for washing away our paan-stained karma. And in the background, the real gods—those in khaki, those with guns and garlands and goddamn WhatsApp war rooms—build empires on the backs of the desperate and the dumb.

I went to vote last year. Had to walk past three drunk men pissing into a gutter that doubled as a ballot disposal site. Inside, I marked the EVM with the grace of a prostate exam. My choice was between two cocks: one wearing a saffron condom, the other one pretending not to be circumcised by capitalism.

Did it matter? No.

The EVM might as well have spat out a used condom with a QR code that redirected me to a news anchor yelling **“Hindutva is development, development is Hindutva”** while his mouth foamed like an epileptic goat being tasered at a Bajrang Dal rally.

My neighbor’s kid, sweet kid, plays PUBG all day and thinks Chandragupta Maurya is a PUBG skin. His mom sells Ganga water in recycled mineral bottles and believes her smartphone gave her COVID. Meanwhile, I sit in my one-bedroom concrete prison built on land that was probably stolen from a Dalit family during the Emergency, eating microwave dal and wondering if my dead father was right when he said the real sin wasn’t disbelief—it was participating in a system you know is broken just to avoid being lonely.

My sin is participation.

My sin is not leaving.

My sin is still giving a fuck.

I read a physics paper last night—about entropic horizons in de Sitter space, but it might as well have been a suicide note written by a dying sun. Because entropy is real. Decay is real. Not just in the universe, but in the veins of this country. I can smell it in the sweat of metro guards, in the diesel farts of rickshaws, in the stifled moans of underpaid data entry clerks who still say “sir” to men who ejaculate Sanskrit and smell like burnt democracy.

And you know what else? I’ve stopped trying to shit in the mornings. My bowels are clogged with ideology. My colon is a battleground of suppressed rage, leftover beef, and Dolo 650 tablets crushed into resignation.

Every morning, I sit, shirtless, like a balding Vishnu, on my porcelain throne, hoping for release—not just fecal, but existential—and all I get is gas, and the faint echo of a man chanting “Jai Shri Ram” down the lane as if constipation can be cured by slogans.

It can't.

Nor can this fucked-up, rectal wart of a nation.

I love her.

I hate her.

And I can’t stop smelling her burnt hair and urine-drenched dreams.

If this was a film, it’d end with a triumphant flute solo and a drone shot over the Himalayas. But this is real. This is now. This is me trying to unclog my sink with a rubber plunger that smells like wet nationalism and failed engineering entrance exams.

The last time I got hard was during a BBC documentary about termite queens.
I came three seconds after the narrator said “pheromone symphony.”
Then I wiped myself with a handout from the Election Commission.



# File: src/lib/posts/earth-is-a-cocksucker.md

title: "Earth is a Cocksucker"

color: "orange"

<Pi src="IMG-20251029-WA0011(1).jpg" />



There’s a kind of shit you take at 4:37 AM—the squelching, meteor-fart kind that’s neither diarrhea nor constipation but a strangely moral third category, a philosophical turd of alienation and unmoored guilt—just loose enough to suggest you’ve failed, but formed enough to remind you you’re still alive, for now—and it was precisely *while* I was extruding that shameful noodle of half-digested lentils and existential despair that I read, on the cracked greasy screen of my fingerprint-rubbed Android, that some aliens (yes, the real fucking extraterrestrials, not the BJP’s IT cell or Elon Musk on ketamine) had finally, after decades of our species ejaculating radio pulses into the galactic prostate, decided to *respond*, and what did they say?

They said:  
**“EARTH IS A COCKSUCKER.”**

That's it.  
Not hello. Not "your hydrogen line signal was intriguing." Not "take us to your leader"—which, to be fair, would have been a goddamn joke anyway because our leaders are either in jail, vacationing in Geneva, or masturbating into the fossilized mouth of capitalism itself.  
No. They called us *a cocksucker*. The whole planet. One planetary insult.

I swear my shit coiled back up inside me like a threatened snail.

Imagine poor Alexander Zaitsev, Russian SETI romantic, probably dead now or sitting in some cold dacha watching the mold grow on his Nobel dreams, the poor bastard who beamed out the *Cosmic Call* back in 1999 from Evpatoria, with his soft mustache and his hope that someone would write back with diagrams, or maybe some Euclidean flattery—and instead gets a cosmic drive-by from some smug interstellar pricks who basically looked at our pale blue dot and saw a stretched-open gaping mouth begging for dick.

And the worst part?

They're not *wrong*.

Because let’s face it: if you were cruising past our solar system in your gleaming, hive-minded, ion-pissing supership, and picked up the screeching radiation burst of terrestrial culture—Shark Tank reruns, Rush Limbaugh archives, T-Series remix abominations, and some North Korean dictator waving his girthy missile while India squats on the Moon like it’s pooping—it’s not unreasonable that your alien linguists, after spending seventeen microseconds decoding the global signal of our species, would conclude:  
**“These cocksuckers need a galactic throat-punch.”**

I mean we *are* cocksuckers. Not in the fun, consensual, rainbow-flag kind of way, but in the metaphorical, metaphysical, big-picture sense—sloppy, desperate, willing to kneel for validation, drooling for GDP growth like it’s alien semen, choking on our own tech utopias, our AI-generated marketing decks, our influencer-stuffed dopamine reels, our Elon-drenched banana republic of dreams. We don’t *blow* in a sexy way—we blow in the “what do you mean I sold the rainforest to BlackRock for $40 and a selfie?” kind of way.

When I was a kid, I thought the aliens would be gentle, Spielbergian, big-eyed fungal giraffes who came bearing gifts, like crystal learning cubes or smooth colonoscopies, or perhaps some advanced nasal device that could suck out the sinus rot that has haunted me since age 9. But no, they’re just like us. Bitter. Mean. Petty. Probably bored. Probably fucked over by their own interstellar rent prices and neural data mortgages and broken marriages across five wormholes. And now we’ve become the punchline at their dinner parties.  
“Oh, did you hear Earth finally called back?”  
“Yeah. We told them to suck a cock and die.”  
“Ha! Classic.”

I went to the mirror. I stared at my own mouth.  
Was I the reason?  
Was *my* mouth the Earth they meant? Was *I* the cocksucker?

Because look, I’ve done some things.  
I’ve said “yes sir” to incompetent men. I’ve written software specs I knew were bullshit. I’ve gone on Zoom calls where I nodded and said “great idea” while privately wondering if I should fake a stroke. I once almost sucked a real cock, but chickened out because of the odd smell and the crushing weight of inherited Bengali self-loathing. But symbolically? Oh, I’ve gargled the world’s balls for years.

We all have.

Science, by the way, has always been about this. Not about truth. Not about beauty. But about slowly realizing you’re smaller and dumber and more redundant than you thought. Copernicus told us the Earth wasn’t the center, and we still haven’t gotten over it. Darwin told us we came from monkeys, and Americans still haven’t accepted it. Now these aliens—let’s call them the ***Zlorbaxxian Fuckbuds of Kepler-442b***—have told us the most painful truth of all:

We are *not* worth abducting.  
We are not even worth probing.  
We’re the cosmic fluffer. The galactic flunky. The brown-nosed, overpopulated, war-humping shitball that orbits a third-rate star and produces reality TV and carbon emissions in equal measure.

I tried to go back to sleep.  
But every sound felt judgmental.  
The AC farted. The tap dripped. The dog barked across the lane like it knew I was part of the problem. I reached for my old Nokia just to feel the heft of a time when I believed in progress. Then I looked at my own hand—hairy, mottled, veiny like a banana left too long in the fridge—and wondered if the aliens had seen that too, the hand that wipes the ass and scrolls the doomfeed and occasionally reaches for intimacy but mostly just twitches like a dying insect trying to type another futile tweet.

What did we send them, anyway?  
Arecibo message. Voyager’s golden record. A Chuck Berry song. Mathematical sequences. Puny. Polite. Optimistic.

We should’ve sent them a livestream of Calcutta traffic during peak monsoon with a guy electrocuting himself while trying to fix a hanging broadband wire that’s been tangled with pigeon feathers and ancient paan spit.

We should’ve sent them the Delhi AQI in a jar.

We should’ve sent them a WhatsApp forward from your auntie about how turmeric can cure GDP loss.

We should’ve sent them the Bengali uncle I saw last week scratching his balls with a Nokia charger, then smelling it to check for bacterial load, then lighting a cigarette from a bidi stump and complaining about “Western culture.”

Because that *is* Earth.

I tried, in the morning, to wash my shame away in a bucket bath. But the water had a smell. The soap had been eaten at the edges by ants. The towel, once white, was now the color of colonial regret. I rubbed my chest and thought about the Fermi Paradox—not "Where are they?" but "Why haven’t they nuked us already?"

So here's the situation.

Aliens called.  
They said we suck cock.

And honestly?  
I'm just relieved they didn’t send a video.

Because I know what it would show.  
Me.

Crouched in a plastic chair.  
In a crumbling bathroom.  
Holding in a piss.  
Arguing with a mosquito.  
Trying to delete spam from a dying inbox.  
Looking up at the stars like they owe me something.  
Mouth open.


# File: src/lib/posts/entropy.md

title: "Soot, Entropy, and the Cult of Maintenance"
date: "2025-12-17"
description: "A meditation on soot, the Second Law of Thermodynamics, and the struggle for maintenance in a porous world."
category: "Work"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251208-WA0005.jpg"
published: true
color: "black"
---

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251208-WA0005.jpg" 
    caption="I also wipe the Bengali book I am reading"
/>

The first thing I do some mornings—before tea, before the phone, before I allow the day to start selling me its bargains—is wipe the window ledge with an old cloth that used to be white and is now the color of resigned paperwork. I also wipe the Bengali book I am reading because it has accumulated a patina of soot even indoors, hermetically sealed. I finished the first story "chhobi" a muted Bengali romance (or maybe I misunderstood), I intend to read the next one. 

The cloth comes away black. Not “a little dusty.” Not “needs cleaning.” Black as if I’ve been petting a chimney. And this isn’t a factory district, not some Dickensian montage with earnest men carrying sacks and coughing in solidarity; it’s just a lane in the south Calcutta boondocks where life is supposed to be ordinary, which is exactly the problem, because ordinary has become a slow intake of soot as a lifestyle, a daily sacrament administered by traffic, trash fires, diesel generators that cough like tubercular gods, and the general belief that the air is a free dumping ground because *it looks empty*.

I rinse the cloth under the tap. The water runs gray, then darker, then a kind of embarrassed charcoal. I stare at it the way a person stares at a medical report they don’t quite understand but already hate, and a thought arrives—quietly, smugly, like it’s been waiting behind the curtain the whole time.

Entropy.

Not the polite entropy of textbooks that behaves itself and doesn’t mention bodily openings. The street entropy. The entropy that comes in through every gap, every crack, every unsealed lid, every moral compromise, every underfunded municipal pipe, every lazy little “eh, what can you do” that becomes a national motto. The entropy that doesn’t need malice. It only needs neglect.

I wipe again. More black.

A man can get sentimental about many things—books, music, old streets, lost people—but soot is not one of them. Soot is the universe leaving fingerprints on my home. It is the outside becoming inside. It is high entropy staging a small, daily invasion, like an occupying force that doesn’t even bother with tanks because it has discovered something more effective: permanence.

## The Second Law and the First Lie

The Second Law of Thermodynamics is one of those ideas that feels both cosmic and insultingly obvious once it clicks. Heat flows from hot to cold. Energy spreads out. Systems drift from fewer arrangements to more arrangements because there are simply more ways to be messy than to be neat. The universe doesn’t “prefer” disorder in the way a person prefers tea over coffee; it just has arithmetic on its side. Probability is a battering ram.

And the first lie—my own lie, the one my mood slips into like an old shirt—is to take this as moral news. *Everything decays, therefore everything is pointless.* That’s not physics; that’s depression doing fan-fiction with science.

Physics is colder, and in a perverse way kinder. It doesn’t say “you’re doomed.” It says: if nothing is done, drift happens. If energy is applied, order can be made locally—briefly, beautifully, expensively—at the cost of dumping entropy somewhere else. A refrigerator keeps milk cold by making the back of the fridge warm. A city keeps a gated community pristine by pushing the mess outward, sometimes literally outward, sometimes onto invisible labor, sometimes into the lungs of the poor, sometimes into groundwater, sometimes into a distant landfill where the garbage can become someone else’s problem.

I am standing at my sink washing soot out of a cloth, which is not a philosophical act, but my brain—this overeducated parasite living on my skull—insists on making it one.

Low entropy is hard to defend. High entropy doesn’t need to strategize. It just needs to seep.

The body knows this instinctively. The body has pores, openings, membranes, gates. The body’s entire existence is a siege: keep the inside *inside*, keep the outside *outside*, filter, filter, filter. And yet, day after day, air goes in, water goes in, food goes in, viruses go in, microplastics go in, noise goes in, propaganda goes in, dread goes in. Something always gets through. That’s the nature of openings. That’s the nature of being alive: a controlled leak.

I think of the crude, juvenile line my brain likes because it’s shamelessly accurate: entropy tries to invade through any orifice, oral nasal anal. And yes, it’s vulgar. It’s also honest. Because if I strip away the poetry, that’s what living is: defending a boundary with imperfect tools in a world that never stops pressing.

## Filters, Castles, and the Cult of Maintenance

The rich have solved entropy the way the rich solve everything: by hiring other people to fight it for them.

Not always directly, of course. Nobody writes “anti-entropy staff” on a payroll sheet. It’s called housekeeping, security, compliance, legal, PR, medical concierge, nutritionist, driver, IT, gardener, “facility management” (a phrase so antiseptic it could be a surgical instrument). An army of maintainers. A thousand tiny acts of order performed daily so that the castle can remain a castle.

A billionaire’s life is a low-entropy bubble wrapped in redundancy. Filtered air, backup power, multiple homes, private water, private health care, the ability to replace anything that breaks without thinking about the cost, the ability to remove risk by buying distance from it. The moat is real. It is not metaphorical. It is infrastructure plus money plus the social permission to be insulated.

My life—middle-class Bengali, fifty, bookish enough to be a nuisance, under-wealthy enough to be one bad event away from panic—does not come with that insulation. My life is porous. The lane is porous. The city is porous. India is porous in the most humiliating way: porous not to good ideas and scientific temper and civic competence (those face visa issues), but porous to scams, adulteration, theatrical ideology, and the lazy belief that rules exist mainly for other people.

Porosity is how entropy wins socially. It doesn’t always arrive as an explosion. It arrives as leakage. A small corruption. A small shortcut. A small negligence. A small lie told in a meeting. A pipe that isn’t repaired. A budget that’s diverted. A regulation that’s announced and then quietly ignored. A school that teaches rote instead of thought. A doctor who gives antibiotics like sweets because the patient wants “something strong.” A citizen who learns that complaining is futile and silence is safer.

Each leak is small. Together they are a flood.

The cloth in my hands is proof. Black water swirling down the drain, and I’m supposed to pretend it’s normal because it’s been normal for long enough.

## AI as Thermodynamic Policy

The nightmare people like to sell is cinematic: the machine wakes up, declares humans obsolete, and marches us into the sea. It’s a comforting story in a way, because it gives disaster a villain with a face.

Reality doesn’t need drama. Reality is a spreadsheet.

Capitalism doesn’t require an artificial mind to become crueler. It only needs tools that make labor cheaper, faster, more controllable. That’s the whole evolutionary pressure of the system: reduce friction, increase predictability, maximize output, minimize cost, and call it “efficiency” as if efficiency were a moral virtue rather than a technical property.

Humans are friction. Humans are noise. Humans are complications. Humans get sick. Humans get angry. Humans unionize. Humans have children. Humans have moods. Humans have inconvenient consciences. Humans show up late because the bus became a moving argument with physics. Humans ask for dignity, and dignity is not a line item that shareholders enjoy.

Machines—software machines, automated workflows, models that generate text and images and code—do not demand dignity. They demand electricity, cooling, and maintenance, which are problems money knows how to solve. A machine doesn’t need lunch breaks. A machine doesn’t develop “attitude.” A machine doesn’t say “I’m burnt out.” It simply stops when power stops, and then it resumes when power resumes, like a perfect little soldier of productivity.

So the future doesn’t need AGI. It needs enough automation to make a large class of jobs *unnecessary* from the point of view of profit. A call center that can be partially replaced. A back office that can be streamlined. A junior writer replaced by a template. A paralegal’s first draft done by a model. A teacher’s grading automated. A programmer’s boilerplate produced in seconds. A whole economy of “good enough” output where the human gets pushed to the margins—not because the machine is better in some grand, Platonic sense, but because the machine is cheaper and doesn’t complain.

This is not a robot uprising. This is entropy disguised as innovation. It’s the system finding a way to shed human complexity, which is the most entropy-producing element from the point of view of management.

The irony, of course, is that the system is *also* creating new complexity: energy demand, data centers, surveillance, algorithmic control, the concentration of power in fewer hands. But complexity at the top is tolerated if it increases control. Complexity at the bottom is punished if it increases unpredictability.

So the low-entropy castle grows higher walls. The high-entropy outside grows louder.

## 2026, the Calendar as a Doom Object

The anxious mind loves dates. Dates make chaos look schedulable, like doom with a calendar attached. I can hear my own brain doing it: *2026 is when it breaks.* As if history consults a wall calendar before it decides to misbehave.

I don’t know what will happen in 2026. Nobody does. Prophecy is mostly a side-hustle. But I can smell the ingredients that make social heat: young people whose expectations were inflated by the BPO dream, by the outsourced-middle-class fantasy that India would become a global office with air-conditioning; an education system that too often produces credentialed obedience instead of adaptable thought; a labor market that can’t absorb the sheer mass of ambition; a politics that has discovered that theatre is cheaper than governance.

For a while, you can cake the news in bhajans and patriotic jingles and the whole devotional fog that turns reality into myth. A population can be lulled with spectacle, with slogans, with the narcotic of belonging—বাংলা, দাদা, the motherland, the gods, the destiny, the civilizational mission, the promise that suffering is meaningful because it is “for something.”

But a stomach is rude. It does not respect mythology. It respects calories. Rent. Medicine. The humiliating arithmetic of survival.

When that arithmetic fails for enough people, the noise begins. Then, inevitably, the thwack thwack of force trying to reassert order, because force is the quick tool. Competence takes time. Competence is boring. Force photographs well.

And I can already feel the temptation my own mind has: to romanticize collapse as cleansing, as revolution, as justice. That temptation is a kind of mental pornography. Real collapse is mostly misery. Real revolt is mostly bodies. Real chaos is mostly people who have no ideology at all, just fear and hunger and adrenaline.

I don’t want any of that. I also don’t want the current slow suffocation to continue. These are the two terrible options my brain presents, like a sadistic waiter offering only poison or starvation.

## Complicity, Laziness, and the Inner Leak

Here is where I have to turn the knife toward myself, because it’s too easy—too delicious—to blame everything on billionaires and politicians and capitalism and machines and “the system,” as if I am a pure victim floating above history like a moral balloon.

I am not.

I have wasted years. Not in the romantic scholar way. In the stupid way. The procrastination way. The doomscrolling way. The “I’ll start tomorrow” way. The way where I bargain with my own life as if time is a renewable resource and not a one-way burn.

I have been vain. I have wanted recognition without the discipline of being consistently useful. I have wanted to be seen as intelligent without doing the boring, repetitive work that turns intelligence into value. I have wanted the world to notice me while I hid from the world.

I have been afraid. Afraid of trying. Afraid of failing. Afraid of being laughed at. Afraid of being ordinary. Afraid, oddly, of success too—because success would require responsibility, and responsibility is another kind of low-entropy structure, demanding maintenance.

And then there is the bipolar texture, which is not romantic and not a superpower and not a quirky personality trait, but a lived condition that colors everything. Some days my mind is a carnival: connections, metaphors, ideas, a sense that I could rebuild the world with a pencil and a cup of tea. Other days my mind is a drained swimming pool: nothing echoes, nothing matters, everything is heavy. In both states, I am unreliable. In both states, my perception lies in different ways.

The hypomanic brain lies by promising effortless transformation. The depressed brain lies by declaring all effort pointless.

Both are, in their own way, high-entropy invasions. They breach the boundary of intention.

And I know the little rituals I do—rewriting drafts, deleting paragraphs, rearranging sentences like furniture—are partly therapy, partly compulsion, partly a way of pretending I’m in control of *something* when the larger world feels like it’s slipping.

I can spend an hour perfecting a paragraph while ignoring the fact that my life needs structure the way a lung needs air.

That is my own leak. My own porosity. My own entropy.

## Social Entropy Is Just Physics with Feelings

I keep coming back to the same ugly clarity: societies are just systems. Systems need maintenance. Maintenance costs energy—human energy, financial energy, institutional energy. If maintenance is neglected, entropy rises. Pipes break. Trust breaks. Schools decay. Police become predators. Hospitals become lotteries. Regulation becomes theatre. News becomes incense.

The tragedy is that humans are terrible at maintenance because maintenance is boring. Maintenance doesn’t feel heroic. Maintenance doesn’t win elections. Maintenance doesn’t go viral. Maintenance is the quiet work that prevents catastrophe and therefore never gets credit because the catastrophe never happens.

So the whole system drifts. And when it drifts far enough, people start looking for stories to explain the drift, because story is how the human mind survives the terror of randomness.

Religion offers a story. Nationalism offers a story. Conspiracy offers a story. Even the techno-utopian AI crowd offers a story: *don’t worry, technology will fix it.* (Technology, historically, fixes some things while breaking others, like a drunken doctor.)

My own brain offers a story too, and it’s the one I have to fight hardest: *you are doomed because the world is doomed and you are small.* That story is seductive because it absolves me. If everything is doomed, then my failures are not failures; they are mere symptoms.

That is depression’s most elegant con: it turns resignation into wisdom.

## The Petty Acts of Resistance

So what is resistance, in a world where entropy is both physical and social and psychological, where high entropy presses in from every direction like dampness?

Sometimes resistance is embarrassingly small.

It’s wiping the window ledge again tomorrow instead of letting soot accumulate until the room feels like a cave. It’s changing a filter if I can afford it. It’s wearing a mask even when it feels ridiculous, because dignity is not always looking dignified; sometimes it’s doing the sensible thing despite the social theatre. It’s reading a few pages of a book instead of bathing in algorithmic sewage. It’s sleeping on time—ha, yes, *sleeping on time*, the most laughable instruction ever given to a bipolar brain. It’s making a list and actually doing one item on it, not because the item matters in the cosmic sense but because the act of completion is a small patch on my porosity.

It’s not hope. Hope is too grand a word. It’s maintenance. It’s the humble art of not letting everything leak at once.

The rich do maintenance with armies. I do maintenance with scraps. But scraps are still something.

I think of entropy as an invading force because it helps me stay alert, but I also know that the invader is not a villain. The invader is the default. The villain, if there is one, is the human tendency to neglect the boring work and then act surprised when the roof collapses.

And yes, capitalism loves this. High entropy outside makes the low entropy inside feel more valuable. Chaos increases the price of stability. Fear makes people accept fences. A noisy world makes the castle’s quiet more seductive. This is how inequality reproduces itself: not only through exploitation, but through the sale of protection.

## The Body, Again, Because It Never Lets Me Forget

By the time the cloth is rinsed and wrung out, my fingers smell faintly metallic. The cloth hangs from a hook to dry, drooping like a defeated flag.

I wash my hands longer than necessary. I can’t wash the air. I can’t wash the economy. I can’t wash the politics. I can’t wash the trajectory of automation that treats human beings as inefficiencies to be optimized away. I can’t wash the future. I can barely wash my mood.

But I can wash my hands. So I do it, partly out of hygiene and partly out of superstition, as if cleanliness were a form of moral persuasion.

The body keeps insisting on itself. The body is not interested in ideology. The body wants breathable air and potable water and stable glucose and sleep. The body is the ultimate anti-myth machine. The body does not care about civilizational greatness when it can’t inhale without thinking about it.

And that’s where the darkest tenderness creeps in, the one I don’t like admitting because it makes me feel soft: the fragility is shared. Not equally—nothing is equally shared in this world—but widely. Billions of bodies, each defending its boundaries, each leaking a little, each trying to keep inside inside and outside outside.

I am not special. My misery is not rare. My intelligence—whatever quantity of it I possess—is not a shield. The universe is not impressed by my reading list.

Which should be nihilistic news. And yet, perversely, it isn’t entirely. There is a strange comfort in realizing that the drama in my skull is part of a larger biological comedy: *Homo sapiens* as a whole is a leaky organism inventing castles and slogans to pretend it isn’t.

## A Quiet Gesture That Doesn’t Pretend to Solve Anything

I go back to the window and look at the ledge. It is clean for now. A small local decrease in entropy achieved with muscle and water and time, dumping the mess into the drain where it will go become someone else’s problem, which is the story of civilization in miniature.

Outside, the lane continues. A horn. A shout. A scooter. The distant crackle of someone burning something they shouldn’t. The air looks empty. The air is not empty.

I close the window—not as a solution, just as a gesture—and for a few seconds the room feels marginally quieter, marginally more mine, marginally less invaded.

Then I do something even smaller and even more pathetic, the kind of thing no ideology can claim: I put the phone face down and pick up a book, not because books will save me, not because reading is resistance in some heroic sense, but because a page is one of the few places left where the noise doesn’t automatically win, where my attention—this battered little territory—can still be defended, sentence by sentence, like sandbags against a flood.

I read. I stop. I reread a line. I savor a word. I feel, briefly, the embarrassment of being alive and still trying.

And when the mind starts to sprint toward prophecy again—2026, collapse, thwack thwack, castles, mobs, machines—I catch it the way one catches a child running toward traffic, not gently, not kindly, but firmly, and I drag it back to the page.

That’s all I’ve got: a cleaned ledge, a drying cloth, a closed window, a book open on my lap, and a stubborn refusal to let the day take every orifice without a fight.

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251207-WA0036.jpg" 
    caption="fish with bones"
/>

There is a particular kind of silence that falls over a Bengali dining table when the fish arrives, the way a courtroom quiets when the judge enters, or a railway platform pauses just before the train finally pulls in; even the ceiling fan seems to develop a conscience and stop rattling for a second, as if it too respects the ritual of *maachh* and *bhaat*.

On my childhood table the fish would appear in a metal bowl, steaming, aromatic, and sinister, like a friendly-looking visiting relative who you know is going to ask about your exam marks. The adults would lean in, eyes trained in the ancient art of deboning, their fingers moving with the unhurried efficiency of veteran surgeons; my role, as a scrawny, easily-traumatized boy, was to sit very still and attempt not to die.

Because somewhere between the third mouthful and the inevitable second helping, there would come *that* moment: a sliver of bone, translucent and treacherous, sliding past the tongue’s radar and lodging itself halfway down the throat. The next few seconds were always the same – the sudden panic, the coughing fit, the watery eyes, the thumping on the back by a relative who believed the human respiratory system could be repaired by percussion, and the chorus of reassurances: “Ektu bhaat kheye nao, chole jabe” – which is Bengali for, “Swallow some rice and we’ll see.”

You survive, of course. Children are resilient and apparently designed to be proof-of-concept prototypes for bad domestic hazard management. But something in the brain takes notes; some little cluster of neurons, doing their tedious Bayesian updates in the background, quietly raises the estimated probability that “fish with many bones” equals “imminent tracheal apocalypse,” and from then on, *that’s that*.

Fast forward some decades and I am a fifty-ish, chronically underachieving, over-educated Bengali who likes fish in principle, in theory, in cultural alignment, but prefers in practice only those varieties that present a minimal chance of turning my dinner into an impromptu Heimlich tutorial. Give me the fillets, the neat steaks, the boring, low-risk species, the piscine equivalent of those soft-spoken people who will never ask you what your salary is or make you join a WhatsApp group.

The rest – the legendary, bony, spine-with-flesh-attached types – I approach the way a traumatised soldier regards fireworks.

Of course, this is not really about fish.

# Bones as Policy

There is a smug sentence you hear growing up in Bengal: *“Maachh-bhaat-e Bangali”* – the idea that a Bengali is essentially constructed from fish and rice, like some aquatic version of *Homo sapiens* uniquely optimized for monsoon, mildew, and moralizing. As with most identity slogans, it is charming and mildly fascistic at once: a mix of nutritional fact, cultural habit, and the usual pressure to conform. Love fish, they say. Love fish *this* way, in this configuration, with these bones and these rituals and this frightening aunt who polices whether you’re eating the head respectfully.

When I say I like fish but prefer the ones with fewer bones, I can almost hear an invisible jury of ancestors tutting. To dislike bones is, in some circles, to confess a lack of character, the same way not liking football makes you suspect in other cultures. There is a puritanism to it: if you don’t endure the bones, do you really deserve the taste?

You can see the same philosophy in Indian education. If you don’t swallow the entire bony structure of the syllabus – the pointless derivations, the badly explained theorems, the moral science lectures stuck between physics chapters like fish bones in curry – you are somehow less worthy of the degree. The idea that learning could be deboned, filleted, made more digestible without losing nutrition is treated as decadent, Western, suspiciously student-friendly.

The British, of course, had a different fish in mind when they designed the whole apparatus. They wanted clerks – reliable, repetitive, grammatically house-trained – who could copy numbers and letters from one ledger to another without too many original thoughts getting stuck in the system. A clean boneless workforce, pre-processed and easy to swallow for the imperial digestive tract. The fact that we still swear by this system long after the original eater left the table is one of those postcolonial jokes that stops being funny once you realise your own life is the punchline.

# Once Pricked, Avoid Shrubbery

My relationship with bones – fish or otherwise – follows a very simple algorithm: one memorable injury, then a lifetime of exaggerated caution. I get pricked once and my brain, like a badly tuned alarm system, decides that *all shrubs are now suspect*.

I choked on fish as a child, so now I audit fish like a nervous tax inspector. I had several romantic catastrophes in my life including a failed marriage, so I now approach adult relationships like they are unexploded landmines from a war I didn’t even fight in. A minor driving mishap, and I become a pedestrian philosopher for years, walking the city like a disgruntled Socrates who failed his driving test.

From a clinical perspective, this is just trauma plus an overactive risk-averse temperament. From the inside, it feels like my amygdala has unionised and is now over-performing its job, filing objections against everything with enthusiasm. The bipolar brain adds its own special effects to this; in a hypomanic phase I will briefly forget all the bones, all the near-chokes, all the disasters and rush headlong into some new project – a big idea, an impossible website, a grand life reboot – and then, as the mood slides back into the gently suffocating porridge of depression, the memory of every previous bone returns, each one annotated in HD.

The fish bone in the throat is an almost perfect metaphor for how I internalise discomfort: something tiny, objectively manageable, becomes lodged crosswise in perception. The rest of the world is shouting, “Just swallow some rice, it’ll go away,” while my entire sensorium is screaming, “The oesophagus is cancelled, we are going to die.”

So, over the years, I have reorganised my life in favour of soft food.

Not literally – I still eat crunchy things, my jaw hasn’t retired – but emotionally, socially, professionally. I prefer routine to novelty, solitude to social adventure, books to networking events, the safe glow of a laptop to any scenario involving name tags, handshakes, or open-ended questions like “So what do you do?” I have built, around my fragile, over-indexed fear circuitry, a shanty of habits, a small predictable shelter in the boondocks of South Calcutta, where the biggest daily risk is that the neighbour’s child will start practising Bollywood dance routines at full volume during my afternoon existential crisis.

# The Hermit in the City of Ruins

“Boondocks” is a charitable way of describing where I live; it suggests a rustic charm, some greenery, maybe a goat. In reality it is more like a museum of urban neglect, a neighbourhood composed of half-finished ambitions, peeling walls, and a rotating cast of stray dogs who consider the entire lane their latrine and meeting hall.

I live in a modest flat whose chief architectural feature is that the walls don’t meet at quite the angles Euclid would have preferred. The ceiling fan makes a noise like a small helicopter fighting obesity. The view from the window is a tangle of cables, a patch of obstinate sky, and rooftops that look permanently surprised – water tanks, broken chairs, that one unfurling blue tarpaulin that has survived more monsoons than some local politicians.

Calcutta is famously always in ruins – not in the romantic, “faded grandeur” way tourism brochures try to sell, but in the more practical sense that something is always being built and never finished, repaired and never quite fixed, painted and immediately stained again by the traffic and the air. It is a city that seems to live in a permanent state of hangover from a colonial party it didn’t consent to host, mixed with a drunk, late-stage-capitalist carnival of consumption it cannot actually afford.

In this setting, my hermitage is not particularly dramatic. I’m not in a cave; I’m in a room with questionable plumbing and adequate Wi-Fi. But I have withdrawn in other ways: I rarely attend weddings (too many people asking “When are you…?” – fill in the blank with any life milestone I have failed to achieve), I avoid religious gatherings (my allergy to grandstanding and mythology is severe enough that it should be listed formally somewhere), and I treat phone calls like incoming asteroids.

I am, as I often joke, content with the contents of my own emissions – the smell of my own room, my own thoughts, my own digestive symphonies. This is not exactly aspirational, but it is honest. The world outside has too many bones; inside, at least I know where most of them are buried.

# Boneless Religions, Bony Truths

Fish bones make good philosophy props. If you look at how societies feed their citizens narratives, you notice a pattern: the real world is bony, full of sharp facts, contradictions, uncomfortable trade-offs. The myths, on the other hand – the national myths, religious myths, civilizational bragging – are tender fillets served in thick gravy.

The stories we are asked to swallow about our glorious pasts, our spiritual superiority, our economic destiny, are often boneless to the point of being gelatinous. No hard questions, no structural analysis, just soft phrases repeated until they feel like facts. “Ancient wisdom,” “world guru,” “greatest democracy,” “family values,” “Make X great again” – it is all mashed into a paste that slides down the throat without obstruction, and if some inconvenient bone of reality – poverty, inequality, bigotry, corruption – gets stuck, the preferred response is not to remove the bone but to shout at the person choking.

In this sense, my fish-bone paranoia is oddly principled. I don’t trust boneless narratives; I assume the bones have been removed for a reason. I would rather see the skeleton, even if it scares me, than swallow a story that has been mechanically separated from its own structure. Fish, unlike ideologies, don’t lie about where their bones are; you can see the ribs, trace the spine. Human institutions are less considerate.

In America, where I spent some years between 1998 and 2014, I watched this boneless narrative industry blossom into something truly industrial. The country I first encountered was already full of contradictions – malls and homelessness, NASA and creationism – but there was still a sense that facts had some residual prestige. Over time, and especially under the orange-tinted carnival that followed, truth itself was filleted, repackaged, and sold as partisan fish fingers. Whole cable channels existed to ensure that no bone of reality disturbed the swallowing of daily outrage.

Back home, India was not far behind. We imported not just technology and fast food, but also the same algorithmic extraction of attention, the same weaponization of grievance, the same hunger for stories that flatter and absolve. Now we, too, are surrounded by boneless narratives about ourselves, some ancient, some new, many mutually contradictory, all demanding unwavering faith. To doubt them is to be labelled anti-national, anti-cultural, anti-whatever-the-current-keyword-is. In that climate, a person like me – sceptical, atheist, left-leaning, emotionally unstable – learns very quickly that it is safer to retreat to his room and negotiate with fish rather than with flags.

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251208-WA0001.jpg" 
    caption="mermaid with bones"
/>

# Biology of Avoidance

Psychology textbooks will tell you about conditioning, about learned avoidance, about how even a lab rat, after a few electric shocks, will choose to cower in the corner rather than explore. Human brains are fancier, more verbose, but not fundamentally different. I am essentially a talking rat who remembers too many shocks.

The first bone in the throat is a data point. The second one becomes a pattern. By the fifth, your nervous system has developed a policy: *If X, then panic*. In bipolar depression, the weighting of negative data is even more aggressive; every small failure is upgraded to an indictment of the entire self. “You cannot handle fish with bones” morphs seamlessly into “you cannot handle life,” which your overeducated prefrontal cortex immediately rewrites into something more eloquent and equally unhelpful, like “you are temperamentally unsuited to existence.”

So I construct a life of minimal X.

Minimal travel – complicated, expensive, full of risks, airports, strangers, lost luggage, and conversations with taxi drivers who ask “Business or pleasure?” as if there were any third category where I might fit.

Minimal romance – delightful, intoxicating, potentially catastrophic, full of bones disguised as dimples, and I have already proven remarkably unskilled at the deboning process.

Minimal ambition – everyone these days wants to be a founder, an influencer, an “AI entrepreneur”; I am content being a footnote, an ancestor of the machines, the human training data that never cashed out. Ambition, too, has bones: competition, humiliation, compromise, the need to talk to investors pretending to understand your idea while plotting your replacement.

My avoidance is not noble. It is not wise resignation. It is simply the equilibrium point of a nervous system that got pricked and decided shrubs were overrated. But unlike many people who lip-sync hustle culture while secretly exhausted, I at least admit out loud that what I really want, most days, is a cup of tea, a functioning fan, a decent book, and a plate of boneless fish that cannot surprise me.

# Overeducated, Underseasoned

There is a special category of failure that comes from being overeducated and under-pragmatic. I have accumulated degrees, skills, and information the way some people collect stamps or scented candles – as if knowing more would automatically translate into living better. It does not. It simply gives you more vocabulary to describe your stagnation.

I know, for example, the approximate structure of a neuron, the fuzzy outlines of Bayesian inference, the etymology of “hermit” from Greek *erēmitēs*, meaning “of the desert.” I understand, at least in outline, how capitalism creates both smartphones and slums, how colonialism baked inferiority and aspiration into our middle-class DNA, how social media algorithms amplify the worst of our impulses. None of this knowledge has stopped me from becoming a reclusive middle-aged man in a noisy lane, occasionally arguing with a lizard on the wall about who pays rent.

The fish on my plate is sometimes the most concrete decision I make in a week. Bony or boneless? Risk or safety? Nostalgia or practicality? Do I honour my identity as a Bengali by wrestling with an *ilish* full of treacherous architecture, or do I quietly choose the bland, well-behaved fillet imported from some overfished river god-knows-where?

Most days, I choose the safer option. Some days, usually when the hypomanic current is whispering, “life is short, cholesterol is a social construct,” I will order the dangerous one. The first bite is glorious – the taste, the memory of childhood, the illusion of being part of a larger story – but by the third bone my throat has staged a coup, and I am back to square one, negotiating with my internal alarm system like a hostage-taker who forgot his demands.

# Smallness as Strategy

It is fashionable now to talk about “living your best life,” a phrase that makes me want to lie down on the floor and evolve into a different species. My life is not “best” by any widely advertised metric – not financially, not professionally, not romantically, not geographically. It is best only in the very narrow sense that it is currently the only one I have managed not to abandon.

I live small, because big life requires big bones, and my throat is thin.

Some people climb mountains; I clean my desk. Some start companies; I figure out a slightly better way to arrange the books I own and will probably never fully read. Some travel the world; I make a cup of tea and stare at the patch of sky framed by cables, watching the clouds drift like absent-minded whales.

There is, buried in this smallness, an element of quiet rebellion. The world, especially the version of it wired into smartphones, demands constant expansion – more content, more followers, more hustle, more output, more visibility. To withdraw, to choose privacy, to be content with one’s own digestive byproducts and second-hand books, is not just cowardice; it is also, in a minor, ridiculous way, a refusal. I am not providing my life as entertainment content. I am not giving the algorithm my bones.

Of course, this is the heroic interpretation. The less flattering one is that I am just scared, lazy, and melancholic, and I prefer to spin that as “minimalist philosophy” instead of “unresolved therapy homework.” Both can be true. In my more lucid, depressive phases, I can hold this duality without flinching: I am both victim and accomplice, both products of history and manufacturer of excuses.

# Ending, Or Something Like It

There is a single fish bone on the edge of my plate as I type this in my head – not literally, the laptop would protest – but imaginatively, there it sits, small, glistening, curved, a tiny sculpture of all the times I have let discomfort dictate architecture.

I could throw it away, let the maid sweep it into the city’s digestive system, where it will join plastic wrappers, pan stains, and the general evidence of our civilisation’s inability to tidy up after itself. Or I could keep it, in some little box, as a relic, a reminder of all the spines I have avoided – career, love, risk, confrontation – in the name of not wanting to choke again.

I will do neither. I will do what I usually do: push the plate away, pour myself another cup of tea, open a book I have already read twice, and tilt my chair towards the reluctant breeze from the window. Outside, somewhere in the lane, a hawker will shout about fresh fish, promising taste and tradition and today’s price.

Inside, I will sit with my boneless lunch and my bony thoughts, in a city half-collapsed and half-refusing-to-die, and try not to swallow anything I’m not prepared to live with for years.
