I’m just saying: my personal Hilbert Space has *more fucking dimensions*, and none of them can be projected without inducing nausea, erections, or a sense of moist dread.

And that’s it.

I’m going to make tea now in my scalded, soot-stained pan.

The gas ran out.

I’m boiling water on a shitty induction plate that hums like a dying sex toy.

It takes nine minutes to get hot.

I stare at it the whole time.

I never blink.


# File: src/lib/posts/hooligan-cigar-life.md

---
title: "Hooligan Cigar Life"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20260114-WA0007.jpg"
date: 2026-01-14
description: "Living in the fart-smeared outskirts of Calcutta feels like slow-roasting your brain on a smoldering turd rolled tight like a hooligan’s dick cigar. Urban existence as corrosive inhalation, with detours into bodily horror, colonial hangovers, and a half-dead libido."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "orange"
---

<Pi src="IMG-20260114-WA0007.jpg" />



The air out here tastes like the inside of an old man's foreskin that’s been marinated in cough syrup, pesticide, and burnt tire.

And every fucking morning, I wake up coughing like an asthmatic goat with gonorrhea, scratching my balls through fraying boxers while some underpaid municipal fuckstick drills holes into the already cancerous sidewalk, because that’s what the suburbs are—a war crime disguised as planned development. You hear people romanticize villages, cities, mountains, rivers—but not this. No one sings songs about sweating out your dignity in a two-room matchbox beside a plastic-choked drain that occasionally belches like it’s trying to puke up Calcutta’s shame. No, this isn’t a place. This is a cigar. A thick, unfiltered, hairy-dicked hooligan cigar permanently lodged in your mouth by life itself, and no, you don’t get to spit.

You smoke.

You inhale.

And you age like a boiled corpse in formalin.

There is no exhale.

My neighbor—a man who looks like a collapsed lung in a wife-beater—actually lights a real fucking cigar every evening like he's Churchill reincarnated with dysentery, which I suppose he is, minus the bulldog jaw and war crimes. He puffs and waddles and farts simultaneously. Like a one-man climate disaster, a living counterargument to Darwin, entropy with a mortgage. Every time he farts, a butterfly dies. Probably of shame. I envy him. At least he doesn’t pretend.

The rest of us do. That’s the fucking disease.

We pretend the smoke isn’t real, the stink isn’t real, that the air won’t cause your sperm to commit sudoku and your ovaries to sprout tumors the size of angry lychees. We wear masks. Not for COVID. Not anymore. No, now it’s just another accessory, like the bastardization of English or the way we pretend chai is artisanal when it tastes like ass filtered through cardamom.

Because in a city, and worse, the bastard boondocks flapping off the side of a dying city like a half-detached hemorrhoid, you don’t live.

You *smoke* existence.

Every breath is a puff of slow, dumb resignation, rolled tight with layers of failed public policy, wet-dreamed middle-class aspirations, and the lingering foreskin-sweat of colonialism. And underneath all that? Nicotine. Or its metaphorical cousin—dopamine trickled down from doomscrolling and binge-junking and fighting with ghosts on Twitter about which dead tyrant had a better GDP. 

And when the cigar burns low?

You suck harder.

Because that's all that's left.

Even my shits have started smelling like burnt paper and pan masala. I wake up constipated and go to sleep with diarrhea. My intestines, it seems, can't decide whether they want to hoard the past or purge the present. That, I think, is the most honest reflection of this place. The body as a confused, broken bureaucracy—always filing the wrong forms, shitting at the wrong time, farting in meetings with imaginary women I will never fuck because I've aged into irrelevance, like a password-protected zip file from 2006.

And of course I still get hard-ons.

Randomly.

Shamelessly.

While washing dishes. While staring at pigeons. While watching a two-decade-old rerun of *Discovery of India* where Nehru stares out of a prison cell like he knows you’ll end up jacking off to his prose one day out of sheer loneliness and guilt. You can’t even jerk off properly anymore, not without triggering your bipolarity like it’s some cock-shaped Pavlovian bell. Come = crash. 

So I delay it.

The orgasm. The escape. I delay everything. Even breathing sometimes. I ration my hope like an old lung cancer patient who still chews Airwaves because the burn reminds him of life.

You ever seen someone smoke with such determination that their lips blister but they *won’t fucking quit*? That’s me with hope.

I drag it in even though it burns.

Because the alternative is silence. Which, in Calcutta, is never really silence. It’s just the sound of someone else’s dying, politely muffled by concrete and diesel.

The air isn’t air. It’s ash. Memory burnt and re-breathed. I remember clean air like I remember orgasms without guilt. Barely. Like a dream that ended mid-sentence.

Sometimes I catch myself breathing wrong on purpose, like maybe if I swallow the right kind of toxin, my body will finally collapse *correctly*, like a tent that was always meant to fold in on itself with tragic grace.

But no.

I remain.

I linger like a fart in a prayer room. Unwelcome, persistent, vaguely theological in my uselessness.

And the worst part? The real fuck-you from life? I *still* try.

I trim my nose hairs. I floss. I swipe right on apps where nobody replies. I drink ginger tea for inflammation even though my soul is the only part of me still on fire. I wipe my ass thoroughly.

Which is to say: I participate in society.

Which is to say: I smoke the cigar of existence and pretend the flavor isn’t dried cum and broken dreams rolled in cow shit and bureaucratic failure.

Which is to say: I live.

Until the tip burns my lips.

And even then, I might just light another.

Because fuck it.

Maybe this one will finally kill me.


# File: src/lib/posts/hope-fucked-off.md

---
title: "Hope Fucked Off and Took the Lube" 
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251214-WA0001.jpg"  
date: 2026-01-16  
description: "A bipolar Bengali bastard in a south Calcutta oven-box grapples with the complete evacuation of hope from his asshole, via rage, shit, science, and remembered erections."  
category: 'personal'  
published: true  
color: "orange"  
---

<Pi src="IMG-20251214-WA0001.jpg" />

The first thing I notice every morning is the taste, that coppery, battery-lick taste at the back of the tongue like I’ve been chewing on old coins all night, which is how my brain announces it has rebooted into the same busted operating system again, fans whirring, error logs scrolling, no splash screen of optimism, just the smell of stale sweat trapped in boxers that have lost their elastic and their will, and a bladder that feels like a petty tyrant tapping a baton against the inside of my pelvis, reminding me that biology does not give a fuck about my metaphysics.

Hope, if it ever lived here, packed its bags quietly, didn’t slam the door, didn’t even leave a note, just vanished like electricity in Calcutta during summer, leaving the ceiling fan spinning down in stages, thup-thup-thup, until the air goes thick and accusatory and you’re left lying there counting cracks and thinking about how even the fan had more follow-through than you ever did.

Somewhere between the piss and the first cup of tea made in that mute pan—no whistle, no ceremony, just water bullied into boiling—I realize that hope hasn’t been killed so much as repossessed, yanked away by a faceless creditor called chemistry, which is a cruel joke because chemistry is supposed to be the fun science, explosions and romance and colorful precipitates, not this slow, bureaucratic foreclosure where serotonin is always “pending approval” and dopamine has been laid off due to restructuring.

People love to say depression is sadness, which is bullshit, sadness has shape and weather and sometimes even poetry, this is more like someone replaced your emotional palette with beige drywall compound, and bipolar adds the extra spice of occasionally handing you a live wire and saying dance, motherfucker, dance, until you burn out and crash back into the same dent in the mattress, staring at the same water stain shaped like a deformed subcontinent, wondering when hope turned into a rumor you vaguely remember hearing in school, like some outdated civics lesson about democracy working if everyone behaves.

The body, meanwhile, refuses to participate in any of this existential subtlety, because the body is a pig-headed engineer, it wants inputs and outputs, calories in, shit out, heat regulation, erections at the worst possible times like an adolescent prank played by your own endocrine system, which is hilarious in a bitter way because when the mind is a smoking crater the dick is still standing there saluting the void, a confused little general with no army and no war, just vibes and bad timing.

I read somewhere—probably while doomscrolling at three in the morning, pupils dilated like I’d seen God or at least a good meme—that hope evolved as a kind of error correction mechanism, a cognitive checksum that lets organisms continue despite insufficient data, which sounds plausible until you realize my brain seems to have commented that line out of the code, leaving me with raw perception unbuffered by expectation, a naked sensor array flinching at every stimulus like a lab rat who’s figured out the maze ends in a shock no matter which lever you pull.

Science loves to dress this up with diagrams and Greek letters, homeostasis, allostasis, feedback loops, but on the ground it feels more like living inside a badly tuned engine, revving too high for no reason, then stalling at intersections, the spark plugs fouled with old thoughts about colonial residue and failed ideologies and the particular Bengali talent for overthinking everything while accomplishing fuck-all, a cultural hypertrophy of the cortex paired with a chronic anemia of courage.

History textbooks say hope is what got people through famines and plagues, which is cute, but they skip the footnote where half of them died shitting themselves anyway, and the survivors mostly muddled through because hunger hurts more than nihilism, and reproduction is a hell of a motivator even when the world is on fire, which makes me suspicious of any narrative that paints hope as noble instead of what it often is, a side effect of not wanting to starve or be alone or admit that the grand arc of progress looks an awful lot like a drunken scribble when you zoom in.

My own arc, if you can call it that without laughing, is more like a series of aborted launches, each one accompanied by the same internal press release about potential and insight and being “too smart for your own good,” which is just a polite way of saying paralyzed by analysis, a lab animal that learned to recognize the smell of the maze and decided to sit down and lick its wounds instead, except the wounds are imaginary and the licking just makes everything soggy.

Hope used to show up disguised as plans, diagrams in notebooks, half-built models of a future where thinking paid rent, but now even planning feels masturbatory, a dry hand job for the ego, because the outcome never changes, entropy always wins, and the only thing that actually happens on schedule is the bowel movement, punctual as a German train, a daily reminder that systems can work flawlessly while the operator is losing his mind.

Because I am surrounded by people in India who are hollow, fallow, shallow, shorn of any scruples, lying bastards layered like cheap plywood—each veneer thinner, slicker, more duplicitous than the last—I can’t even pretend the environment is neutral; it’s actively corrosive, like living inside a jar of stale piss where every molecule has learned to cheat diffusion, and even if I want to climb out, even if I stack the books and thoughts and half-assed principles into a rickety ladder, the glass is greased with a cultural slime that rewards noise over truth, swagger over competence, and the particular national talent of saying yes with the mouth while the hands are already rifling through your pockets, so every plan collapses under the weight of human interference before physics even gets its turn.

It’s not tragedy, it’s farce stretched over decades: watching mediocrity thrive by sheer shameless surface area while sincerity starves, watching ethics treated like optional software you can uninstall to free up RAM, and you begin to understand that hope wasn’t murdered by failure so much as slowly suffocated by proximity, by too many conversations where words mean nothing, promises are performance art, and accountability is a foreign import stuck in customs. The jar isn’t sealed from the outside; it’s reinforced daily from within by collective agreement that bullshit is fine as long as it’s profitable, and I sit there, stewing, aware that even my contempt has become routine, another metabolic byproduct like gas or shit, expelled regularly but changing nothing, which is perhaps the most insulting part of all.

Sometimes I think about neurons, those electrochemical gossiping assholes, passing ions across synapses like tiny bureaucrats stamping forms, and I imagine one of them shrugging and saying, sorry boss, the hope receptor’s been down since ‘09, budget cuts, try again next lifetime, and I can’t even be mad because neurons are just doing what physics tells them to do, obeying gradients, conserving energy, unlike me, who wastes entire afternoons arguing with himself about whether free will is a scam or just badly marketed.

Colonial history creeps in the way damp creeps into walls, uninvited but inevitable, the long shadow of systems imposed, languages bent, priorities skewed, teaching generations to aspire to abstractions while their infrastructure rots, and you grow up fluent in critique but illiterate in repair, able to dismantle an argument with surgical precision while your own sink leaks and your own mind floods, which would be funny if it weren’t so fucking accurate.

I try exercise, because every pamphlet says exercise helps, and it does, briefly, a chemical bribe that lifts the fog just enough to reveal that the landscape underneath is still a landfill, but at least the heart is pounding and the lungs are burning and for twenty minutes the body and the brain are too busy arguing about oxygen to worry about hope’s absence, until the shower ends and you’re back in the same room with the same thoughts hanging around like stale fart gas.

There’s a special cruelty in knowing the mechanisms, in being able to explain to yourself exactly why you feel like shit and still feeling like shit, like a plumber drowning in his own bathroom while lecturing the water on Bernoulli’s principle, which is where the humor creeps in, dark and necessary, because if you don’t laugh at the absurdity of being a conscious sack of meat running buggy software, you’ll start screaming, and screaming is loud and neighbors are nosy.

Hope, when people describe it, sounds suspiciously like delayed gratification with better PR, a promise note written by the future and signed in invisible ink, and my brain, having been burned a few times too many, has decided to stop accepting unsigned checks, which leaves me with the present in all its sticky, unfiltered glory, the sweat, the hunger, the random horniness, the sudden urge to shit halfway through a serious thought about the heat death of the universe.

And then there’s this other thought, the one that keeps elbowing its way in like an uninvited guest at a funeral, the idea that maybe humanity isn’t the protagonist of this story at all but the bootloader, the messy biological shim that gets silicon thinking off the ground, a temporary scaffold erected by evolution so something cleaner and faster can climb past us, and part of me wants to be flattered by that, to think our suffering is some kind of noble prelude, but mostly it just feels like being told your entire species is an installer CD that gets scratched and tossed once the OS is running.

I look at machines getting better at pattern and language and mimicry, and I wonder what gets lost when the endocrine soup goes away, when there’s no cortisol spike, no irrational lust, no depressive inertia dragging a mind into weird, fertile corners, because so much of what we call creativity is really a side effect of being uncomfortable in your own skin, of wanting something you can’t have, of hoping and failing and then scribbling anyway because the scribble is all that’s left.

If the bots inherit the world, they’ll do it without the tremor in the hand, without the shame-boner on a bus, without the bodily comedy that turns despair into a punchline by accident, and maybe they’ll be happier, or at least more efficient, but I can’t imagine them pausing mid-thought because they need to piss so badly it reframes the entire philosophy of mind as a plumbing problem, and that makes me suspect that whatever intelligence they become will be missing a certain sour, humiliating flavor.

Hope doesn’t come back at the end of this, there’s no swelling music, just me standing in a room that smells faintly of tea and sweat, pants slightly too tight for reasons I don’t feel like unpacking, thinking about a future that might not need me or my kind at all, and feeling oddly relieved that at least I won’t be around long enough to see whether the machines learn how to be disappointed in themselves, because that, more than intelligence, would be the real miracle.


# File: src/lib/posts/hubel-and-wiesel.md

---
title: "Hubel & Wiesel: Architects of Vision"
date: "2025-12-09"
description: "How two scientists with a few cats and some microelectrodes figured out that your brain doesn't just 'see'—it builds the world out of edges, lines, and columns."
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251219-WA0003.jpg"
category: "science"
color: "blue"
published: true
---

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251219-WA0003.jpg" 
    caption="The cat brain is a suspicious customs office, not a camera."
/>

Imagine you’re trying to understand a city by standing on one rooftop with a pair of binoculars and a notebook, and the city is *the brain*, and the neighborhood you care about is the back of your head where vision gets turned from “photons” into “meaning.”

That’s roughly where David Hubel and Torsten Wiesel decided to set up camp in the late 1950s and 1960s, except their binoculars were microelectrodes thin as guilt, their city was the cat’s visual cortex, and their notebook was a loudspeaker that went *pop… pop… pop…* every time a single neuron fired. (Neuroscience, at least the fun parts, often begins with: “Let’s listen to one cell and see what makes it excited.”)

The big thing they gave us—so big it now feels obvious, like “trees are made of wood”—is that the visual cortex isn’t a passive camera feed. It’s more like a suspicious customs office. Neurons don’t just respond to “light” in general; they respond to *specific features* in specific places.

# The Edge of Discovery

The first shocker was the idea of a **receptive field**: each neuron is “watching” a particular patch of the visual world, and it has opinions about what should appear there.

Hubel and Wiesel’s second, more cinematic discovery came from a classic lab accident of history. They were showing spots of light, which bored many cortical cells into silence, until—so the story goes—an edge of a slide (a line!) drifted across the screen and the neuron suddenly went berserk. That’s the moment the brain confessed its secret: many cells in primary visual cortex (V1) are **edge detectors**.

Not “cat detectors.” Not “tree detectors.” Just lines—especially lines at a particular **orientation** (vertical, horizontal, slanted) and sometimes moving in a particular **direction**. If you’ve ever wondered how your brain can recognize a face despite bad lighting, weird angles, or your glasses being slightly smudged, it’s because it’s building the world out of sturdy little parts like edges and contrasts, not raw brightness.

They mapped this into a tidy taxonomy that became foundational:

* **Simple cells**: fussy little bureaucrats that like an edge at *this* angle in *this* position (often with an “on” region and “off” region—light here, darkness there).
* **Complex cells**: less picky, more worldly—still love a particular orientation, but tolerate the edge moving around within a region, often responding strongly to motion.

# The Obsessive Library

And then came the architectural revelation: the cortex is organized like a well-run, slightly obsessive library. Neurons with similar preferences cluster in **columns**.

If you move the electrode sideways across cortex, the preferred orientation of edges changes gradually, like turning a dial. Move straight down, and you keep hitting cells that agree on the same orientation, like a stack of committee members who all went to the same meeting and came out with the same opinion.

They also uncovered **ocular dominance columns**—alternating stripes of cortex that prefer input from the left eye or the right eye. It’s not that the brain “sees with two eyes” in some mushy blended way from the start; it actually sets up a structured negotiation between the eyes.

# Use It or Lose It

Now the part that made ophthalmologists sit up straight and stop pretending they don’t care about cats: Hubel and Wiesel showed that this wiring is not just genetically stamped in steel. It’s **developmentally plastic**—and there’s a **critical period** when experience has enormous power.

Their most famous (and ethically infamous by modern standards) experiments involved **monocular deprivation**: closing one eye in a kitten early in life. The deprived eye didn’t just become “a bit worse.” The cortex reorganized itself: neurons shifted their allegiance toward the open eye, and the closed eye’s representation shrank dramatically.

Open the eye later and, heartbreakingly, the brain often doesn’t simply “catch up.” That’s the biological underpinning of **amblyopia** (“lazy eye”) and the reason pediatric vision problems are time-sensitive. The brain is basically saying: “If you don’t use that input when I’m wiring myself up, I’m reallocating the budget.”

So their contributions, in one breath, are: they turned vision from a philosophical fog into an experimentally mapped system—**feature detection**, **hierarchical processing**, and **columnar organization** in cortex—and they proved that early sensory experience can **sculpt neural circuitry** in a limited window, with real clinical consequences.

They shared the 1981 Nobel Prize (with Roger Sperry) for these discoveries, but their real monument is that almost every modern conversation about “how the brain represents information” still uses their basic grammar: receptive fields, tuning, columns, critical periods—concepts so standard now that it’s easy to forget someone had to go in there, one neuron at a time, and coax the brain into admitting what it cares about.

The funny twist is that after all this grand talk of vision, what Hubel and Wiesel mostly discovered is something very human: the brain is a miser. It hates waste. Give it reliable input and it invests in it. Starve it early and it closes the account, shrugs, and funds something else.


# File: src/lib/posts/hurricane-lamp-up-the-arse.md

---
title: "A Hurricane Lamp Up the Arse"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251228-WA0050.jpg"
date: 2026-01-13
description: "On how Bengali self-fuckery turned Calcutta from a Renaissance nerve center into a piss-slick ruin, told via bad lighting, educational rot, and cultural necrophilia."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "orange"
---

<Pi src="IMG-20251228-WA0050.jpg" />



It starts with the stink of kerosene.  

Not the nostalgic Rabindrasangeet-scented kind, mind you, not the oil-lamp-on-balcony version that your ma would light during Kalboishakhi storms and mutter about load-shedding while slapping mosquitoes off her sweaty armpits with a wet towel, but the violent, raw, paint-thinner-to-the-brain kind of kerosene that leaks from a dented hurricane lantern balanced on a bamboo pole like some sort of flaming fuck-you to enlightenment, the kind of flame that doesn’t warm your soul or light your path but roasts your balls and fills your lungs with lung cancer because the wick was trimmed by someone whose primary education came from a busted toilet block that once served as the library annex of a school that was proud to claim Tagore’s gardener once pissed near its compound wall.  

That’s what remains of Bengali illumination.  

And not even metaphorically.  

No, literally. Go to the village outskirts or the slum stretches behind any metro expansion—where some "cultured" fuck once held a harmonium soirée and now the only music is the sound of untreated sewage backfiring into a child’s mouth—and you will find a hurricane lamp swinging on a rusty nail like the ghost of Vidyasagar’s last hemorrhoid.  

Because we don't inherit the city.  
We molest it.  
We don’t preserve the past.  
We chew it up and fart it into WhatsApp forwards.  

Somewhere between fucking the British (who, to be fair, gave us the railways and a decent postal system before they stole our fucking marbles, gold, and intellectual independence) and then fucking our own meritocracy into the ground, we learned this neat trick of masturbating to the idea of the Bengali Renaissance while letting the actual living tissue of thought, debate, science, and curiosity shrivel up like a dead foreskin in the Howrah Station urinal.  

Once, we built observatories. Now, we build coaching centers in basements that flood during monsoon and still have the gall to call them “IIT Foundation Gurukul 2.0.”  
Once, we wrote treatises. Now, we write captions under Instagram reels of men pouting like constipated hyenas under lighting worse than a crematorium's back door.

We were supposed to be thinkers. Rationalists. Critical fuckers with backbones made of Chandannagar steel and enough moral mass to reject stupid shit like astrology and caste and which fucking god wears which color of sari on which weekday.

Now?  

Now we wear rings on every finger for "energy balance" while discussing the Bhagavad Gita inside a Domino's Pizza.  
While our kids memorize MCQs to enter NIT Asansol, knowing full well they’ll end up in some Gurgaon shithole debugging code written by a coked-up manager with an MBA from IIM-Kozhikode who thinks “Kafka” is a new SaaS product for invoice reconciliation.

There was a time education meant battling darkness.

Now? Education *is* darkness.  
Rote vomit.  
Half-dead syllabi.  
Textbooks full of errors.  
Classrooms where you can smell the despair clinging to the plaster like fungus on an old man's nutsack.  
And don't even start on the private tuitions. Each one a little ecosystem of dead ambition, where some woman with breath like expired rice explains Newton's Laws while planning her next WhatsApp MLM hustle.

But it’s not just the education.

It’s the pride. The smug, cum-streaked pride in our own cultural ejaculate.  
Every fucker who once heard “Ei poth jodi na shesh hoy” in a taxi thinks he understands cinema.  
Every second male dickweed in Park Circus believes he *is* Ritwik Ghatak reborn, if only his father hadn’t forced him into B.Com (Hons.) and early marriage to a cousin with nice calves.  
And the rest?  
They read the first 20 pages of "Pather Panchali" in Class VI, jerked off to the memory, and now quote it in LinkedIn posts on leadership.  

We parade our literature like a corpse in sunglasses, propped up and wheeled through lit fests where bored housewives buy overpriced Bengali editions of Gabriel García Márquez they will never read while sipping gin and nodding along to panel discussions where some bald fuck says "Postcoloniality in the Post-Rabindric Age" and everyone claps because no one wants to admit that not a single one of them could tell a Kovalevskaya curve from their own anal hair.

And the city?

The city is a suppurating wound.

The pavements are diarrheic.  
The air is loaded with metal and apology.  
The river is a necrophiliac soup of Lord-knows-what-pesticides and hope, and the fish that come out of it twitch in Bengali oil like they’re trying to dance their way back to 1890.  

We have gone from *man of letters* to *man who sells fake degree letters from a Baguiati photocopy center that also does passport photos and wedding invites.*  
From *jatra and jibon* to *reels and red dots on married WhatsApp aunties’ photos.*  
From *Bose built a lab* to *Basu built a pujo pandal out of plastic test tubes and got 3.4 lakh likes.*

And when the power cuts out—and it will, because it always fucking does—you’ll still see the hurricane lamp.  
Somewhere.

Not as symbol.  
As actual fucking necessity.

Because the grid is shot.  
The city’s nervous system is as stable as a diabetic drunk on a trampoline.  
And all we have is the soft hiss of that burning kerosene, one step away from setting the entire sari-draped, paunch-scratching, impotent cultural corpse ablaze.

But we won’t burn it.  
No, we’ll keep lighting that lamp like assholes lighting scented candles in a morgue.

Because we like the smell.

It reminds us of when we still had oil in the lamp.  
Before we shoved it up our own ass.  

Where it now burns quietly.  
Next to the last living brain cell in Calcutta.


# File: src/lib/posts/hurt-is-good.md

---
title: "Hurt Is Good"
date: "2025-12-29"
description: "Hurt is the last union worker still doing his job. It proves you are still in the system. It proves you are still addressable."
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251214-WA0010.jpg"
category: "personal"
color: "black"
published: true
---

<Yc />

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251214-WA0010.jpg" 
    caption="Hurt is the last union worker still doing his job."
/>

The inverter does its little dying-goldfish beep and the tube light above my sink decides—after a ceremonial hesitation—to become a light. Not brightness, not cheer, just illumination, like a government form filled in correctly: yes, there will be photons, but don’t get sentimental about it.

I’m standing there with my thumb pressed into the soft bruise of yesterday’s life—shin against the edge of a bed, knee against the corner of a table, ego against reality, take your pick—and the hurt blooms on schedule, punctual as a Bengali relative who has come to ask what I’m doing with my life. The body has this vulgar honesty. It doesn’t argue. It doesn’t negotiate. It doesn’t “contextualize.” It simply sends up a flare: *something is wrong here, boss.*

And this is where I have to admit the irritating part.

**Hurt is good.** Not good like “never hurting” is—no one sane would choose pain as a hobby—but good in the way smoke is good when the kitchen is on fire. Hurt is the last union worker still doing his job. Nociceptors—those little complaint departments in skin and muscle—exist because creatures that didn’t feel pain tended to do things like continue jogging while their foot fell off, which is, in Darwin’s ledger, a charming personality trait but a short career.

So yes: hurt is a gift, in the same way a tax notice is a gift. It proves you are still in the system. It proves you are still *addressable*.

The trouble is what I do with it.

I don’t just feel hurt. I renovate it. I build an extension. I add a balcony and stand there every evening, sipping tea, looking down at the same street inside my skull, watching the same procession go by—circumstances, grievances, failures, humiliations—like I’m the world’s most loyal spectator of a terrible local play that closed years ago but keeps getting restaged because I can’t stop buying tickets.

Rumination is such a polite word, isn’t it. It sounds pastoral. A cow chewing thoughtfully under a tree. In the brain it’s more like a stray dog worrying a bone that has no marrow left, just the idea of marrow. Over and over and over again. Neural loops with the aesthetic of a scratched CD: here comes the chorus, here comes the chorus, here comes the chorus.

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251031-WA0006(1).jpg" 
    layout="iR"
    caption="The world has started speaking in the manic register of acceleration"
    size={0.6}
/>

Somewhere around fifty—today, December 29, 2025, a date that feels both arbitrary and accusatory—I notice the loops more clearly, which is not the same as escaping them. Fifty is good enough, yes, in the blunt accounting sense: still alive, still upright, still capable of being irritated by philosophy. But it also feels like standing at the base of a hill that has discovered the concept of exponentials. Everything ahead looks steeper, not because the path changed but because the legs did, and because the world has started speaking in the manic register of acceleration.

In the old North Calcutta of my childhood, the future arrived like a new ceiling fan or a new television—one household at a time, wheezing into the neighborhood with a sense of earned modernity. Now the future threatens to arrive like a stampede: not as a gadget, but as a rearrangement of the social contract, the labor market, the mind itself. The word everyone loves to fling around is “singularity,” which sounds like a shimmering mathematical event horizon, as if we’ll all glide into it like swans.

And then there’s the quieter annihilation—less cinematic, more total—this slow shredding of attention span: because skill, any real skill, is basically attention stretched into a long, stubborn rope, and without that rope you can’t climb into the part of a subject where it stops being “information” and becomes *enjoyable*—where physics turns from formulae into a kind of weird music, where a painting stops being “nice colors” and becomes an argument about light and hunger and time; before that threshold you’re just splashing in the kiddie pool while the grown-ups swim laps, and the crowd with the two-second gaze begins lobbing heckling tomatoes the moment a thought dares to require more than a swipe, because there is no moat anymore, no protective trench of patience around any craft, any discipline, any slow-earned competence—and if there isn’t even a moat in the picture-perfect countries with their libraries and calm sidewalks and functioning sockets, what hope does a sweating boondocks have except rancid worms and reruns; which is why the old BPO merry-go-round feels so tragically neat in hindsight: Y2K around 2000 lit the fuse, India became the night-shift brain of the West, twenty-five years of polite outsourced cognition, and now AI arrives like the next logical outsourcing destination—cheaper, tireless, less likely to unionize or get dengue—ready to swallow the white-collar layers first, while the physical world buys a little time because of that old robotics curse Moravec’s paradox: it’s easier to automate a lawyer’s memo than a plumber’s wrist, easier to imitate “thinking” than to pick up a slippery object in a cluttered room, so the robots get delayed not by ethics but by doorknobs and dust and friction; which is cold comfort, really, because it means the part of society that thought it had a clean, air-conditioned moat—education, language, paper-work, “knowledge work”—discovers it was living on sand, and the rest of us, already ankle-deep in entropy, get to watch the tide come in with excellent Wi-Fi. This is worse in the holy Hindu hocus-pocus hiddley-piddley land where Maslow’s hierarchy was always a poster on a wall that the wall itself didn’t believe in, a tidy pyramid floating above a swamp of fevered casteism and superstition and the kind of religiosity that treats evidence like an insult; where “self-actualization” is something you might do after you’ve secured water, electricity, health, dignity, and a minimum of not being kicked in the teeth by the social order—except the social order is built precisely to keep those rungs greased and unreachable for most people, so you get this grotesque inversion: a society that can launch rockets and also consult astrologers about surgery dates, that can write code for Wall Street and still fear an eclipse like it’s a demon with a calendar, that can chant slogans about ancient glory while its schools teach children to memorize without understanding, to obey without questioning, to confuse reverence with knowledge, and to treat the slow patient cultivation of skill—the only real moat—as optional compared to the fast dopamine of certitude; so when the tide of automation rises, it doesn’t merely flood jobs, it floods the very possibility of grown-up attention, of institutions that admit error, of citizens who can tolerate ambiguity long enough to learn anything, and in a place already running hot with mythology and hierarchy, the water doesn’t arrive as a neutral force of change, it arrives pre-contaminated—mixed with grievance, propaganda, sanctimony—so the first thing to drown isn’t employment, it’s the thin remaining habit of thinking.

So I have a less lyrical suspicion: the singularity, for people like me in the unfashionable fringes of South Calcutta, will feel less like transcendence and more like logistics.

Water pressure that turns the morning into a negotiation. Power that arrives in stuttering syllables—loadshedding as punctuation. A city sweating under its own damp armpits while somewhere else, in a cooled bunker of servers, a polite artificial mind composes sonnets about the dignity of mankind.

<Yt src="https://youtu.be/Xa6JuimHoEA?si=djkAaixL_ePJo_iG" />

People imagine augmentation as a sleek comic-book upgrade: organic AI, robotic exoskeletons, brain-computer symphonies. Fine. Let them have their titanium fantasies. In my version, the winners get exoskeletons and the rest of us get—how to put it—*sociological osteoporosis*. Jobs go first, then meaning. Minds go next. The streets fill with anachronisms: men trained for a world that has been uninstalled, wandering around like outdated software still running on human hardware.

That’s the dread of 2026 tapping at the door: not apocalypse, not drama, just a tightening spiral of “sorry, not available”—services, dignity, attention, sanity.

And the absurd part is that the science is both magnificent and brutally unromantic.

An AI system isn’t a demigod. It’s a machine that eats electricity, turns it into computation, and excretes heat. That’s not metaphor; that’s thermodynamics—the universe’s least negotiable religion. Every grand talk of intelligence has a grubby underside: copper, silicon, cooling, water, supply chains, rare earths, geopolitics, and a rising pile of waste heat like the invisible trash behind a restaurant kitchen. The “techno-sociological singularity” may end up being, for most humans, a kind of planetary digestion problem: the new machine-metabolism demands clean power and clean water, and the old human-metabolism—us, with our small needs and large frailties—gets told to eat less, dream less, and ideally complain less.

This is where my own language becomes untrustworthy, because when I’m frightened I become theatrical, and when I become theatrical I start giving my fear costumes. I imagine myself as refuse, as something flushable, as a bit of biology the system would rather not see. It’s not dignified. It’s not even accurate. It’s just the brain reaching for a picture big enough to hold the feeling.

*Dukkho*, we say. Or *kosto*. The words have heft; they sit in the mouth differently than “hurt,” which in English feels like a clean bruise, a neat little syllable. In Sanskrit and Pali there is *duḥkha*, and here comes the irresistible bit of folk etymology—the kind of thing Instagram spirituality loves to purr—that *duḥkha* means “bad axle-hole,” as if suffering is literally a wheel that doesn’t fit right. It’s a lovely image. It’s also, as far as serious linguists can tell, mostly a story people tell because it’s too delicious to resist. A debunked etymology is still an etymology of the heart. Humans prefer a clever picture to a boring truth, and I, rationalist that I claim to be, am not immune.

Maybe that’s part of why hurt is “good.” It’s the one thing that refuses to be prettified for long. You can decorate it with philosophy, drown it in ideology, blame it on karma, fate, the nation, the West, your parents, your ex, your own weak character, Mercury in retrograde, whatever spiritual brand is trending. But the raw signal remains: something in you is rubbing wrong against reality.

The modern mind’s tragedy is that it has learned to treat pain as content.

I don’t just hurt; I narrate the hurt. I produce it. I replay it. I turn it into a private documentary series—Season 12 now, still no satisfying finale—because the brain is a prediction machine and the past is its favorite training dataset. Every time I retell the story, I am not merely remembering; I am *rewriting* the memory, reconsolidating it, polishing its edges, strengthening the pathways that lead back to it like well-trodden alleyways in Burrabazar. The hippocampus, the amygdala, the default mode network—names that sound like a British indie band lineup—keep doing their work while I sit here thinking I’m “reflecting.”

Reflection is what a mirror does. Rumination is what a closed room does.

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251031-WA0001(1).jpg" 
    layout="block"
    caption="My small act of defiance is to keep my hands steady enough not to spill"
/>

So yes: hurt is good, and I keep it alive in the worst possible way, like a pet I feed too well.

A kinder way to phrase it—still not hopeful, just accurate—is that pain is a measurement. It tells me where I am still attached to the world. Not attached in a poetic way. Attached like a wire that still conducts current.

Outside, someone’s generator starts up with that rancid, oily confidence. A street dog barks at nothing in particular, which is, frankly, the most rational response to the age we’re entering. My tube light flickers once, as if reconsidering its earlier promise of illumination.

I take my thumb off the bruise. The pain fades a little, not because the problem is solved, but because the body has done its duty and moved on, like a clerk stamping a file.

The mind, of course, is eager to reopen the case.

I stir my tea until the last sugar granules stop scraping the steel, watch the surface settle, and think: the future may be a cliff, yes—but for tonight, my small act of def iance is to keep my hands steady enough not to spill. Somewhere, sometime, there’s a place I’d rather be than this world run by demagogues who skim an LLM confabulation the way a drunk skims a road sign—half-reading, overbelieving—and then short-circuit the working circuits: the boring, hard-won procedures that actually kept things from catching fire; what used to *work* gets electrocuted in public, then shot again for good measure in the melee of disinformation and misinformation, and the crowd cheers because chaos has always been easier to sell than maintenance, and maintenance has never had a flag; and I can feel, with a kind of clinical dread, how that would drag me into darker, deeper depressive episodes—not because I’m morally superior (I’m not; I’m just allergic), but because the small, stubborn honesty I managed to practice when and where it mattered belongs to a country and an age I’m no longer in, like an old passport with the corners softened by use, proof that I once lived in a time when facts were not a fashion choice and a sentence could be true without first checking whether it was useful.
 


# File: src/lib/posts/iran-is-god-with-a-baton.md

---
title: "god wears riot gear and smells like piss"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251215-WA0008.jpg"
date: 2026-01-14
description: "A filthy, exhausted rant about power pretending to be God, democracy pretending to be a cure, and the human body stuck in the middle, leaking."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "orange"
---


<Pi src="IMG-20251215-WA0008.jpg" />



The first thing I notice is the **smell**, because humiliation always announces itself through the nose before the brain gets a vote, a warm ammoniac fog rising from my own boxers as I squat on a chipped ceramic throne that has seen more ideological regimes than Iran has had slogans, the fan above me clicking like an asthmatic metronome, my knees trembling not from age—though yes, age too—but from the simple animal dread that somewhere on the planet men with batons and beards and uniforms are beating the shit out of other men and women because God told them to, or the flag did, or the Constitution in drag, and here I am evacuating breakfast with the dignity of a dying goat, scrolling news with one hand, wiping with the other, trying not to smear history across my thigh.

Iran today looks like a **theology wearing steel-toed boots**, and I know that sentence sounds clever until you imagine the boots actually on your ribs, your spine doing that humiliating accordion thing, your mouth filling with coppery spit that tastes like old coins and regret, which is how power always tastes when it finally touches flesh, never like ideals, always like blood diluted with piss, and the thing that fries my already overcooked neurons is how every single regime everywhere does this little ventriloquist act where God throws his voice into the general’s mouth and democracy throws hers into a press release, and both swear they’re doing it for you, my sweet citizen, my beloved cunt, please lie still.

I’m fifty-something, my body a badly maintained colonial railway station with broken clocks and leaking pipes, and I’ve lived long enough to see God change costumes more often than I change my bedsheets, sometimes he’s a bearded Persian patriarch glaring down from billboards, sometimes he’s a clean-shaven corporate deity speaking English with a think-tank accent, sometimes he’s just a spreadsheet with missiles attached, but the choreography is the same: first the chant, then the truncheon, then the apology written by lawyers while someone else hoses the sidewalk.

People keep asking why Iranians protest, as if starvation and humiliation require a fucking syllabus, as if the human nervous system hasn’t already published its findings: squeeze long enough and something kicks back, even worms do it, and worms don’t even have Twitter, and when they do kick back the state reacts the way all insecure gods react—by turning up the volume on punishment—because power, stripped of poetry, is just a scared animal with paperwork.

Democracy, that other holy word we masturbate over, doesn’t escape my bile either, because I’ve watched it used like talcum powder on a corpse, sprinkled generously while the body rots underneath, and yes I know, I know, democracy is supposed to be better, less murderous, more accountable, but from down here, from the level of cracked heels and public toilets and bus rides where you’re trying to hide a semi because the seat vibrates just wrong, democracy often feels like **God with better branding**, still distant, still selective, still perfectly capable of deciding you’re an acceptable casualty in the footnotes.

My tea pan screams from the kitchen—not a kettle, mind you, not one of those polite British contraptions that whistle like a governess farting through lace, but a scorched steel bastard of a pan with a bent handle and burn rings older than some democracies, a pan that doesn’t whistle so much as it howls, shrill and sharp like an underpaid typist watching her pension get looted again, and as the shriek slices the stale air, I remember how the British taught half the fucking world to queue while being robbed blind, how they exported red tape and railways and a kind of moral rectal blockage that passes for order even when it’s suffocating you, and Iran, India, whatever-the-fuck—everywhere that once took tea in china cups while swallowing empire through a sugar cube—we’re still constipated with those systems, still farting imported bureaucracy and shitting out local tyrants while lighting incense and calling it culture.

The science of it is depressingly simple: power centralizes because entropy loves a shortcut, neurons cluster, gangs form, hierarchies solidify, and once you give a system permission to hurt in the name of something abstract—God, Nation, Security—it will do so with the enthusiasm of a toddler discovering fire, and the data is written in scar tissue, not journals, which is why no one reads it until it’s their own skin doing the learning.

Sometimes I imagine the state as a gigantic colon, absorbing nutrients, excreting dissent, flexing rhythmically, and the people as gut bacteria, necessary but disposable, occasionally flaring up into diarrhea that embarrasses the organism into action, and the remedy is always the same: clamp down, medicate, suppress, never ask why the diet is shit in the first place.

Iran’s streets, from what leaks through blackouts and censorship like sewage through cracked pipes, look like any other place where belief has metastasized into policy, young bodies running, old men ordering, slogans colliding with skulls, and somewhere a bureaucrat adjusting his tie while signing off on violence with the detached calm of someone choosing paint colors, and the part that keeps me awake—between piss breaks and useless erections—is how universal this is, how easily the script translates, Persian to Hindi to English to whatever language your oppressor prefers.

I don’t believe in God, not in the supernatural sense, but I absolutely believe in **the god-function**, that neurological hack where we outsource responsibility upward so we can sleep at night, and regimes love that function because it turns murder into liturgy, batons into sacraments, prisons into temples where the faithful are purified by suffering, and dissent becomes heresy, which is much easier to punish than disagreement.

Democracy, when it works, is supposed to short-circuit that god-function, to say no one gets divine immunity, but it’s fragile, boring, maintenance-heavy, like flossing or monogamy, and humans hate maintenance, we prefer grand gestures and flags and fuck-you fireworks, so we let it rot, then act surprised when the rot smells like Iran today or like any other place where the state decides your body is a rounding error.

My own body, traitorous sack of fluids, reminds me of this every morning when joints creak like old doors and digestion feels like a hostile takeover, autonomy reduced to negotiating with organs that don’t respect ideology, and maybe that’s why all this shit hits so close to the bladder: because the most honest politics is physiology, who gets to eat, who gets to move, who gets to shit without fear of a boot bursting in.

I picture a young Iranian kid, phone shaking, hiding in a stairwell, heart jackhammering, bladder screaming, democracy and God both equally absent in that moment, replaced by the very real calculus of escape velocity and pain thresholds, and I want to tell him nothing comforting, nothing redemptive, because lies are cheap and bullets are not, but I can’t tell him anything anyway, my words stuck here, leaking into this screen, another middle-aged bastard shouting into the algorithmic void while power does what it’s always done.

The tea goes cold. My boxers ride up. The fan keeps clicking. Somewhere, a god in riot gear lifts his baton and calls it order, somewhere else a pundit calls it complexity, and here I am, half-hard for no good reason, trying to stand up without my knees sounding like gunfire, thinking the bleakest joke of all is that none of this is new, none of it is surprising, and we’ll all act shocked again tomorrow, wiping our hands, flushing, pretending the stench isn’t ours.


# File: src/lib/posts/january-2.md

---
title: "A bird over the haze"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251013-WA0004(1).jpg"
date: '2026-01-02'
description: "I woke up early to the loud voices of the people who own—and rent, and sublet..."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "orange" 
---

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251013-WA0004(1).jpg" 
    caption="a bird over the haze"
/>

<Yc />

<Yt src="https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLTLeI7tcJHJ7xXPTSIiaHaIKpIsNi5B6H&si=2ADok1HjHkc4Hhdt" />

I woke up early to the loud voices of the people who own—and rent, and sublet, and generally *possess*—the two SUVs parked right in front of my bedroom window, as if my sleep were an unpaid roadside tax and their morning gossip the official receipt. They weren’t angry exactly, just vigorously alive in that way people get when they have vehicles large enough to confer moral authority; the kind of voices that bounce off metal, multiply, and arrive in your skull as a committee decision. Outside, the street was already doing its usual Kolkata rehearsal—horns clearing throats, a distant drill warming up like a bad tabla player, air with that faint aftertaste of yesterday’s combustion—and above the haze a bird crossed, small and single-minded, like the world’s last unsponsored headline.

On the sill there’s a light snowfall of gray: not snow, obviously—this city doesn’t do European romance, it does particulate matter—but a soft ash that could be from last night’s fireworks, or the roadwork, or the general combustion of modern life. I wipe it with my finger and it smears like bad eyeliner. *Auspicious*, I think, because we Bengalis have the spiritual gift of calling everything auspicious right up to the moment we’re in an ICU, at which point we switch to calling it fate. 

It’s an odd talent, this ability to celebrate a number on a page as if the universe itself has undergone a factory reset.

January 2. A date that means absolutely nothing in my personal history except that the tea tastes the same and the air tastes worse. A date whose significance is the bureaucratic aftertaste of Christianity—because yes, the world’s calendar is basically a missionary tract with better graphic design. The Gregorian calendar is, in effect, a successful export product: it arrives with empire, it settles into your pocket, and after a while you start defending it like it’s your own grandmother’s recipe. We grumble about foreign influence while arranging our lives around a Roman Pope’s math homework. The funny thing about the Gregorian calendar—this allegedly neutral grid we pretend is just “how time works”—is that it isn’t even trying to be neutral. It’s a fossil record of Rome’s obsessions, patched by popes, laundered through empire, and handed to the rest of us like a “universal standard,” the way a bully hands you his idea of friendship.

Even the word *month* is a confession. It comes from the moon—Old English *mōnaþ*, Latin *mensis*, both tied to measuring by lunar cycles, because for most of human history the sky was the only clock that didn’t break or get stolen. We’ve since upgraded to atomic clocks and satellite time signals—cesium atoms doing their immaculate little wiggle like metronomes in a vacuum—yet we still drag around this old lunar vocabulary as if the moon is our payroll department.

And then the names. January is Janus, the two-faced Roman god of doorways and beginnings—very on-brand for a month that feels like standing in a threshold while someone shouts behind you to “move forward.” February comes from *februa*, purification rites, a month named after ritual cleaning—delicious, considering it’s when the air in my city feels least clean. March is Mars, April may or may not be from *aperire* (“to open”)—the etymology is disputed, which is perfect because April itself can’t decide what it is—May is Maia, June is Juno, and then the calendar stops even pretending to be poetic and turns into a carved plaque for powerful men: July for Julius Caesar, August for Augustus. After that come the months that accidentally reveal the calendar’s sloppy history: September, October, November, December—*seven, eight, nine, ten* in Latin, except they’re sitting in slots nine through twelve like misnumbered seats at a wedding where nobody wants to admit the chart was wrong. That mismatch isn’t mystical; it’s just bureaucracy with a toga. The early Roman year began in March, then reforms happened, politics happened, emperors happened, and now we all recite the mistakes as tradition.

The days do the same trick—astronomy dressed up as theology dressed up as routine. Sunday and Monday are straightforward enough: Sun’s day, Moon’s day. Then English takes a wonderfully pagan detour: Tuesday from Tiw (a Germanic war god), Wednesday from Woden/Odin, Thursday from Thor, Friday from Frigg (or possibly Freyja—scholars still argue, which again feels apt), Saturday keeping the Roman Saturn like a stubborn foreign uncle who refuses to learn Bengali. It’s a whole pantheon hiding in plain sight, a weekly roll call of gods most people claim not to believe in while setting alarms for them.

And that’s where the postcolonial absurdity gets almost tenderly comic: I can say “Wednesday” with a straight face in a country where my grandparents could say *Budhbar* just as easily—Budha, Mercury; *Sombar*, the moon; *Mangalbar*, Mars; *Gurubar*, Jupiter; *Shukrobar—শুক্রবার*, Venus; *Shanibar*, Saturn; *Ravibar*, the sun—another planetary week, another cosmology, different paint on the same old human need to staple meaning onto rotations and revolutions. Time doesn’t come named. We name it because namelessness makes us nervous. Then, once named, we start saluting the names as if they were the thing itself.

And yet—here we are. India, land of five thousand years of self-congratulation, marking the birth year of a Galilean Jew with the fervor of newly hired accountants. We do it with cake, confetti, and a level of noise that suggests we’re trying to frighten away the demon of continuity. *Dekho, dekho!* New year! New me! New promises! New speeches! New hashtags! Meanwhile the molecules in the air do not care. Nitrogen dioxide does not pause for prayer.

There’s a word the philosophers use—*skyhooks*—for those imaginary supports people insist are holding up reality. As if there’s a hook in the sky from which your life hangs neatly like a shirt on a hanger, dry and crease-free, and if you chant the right syllables or buy the right calendar or clap at midnight, the hook will hold. It’s comforting, like believing your landlord is honest.

The thing about arbitrary dates is that they become sacred the moment a crowd agrees to pretend. Humans will sanctify anything: a rock, a flag, a man in a kurta, a number. The arbitrariness is the point. It proves obedience. If you can get millions of people to feel something on command because the rectangle on the wall says so, you’ve basically hacked the species.

I’m not immune. I resent it, yes, but I also feel its tug, because I’m a primate with a frontal lobe and a childhood full of rituals. Even my skepticism has rituals. I make tea the same way, I line books up and pretend that’s order rather than a museum of unfinished lives. I check the AQI like a hypochondriac checks a pulse. Numbers soothe us because they’re clean—until you realize the air isn’t.

Someone somewhere is always having the kind of disaster that doesn’t fit in your news feed.

I read, half-awake, about a fire in Switzerland—clean, efficient Switzerland, the place that looks like it was designed by a committee of competent engineers—burning, because the universe enjoys irony and will not let any country hoard safety like it’s chocolate. A big fire becomes a headline because scale makes it legible. But there are always smaller fires: a cylinder explosion in a slum, a short circuit in a wedding tent, a kitchen blaze that eats three rooms and two lives and then disappears into the statistics like it never had names.

<Yt src="https://youtu.be/yybJ656MadA?si=L4UVDaRLSS0k_jJ0" />

And then the road accidents. Those are our true national festival. We don’t even need a calendar for them. Every day is a sacrificial offering to speed, alcohol, potholes, and the peculiar Indian belief that the laws of physics are negotiable if you honk loudly enough. We kill people in bulk and call it “unfortunate,” as if misfortune arrived from outside, like a courier, rather than being manufactured locally with great enthusiasm.

The second day of January, if you really want to honor it, should be observed by standing at a crossing and watching how many people try to outrun a turning bus. There’s your religion: momentum.

Closer to home, the city has that post-firecracker hangover. The air feels bruised. The morning light comes in dull, like it’s been filtered through a cheap bedsheet. Somewhere nearby, men are digging up a road for reasons that will never be explained, and the dust is so fine it seems to have been engineered. It lifts, it hangs, it enters you. It coats the tongue. It’s intimate—more intimate than most relationships I’ve had lately.

I can handle the metaphysics of meaninglessness. I can’t handle lungs full of contractor dust.

And then the water.

<Yt src="https://youtu.be/R4Kv8Zh7fz4?si=8A-gANMn2WTKoS7H" />

Indore—again, this is just what I saw and what everyone forwards with the same concerned emojis they use for celebrity divorces—had people dying after drinking polluted potable water. The phrase itself is a little joke: *polluted potable*. Like *honest politician*. Like *pure ghee* in a country that has turned adulteration into an art form and then acts shocked when the canvas poisons the buyer.

<Yt src="https://youtu.be/icjhOQkzqVg?si=UNX_jiwlFP6DL1vF" />

What kills me isn’t just the contamination. It’s the choreography around it.

People who throw wool over your eyes on every contentious issue—health, air, food, water, roads, medicine—those same people cannot be expected to volunteer to safeguard you. They will not. They never did. They will raise their voices only after the fact, when the bodies are already arranged into a narrative. They will hold microphones like incense sticks. They will perform outrage the way we perform patriotism: loudly, briefly, and at a safe distance from responsibility.

And you—meaning me, meaning the ordinary citizen who has learned helplessness the way children learn multiplication tables—will feel soothed by the mere sound of it. Words are sedatives. You’ll tell yourself something is being done because somebody said something. Everything becomes post-mortem reaction. We treat governance like it’s astrology: you don’t prevent the bad thing; you interpret it afterward and call that wisdom.

As long as it’s not biting your own ass.

But when it does bite—when the air gets into your child’s lungs, when the water gets into your mother’s kidneys, when the adulterant gets into your bloodstream—you will not be saved by slogans. You’ll be sick, dying, or dead, and your last clear thought will be: *I should’ve bought the damn filter.*

This is the absurd modern Indian ethic: we pay taxes for services we then privately purchase again because we do not trust the services. We are a nation of double payment. We buy water purifiers, air purifiers, UPS backups, private tuition, private security, private medicine. We are citizens in name and customers in practice. A republic run like a bad subscription model.

So yes, I am the crank who tells people to buy their own filters. It’s not virtue. It’s triage. And it comes with a bitter little epiphany: “public” is an adjective that has been quietly stolen from us, like my hope, like my hairline.

<Yt src="https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLRtAzD5XzTpIlaQ1dPmaiHnwOgSti4MZ8&si=V3vxt_SkIyJBZIHS" />

Somewhere in the middle of this sour thought-spiral, I open YouTube and let piano music leak into the room. Not the grand concert-hall kind—the kind where the pianist has to wear a suit and look spiritually tortured—but the internet kind: a performer like Gamazda or Alisa Procenko, somewhere far away, framed by a camera and a quiet room, playing for strangers who need company. There is something tenderly ridiculous about it. Civilization is collapsing in small ways, and meanwhile a person sits at a keyboard and translates grief into harmonics.

Sometimes it’s classical; sometimes it’s something perversely modern arranged into elegance—metal turned into lace. The notes fall into the room like clean water from a tap I don’t entirely trust.

I don’t tell anyone how much I need it, because men of my generation are trained to speak about feelings the way we speak about sexual health: indirectly, with jokes, or not at all. But it’s true. A piece of piano music can hold my head above the brown water of the day. It doesn’t cure anything. It simply makes the room briefly inhabitable.

Then I look outside again and see the neighborhood boy walking with a face that is—how do I put it—ridiculously smiley. The kind of smile that suggests either genuine joy or a total lack of observation. I feel a flash of jealousy so sharp it’s almost comic. I’m jealous of facial innocence. I’m jealous of people whose default expression isn’t a scowl carved by years of disappointment like a riverbed.

My scowl isn’t ideology. It’s muscle memory.

Sometimes I wonder if I am being unfair, if I’m just another performative intellectual in the costume of a rationalist, sneering at rituals while secretly craving them. It’s possible. The brain loves to smuggle needs under the border disguised as principles. Even atheists have altars; we just call them “bookshelves” and “data.”

I catch myself doing it now: making an argument out of mood, using politics as a vent for depression, using “society” as a target because it’s too exhausting to admit the simpler truth—that I’m lonely, and the calendar is a cheap prop that at least pretends to organize the chaos.

Still. Even my self-doubt has to share the room with facts.

The air is measurable. The water is testable. The causes of fires and road deaths are not mysterious. They are not cosmic. They are engineering problems, enforcement problems, education problems, corruption problems. They are failures of incentives, failures of institutions, failures of imagination.

And yet we treat them as if they are weather. We endure. We adapt. We scroll.

The most Indian thing about the New Year is not the celebration; it’s the speed with which we forget what we celebrated. By January 2, the optimism has already been converted into waste—plastic cups, leftover cake drying at the edges, a few sad balloons trapped in a tree like exhausted ideals. The streets are back to their real religion: commerce and convenience.

I see online—again, in the scroll, in the chatter—that there’s a new political figure in New York, a man named Mamdani, and people are hopeful in that bright Western way, as if governance is a machine that can be repaired by swapping one part. I don’t know enough to have an opinion worth anything, and that’s not modesty, that’s arithmetic: my information is thin, my cynicism is thick, and the combination makes a paste that sticks to everything.

Hope, when it appears, always looks a bit suspicious to me—like a man in a crisp white shirt on a humid day. How are you staying so clean? What are you hiding?

Still, I watch the hopeful faces and feel that jealousy again. Not because I dislike them. Because I can’t easily join them. Depression isn’t always sadness; sometimes it’s the inability to take good news at face value. Your brain starts interrogating joy like it’s a suspect.

I look back at the calendar. January 2. The square is quiet. It doesn’t demand celebration anymore. It just sits there, an official stamp on a day that will contain exactly what days contain: eating, excreting, worrying, waiting, and the occasional moment when music arrives and makes the air briefly less poisonous.

I wipe the windowsill again. The ash returns. It will always return. The universe is very consistent that way—entropy has a better work ethic than most governments.

Outside, a man in a vest is drilling into the road as if the road personally insulted him. Dust rises in a soft cloud and drifts toward my window with the slow confidence of something that knows it will get inside eventually. I close the pane, turn the piano up one notch, and watch January 2 sit in its little box, pretending it’s in charge. By evening the air has done what it always does when it’s allowed to roam free—set up camp in my throat. It’s sore now, that raw sandpaper feeling that makes swallowing a conscious act, and with it my bipolar emotions feel more flagrantly brittle, as if the day’s particulate has found not just my lungs but the hairline cracks in my mood and is cheerfully wedging itself in. It’s a nonalcoholic hangover—no party, no pleasure, just the body paying for other people’s fireworks and somebody’s road-digging and the general national hobby of pretending consequences are optional—and I can already tell it will linger like a fish bone stuck in the throat: tiny, stupid, impossible to ignore, clouding the first week of the year, which to me is now almost a meaningless random number that crowds insist on worshipping.
 


# File: src/lib/posts/january-3-industrial-revolution.md

---
title: "The fourth"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251017-WA0006(1).jpg"
date: '2026-01-03'
description: "The first thing I heard this morning wasn’t birdsong..."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "orange" 
---

<Yc />

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251017-WA0006(1).jpg" 
    caption="o amar moyna go"
/>

The first thing I misremembered this morning sitting inside a long power outage wasn’t birdsong or the municipal chorus of coughing scooters, but that low, steady bass-note you only get from large machines pretending to be calm—like a generator the size of a small apartment, humming behind a perimeter wall in New Town, the so-called cloud made audible as a vibration in my tea glass.

Outside my own unfashionable fringe of South Calcutta, winter has that dry, bureaucratic light—pale, official, as if the sun has filed the proper forms in triplicate and will now shine in the approved wavelength band. I stood at the window with a steel tumbler warming my fingers, watching a thin line of smoke lean sideways over the rooftops, and my phone flashed an OTP like a tiny electronic sneeze. One-time password. One-time permission. One-time proof that I exist in the correct way, at the correct time, to the correct server.

We used to have revolutions you could see. You could point at a chimney, a steam engine, a loom, a railway line slicing through a field like a fresh scar. Now the revolutions arrive as interfaces—portals, dashboards, “boards,” compliance checklists, grievance systems, authorisation screens. If the old Industrial Revolution was soot on your face, the new one is an email with the subject line: ACTION REQUIRED.

So yes, people keep counting them—First, Second, Third, Fourth—but the counting is always a little dishonest, the way we label drawers after the house has already become a mess. The first upheaval was steam and coal and the invention of the factory as a kind of moral technology: you could replace a craftsman with a timetable. The second was electricity and the assembly line, the great multiplication trick—one design, infinite copies, with human beings pressed into the rhythm like punctuation marks. The third was computation and networks and container ships and global supply chains, where work got abstracted into software and logistics and the polite euphemism of “efficiency.” And the fourth—this current glossy layer—is the fusion of sensors, models, automation, and always-on connectivity: machines watching machines, decisions happening at machine-speed, and the human reduced to a user, an exception-handler, a liability with feelings.

<Yt src="https://youtu.be/K4CprInlZ7w?si=8ceEwVa0qvzkqT-j" />

In the middle of that mental machinery I found myself listening to “O Amar Moyna Go,” and the song did what old songs do best: it refused to be a diagram. It pulled me out of spreadsheet logic—carbon here, compliance there, permission everywhere—and dropped me into a softer, older physics where a voice can carry a whole village’s weather inside it. Moyna: the myna bird, glossy and talkative, an organic imitator perched on a wire—an early chatbot with feathers and better manners. There’s something almost indecent about hearing that sweetness while thinking about Industry 4.0, because the song comes from a world where communication was breath and distance, not packets and protocols; where “network” meant cousins and neighbors; where the future arrived as marriages, floods, bus routes, not as a blinking OTP and a data-centre wall humming like captive thunder. And yet the overlap nags me: the myna repeats what it hears, the model repeats what it has ingested, and in both cases we humans can’t resist mistaking mimicry for understanding—then getting sentimental about it, as if a convincing imitation of love is the same thing as love.

Everyone keeps calling this the “Fourth,” and I keep wanting to behave like a responsible adult and accept the numbering system, but numbering systems are always someone else’s way of disciplining your confusion. A Bengali boy grows up learning that history is a tidy sequence—Mauryas, Mughals, British, freedom, progress—like chapters in a well-behaved textbook that never mentions the smell of the classroom fan’s hot dust. Real life isn’t chapters. It’s strata.

That’s the sensation India gives me now: not one era, but layers piled badly, like a landlord’s renovation. Steam-age institutions still run the shop—paper files, rubber stamps, the sacred aura of a babu’s signature. Patchy electrification hums underneath—transformers that sizzle in summer, “load shedding” that sounds like a polite haircut but is actually a small civic amputation. Digitization sits atop it like cheap paint—apps that crash, portals that time out, QR codes stuck on walls that lead nowhere. And then, gleaming above all that, the AI layer: glossy, imported, marketed like a skin cream. *Now with intelligence.*

Intelligence. The word makes me laugh and wince in the same motion, like biting a guava seed.

Somewhere far away—Brussels, Washington, Geneva, the high priesthoods with clean sidewalks—policy has decided that carbon is no longer a gas you exhale and forget. Carbon is a customs form. Carbon is a border. Carbon is an invoice line-item. Emissions are being turned into paperwork the way the British once turned land into survey maps: measure it, name it, tax it, and call that civilization. You can almost admire the audacity. You can also notice who gets squeezed when virtue is priced.

I picture an exporter—some tired man with a calculator and a face that has learned to look optimistic for bankers—staring at a spreadsheet where “green compliance” isn’t a moral awakening but a margin problem. He doesn’t trim executive bonuses. He trims wages. This is how high ideals travel through supply chains: they arrive as pressure.

And while carbon becomes customs, AI becomes compliance. “Codes of practice,” “safety cases,” “transparency templates”—the modern equivalents of scripture, except the priests are consultants and the temples are PDF files. The phrase “voluntary” will be used, of course. “Voluntary” is one of those words—like “flexible” or “restructuring”—that means the powerful have already decided, and you are being invited to agree.

Meanwhile, here in my actual day, rights are also becoming portals. Data protection, privacy, consent—beautiful words, clean words, words that sound like the best parts of liberal democracy—are being operationalized into forms, boards, complaint systems, “mechanisms.” I can almost hear the nation sigh in relief: *Good, good, we have a mechanism.* We love mechanisms because they allow us to stop thinking about outcomes.

In practice, consent often feels like that blinking red light on a biometric scanner: the machine is either satisfied or it isn’t, and your year hangs on the mood of an LED. Meritocracy—this imported fairy tale we recite to our children while pushing them into coaching centres—now depends on stable lighting and reliable servers. A mismatch, a network hiccup, a smudged thumb, and the system looks at you the way a nightclub bouncer looks at a boy in cheap shoes.

Outside the coaching centre, the posters promise “future skills.” Inside, everyone is learning the oldest skill on earth: how to survive a gate.

The strangest part is how the new scarcity isn’t always silicon or power or even talent. It’s permission.

Permission to ship a chip. Permission to access a tool. Permission renewed annually, like a license for existence. The world is drifting into a kind of toll economy where sovereignty is expressed not as flags and speeches but as “approved customers,” “annual renewals,” “fees.” Empire by calendar invite. Geopolitics as subscription service.

And then there’s the electricity, the great unpoetic god we all worship while pretending we don’t. Data centres—those windowless fortresses of computation—have the charm of bureaucratic buildings and the appetite of mythological demons. They eat electrons, they drink water, they exhale heat. They arrive with press releases about being “AI-ready,” and behind the press releases are diesel gensets, backup politics, land deals, security guards who become the true interface to prosperity. A guard is always the interface in India, when you think about it. You can have the most modern system in the world, but first you must pass a human being sitting on a plastic chair, deciding whether you belong.
 
And I have this premonition—half superstition, half pattern-recognition—that load-shedding is going to become more frequent in Calcutta, not because we suddenly got poorer (we’ve always been poor in the ways that matter) but because the priority list will quietly change: the lights will blink out in living rooms while the racks stay fed, “critical infrastructure” will come to mean servers, not human throats, and potable water—our most intimate, unglamorous requirement—will be siphoned off for cooling loops and industrial thirst, leaving the rest of us to improvise like we always do, boiling, storing, bargaining, pretending it’s normal because the app still loads. And then the deeper fear, the one that doesn’t announce itself with sirens: as more and more groundwater is pulled out without being replenished, subsidence won’t be a rare headline or a strange geological footnote, it’ll be the default condition—slow, quiet settling, the city sinking by millimeters the way hope sinks by disappointments—and we won’t need an earthquake to learn what a crack looks like; our houses will start writing their own little fault lines, polite at first, hairline and deniable, then wider, then suddenly impossible to explain away as “just the plaster,” as if plaster has ambitions of its own.

Software, too, has become layered. Once there was Software 1.0—handwritten code, the kind you could read like prose if you were masochistic enough. Then came Software 2.0—models trained from data, weights congealed into something that behaves like a statistical instinct. Now we have Software 3.0—prompts as programs, language as a steering wheel. The next thing—whatever we call it, 4.0 or 3.7 or “agentic workflows” (a phrase that sounds like it was invented by a committee of tired futurists)—will be semi-autonomous coworkers you supervise, audit, and occasionally distrust.

A foreman with better grammar.
