People say this will make us more productive. I don’t doubt it will make *something* faster. Bureaucracy loves speed when it is rejecting you. “Faster processing” often means faster denial. In India, “digital” sometimes feels like the same old indifference, delivered with less eye contact.

And labor—always the quiet casualty in grand narratives—will be asked to adapt, to reskill, to be “agile,” to reinvent itself every quarter like a tech company’s branding deck. The missing first rung is the part that scares me most, not because I worship the dignity of entry-level jobs (I’ve met enough petty tyrants in junior positions to know that hierarchy reproduces itself at all ages), but because societies need ladders. A civilization that removes the first rung and then lectures the falling about “mindset” is not modern. It is cruel with Wi-Fi.

At College Street, you can still find old men bent over books as if the world’s noise is an optional subscription they never activated. There is tenderness in that, a stubborn, quiet refusal. Paper doesn’t ask for an OTP. A page doesn’t blink red at your thumb. A book will judge you only by whether you can read, and even then it will wait patiently while you learn.

I almost start to romanticize it—there’s the trope forming, the sentimental little lantern of “books will save us”—and I swat it away like a mosquito. Books don’t save us. Books merely make the darkness more articulate.

Still, I think about the layers again: steam, electricity, digitization, AI. Strata of progress, stacked unevenly, with cracks where the old infrastructure shows through. In the rich countries, the Fourth Revolution is marketed as fusion—cyber-physical systems, smart everything, seamless automation. Here, it sometimes feels like a new coating over old rot, and the rot is not just corruption or incompetence but the deeper habit of treating human beings as interruptions.

The misremembered imagined generator bass-note continued all day at the back of my skull, steady as a mantra, except this mantra didn’t promise liberation or moksha—only uptime.

At dusk the sky went the color of unwashed cotton, that familiar Kolkata compromise between beauty and particulate matter, and the red light on my phone’s screen lit my palm again—another code, another proof, another tiny petition to the machine-gods. Somewhere behind a wall, a diesel engine kept the cloud alive. The future, as ever, smelled faintly of fuel.

And then, just to remind you who gets to treat the planet like a chessboard, the news on 3 January 2026 is of the United States carrying out large-scale strikes in Venezuela, with Trump claiming Nicolás Maduro (and his wife) were captured and flown out, while Caracas hears explosions and the Venezuelan state declares emergency and talks of “military aggression” and resistance—details still foggy in that special way that only war can make “facts” feel like damp laundry. I read this with my own lights flickering, the fan doing its lazy little death-spiral, and it hits me how empires always have electricity for their ambitions: missiles don’t seem to suffer load-shedding, permission never runs out for the powerful, and the rest of us—Bengali commoners counting inverter minutes, rationing water, watching our walls crack one hairline at a time—are expected to call this “global affairs,” as if it’s weather, as if it isn’t someone else’s air-conditioned decision raining down on somebody’s street. 


# File: src/lib/posts/let-f-be-a-field.md

---
title: "Let F be a Field"
date: "2025-12-09"
description: "The first time I remember seeing the sentence 'Let (F) be a field' I had the same feeling you get when you walk into an American kitchen and there’s already a tray of ice cubes sitting there like a small, polite miracle."
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251207-WA0003.jpg"
category: "math"
color: "green"
published: true
---

<script>
    // Pi is auto-imported by svelte.config.js
</script>

The first time I remember seeing the sentence “Let $F$ be a field” I had the same feeling you get when you walk into an American kitchen and there’s already a tray of ice cubes sitting there like a small, polite miracle.

Not because ice cubes are deep. Because they’re *assumed*. They’re infrastructure. They’re the silent background music of expectation: water is cold, toilets flush, there is paper, there is soap, there is a mechanism by which your body’s humiliations can be processed and forgotten.

Then you come back to Calcutta and the universe hands you a different set of axioms.

Sometimes the restroom is a philosophical prank. Sometimes it’s a war crime against the concept of dignity. Sometimes it’s a tiled cubicle with the emotional aura of a medieval oubliette where you realize—very quickly—that “expected amenities” are not a human right, they’re a local theorem, and here your theorem does not hold. There is no paper. There is no water. There is, occasionally, a broken tap that produces one resentful dribble like it’s being paid per molecule.

And you stand there with your civilized assumptions—your little ice cubes of certainty—melting in real time, and you understand what mathematicians mean when they say “assume the following.”

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251207-WA0003.jpg"
    caption="Infrastructure is the silent background music of expectation"
    layout="iR"
/>

A field is that kind of assumption. It’s a tiny constitution for arithmetic. A well-equipped framework of overcomplicated jargon that, when you strip it naked, says: you can add, you can subtract, you can multiply, and if you have a nonzero thing you can divide by it without the universe throwing a chair. The end. That’s the whole scandal.

But mathematicians, being the sort of people who can’t order tea without defining a sigma-algebra, decided to write it as a list of “axioms,” which are really just a way of demanding that your arithmetic doesn’t turn into a street brawl.

* **Closure** — no surprise outsiders sneaking in.
* **Associativity** — so you don’t have to parenthesize like a madman.
* **Commutativity** — so $a+b$ doesn’t behave like a Bengali queue where position is an opinion.
* **Identities** — $0$ and $1$, the two most important freeloaders in human history.
* **Inverses** — so every number has a way to undo itself, and every nonzero number has a multiplicative escape hatch.
* **Distributivity** — so multiplication plays nicely with addition instead of sulking in a corner.

If you hand me any set where all that is true, I will call it a field and go on with my life. If you don’t hand me that, then linear algebra starts behaving like Calcutta plumbing: things still flow sometimes, but only if you develop a suspicious intimacy with blockages.

# Why the name “field” is so weird, and why Germans were involved

It is a delicious linguistic oddity that mathematicians chose the word “field,” which in normal English means a place where cows stand and contemplate their inevitable conversion into curry, to mean “a place where division works.”

The Germans were there first, of course. They used *Körper*—“body,” “corpus”—for the idea of a number system closed under the four operations, a phrase that always makes me think of an organism: self-contained, internally coherent, not leaking algebra onto the carpet. Dedekind is commonly credited with using *Körper* this way around 1871.

Now, Germans naming something “body” makes perfect sense. Germans can name anything. They can name a feeling you didn’t know you had while staring at a closed bakery on a rainy Tuesday. So *Körper* is tidy: arithmetic is a body, a whole creature.

English, however, has the attention span of a squirrel in traffic, and we did not keep “body.” We went with “field,” which sounds pastoral and harmless and completely fails to warn you that you’re about to spend the next decade proving theorems about polynomials that behave like cursed jewelry.

The English term *field* in the modern algebraic sense is usually attributed to Eliakim Hastings Moore, an American mathematician, who used phrases like “field of order $s$” and “Galois field” in the 1890s—famously around the Chicago math congress era (1893).

So yes: Germans gestated the concept in their orderly, cathedral-like prose; then English-speaking mathematicians—particularly Americans—gave it a name that sounds like a place you’d take a picnic. That’s civilization for you: you invent something profound and then label it like a children’s book.

# Moore, Weber, Steinitz: the bureaucrats arrive

Moore didn’t invent fields out of pure ether. The century was already thick with the smell of algebraic smoke—polynomial equations, Galois theory, number fields, function fields. People were using these structures before they were fully christened and standardized, in the same way Calcutta uses “traffic patterns” without ever agreeing on the existence of lanes.

Around the same time, Heinrich Martin Weber gave one of the first clear abstract definitions of a field (late 19th century; often cited as 1893), and then Ernst Steinitz, in 1910, did what the Germans do best: he systematized the whole thing into a grand theory—*Algebraische Theorie der Körper*—the paper that makes “field theory” feel like an actual subject rather than a set of clever ad hoc tricks.

This is the part of mathematical history that always makes me want to laugh and sigh at the same time: first we have wild invention—ideas sloshing around, half-defined, used because they work—and then the bureaucrats of rigor show up with clipboards and stamps and say, right, we’ll need a definition, and a classification, and a set of standard lemmas, and we’ll call the whole enterprise “field theory,” which sounds like a career in irrigation.

And it matters. Because once you define a field cleanly, you can stop re-proving the same little hygiene facts every time you do algebra. You no longer have to check, nervously, whether division is going to betray you. You know your nonzero pivot has an inverse. You know subtraction won’t kick you in the teeth. You can build.

# A field is just “arithmetic with amenities”

I keep coming back to the restroom metaphor because it’s vulgar and therefore honest.

A field is arithmetic with amenities. It’s the math version of “there will be toilet paper and it will not be counterfeit tissue that disintegrates into confetti the instant it meets reality.”

You can do arithmetic in lots of places that are not fields. The integers $\mathbb{Z}$ are a perfectly respectable neighborhood: you can add, subtract, multiply, no problem. But division is a scandal. Try to divide 1 by 2 and the integers look at you like you’ve suggested sacrificing a goat on the living-room carpet. You can say $1/2$, but it doesn’t live there. It’s an immigrant. It needs a different citizenship.

That’s why we have this ladder of “number systems” you meet as a child, each one created by someone who got tired of being told “you can’t do that here.”

* **Natural numbers**: subtraction breaks.
* **Integers**: division breaks.
* **Rationals**: you can divide, but not solve $x^2=2$ cleanly.
* **Reals**: you can solve that, but then polynomials demand complex numbers like a spoiled prince demanding a third dessert.
* **Complex numbers**: now you can solve every polynomial, but you’ve lost ordering; you can’t say which number is bigger without starting a philosophical bar fight.

A field is the moment where you say: for my purposes, I want the amenities of rational arithmetic—division by nonzero things—and I am willing to encode that as law.

# The America I lived in, and the America now

When I first came to the United States (late 90s, the era of dial-up shrieks and optimistic tech brochures), the country had the same vibe as a good algebraic structure: a slightly smug assumption that the basic operations work.

You wanted to open a bank account? It worked. You wanted to buy a sandwich? It worked. You wanted to argue with a professor about whether your proof was valid? It worked (and you could do it without anyone asking which god you prayed to first).

You wanted to find a restroom in a gas station off the highway? There was paper. There was soap. There was an unspoken pact between strangers that bodily maintenance would remain private and mostly dignified.

It wasn’t utopia. It was empire with good plumbing. But the plumbing mattered, because it created a psychological baseline: a sense that the “axioms” of daily life were stable enough that you could waste your brain on abstract problems like whether a certain set is closed under multiplication.

Now, in the Trump era—this carnival of grievance and performance and permanent campaigning—the country often looks like it’s experimenting with life over a ring instead of a field. Division fails. Inverses don’t exist. Every disagreement becomes “you’re either with us or you’re a traitor,” which is a very efficient way to destroy a shared algebra.

I say this with caution because memory is treacherous and nostalgia is a liar with good handwriting. But the contrast feels real: the older America I experienced was confident in its infrastructure, while the current one seems delighted to set fire to its own axioms and then argue about whether fire is woke.

Of course India has its own bonfire of axioms—ours is older, smokier, more mythologically decorated, and we’ve been roasting ourselves on it for centuries with great spiritual enthusiasm and poor sanitation—so I’m not delivering a supremacy sermon here. I’m just saying: societies, like algebraic systems, depend on boring rules holding quietly in the background. When those rules become negotiable, everything becomes expensive.

# Why linear algebra cares so much about fields

Linear algebra is, at heart, the study of solving many equations at once without losing your mind.

You have vectors. You have matrices. You have systems like $Ax=b$. You have the intoxicating promise that you can reduce messy reality to a grid of numbers and then do things to it—rotate it, project it, solve it, diagonalize it, compress it, make it confess.

But none of that works smoothly unless your scalars—the ordinary numbers you multiply vectors by—live in a field.

Because Gaussian elimination, that humble algorithmic workhorse, repeatedly does one scandalous act: it divides by the pivot. Over a field, that’s legal as long as the pivot isn’t zero. Over something that’s not a field, you can get stuck. You can have nonzero elements that don’t have inverses. You can have solutions that exist but can’t be reached by the usual clean steps. The whole business turns from “linear algebra” into “linear algebra, but with tragic complications and supplementary paperwork.”

This is why a vector space is defined over a field. The field is the reliable currency. The vectors are the objects you’re buying and selling. If your currency can’t make change—if division fails—then your nice geometric intuitions start falling apart.

And then you meet the next concept, like a new level in a video game: if you replace the field with a ring, your “vector spaces” become *modules*, and modules are wonderful and deep and also, sometimes, a haunted house. The same equation $ax=b$ may have many solutions or none, because you can’t just divide by $a$.

So, fields are the quiet enablers. The background assumption that lets linear algebra be the crisp, geometric, almost cinematic subject that makes people fall in love with mathematics: planes slicing through space, shadows on walls, eigenvectors standing stubbornly in place while the world stretches around them.

Without fields, that cinematic clarity turns into a Bengali government office: still theoretically functional, but everything takes longer and you need a stamp.

# The joke, and the not-joke

The joke is that a field is “just” a set with operations that behave like rational numbers.
The not-joke is that this “just” is the difference between a world where you can build a cathedral of theory and a world where every step requires improvisation.

This is why the history matters. Because the concept of a field didn’t arrive because mathematicians love abstraction for its own sake (though some do, and I salute their weird little hearts). It arrived because the algebra demanded a clean stage.

* Solving polynomial equations forced people to enlarge number systems.
* Number theory forced people to understand extensions—what happens when you adjoin roots that don’t exist yet.
* Geometry, especially the algebraic kind, forced people to treat functions and coordinates as living in their own number universes.

And at some point, someone said: we keep encountering these number-like systems where arithmetic works reliably; we should give that reliability a name, bottle it, label it, and stop reinventing it.

So: **field**.

A word that makes it sound like wheat, but actually means: the rules won’t betray you. Not today.

# Small personal confession, because my moods are part of the apparatus

When I’m hypomanic, the word “field” feels like freedom. Like, yes, give me axioms, give me structure, give me a clean little universe where the inverse exists and the distributive law holds and I can finally stop negotiating with chaos.

When I’m depressed, “field” feels like another smug certificate issued by the empire of abstraction, another club with velvet ropes, another reminder that my real life does not have inverses—some mistakes don’t undo, some debts don’t cancel, some losses don’t factor nicely.

And then, because I’m me, I oscillate. I want the cleanliness of a field and I also want to throw the whole apparatus into the Hooghly and watch it float past the idols and the sewage and the prayers.

But I keep coming back. Because a field, for all its jargon, is a kind of promise: if you can agree on a few simple rules, you can build something that doesn’t depend on who’s shouting loudest.

Tonight I open my notebook—cheap paper, slightly rough, the kind that absorbs ink like it’s thirsty—and I write, almost as a ritual, almost as a superstition:

*Let $F$ be a field.*

Then I pause, as I always do, and I think of ice cubes, and of the strange luxury of assumptions, and of how much of civilization—mathematical or otherwise—is just a collective decision to keep the basic operations working.

I close the notebook, not triumphantly, just quietly, like turning off a light in a room that has been arguing with you all day.


# File: src/lib/posts/lingam-milk-and-my-bad-knees.md

---
title: "Milk on the Stone, Shit in the Soul"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251227-WA0018.jpg"
date: '2026-01-10'
description: "A washed-up Bengali atheist watches devotees pour milk over a Shiva-lingam and can’t stop thinking about bodies, shame, hunger, and the elaborate tricks we use to call our desires “pure” while my own body keeps filing complaints."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "orange"
---

<Pi
 src="IMG-20251227-WA0018.jpg"
 caption="The white stream, the black stone, the old bargain: call it worship and nobody has to admit what they’re looking at."
/>


The milk hits the stone with a sound that isn’t a sound so much as a wet little agreement, a soft slap that says yes, yes, yes, this is what we came for, and the lingam sits there in its oiled black dignity—half polished by centuries of hands, half slick from yesterday’s leftovers—while the priest’s wrist performs the same circular motion my own life has been doing for fifty years: revolve, repeat, pretend it’s a new orbit.

It’s cold in the temple in that damp winter way Calcutta has, where the air itself feels like it’s been stored in a fridge next to a bowl of old fish curry, and my knees creak when I squat, and my stomach does that sour, theatrical gurgle like a bad tabla player warming up, and I can smell everything at once: incense, sweat, camphor, cheap perfume, wet stone, and the faint ghost of piss that all holy places have, because humans are humans and holiness is mostly a signage problem.

A woman in a red-and-white sari leans forward with her steel lota, and the milk arcs out with devotional confidence, and it lands right on the rounded top, and for a second my brain—traitorous, overeducated, porn-poisoned, too fond of biology—does the obvious translation: that’s a penis, madam, you are pouring milk on a penis, a sacred penis, a cosmic penis, the penis of the god whose whole brand is raw power and destruction and untidy appetite, and you’re doing it with the tender seriousness of someone watering a tulsi plant.

And then, because my mind is a fucking sewer with a library card, it adds: not just any penis, but the politely abstracted kind, the kind your aunties can look at without blushing because everyone has agreed to call it “symbol,” like calling a fart “wind” so the room doesn’t have to acknowledge what just happened.

I’m standing there with my hands half-folded, half-itching, watching the milk run down the stone in white rivulets, pooling at the base where flowers and ash and old streaks of vermillion cling like the last patients in a government hospital corridor, and I’m thinking about how symbolism works, how it’s basically compression—like zipping a messy folder of human hunger into a neat icon you can carry around without spilling your shame all over the bus.

Because if you don’t compress it, if you keep it unzipped, you get the actual thing: bodies, heat, smells, fluids, clumsy desire, the sweaty panic of wanting someone who doesn’t want you back, the nightly humiliation of your own hand, the morning regret that tastes like metal, the whole undignified circus. Religion, in this sense, is a brilliant piece of engineering. It takes the unpresentable and gives it a dress code.

Nobody tells you this when you’re a boy in North Calcutta, when you’re made to stand in line with your mother while she says “pronam” and you copy her like a little monkey with good manners, and you stare at the stone and feel nothing except boredom and the itch of your own underwear elastic. Nobody says: listen, kid, this is a way we talk about sex without saying sex, this is how we keep the village from collapsing into a horny riot, this is how we get women to perform reverence at the altar of male power and call it spirituality, and this is also—because humans are complicated and never satisfied with one meaning—how we sneak in a kind of equal-opportunity awe at the brute fact of creation.

Instead they tell you it’s “Shiva,” as if that explains anything, as if naming a mystery is solving it, like putting a label on a jar of termites.

The women don’t look like they’re thinking “penis.” They look like they’re thinking “blessing.” They look like they’re thinking “my husband’s health,” “my child’s exam,” “my mother-in-law’s blood pressure,” “please let the landlord not raise rent,” “please let the bus not kill me today.” Practical prayers. Low-budget metaphysics. And I, the bitter atheist with the malfunctioning plumbing, am the one standing there feeling scandalized, as if my own head isn’t full of far filthier images than a smooth stone receiving milk in public.

This is the part where the rationalist in me tries to be noble, tries to say, don’t be a cunt, let people have their rituals, they are coping mechanisms, we are all just apes with anxiety. The rationalist then slips on a banana peel made of hypocrisy and falls face-first into the truth: I am not scandalized by them; I am scandalized by myself, by the way my mind can’t see a symbol without dragging it back into flesh.

And flesh is where I am losing the war.

At fifty-something the body stops being a home and becomes a hostile bureaucracy. You file a request for a decent night’s sleep and the department says, sorry, backlog, maybe next quarter. You apply for a reliable erection—nothing heroic, just a functional piece of equipment, like a ceiling fan that doesn’t wobble—and the clerk looks at you over his glasses and says, “Try again after reducing stress,” which is like telling a man in a burning building to “relax.” Meanwhile your gut runs its own political party, issuing surprise elections at the worst possible time, and your sweat glands behave like they’re paid per litre, and your skin develops its own geography of rashes and small humiliations.

So yes, I stand in a Shaivite temple and think about the penis, because my own body is a constant reminder of how much of life is plumbing and electricity, and how little of it is poetry, no matter how many fucking books you read.

The milk keeps flowing. Someone offers me a spoonful of charanamrit—sweet, diluted, the sugar trying desperately to convince you it’s sanctified and not just sticky water—and I take it because refusing would start a small war, and I don’t have the energy for wars anymore, not even the fun ones. The spoon touches my tongue and my mind, which is always eager to be disgusting, imagines the day’s trajectory of that milk: poured, warmed, blessed, sipped, swallowed, absorbed, and eventually—let’s not be coy—shat out tomorrow morning in a different form, because the cosmos is a recycling plant and we are its embarrassed workers.

Somewhere in that cycle is an abstract thought: ideology is like digestion. You take in stories and slogans and you break them down, and you keep the nutrients—meaning, belonging, a sense of control—and you excrete the rest. The problem is that in this country we have a lot of people proudly eating plastic and calling it prasad, then acting shocked when their politics comes out as toxic sludge.

And the temple, which should have been a place to acknowledge raw human energy—sex, death, fear, power—has become, like everything else, a stage for performance. Even the atheists perform. I perform my contempt. I perform my distance. I perform my little educated sneer. Inside, I’m a trembling sack of needs like everyone else, but with worse posture.

Colonial history does this to you too. It teaches you shame in English, which is a very efficient language for shame because it comes with paperwork. The British didn’t invent our guilt, obviously—Indians have been inventing guilt since before it was fashionable—but they gave it a modern corporate sheen. Now you can be ashamed of your desire while also being ashamed of being ashamed, like a two-tier tax system.

And then, in a delicious twist of irony, the same people who claim to be guardians of “our culture” will clutch their pearls at the mention of sex, while praying to a god whose most iconic object is, again, a stylized cock on a pedestal. My shoulder brushes someone’s arm, and the contact sends a tiny, stupid electric message through my skin, the kind that used to mean something when I was young and full of animal optimism, before life taught me that longing is a self-renewing subscription service you never asked for.

For a second—just a second—my mind does what it always does: it tries to turn that spark into a fantasy, something soft and impossible and humiliating, because fantasy is cheaper than reality and doesn’t require you to fix your teeth or your bank account or your personality. Then the fantasy collapses under its own weight, because the body is not cooperating, the years are heavy, and my self-respect is a thin, moth-eaten shawl that doesn’t cover anything important.

The priest rings a bell. The bell says: pay attention, be present, stop thinking, surrender. My stomach answers with a different bell, a gurgle that says: find a toilet, you idiot, the gods can wait.

And that’s the punchline of my life, really. Not grand tragedy. Not noble suffering. Just the constant negotiation between metaphysics and mucus.

Outside the temple the winter sun is weak, like a cheap LED, and the street smells of exhaust and frying oil and old dust. A bus honks like it’s angry at the concept of existence. I walk carefully because my knees are traitors, and because my mind, still stuck on the lingam, keeps replaying the white milk sliding over black stone, and how everyone around it can treat it as pure devotion while I can’t stop seeing the dirty human engine underneath.

Maybe they’re healthier than me. Maybe they’re smarter. Maybe ignorance is a kind of mercy. Or maybe they know perfectly well and the whole point is that they know, and they choose, collectively, to look straight at it and not flinch, while I, the sophisticated asshole, flinch at everything—including myself.

At the corner tea stall I buy a paper cup of tea that tastes like boiled impatience. The first sip hits my gut and the gut sends a memo: emergency meeting. I start walking faster, which at my age is less “urgent” and more “comedy,” a man trying to hurry while his joints negotiate every step like unionized workers.

A girl in a sweater passes by, laughing at something on her phone, and my eyes betray me for half a second, and my heart does the old foolish twitch, and then my body, that unreliable collaborator, responds with a faint stirring of interest that is immediately drowned by the much louder and more authoritative signal: you are going to shit yourself if you don’t get home in five minutes.

So yes. Shiva’s cosmic sexual energy. Raw creation. The universe’s thrust and pulse. The eternal lingam bathed in milk.

And me, waddling home with a clenched asshole, trying to hide a ridiculous, half-hearted hard-on from nobody in particular, because even my defeats can’t coordinate properly.

# File: src/lib/posts/lu-factorization.md

---
title: "LU Factorization"
date: "2025-12-22"
description: "Triangular matrices are the divas of linear algebra: fussy-looking, but once you have one, solving linear systems becomes embarrassingly straightforward."
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251207-WA0019.jpg"
category: "math"
color: "green"
published: true
keywords: ["linear algebra", "matrices", "algorithms", "math"]
---

<Yc />

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251207-WA0019.jpg" 
    caption="Decomposing the complex into the triangular"
    layout="block"
/>

<Yt src="https://youtu.be/QVKj3LADCnA?si=pFnGD1PHdrK5MbNj" />

## What LU factorization is (the “what”)

Take a square matrix $A$ (think: the coefficients in a pile of simultaneous linear equations) and rewrite it as a product of two triangular matrices:

$$
A = LU \quad (\text{or, more often in real life, } PA = LU)
$$

Here $L$ is **lower triangular** (zeros above the diagonal) and $U$ is **upper triangular** (zeros below the diagonal). The $P$ is a permutation matrix—a bookkeeping gadget that means “we swapped some rows to keep the arithmetic sane.”

Triangular matrices are the divas of linear algebra: fussy-looking, but once you have one, solving $Tx=b$ becomes almost embarrassingly straightforward. Lower-triangular systems solve by **forward substitution** (top to bottom), upper-triangular by **back substitution** (bottom to top). LU factorization turns “hard once” into “easy many times.”

## Why anyone should care (the “why”)

Because LU is the difference between:

1.  Doing the same tedious elimination steps again and again every time you get a new right-hand side $b$, versus
2.  Paying the “elimination cost” **once**, then reusing it like a master key.

If you need to solve $Ax=b$ for lots of different $b$’s—common in engineering, simulation, statistics, optimization, graphics, circuits, weather models, you name it—LU is a workhorse. You factor $A$ once, then solve two triangular systems each time:

$$
Ly=b \quad\text{then}\quad Ux=y
$$

That second phase is much cheaper than re-eliminating from scratch.

It’s also conceptually satisfying: LU is Gaussian elimination with its receipts kept neatly in a folder. Same story, better accounting.

## How it works (the “how”), without assuming background

Imagine you’re trying to solve a system of equations. Gaussian elimination’s idea is simple: use the first equation to knock out the first variable from all equations below it, then move to the next variable, and so on until the system becomes a staircase.

LU factorization notices something almost sneaky:

* The numbers you use to “knock out” entries (the multipliers) can be stored in $L$.
* What’s left after you’ve knocked everything below the diagonal to zero is $U$.

So LU is not a different magic trick—it’s the same trick, but written as a clean factorization.

---

## The mechanism: Row-operation gremlins

The clean way to see LU is to make the “row-operation gremlins” explicit as elementary matrices.

Take a matrix $A$. In Gaussian elimination, you do row operations like:

$$
R_i \leftarrow R_i - m R_j \quad (i>j)
$$

That single operation can be encoded as left-multiplication by an elementary matrix $E$ (because left-multiplying mixes rows).

### The “extra $EA$” part

Start with $A$. After the first elimination step you have:

$$
E_1 A = A^{(1)}
$$

After the next step:

$$
E_2 A^{(1)} = E_2 E_1 A = A^{(2)}
$$

Keep going. After $k$ elimination steps you end up at an upper-triangular matrix $U$:

$$
E_k E_{k-1} \cdots E_1 A = U
$$

Now solve that for $A$ by multiplying both sides on the left by the inverse product:

$$
A = (E_1^{-1} E_2^{-1} \cdots E_k^{-1}) U
$$

So if you define:

$$
L = E_1^{-1} E_2^{-1} \cdots E_k^{-1}
$$

then you’ve literally obtained:

$$
A = LU
$$

That’s the whole “$E^{-1}$ becomes $L$” punchline: $L$ is the product of the inverses of the elimination matrices.

### Why $E^{-1}$ looks like $L$

For the elimination operation $R_i \leftarrow R_i - mR_j$, the corresponding $E$ is the identity matrix with a single extra entry $-m$ in position $(i,j)$:

$$
E = I - m e_i e_j^\top
$$

(where $e_i$ is the $i$-th standard basis vector).

Its inverse undoes the row operation, i.e., it adds back what you subtracted:

$$
R_i \leftarrow R_i + mR_j
$$

and the inverse matrix is:

$$
E^{-1} = I + m e_i e_j^\top
$$

So $E$ has $-m$ below the diagonal; $E^{-1}$ has $+m$ below the diagonal. Both are unit lower-triangular (1s on the diagonal), which is exactly the structural DNA of $L$.

### Tiny concrete example (so it doesn’t feel like wizardry)

Let

$$
A=\begin{pmatrix}
2&1\\
4&3
\end{pmatrix}
$$

Eliminate the $4$ under the $2$: multiplier $m = 4/2 = 2$. Do $R_2 \leftarrow R_2 - 2R_1$.

That corresponds to:

$$
E=\begin{pmatrix}
1&0\\
-2&1
\end{pmatrix}
$$

Compute:

$$
EA=
\begin{pmatrix}
1&0\\
-2&1
\end{pmatrix}
\begin{pmatrix}
2&1\\
4&3
\end{pmatrix}
=
\begin{pmatrix}
2&1\\
0&1
\end{pmatrix}
= U
$$

Now invert $E$:

$$
E^{-1}=
\begin{pmatrix}
1&0\\
2&1
\end{pmatrix}
$$

and indeed:

$$
A = E^{-1}U
$$

So here $L = E^{-1}$. In bigger matrices you have multiple elimination steps, hence multiple $E_i$’s, and $L$ becomes the product $E_1^{-1}E_2^{-1}\cdots$, still lower-triangular with 1s on the diagonal, and with the multipliers living below the diagonal like fossils of the elimination process.

If you also allow row swaps (pivoting), you get:

$$
E_k \cdots E_1 PA = U \quad\Rightarrow\quad PA = LU
$$

with the same $L = E_1^{-1} \cdots E_k^{-1}$ idea, just wearing a $P$ hat because reality is messy and pivots can be dramatic.

---

## Where it came from (the “when / who / where”)

This story starts long before anyone said “matrix.”

* **Ancient China, ~150 BC onward:** Methods equivalent to elimination appear in *The Nine Chapters on the Mathematical Art* (later referenced by title around 179 AD), with commentary by Liu Hui in the 3rd century. That’s elimination as a computational craft, centuries before European textbooks got around to it.
* **Cambridge, 1669–1670 → published 1707:** Isaac Newton wrote notes laying out how to solve simultaneous equations; they were later published as *Arithmetica Universalis* (1707).
* **Early 1800s, Germany:** Carl Friedrich Gauss refined elimination notation for the kinds of linear systems that show up in least-squares and surveying; a key reference point is Gauss (1810) in the historical record.
* **United States Coast Survey, 1881:** Myrick Hascall Doolittle (a “human computer,” in the old job-title sense) pushed elimination into an efficient tabular form that working agencies could actually run at scale.
* **Kraków / Jagiellonian orbit, 1938:** The Polish astronomer Tadeusz Banachiewicz is credited with introducing LU decomposition explicitly as matrix factorization (the modern conceptual framing).
* **MIT, 1941:** Prescott Durand Crout reorganized elimination so it fit the strengths of mechanical calculating machines—an early example of algorithms evolving to match the hardware of their era.

A fun historical footnote: the term “Gaussian elimination” itself is a comparatively late naming habit—it was only called that widely in the 1950s, partly via historical confusion.

So LU factorization isn’t a lone genius’s invention; it’s the moment elimination grew up, got standardized, and learned to wear the suit-and-tie of matrix notation.

## Why this still matters in 2025-world

LU is one of the silent pistons inside modern computation. Any time you see “solve a linear system,” you’re in LU territory (or a close cousin like QR or Cholesky, chosen for special structure). LU is the default general-purpose engine because it’s fast, reusable, and conceptually tied directly to elimination.

It’s also a kind of philosophical upgrade: mathematics taking a messy procedure (“do row operations until it works”) and distilling it into a reusable object (“this matrix is the product of these two structured matrices”), which is exactly the sort of move that lets science scale—from hand computation in surveying offices to numerical linear algebra libraries running on machines that don’t know what a triangle is, except as zeros in the right places.

If you learn one thing here, make it this: **LU is the art of turning a hard problem into two easy problems—without losing the trail of breadcrumbs that got you there.**

# File: src/lib/posts/marys-retarded-room.md

title: "Mary's Retarded Room, a Fucking Philosophy"

It smelled like wet socks, boiled cauliflower, and guilt.

Like something that had been farted out of a brain rather than an ass, and left to curdle on a beige bedsheet in a poorly-lit biology tuition room with a ceiling fan that ticks like a fucking countdown to madness. That was Mary’s room. Or rather, the "Room," capital R, like it was some vaginal Vatican of epistemology—except instead of hymns and child abuse we got black-and-white knowledge and a woman who knows *everything* about color except the taste of a ripe mango or the incandescent insult of neon green on a nightclub wall when you're thirty-five, drunk, and rejected by someone wearing platform Crocs.

They say Mary the neuroscientist lived in a monochrome world, but I say she lived in Ballygunge, because only in Ballygunge could some cunt say they understood red without ever bleeding on a toilet seat. She knew the spectrum down to its electromagnetic dick print—wavelengths, reflectance curves, cone cell absorption rates—but hadn't seen a fucking sunset. Which is how I feel every morning when I take my post-tea dump and contemplate the shape of truth while scraping dried fecal flakes off my left butt cheek because my tap water pressure is so low it wheezes like a lung cancer patient giving a blowjob.

See, the whole damn philosophical experiment is like shoving a fluorescent tube up your ass and calling it enlightenment. Mary’s Room isn’t about knowledge. It’s about how philosophy farts in your face and pretends it’s perfume. The bitch knew all the physics, all the neural mappings, all the fuck-all diagrams about vision—but when she saw red for the first time, she learned something "new." Ah, qualia. Subjective experience. Or as I call it, the inescapable stench of meaninglessness wrapped in Victorian lace panties.

Because here's the thing: **we all live in some version of that room.** Mine has a dusty Prestige rice cooker, two cockroaches who might be dating, and a crusty towel that smells like dried semen and Baygon. I know what a kiss is. I can model the lips, the pressure, the diffusion of heat and moisture, the micro-changes in oxytocin levels—but the last time I got kissed was during a power cut when a bat flew into my window and I panicked and accidentally kissed the mosquito net in sheer terror. Still counts.

Anyway.

Philosophy wanks itself raw over these things. Minds. Brains. Consciousness. It jerks off in the corner of Plato’s cave and calls it ontology. But the problem is not that we don’t know enough—it’s that we’re all constipated with knowing *too fucking much* and still can’t feel a damn thing that isn’t buffered through five layers of sarcasm, porn addiction, and WhatsApp forwards. I have more bookmarks on free will and emergentism than I have clean underwear. I read fucking Dennett on the toilet and wipe my ass with a copy of Nagel’s *Bat Essay*, and yet when I stub my toe I still scream “fuck” like it’s the only truth that matters.

You want truth?

Truth is that no Indian engineer from Salt Lake who wrote a C program to simulate the RGB color space ever got laid for it. Truth is that even if Mary saw all the colors, she probably still went home and cried while ordering Domino’s thin crust and bingeing some emotionally retarded BBC series where white people whisper feelings they clearly don’t have. Truth is that no amount of Bayesian inference, connectome mapping, or synaptic shitfiddling will explain why a 50-year-old Bengali atheist like me still feels a brief pulse of erection watching a woman peel an orange on the metro. That’s qualia, motherfucker. That’s the ineffable. That’s the whisper of god shit in the perineum.

And don’t give me this reductionist horseshit either. I’ve seen the inside of a lab. I’ve labelled fMRI slices while half-pissing into a bottle during data collection. I've read the literature. They want you to believe consciousness is a brain state, a pattern of firings, a stable attractor in neural phase space—which, sure, maybe it is—but then why do I sometimes cry looking at the window grilles at 3 a.m., remembering a plastic chair that my mother threw away in 1992?

That chair had *texture*, man.

That chair was my Mary’s room.

The real joke is, of course, the rest of us *never left* the room. We're in it. Trapped in digital grayscale. Trapped in monochrome porn thumbnails and dopamine loops and AI-generated images of tits that no real woman has, all pixelated pussy and no soul. Trapped in philosophical masturbation loops like dogs licking peanut butter off their own taints, thinking we’re doing epistemology.

And every time someone says "but maybe we can simulate the Mary effect using GPT or diffusion models" I want to shove a coloring book up their ass and staple it there.

Listen.

Experience isn’t *about* knowledge.

It’s the fucking tax you pay for having a body.

It’s the groin itch during a conference call.

It’s the bleeding gums when you brush too hard while thinking of death.

It’s that panicked fart in a lift.

And yes, it's also that bitter pang of unfairness when Mary steps out of her stupid colorless room and feels something you, with all your knowing, all your books and arguments and semantic parsing—*you*—will never feel, because you spent your life reducing life into sentences and diagrams instead of licking a mango off someone’s bare shoulder.

Or even trying.

Fuck, I don’t even have a conclusion.

I just wanted to say that sometimes I look at my window—cheap aluminum grille, pigeons fucking on the ledge, a towel that dried in its own bacteria—and I feel something. Not color. Not meaning.

Just a kind of slow sadness.

Like the room itself is watching me back.

And jerking off.

One of those high-pitched, suspiciously eloquent ones that sounds like it’s quoting Latin and accusing you of crimes at the same time—philosophical fart, not just a random butt burp but a prelude, a warning, a fucking Sanskrit overture. You ever try to time your dump so the water splash doesn’t slap your balls with last night’s regret? I do. I conduct my shits like a Vedic orchestra, every grunt a stanza, every turd a metrical unit, every hemorrhoid a tortured vowel.

Real fuckers with real tongues who sat there counting combinations of long and short syllables—Laghu and Guru like a goddamn Morse code for monks with prostate issues. And while some Italian dick named Fibonacci was still figuring out how to grow rabbits without fucking his cousin, these motherfuckers were metering entire universes into chants.

You know what's recursive? My despair. Hope. Disillusionment. Rage. Repeat.
Hope. Disillusionment. Rage.
Repeat.

Because that’s the fucking rub. The moment I feel awe, my brain coughs up a hairball of shame.

A recurrence of regret.

# File: src/lib/posts/mattering-is-a-shitty-ghost.md

The smell came first, always does, that warm iron-and-ammonia tang that rises from a Calcutta latrine at dawn, when the city is still half-asleep and the shit hasn’t yet been trampled into modernity by a million sandals, and I’m squatting there with my knees creaking like colonial furniture, anus hovering over a porcelain bowl that has seen more despair than any philosopher, phone in one hand, cock useless and dangling like a sad afterthought, and my brain—this treacherous sack of electrified tapioca—whispering its daily sermon: you do not matter, you have never mattered, you will never matter, now push.

Sometimes the shit comes easily, a sloppy brown resignation letter from the body to the day ahead.
Sometimes it clings.
Today it clung, like meaning.

I have bipolar depression and anxiety, which sounds dramatic until you realize it mostly means lying on a bed staring at a fan, masturbating without enthusiasm, and inventing reasons why everything feels like a cunt punt to the soul. The psychiatrists love neurotransmitters because neurotransmitters don’t argue back, but I know a story when I see one, and my head is stuffed with them, childhood fables about destiny and worth and being special, fed to me like sweetened condensed milk until my teeth rotted with expectation. Somewhere in there, lodged like a turd that refuses to flush, is the idea that I am supposed to matter.

Mattering.
What a ridiculous word.
Sounds like battering something with meaning until it submits.

The brain, from what the nerds say, has this thing called the default mode network, which is a fancy way of saying the mind’s gossip aunt who never shuts the fuck up, constantly narrating, constantly looping back to me-me-me, replaying humiliations like a highlight reel no one asked for. It’s the part of the brain that turns a bad bowel movement into a referendum on your existence. It’s not a physical organ you can cut out with a scalpel, which is unfortunate because I would gladly rent one for the afternoon, but a psychological fiction, a story-generator with IBS.

I read somewhere—because of course I did—that happiness is sometimes just the absence of that narrator, a brief electrical silence where the self fucks off for a cigarette. I remember this from Ambien nights, those soporific holidays where the brain loosens its grip and you feel oddly buoyant, detached, even joyful, while brushing your teeth with shaving cream or texting an ex about the metaphysics of tits. Chemical amnesia as grace. Proof that the self is optional, like underwear at home.

But when the drug wears off, there’s the rent.
And the books.

I want to buy a book by Rebecca Goldstein about meaning, because apparently when your life feels like a stalled auto-rickshaw belching fumes, you’re supposed to consult philosophers, as if Plato ever had to choose between lithium and groceries. I’m an atheist Bengali rotting in the boondocks of Calcutta, which is a sentence that already feels like a punchline written by a cruel god I don’t believe in, and my grand spiritual practice is listening to smart people and reading books I can barely afford. Below the bread line, even by third world standards, which is impressive in the same way having the smallest dick at the orgy would be impressive if anyone were keeping score.

Books are all I spend on.
No travel.
No restaurants.
No joy accessories.

If you visited me on a random day, you’d see a middle-aged middle-class nonentity, no one, surrounded by stacks of paperbacks like a failed fortification, struggling to read them because depression turns paragraphs into mud. A man with more spines than prospects. I sit there, ass imprinting the bed, flipping pages slowly, the way old men chew, as if savoring the last calories of relevance.

Science tells us the brain is a prediction machine, constantly guessing the next moment, and depression is when every prediction is shit. The body believes the future will hurt, so it prepares by hurting now. Anxiety is the same asshole, just caffeinated. Evolutionarily, this made sense when tigers were involved. Now the tiger is an unpaid electricity bill and a book you want but can’t buy.

Colonialism fucked us in many ways, but one of its quieter crimes was teaching us that ideas come wrapped in imported paper, that meaning arrives via hardback from elsewhere, footnoted and authoritative. So here I am, counting coins like a Victorian orphan, trying to decide whether I can afford a paperback on why I matter, which is objectively hilarious. Paying to be told you exist. Capitalism really will sell you your own reflection if you’re lonely enough.

The body, meanwhile, has its own opinions.
It wants to piss.
It wants to shit.
It wants, occasionally, to fuck, in that dull, stubborn way that feels less like desire and more like a system error.

Abstract concepts like meaning are just bodily urges in drag. You want significance the way your colon wants release: pressure builds, discomfort rises, and eventually something has to give. Philosophers dress it up in Greek, but it’s the same plumbing. When the shit won’t come, you feel wrong. When life won’t make sense, same feeling, different hole.

I keep thinking if I can just understand the mechanism—if I can map the neural circuitry of this me-me loop, annotate it like a bad diagram—I can slip out of it. But knowledge is a tease. You can know the biochemistry of desire and still get a pointless hard-on on a crowded bus, trying to hide it behind a bag of onions while pretending to be fascinated by traffic.

Politics says I should matter as a citizen.
Religion says I should matter to god.
Family says I should matter because blood.
The market says I matter only if I produce.

All of them can eat my ass.

The left promised meaning through solidarity, then got lost in slogans. Nationalism promised belonging, then demanded my brain as collateral. Masculinity promised power, then handed me a limp script written by dead men. Spirituality promised transcendence, then asked for my credit card. Every system wants to rent space in your default mode network and run ads.

Sometimes, late afternoon, when the heat presses down like a fat relative, I lie there thinking maybe meaning is just a side effect, like nausea, something you don’t chase but tolerate when it shows up. The happiest moments I remember are stupid ones: a perfectly timed fart in an empty room, the clean click of a switch, the sudden relief after a long-held piss that makes you shiver and sigh like you’ve just solved a theorem.

Maybe mattering is the wrong unit.
Maybe sensation is enough.

But then the narrator kicks in again, that internal cunt with a clipboard, tallying failures, comparing me to imaginary versions of myself who did better, fucked more, published something, mattered. The body answers by sinking, by making gravity feel personal. Depression is gravity with an opinion.

I imagine buying the book. I imagine the cover in my hands, the smell of fresh paper, the tiny dopamine hit of ownership. I imagine underlining a sentence and thinking, yes, that’s it, that’s the key, while my stomach growls because I skipped lunch to afford it. Knowledge has always been my cheapest drug, but it still costs.

Outside, the city groans. Somewhere, someone is praying loudly. Somewhere else, someone is fucking. The sewer gurgles like it’s thinking about philosophy. I get up to piss again, because the body doesn’t care about narratives. The stream is weak, hesitant, middle-aged. I watch it, hypnotized, thinking about flow states and Buddhist emptiness and how none of it stops urine from splashing back on your toes if the angle’s wrong.

I return to the bed, books staring at me like disappointed teachers. I pick one up, read a page, forget it, read it again. The brain resists meaning the way a constipated asshole resists fiber. Somewhere in the circuits, the self is still chattering, still insisting it deserves a plot.

Night comes.
The fan ticks.
The body wants sleep, then doesn’t.

I think about mattering the way I think about my dick now: something that once promised a future and now mostly gets in the way. I pull the blanket up, feel a half-erection rise and fall for no reason, a pointless salute to nothing. There is no redemption in it, just biology misfiring in the dark.

Tomorrow I might have enough money for the book.
Tomorrow I might not.

For now, I lie there, listening to my stomach bubble, the city breathe, the default mode network mutter its bullshit, and I wonder if this is what existing amounts to: a damp room, a restless brain, a body leaking quietly, trying very hard not to believe its own stories.

I had all my books and notes and paper assets moved from my North Calcutta flat to this godforsaken termite‑ridden South Calcutta prison, this sunbaked asbestos‑top shithole adjacent where I now live surrounded by mediocrity and motorbike exhaust—but in one of the damp trunks, nestled between a bound set of books and my old Jadavpur University BCSE notebook where I’d drawn an amoeba like it had jaundice, I found it—

wedged inside a yellowed envelope that reeked of Dettol and piss—my father’s diary, or more accurately, his medical panic ledger, a fucking Rolodex of desperation, with one dried leaf from an old neem tree squashed inside like it too had tried and failed to cure him.

First page—lists.
Second page—lists.
Every page after that—fucking lists.

Just names.
Doctor names.
Specialties.
Chamber addresses.
Timings that were theoretical, aspirational, almost literary.
Phone numbers scratched out and rewritten like regret.

Because in his mind, and in the minds of every educated, colonially trimmed, exam‑passing middle‑class Indian bastard of his and all generation after in India, *doctor = God*.

Except this God doesn’t wash his hands after fingering your lungs.

He didn’t die of a disease.
He died of a system.
Pneumonia my ass.
He was killed by an algorithm of apathy—a slow, bureaucratic, antiseptic‑smelling manslaughter involving forms, bedpans, and a rotating cast of men in white coats who never once read what the last guy wrote.

Hospital‑acquired resistant infection.
Which is scientific code for: we fed him to the bugs we’ve been cultivating for decades like prized fucking orchids.

Because here’s the part nobody likes to say out loud while they’re busy touching foreheads and chanting *get well soon*—Indians are marinated in antibiotics from childhood. We grow up chewing amoxicillin like orange candy, Ofloxacin like Hajmola, Azithromycin like fucking after‑dinner mints. Every sore throat, every loose motion, every “maybe viral but let’s be safe” gets nuked with something broad‑spectrum and dumb, and nobody—*nobody*—checks resistance. Not then. Not later. Not until the lungs are soup and the catheter site looks like a crime scene.

Doctors don’t test because tests cost time and thinking, and thinking doesn’t bill well. So they keep throwing pills at you like a drunk gambler chasing losses, and by the time someone finally whispers “maybe culture?” it’s already too late, because the bacteria have PhDs now and your immune system is a tired clerk who’s been working overtime since 1982.

And then you go into an Indian hospital while vulnerable, while already cracked open by illness, and your chances of picking up multiple resistant infections multiply like compound interest, because the place is a free buffet floating in the air and the water and the fucking bedrails. You breathe there—you get infected. You drink tea from a plastic cup—you get infected. You piss in a toilet with a leaky flush—you get infected. The stethoscope touching your chest hasn’t been cleaned since Manmohan Singh had hair. Hospitals here are Petri dishes with billing software, five‑star slaughterhouses where the meat pays up front and still dies politely.

The bugs that killed him even had fancy names. *Acinetobacter baumannii*. *Klebsiella pneumoniae*. Sounds like Italian philosophers. Sounds like pasta. And these charming cunts evolved happily in damp corners and old tubing while our MBBS brigade, who memorized Guyton like scripture but forgot the word hygiene, kept scribbling Cipro and hoping for the best.

Nobody reads journals. Nobody updates. Medicine here is a performance art—a kabuki of concern where you frown, tap a pen, say “let’s observe for 48 hours,” and charge 1500 rupees for the privilege of being ignored. Patients are a human ATM queue. Diagnostics get milked. Referrals get stacked. When the cow stops mooing, you say *admit korle bhalo hobe* and move on.

My father didn’t admit. He submitted.

He submitted to a machinery where the human being is incidental, the file is sacred, and continuity of care is a myth told to calm relatives. He asked—not dramatically, just with that quiet Bengali resignation—for someone to read what the last doctor had written. They didn’t. They never do.

In the end, a respiratory consultant didn’t even check his oxygen properly because the pulse oximeter was broken and the junior thought 85 percent was “okay for his age.”

Eighty‑five percent.
That’s not oxygenation.
That’s Russian roulette with a silencer.

And still the diary stayed in his bag like a loyal, stupid dog. Pages of hope. Of follow‑ups that never followed up. He’d written “DR. CHAKRABORTY—PULMO—ASK ABOUT VACCINE” weeks before the infection. Chakraborty said they didn’t have it and it wasn’t necessary for “stable patients.”

Stable.
Stable!
He had one working lung and a stack of X‑rays thicker than my childhood photo album.

Nobody cared. Not really. Not in this decaying, GDP‑wanking country where public health is a punchline and private hospitals are mafias with parking lots. You’re not a man when you walk into a clinic here. You’re a walking EMI.

They let him rot. Quietly. Efficiently. With receipts.

Negligence here is so normalized it’s practically spiritual.

And the cruel joke is his generation still believes in the sanctity of the profession. They still wear socks to appointments. Still say Doctor Babu. Still die clutching lists like paper talismans.

I keep the diary in a box now. Not for memories. For the lists. Because one day, when it’s my turn to cough blood and shit mucus and some app promises “AI‑powered care,” I’ll open it and read:

“DR. Something Something (RETIRED)—charges too high—hands shaky—still maybe okay for second opinion?”

That’s as good as it gets.

And I know all this, because I *fucking worked* on the other side—I was a software engineer who helped build Electronic Health Records and Health Information Exchanges in the U.S., the real-deal ones, not some shady web app with a green button that says “prescribe.” I sat in rooms where doctors had to account for every fucking action, because if they didn’t—if they forgot to wash, or skipped a note, or missed a flag—*they got sued*. They got reamed by compliance officers, by angry families, by class-action lawsuits, by internal review boards with actual teeth. Not spiritual ones. Legal ones. Fear was the glue. Fear kept them alert. Kept them human. Because medical negligence doesn’t wave a flag, but it *is* a felony. Over there, they know if they act like fucks, someone will slide a subpoena up their ass. Here? Here, they just shrug. They’re cavalier. They disappear. They blame your karma or your weak immunity or your delayed admission. And there’s no reckoning. No audit. No learning. Just another funeral and another uninformed family politely asking for the death certificate. Because once you’re fucking dead, it doesn’t matter who killed you.

Today I woke up with acid in my throat. Then I farted, checked the PM2.5—221—and thought how the air is still safer for bacteria than it is for me.




# File: src/lib/posts/melancholia-to-methane.md

---
title: "Melancholia to Methane"
date: "2025-12-14"
