description: "What if my despair, and the despair of people like me, could be harvested like biogas? The chemistry of giving up—transmuted into power."
category: "personal"
color: "black"
published: true
---


<Pi
    src="IMG-20251207-WA0023.jpg" 
    caption="The mattress is on the floor because I have, for years now, been running an experiment in 'minimal viable dignity'"
/>

The mattress is on the floor because I have, for years now, been running an experiment in “minimal viable dignity,” and the results are in: dignity is not a thing you can bootstrap from dust and lint and a phone with a cracked screen.

December in Kolkata arrives like an old clerk with a stamp—thunk, thunk, thunk—approving every pollutant, every bad decision, every damp wall, every lungful of brown air, every unacknowledged life. The city goes into its winter trance, the inversion cap settles like a greasy lid on a pot, and we all simmer gently in our own exhaust while pretending it’s “pleasant weather.” It is pleasant, yes, in the same way a sedative is pleasant—quieting, flattening, reducing you to one long resigned exhale.

I lie there and I can *smell* the civic contract. It smells like burnt plastic and frying oil and damp paper and that peculiar sourness of old concrete that has been losing to water for decades. Somewhere, someone is burning something they should not burn, because the municipal system has the moral backbone of a jellyfish, and the rest of us are the aquarium.

My phone is a little glowing rectangle of doom. My laptop is a slightly bigger glowing rectangle of doom with a keyboard that remembers better days. The fan makes a sound like it is filing a complaint in triplicate. Outside, the city runs on a mixture of faith and fraud and diesel.

And in that mood—this thick, low-pressure mood where even my thoughts feel oxygen-deprived—I begin to entertain one of those ideas that is half metaphor, half insult, and half a sincere engineering proposal (yes, that’s three halves; welcome to my brain): what if my despair, and the despair of people like me, could be harvested like biogas?

Not harvested in the genocidal, cartoon-villain sense—calm down, inner psychopath, go sit in the corner and chew on your own shame—but harvested in the strictly chemical sense, the way a village digester turns cow dung into a blue flame and a cup of tea.

Because *methane* doesn’t care about my résumé. Methane is gloriously meritocratic: give it carbon, give it hydrogen, exclude oxygen, add time and microbes and a bit of warmth, and it will show up like a punctual bureaucrat and do its job.

# Melancholia to Methane

The romance of decomposition. The chemistry of giving up—transmuted into power, into motion, into light.

The Greeks, those dramatic geniuses, gave us “melancholia” from *melas* (black) and *cholé* (bile), because they loved turning misery into bodily fluids. Which is fair. If you’ve ever been depressed, you know it is not an idea; it’s a secretion. It is something your body does to you, like an unrequested tax.

Methane, meanwhile, is named in a way that sounds like a Victorian aunt—*methane*, *methanol*, *methyl*—all that tidy nineteenth-century nomenclature, as if chemistry were a polite parlor game and not, in reality, a catalog of ways matter can betray your expectations. Methane is CH₄, a carbon with four little hydrogens clinging to it like anxious children, and it burns beautifully: blue flame, clean-ish story (until you remember leakage, climate forcing, and the minor detail that we are cooking the planet like a forgotten potato).

But that blue flame is hypnotic. It is the dream of relevance. *Look*, it says, *even your waste can do work.*

And so my mind—always eager to be useful, always eager to be cruel—starts drafting a fantasy apparatus.

In the fantasy, there is a plant, maybe somewhere near the edge of the city where the land is cheap and the conscience is cheaper. A shed, tin roof, puddles, a few bored dogs with the streetwise posture of old philosophers. Inside: digesters. Big cylindrical tanks, painted an optimistic green that no one believes in. Pipes snaking like intestinal thoughts. Gauges. Valves. The gentle, constant burbling of anaerobic life doing what it does best: taking yesterday’s organic tragedy and making tomorrow’s combustible gas.

And then—this is the part where my brain gets lyrical and disgusting in the same breath—there is a feedstock pipeline called The Overeducated Underemployed Middle-Aged Man.

We are plentiful. We are moist with regret. We are rich in carbon. We are, in the blunt thermodynamic sense, *energy-dense sadness*.

You could shovel in our failed plans, our unfinished projects, our GitHub repos with three commits and a grand title, our half-learned theorems and abandoned notebooks, our careful moral scruples that have never once paid the rent, our long emails to powerful people that begin “Dear Sir” and end in silence.

You could shovel in our WhatsApp forwards from relatives, the ones that are half propaganda and half spiritual blackmail, and you could watch them dissolve into slurry.

You could add my particular vintage of gloom—North Kolkata, English-medium education, a childhood of books like a staircase to nowhere, a mind trained to be precise in a world that rewards the vague and the loud—and the digesters would purr.

Then the gas rises. The methane is captured. It is scrubbed—hydrogen sulfide removed, moisture condensed—because even in fantasies I believe in maintenance.

And then the methane goes to a generator. The generator makes electricity. The electricity goes to a data center. The data center runs the glowing pantheon of LLMs, those enormous stochastic parrots with their velvet tongues, composing speeches for ministers and captions for weddings and apologies for corporations, all of it lubricated by the invisible combustion of someone’s disappointment.

This is what my mind does when it is both depressed and literate: it turns grief into a diagram.

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251203-WA0001.jpg" 
    caption="The blue flame is hypnotic. It is the dream of relevance."
    layout="iR"
/>

# The Oxygen Leak

The thing about biogas—about any digester—is that it only works if you stop letting oxygen in. Oxygen is the busybody aunt who ruins the whole party. Methanogens, those archaea with their ancient, quiet competence, do not want oxygen. They want darkness and patience and a steady diet. They want the world to stop fussing and let them metabolize.

There’s a lesson there, of course, and I hate lessons, because they smell like TED Talks and smugness. But the lesson stalks me anyway: my own mind is an oxygen leak.

I cannot just rot. I have to narrate my rotting. I have to annotate it, footnote it, compare it to American culture, relate it to colonial history, drag in an etymology, perform an autopsy while the patient is still insultingly alive.

The city outside provides endless material for this. Kolkata is a palimpsest—a manuscript scraped and overwritten so many times that the older text still bleeds through, ghost-writing the present. A British street plan slapped on older lanes; colonial institutions with postcolonial slogans; marble plaques and broken sidewalks; grand buildings with wiring that looks like nervous tissue exposed.

And everywhere: stories. Each one a tiny anaerobic pocket of decay, producing its own little bubble of gas.

The political class—state and center, whichever jersey they wear this season—feeds on narrative the way methanogens feed on acetate. They take complex reality, chew it into slogans, and burp out certainty. *Certainty* is the most profitable gas in India. Certainty can run engines far bigger than methane.

In Bengal we have our own local theater—our own court jesters and court executioners—our own vocabulary of “development” that somehow never develops the one thing you can’t fake: competence.

And the center, with its grand national mythmaking, its chest-thumping pageantry, its high-definition pieties, plays the same game at larger scale. Different costumes, same stage directions: distract, divide, deify, repeat.

Sometimes I think the real product of politics is not policy but *fatigue*. A population too exhausted to verify anything, too stressed to think slowly, too distracted to notice that the ground beneath them is being quietly sold.

And in that fatigue, the LLMs bloom like algae. They are perfect for a world that wants language without accountability. They will generate a thousand paragraphs of plausible nonsense with the cheerful obedience of a well-trained court scribe. They will say what you want, not what is true, unless you build them—painfully, deliberately, annoyingly—around truth.

That’s the rub, isn’t it. I was trained in computer science, in the old-fashioned sense: logic, constraints, structure, the intoxicating hope that if you define things clearly enough you can make the machine behave.

Then the world pivoted to systems that behave like crowds: statistical, emergent, suggestible, brilliant and unreliable the way a committee is brilliant and unreliable.

And now, the louder people say “AI will change everything,” the more it feels like watching a drunk man promise to build a cathedral because he found a hammer.

None of this is the machine’s fault. The machine does what it does. My bitterness is aimed at the human layer—the managerial, ideological layer—that wants the *appearance* of intelligence without the inconvenience of thinking.

The methane fantasy returns because it is, in a perverse way, honest. It admits that something has to be burned. It admits that energy comes from somewhere. It admits that inputs matter.

A data center is not a cloud; it is a furnace with better marketing.

# The Export of Pathologies

In America—when I lived there, back in the years when I still believed geography could rescue a person—I saw the same basic truth wrapped in better infrastructure. The roads worked. The systems pretended to be neutral. The professionalism was a kind of social lubricant. You could be an odd little foreigner and still get a lease, a job, a coffee, a life.

But even then, beneath the polished surfaces, there was a hunger. America runs on appetite. It consumes people the way an engine consumes fuel. Some people come out as executives. Some come out as ash.

And now—post-2016, post-everything, in this long era of Trumpism whether Trump is in the room or merely haunting it like a persistent odor—the appetite has become a personality. The culture has learned to treat cruelty as entertainment and ignorance as identity.

It is not unique to America, of course. We are all learning this curriculum. We are all being trained, by algorithms and incentives, to prefer outrage to understanding.

But America exports its pathologies with the efficiency of a global brand. If America sneezes, the rest of us catch pneumonia and then argue about whether pneumonia is “anti-national.”

So there I am, in Kolkata, inhaling my city’s winter breath, watching the world’s richest country flirt with authoritarian aesthetics while my own country perfects the art of calling any question a betrayal.

And I think: what is a man like me for?

This is the question I keep circling like a vulture that can’t find a decent carcass.

I am not poor enough to be politically interesting. I am not rich enough to be politically protected. I am not connected enough to be useful. I am not obedient enough to be employable. My virtues—precision, skepticism, candor—are like owning a high-quality umbrella in a town that has outlawed rain.

The economy has become a carnival of performative competence. Job posts read like fiction. “Rockstar.” “Ninja.” “10x.” “Hustle.” These words are not requirements; they are *incantations*. They are meant to summon a young person who has not yet realized that “passion” is often code for “unpaid overtime.”

And the apocalyptic twist is that even the nitwits—my beloved nincompoops, my cherished ninnies—are not safe. The carnival will eat them too. Automation doesn’t discriminate between sincere mediocrity and pretentious mediocrity. It will take your tasks, then your title, then your identity, then it will sell you a subscription to the simulation of your own usefulness.

In that future, my methane plant becomes almost tender. At least it offers a role. At least it says: you are not useless; you are biomass.

# The Blue Flame

I know how grim that is. I know. But depression is the art of accepting grimness as realism. Hypomania, my other uninvited roommate, then swings in and says: *Yes, but make it funny. Make it baroque. Make it science.*

So I start riffing. I start imagining the brochure.

> “Welcome to the Melancholia-to-Methane Initiative. We accept: failed entrepreneurs, disappointed idealists, honest engineers, burnt-out teachers, unrecognized writers, and middle-aged men who keep saying ‘I could have’ as if ‘could have’ were a currency.”

“Drop off your self-pity between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m. Please remove all oxygen. No gods allowed in the digester.”

The digester doesn’t care about ideology. It cares about chemistry.

This is, perhaps, why the idea comforts me: it proposes a universe where rules exist and are enforced. The microbes do not take bribes. The enzymes do not forward WhatsApp rumors. The archaea do not hold press conferences.

They just work.

Sometimes I wish I could be that simple.

But I can’t. I am a human primate with a nervous system that evolved to fear exile, crave status, and invent stories. I live in a city that is itself a story—“City of Joy,” that famous marketing hallucination—and I cannot entirely abandon the longing to be seen as something other than waste.

And this is where my own complicity creeps in, like damp through a wall.

Because I am not merely a victim of the system. I am also, frankly, lazy. Not in the cartoon sense—my mind works like a factory that never shuts down—but in the bodily, executive-function sense. I postpone. I avoid. I let drafts rot. I treat my own life as a document to be revised later, as if later were guaranteed.

I am vain. I want to be right. I want my bitterness to be elegant. I want my insults to sparkle. I want the world to recognize my pain as *well-written* pain, which is a ridiculous desire, and yet there it is, squatting in my psyche like an unpaid tenant.

I am fearful. I fear ordinary failure more than grand failure, which is why grand failure attracts me: it comes with a narrative. Ordinary failure is just you, quietly, not doing the thing.

I tell myself stories about structural injustice—and God knows there is plenty of that, enough to stockpile for decades—but I also use those stories as a blanket. Sometimes the blanket warms. Sometimes it smothers.

So, yes, the methane plant is a fantasy of usefulness. But it is also a fantasy of abdication: a way to imagine that my decline is *productive* rather than merely sad.

And then the city intervenes, as it always does, with something embarrassingly concrete.

A scooter backfires. A dog barks. The neighbor’s TV emits a sermon disguised as entertainment. A mosquito finds the one square centimeter of skin I failed to cover. The practical world insists on its details.

I sit up, irritated, and I think about how methane is actually captured in landfills—pipes driven into mountains of garbage, vacuum systems drawing out gas. It’s not romantic. It’s not philosophical. It’s a maintenance problem. It’s engineering. It’s budgets, corrosion, leak detection, safety protocols, the constant risk of explosion.

In other words: reality.

And I realize, with the faint sting of clarity that depression occasionally grants, that my real complaint is not that I’m compost. We are all compost. *Homo sapiens* is a brief biochemical stunt. The universe is not sentimental about our plans.

My complaint is that the system is *wasteful*.

It wastes human potential the way Kolkata wastes water: everywhere, all the time, with a shrug. It wastes intelligence, sincerity, patience, craft. It rewards loudness. It rewards loyalty to the tribe. It rewards the ability to emit confidence without evidence.

It turns honest people into anxious people, then sells them “mindfulness” as if breathing were a product.

And the reason it can do this is that we have never properly taught people how to think. Not in the slow, methodical, pleasure-of-clarity way. We teach them to pass. We teach them to memorize. We teach them to worship marks. We do not teach them epistemology—the art of knowing what you know and knowing what you don’t. We do not teach them how to be uncertain with dignity.

So they become easy prey: for gurus, for politicians, for scams, for ideologies, for algorithms, for any machine that can mimic certainty.

This is where my own training becomes a kind of curse. I see the cracks. I cannot unsee them.

I watch people treat an LLM’s output as authority, and my brain screams: “It is a probability machine in a costume!”

I watch people treat propaganda as patriotism, and my brain screams: “You are confusing obedience with love!”

I watch the job market turn into a roulette wheel, and my brain screams: “This is not meritocracy; this is musical chairs with better fonts!”

But screaming in your head is not an intervention. It is just another gas.

So what do I do with my gas?

In the fantasy, I burn it. I turn it into electricity. I power the very system that makes me feel obsolete. It’s a perfect tragic loop, a Möbius strip of indignity.

In real life, I do smaller things.

I write. I delete. I rewrite obsessively. I fact-check myself and then forget what I checked. I read a chapter of something serious and then doom-scroll something stupid. I oscillate between wanting to build something and wanting to vanish into the wallpaper.

Some days I can’t stand Kolkata. The filth feels personal, like an insult delivered with bureaucratic consistency. The incompetence feels like a conspiracy, even when it’s just entropy wearing a uniform.

Other days, the city softens. A tea stall glows in the fog like a small, defiant lighthouse. A stray cat sits with the calm arrogance of a minor deity. A man on a bicycle carries vegetables as if performing an ancient ritual of persistence. Someone says “দাদা” in that casual Kolkata way that makes you feel, briefly, like you belong to a species.

Belonging is a narcotic. It doesn’t solve anything, but it changes the flavor of despair.

And I realize—again, not as a moral, not as a poster slogan, but as a quiet mechanical truth—that my relationship with this city is itself anaerobic. I keep returning to it because it is sealed. It excludes oxygen. It keeps my past from oxidizing into something else.

If I left, I might become someone different. Different is risky. Different requires effort. Different might fail in new ways.

So I stay, and I rot, and I write about rotting as if writing were a form of composting.

Maybe it is.

Compost is, at base, a choreography of organisms breaking down what once seemed solid. It is life feeding on death feeding on life. It is not noble. It is not tragic. It is the normal metabolism of the planet.

I am not special. My sadness is not special. My anger is not special. My vulgar metaphors are not special, though I do try to make them entertaining because what else is a man to do with his own interior sewage?

But I am, inconveniently, alive. Which means I still have choices, even small ones, even feeble ones that do not look heroic on LinkedIn.

Tonight, for instance, I can choose not to let my self-loathing metastasize into fantasies of harming “people like me,” as if I were some petty god of eugenics. That road leads nowhere but moral rot.

I can choose to keep the satire pointed upward—at power, at hypocrisy, at the cheerful cruelty of systems—and keep the tenderness pointed inward, even when I don’t feel I deserve it.

I can choose to make my methane into a small flame rather than a bomb.

The fan keeps complaining. The brown air keeps pressing against the windows like a dirty palm. Somewhere, a loud man is telling other loud men what to believe.

I reach for my laptop. I open a draft. I stare at the blinking cursor—the tiniest, dumbest heartbeat—and for a moment it looks like a little pilot light.

Not hope, exactly. Not salvation. Nothing cinematic.

Just a small, stubborn blue flame, fed by whatever I’ve got left, in a city that loves to call itself joy and rarely bothers to earn the title.


# File: src/lib/posts/metallic-phallus-adjustment-syndrome.md

---
title: "Metallic Phallus Adjustment Syndrome"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20260104-WA0006.jpg"
date: 2026-01-13
description: "Why modern tech adoption feels like training for chrome-plated ass penetration and how nobody even blinks anymore."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "orange"
---


<Pi src="IMG-20260104-WA0006.jpg" />



It started, as most awakenings do, with a violent and unconsensual fart.

Not the dainty polite ones that sneak past the buttcrack like a bored librarian late for lunch—no, this was a tectonic plate shift, a gastric Krakatoa, a gluteal demon clearing its throat in the echo chamber of a dimly lit bathroom at 3:47 am while I was squatting, slightly sideways, trying to balance my phone against the soap dish to read about how GPT-5.3 could now detect your sarcasm, your fetishes, and your insecure attachment style all while generating a legal brief *and* optimizing your blood sugar based on your retinal scan. From the toilet camera it installed last Tuesday.

And I remember thinking—mid-wipe, hand half-extended toward a roll of two-ply that had the textural integrity of termite-chewed papyrus—*people are gonna get used to this too, aren’t they?*

We always do. Like dogs slowly trained to enjoy the tickle of stainless steel up their sphincters if it vibrates and gives us dopamine points. Like some smarmy Zuckerberg clone flashing that simian grin while he explains that butt-implanted mesh routers are the next logical step in home WiFi.

We accept it.

We fucking thank them for it.

We update firmware while it's still lodged between the cheeks.

Not me, though.

I still use a rice cooker with a busted lid, a rusted spoon with a jagged edge that sometimes slices the inside of my mouth when I stir tea, and an old desktop fan that sounds like a Buddhist exorcism every time it rotates past true north. And yet here I am, surrounded by young twats who moan about GPT not generating perfect latex equations for their chemistry homework while double-fisting bubble tea and dopamine like their bodies have any intention of surviving past thirty.

The other day, a man half my age asked me why I hadn’t installed a “prostate fitness tracker.”

A fucking what?

Apparently it’s a thing now. A Bluetooth-enabled anal bead with haptic feedback that pings your Apple Watch if it detects “pelvic tension or antisocial thought patterns.”

“Totally normal,” he says. “Game-changer, uncle.”

*Uncle.*

You want me to shove a charging port up my backdoor so Tim Cook can harvest my peristaltic rhythm?

I wanted to throw my flip-flop at his face and scream the names of every extinct butterfly from the Sunderbans but instead I just stared, mouth slightly agape, like I was trying to remember if I had eaten dinner or if I was still hungry or if all hunger was just a metaphor for some other loss.

Because it’s not the tech I hate.

It’s the *acclimation*.

The instantaneous, lube-free, guiltless acceptance of the next invasive novelty.

One moment it’s ChatGPT writing cover letters, the next it’s Amazon Prime shoving deep-learning suppositories into your dog to detect sadness before it barks. And everyone adjusts faster than their attention span can reload TikTok. You show them an AI that can generate Beethoven’s 10th and they yawn, unless it also predicts their ex’s menstrual cycle or gives them stock tips while moaning in a sultry Japanese accent.

Do you remember what it was like to *not know*?

To wait?

To wonder?

I do.

I remember clicking a button and waiting for the dial-up to screech like a robot being castrated with pliers. I remember holding books—paper ones—and licking my thumb to turn pages that had been shat on by time. I remember asking questions and not finding answers. I remember living in the suspense, the rot, the sexy slowness of uncertainty.

And now?

Now I get porn targeted to my childhood traumas.

Now Siri whispers bedtime stories about financial precarity.

Now the fridge gaslights me about my BMI.

I have lived long enough to see data become lube, and lube become mandatory.

And no one blinks.

You show them an AI-powered colonoscopy drone that flies up your rectum while playing Chopin and telling you your credit score, and some chuckle-fuck at the startup accelerator says “Oh nice, does it have a freemium plan?”

We used to fear the Matrix. Now we want it to sync with our sleep cycle and pay for Netflix. And you know what’s most depressing? The ones who *resist* are even dumber. They think buying a copper pyramid and deleting Instagram makes them immune. You’re still breathing the same surveillance particles, dipshit. Your aura isn’t gonna deflect 5G butt rays.

And the worst part?

*I still participate.*

I rant and rail and hiss and moan and yet I still ask ChatGPT to help me remember what the third cranial nerve does. (It’s oculomotor, you fuckwit. Controls eye movement and a bit of pupil stuff. You knew this once.)

I still check my phone in bed before my dick even knows it’s morning.

I still swipe my metaphorical asshole for updates, waiting to be told who I am.

I am complicit.

We are all complicit.

This is not a resistance fantasy. This is a prostate exam by the future, and we’re clenching in the wrong direction.

So next time someone asks you why you look so dazed, so vague, so vacant, don’t tell them it’s depression, or aging, or your thyroid.

Just tell them your firmware’s out of date.

Tell them the metallic phallus in your soul-port got upgraded overnight and now your dreams lag by 1.2 seconds.

Tell them you’re waiting for the patch.

Tell them you’ll cry later.

Tell them you came, but you’re not sure where.

And if all else fails, just fart loud enough to drown the panic.

Because in the end, the only proof of being alive that the machines can’t copyright yet is the irregular, lonely, beautifully stupid poetry of a human fart echoing in a tiled shithole while the future politely asks to be let in through your backdoor.



# File: src/lib/posts/microbial-mirage.md

---
title: "The Microbial Mirage"
date: "2025-12-25"
description: "The cake arrives in a crinkled cardboard coffin, taped like evidence. But the real labour of that cake was performed by small beings."
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251226-WA0015.jpg"
category: "science"
color: "blue"
published: true
---
<Yc />
<Pi
    src="IMG-20251226-WA0015.jpg" 
    caption="A chemical approximation of joy"
/>

<Yt src="https://youtu.be/CDO8DeyAUYY?si=f9OSCDL5Ob0lVoZV" />

I can still smell the dry paraffin of those old candles—white, brittle, cheap. Not birthday candles, not votive candles, but the ones that came wrapped in translucent wax paper and sat unused in kitchen drawers till a power cut, a death, or Christmas. They were never straight. Always bent. Like they'd survived a heatwave or just couldn't be arsed to stand upright. My mother would straighten them, laboriously, over boiling water. Not for Jesus, no—we were Hindus with no formal affiliation—but for the ritual. Or the aesthetic. Or maybe just because that’s what you did with cake in the eighties.

The cake, too, was terrible. Compressed, brick-like, with candied fruit bits that looked like someone had murdered a jellybean. It came in a box with cartoon holly and tasted of dry rum, wet sugar, and the stale morality of Western import. But we laid it out, like an offering, in front of that shoddy, fluorescent-lit framed reproduction of Leonardo da Vinci’s The Last Supper—a cheap offset print stuck in a landscape frame. The Apostles, in that version, looked vaguely Bengali and hungry.

And yes, we lit the candles, placed them in front, and did not—under any circumstance—eat the cake until this quasi-Christian puja was performed. It was *ritual without doctrine*, the very best kind. Nobody knew why. Nobody asked. Least of all me. I was in class six or seven, and like all children in a Hindu family in Calcutta, I accepted that rituals were just part of the ontological wallpaper.

Looking back, of course, I see the whole thing as a baroque act of misdirected syncretism—colonial hangover meets middle-class mimicry, with a twist of Doordarshan kitsch. But at the time, it was just what you *did* before cake. You gave it to Jesus first. The inferior Jesus. The pixelated Jesus. The Jesus who looked like he'd been photocopied too many times and now resided among our family portraits as a kind of bureaucratic mistake.

### I Know Too Much Now

That’s the problem. I know *too much* now. And not in a good way—not the generous knowing of a wide-eyed physicist in love with quarks and uncertainty, but the bitter, tight-jawed knowing of a man who’s seen too many spreadsheets and too few miracles. I know that nostalgia is just a function of trauma plus time. I know that the mitochondria in my cells were inherited from my mother and her mother and her mother, all the way back to some woman squatting by the Ganges whose name nobody remembers.

And I know that Christmas in Calcutta has become performative in the worst sense. *Park Street is lit like an Instagram whore.* Everyone and their flared-jeans-wearing cousin flocks there with DSLRs and no discernible soul. The fairy lights are brighter, yes, but the faces are dimmer. Plastic snowflakes hang on a city that hasn’t seen snow since Gondwana split from Pangaea.

I don’t go anymore. Not because I hate it. I mean, I do—but that's not why. I don’t go because the person who *used to* find magic in it is gone. Dead, in the way that childhoods die. Not with funerals, but with layers. Layers of knowing. Layers of disappointment. Layers of adult.

I sit in my room now, curtains drawn. A room that used to be a study, then became a storeroom, then became a holding pen for the life I never quite managed to lead. And the room—like a good partner—never asks questions. It does not wonder why I haven’t shaved or why I talk back to the tea cup. It simply holds me, dim and indifferent, like an old shoe you refuse to throw away.

### The Quantum of Cake

You know, there’s a weird quantum aspect to memories like this. The act of observing them changes them. They crystallize into something they never were. If I poke at that memory of the 1983 Christmas cake, I start to remember other things. And I remember not knowing what that meant. And not caring. Because knowledge had not yet ruined joy.

Science tells me that nostalgia is limbic system activity tinged with serotonergic decay. A kind of chemical reckoning. It’s the brain trying to reconcile the sharpness of the past with the bluntness of the now. But that doesn’t stop it from feeling like a real place. Like I could go back there if I just walked far enough in the right direction.

### Not This Year

This year, I did not light any candles. I did not buy any cake for Christmas but just because I wanted to sample the bread from the breed of confectioners that are seasonal. I did not even walk down to Bowbazar, where they sell the Chinese fairy lights that blink like caffeinated anxiety. I stayed home. I looked at the crack in my wall that looks like a pussy. I boiled tea. I sat very still. I remembered.

And maybe that’s enough.

A room. A kettle. A ghost. And the quiet certainty that this, too, is ritual. The cake that I bought arrived in a crinkled cardboard coffin, taped like evidence, and when I tore it open the first thing that hit me was not “Christmas” so much as *a chemical approximation of joy*—vanillin (the budget cousin of vanilla), a smack of rum essence that never met a barrel, and that sweet, slightly metallic fog that hangs around anything with too much glycerin and too little shame.

The icing has the texture of wall putty left out in a Calcutta winter—soft, reluctant, vaguely damp—while the inside is studded with fluorescent “fruit” that looks like it escaped from a cheap aquarium: green cubes, red slivers, orange bits, all of them suspiciously immortal. I hold a slice near the tube-light, as one does when one has an underfunded scientific temperament, and I can almost see the economics: an artisanal cake, yes, handcrafted, yes, lovingly, yes—by which we mean a woman in a back room with a hairnet in theory, a mixing bowl in practice, and the municipal water supply as a kind of philosophical question.

Outside, the city is doing its annual theatre. A little tinsel, a little Mariah, a little Santa-in-sweat. People stroll Park Street and behave as if looking festive is the same thing as being alive, as if a photograph with a paper crown can substitute for whatever it is we keep failing to nurture the other eleven months. Somewhere a loudspeaker is murdering “Jingle Bells” with the persistence of a bureaucrat stamping forms. Somewhere someone has decided that the correct proof of cheer is to buy a cake big enough to require structural engineering.

And the cake, the cake is the highlight—*the* highlight—of Christmas in this city that otherwise specializes in long, slow disappointment, because it’s portable celebration. You can carry it home. You can show it to relatives. You can slice it into social legitimacy.

It is also, I suspect, a microbiological crime scene.

# The Great Calcutta Cake Mirage

<Pi 
src="IMG-20251225-WA0010.jpg"
layout="iL"
caption="Calcutta loves a symbol"
size={0.5}
/>

Calcutta loves a symbol. The city is a museum of symbols that have outlived their contents—columns without empires, statues without conviction, slogans without comprehension. So the Christmas cake becomes a kind of edible emblem: proof that you participated, proof that you belong, proof that you were modern for a moment, proof that your household contains “culture” (which, in Indian English, often means *purchased things that suggest you are not desperate*).

The irony is that the real labour of that cake—the deep work, the alchemy, the transformation from wet flour-sadness to something fragrant and structured—was not performed by any saint, chef, grandmother, influencer, or church committee.

It was performed by small beings.

Not small in the sentimental way we say “small” when we mean “cute,” but small in the brutal, accurate way we mean when we talk about bacteria and yeasts and moulds—organisms that don’t care about your surname, your flag, your caste certificate, your religion, your nationalist tantrums, your carefully curated nonsense. They have no ethnicity. They have no country. They don’t even have the courtesy to be visible.

They just metabolize.

And yet we insist on turning the cake into an identity performance. We talk about “our tradition,” “our heritage,” “authentic plum cake,” “secret family recipe,” as if the universe is waiting breathlessly to know whether you used cashews or almonds. Meanwhile, the actual workers—the ones producing carbon dioxide bubbles to lift dough, the ones generating ethanol and esters that smell like warmth, the ones acidifying batter to keep pathogens at bay—continue their quiet labour without credit, without ceremony, without Instagram.

We praise the box. We ignore the factory.

# Fermentation: The Unseen Republic

There is a word that behaves like a tiny documentary: *fermentation*. It comes from Latin *fervere*, “to boil,” because to ancient eyes a fermenting vat looked like it was alive—bubbling, seething, exhaling. Which was correct, except the life doing the boiling was not divine inspiration but microbial respiration and chemical kinetics.

The star of this show is often **Saccharomyces cerevisiae**—a yeast whose name is basically a résumé: “sugar-fungus of beer.” Give it sugar, warmth, a little water, and it does what it has been doing for longer than our moral panics have been fashionable: it eats glucose and produces ethanol and carbon dioxide, plus a bouquet of side-products—esters, aldehydes, higher alcohols—that make bread smell like bread and not like damp cardboard.

CO₂ inflates dough like a soft political lie: airy, persuasive, structurally essential. Ethanol mostly evaporates in baking, but it leaves behind flavour and, more importantly, proof that something genuinely transformed. This is the part people forget: fermentation is not decoration. It is a *phase change* in reality. Before fermentation, you have ingredients. After fermentation, you have an emergent thing with new properties—texture, aroma, digestibility, shelf life.

In a sense, fermentation is the most honest kind of “community work” because it is literally many small agents following local rules and producing a coherent global structure. No committee. No slogans. No “we are proud to announce.” Just distributed labour and a loaf at the end.

And the microbes don’t ask to be thanked. They don’t even know you exist. Which is, frankly, refreshing.

# “Plum Cake” and Other Lies We Eat Happily

Calcutta’s Christmas cake is often called “plum cake,” which is charming, because it usually contains no plums. The “plum” is a historical dodge: a nineteenth-century habit of calling raisins and currants “plums” in certain English-speaking contexts, a linguistic fossil that wandered into colonial kitchens and never left. So we keep saying “plum cake” the way we keep saying “dial” a phone or “tape” a recording—words surviving as ghosts of old technology.

There’s another lie embedded in the modern artisanal economy: “handmade” is treated like a synonym for “safe” and “pure,” when it frequently means “unregulated” and “done in a room where the local fauna has voting rights.” I don’t say this as a snob; I say this as someone who has lived long enough in South Calcutta’s boondocks to understand that hygiene here is often an *aspiration* rather than a condition. We talk about purity obsessively—ritual purity, dietary purity, national purity—yet the kitchen counter is a damp democracy of crumbs, fingers, flies, and existential resignation.

The cake becomes the festive highlight precisely because it is a ready-made miracle. You don’t see the process. You see the finished object. It arrives like a gift from “tradition,” which is just marketing with ancestors.

But process is where the real world hides.

Bread is flour plus water plus time plus microbes. Beer is grain plus water plus microbes plus patience. Many liquors are sugar sources plus microbes plus distillation (which is another kind of selective honesty: you take the chaotic fermented soup and concentrate its intoxicating signal). Indian dishes that we treat as “just cooking” are often microbial collaborations in disguise: batter for **idli** and **dosa** turned airy and tangy by lactic acid bacteria and yeasts; **dahi** set by *Lactobacillus* and friends; pickles that survive because salt and acid create a microbial bouncer at the door; **kanji** that tastes like winter sunlight filtered through bacteria.

Even the things we call “fresh” are often ancient microbial arrangements. Your gut is an ecosystem. Your skin is a landscape. Your food is a temporary parliament of organisms negotiating conditions.

And then we have the audacity to plaster all this with religion and nationalism, as if the yeast is checking your voter ID.

# A Sanskrit Line I Don’t Believe In (But I Understand)

I am an atheist, which in India means I am either “confused,” “angry,” or “Westernized,” like skepticism is a foreign import that arrived with the railways. But there are old lines that still land—not as revelation, but as anthropology, as the kind of accidental wisdom a civilization sometimes stumbles into.

अन्नाद्भवन्ति भूतानि  
(*annād bhavanti bhūtāni*)

“From food, beings arise.”

It’s from the *Bhagavad Gita*, and I don’t take it as cosmic truth, but as a neat observation: food is not just fuel; it’s infrastructure. It’s chemistry that becomes society. It’s agriculture that becomes politics. It’s fermentation that becomes ritual.

What the verse doesn’t say—but what my cake slice is screaming—is that *from microbes, food arises*. Or at least, from microbes, food becomes tolerable, tasty, safe, storable, celebratable. The smallest beings do the biggest civilizing work. They domesticated us as much as we domesticated them.

We didn’t invent bread so much as we learned how to host yeast.

# The Great Festive Bullshit Overlay

<Yt src="https://youtu.be/0XzU_q_DyDw?si=uit3M_J6oTANQvRk" />

Here’s the part where I as an iconoclastic misanthrope become unbearable, so let me at least be accurate while doing it. Every Christmas in Calcutta is a strange colonial hangover, soaked in rum cake and indigestion. The city decks itself in fairy lights and fake snow, but the stomachs beneath those sweaters are brewing full-blown gastric revolts. People gorge on plum cake thick with dried fruits soaked in cheap alcohol, roast meats their intestines haven’t seen all year, and sugary drinks disguised as festive cheer. Hospitals quietly prepare for the annual uptick in emergency admissions—hypertensive crises, sudden spikes in diabetes, gallbladder tantrums—because when Christ is born, Calcutta eats like it’s the Last Supper. Add to that the celebratory tippling—wine for some, whiskey for most—and the night ends with a predictable spike in drunk driving, sirens replacing carols. Then there’s the trash: heaps of wrapping paper, broken baubles, plastic Santas with amputated limbs, all dumped unceremoniously by morning. Park Street glitters, but behind the shimmer is the slow constipation of a city hoarding its own debris—joy, yes, but also cholesterol, chaos, and crap.

Perhaps like the rest I should be festive and cheery, but I can't seem to enjoy the shot glass of way too short-term thinking—this compulsion to gorge, to light things up, to pretend for one blurry night that none of it matters. The debts don’t disappear with tinsel. The loneliness doesn’t shrink with fairy lights. And the planet certainly doesn’t sigh in relief because someone wore a Santa hat and ate six plum cakes. There’s something obscene about celebrating in a city that’s already choking—on its own noise, on plastic-wrapped consumer joy, on the rising bile of comorbid middle age. I step outside and see the streets littered with the aftermath of cheer: broken ornaments, empty liquor bottles, kids vomiting sugar, grown men urinating behind church walls. And I wonder, not bitterly but wearily, if the real miracle of Christmas is how neatly we’ve managed to gift-wrap our collective decay in tinfoil and call it tradition.
 
Christmas in Calcutta—like many imported festivals—has been metabolized into a consumer ritual. It is less about theology than about aesthetics: lights, cake, music, shopping, the intoxicating permission to be briefly theatrical. The city doesn’t need Jesus to enjoy a party; it needs an excuse. The excuse changes; the impulse stays.

The cake functions as a secular sacrament. It’s shared. It’s sliced. It’s offered. It’s photographed. It’s used to mark time: *this is the week we pretend things are okay*.

But the cake’s real miracle is not the season. It is fermentation. It is the fact that little organisms, indifferent and unbribable, did their job.

Which makes our overlay of identity—the “my festival,” “your festival,” “our culture,” “their culture”—look even more absurd. Because the underlying engine of celebration is universal biochemistry. Yeast doesn’t hate. Lactobacillus doesn’t discriminate. They do not form mobs. They do not demand loyalty. They do not write bad poetry about the nation.

They just convert substrates.

It’s embarrassing, really, how much moral drama we drape over processes that are, at root, thermodynamics with personality.

And, yes, I am aware of the irony: I am sitting here moralizing over a cake while the world burns in much more consequential ways. But this is how the mind works when it has read too many books and lived too many disappointments—it takes a small thing and uses it as a portal to the whole damned system.

# A Private Experiment, A Quiet Rebellion

Somewhere between my resentment and my tenderness, I do a small, almost comical act of defiance: I stop buying the festive miracle and start courting the process.

Not heroically. Not in a “back to the roots” performance. Just privately, like a man trying to regain a little agency in a life that often feels like it is being managed by external forces—family expectations, economic gravity, city chaos, the relentless noise of other people’s certainty.

I take a jar. Warm water. A spoon of flour. A pinch of sugar. I add nothing sacred. I say no prayer. I cover it loosely, because microbes enjoy oxygen at the start, like shy guests arriving early.

And then I wait.

By morning there is a faint tang. By evening a few bubbles. By the next day a living smell—something between green apples and damp grain and promise. I am not “making” anything in the grand human sense. I am creating conditions, and life shows up to do what life does.

It’s the closest thing I know to honest optimism: not belief in progress, not faith in humanity, but confidence that if you set the constraints correctly, small agents will coordinate into something coherent. A loaf. A batter. A drink. A meal. A moment of sweetness that doesn’t require a festival committee.

I look back at the purchased cake slice—its glossy icing, its immortal fruit, its air of manufactured nostalgia—and it suddenly feels like a metaphor for so much else: the finished object worshipped, the process ignored, the workers unseen, the branding loud, the truth quiet.

Outside, someone bursts fireworks in a damp lane, the sky flinches, and my little jar of yeast does not care.

It just keeps bubbling, like a tiny, indifferent laugh at all our festive bullshit.


# File: src/lib/posts/mirror-me.md

---
title: "The mirror me"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251221-WA0022.jpg"
date: '2026-01-04'
description: "The mirror in my bathroom..."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "orange" 

---

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251221-WA0022.jpg" 
    caption="The mirror me"
/>

The mirror in my bathroom has the matte patience of a government file. It’s not even properly a mirror anymore, more like a reflective rumor: the silver backing has blistered in constellations, the edges have gone sepia, and if I lean too close I can see my breath briefly cloud it like a small, private monsoon. The light is cruel in the way cheap tube-lights are cruel—flat, municipal, without the decency of shadow—so the face that arrives is not an event but a verdict: tired skin, hollowing under the eyes, the mouth set in that permanent Bengali skepticism that looks like annoyance even when it’s just… thinking.

And yet the mind doing the looking—this is the problem, this is always the problem—shows up in the mirror wearing an old, overconfident shirt from the 1980s, sleeves rolled, hair still obedient, the whole internal posture of a boy who believes adulthood is a crisp suit you step into one fine day, like a Bollywood montage, and then you simply start earning respect and cholesterol. *Pollyanna*, yes—let’s call it that, because the word itself sounds like a plastic doll you could buy at New Market and regret by evening. The mind is still auditioning for the role of “bright young man,” while the face has been promoted without consent into “middle-aged uncle who has opinions about everything.”

The mirror is a basic optical device, obviously—light bounces, the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection, physics applauds itself—yet it behaves like philosophy. It doesn’t show me “me.” It shows me a negotiation between expectation and photons. If brains were honest, the mirror would display a caption: this is your predictive model failing in real time. The boy in my head predicts a certain face because he has not updated his priors since cassette tapes and Doordarshan; the world returns a different dataset, and the error signal arrives as disgust, comedy, grief—choose your poison.

There’s a neat piece of brain trivia people love to misuse at dinner parties: mirror neurons, those little theatrical cells that light up when you act and when you watch someone else act, as if the brain can’t resist doing a bit of method acting. Every WhatsApp philosopher uses this to say we are all connected, love is science, clap clap. But the darker mirror is not empathy; it’s self-recognition. The brain watching itself is like a dog trying to bite its own tail: furious sincerity, ridiculous mechanics. I look at my face and what I’m really seeing is a model of myself—constructed, maintained, defended—being forced to reconcile with a thing called time, which is not a metaphor, not a lesson, not even particularly Indian, just the indifferent bookkeeping of entropy.

People say “adolescence” as if it means acne and mood swings, but it comes from a Latin root about growing toward something—adolescere—like a plant leaning to light. Nobody mentions the unfunny possibility that some of us grow toward a fantasy and then just… stop, stuck reaching forever, stiff as a cheap plastic bougainvillea. I’ve met men who are sixty and still living inside the thirteen-year-old’s courtroom where they are either praised or punished, either the hero or the fool. That inner boy doesn’t retire; he just becomes a cynical accountant, still obsessed with fairness, still keeping score of every insult since 1992.

I used to think this was a personal flaw. Now I suspect it’s a feature of the whole education system: we train people to perform cleverness the way circus bears are trained to ride bicycles. You jump through exam hoops, you learn the posture of certainty, you become a “bright student,” you get rewarded for sounding right rather than being right, and you carry that posture into adulthood like an inherited spine. Then one day you stand in front of a mirror in the unfashionable fringes of South Calcutta—where the streets are dusty and ambitious in the worst way, and the buildings are always mid-construction, like everyone lives inside a perpetual excuse—and you realize nobody is grading you anymore. No invigilator. No marks. Just your face, looking like it has been doing unpaid overtime for years. No one cares to even know if I’m diseased, wounded, rotting, or dead—except a mother in the northern fringes who religiously collects her good morning and good night, with those little emoticons lined up like marigolds on a cracked windowsill, bright enough to pass for love, soft enough to hide the wounded reality. A good thing my posts are boring and long, really—dense as old census books, unscrollable as a Government of India PDF—because that way no one will know, and more importantly no one will even have to know. The casual reader will flee after three sentences, the well-meaning acquaintance will “save it for later” and never return, and the algorithms will take one look and decide I’m commercially unviable as a human being. Which is perfect. Let the suffering be hidden in plain sight, wrapped in clauses and parentheses like contraband; let it sit there unread, unliked, unexamined—my private little quarantine where I can admit the truth without anyone showing up with advice, pity, or the worse contagion of forced optimism.
 
And here the postcolonial part of my brain clears its throat—because it always does, like a professor who can’t help himself. The mirror is a European object in the way the calendar is a European object: a system for telling you where you are in time, and therefore where you should be in life. Colonial modernity didn’t just bring railways and laws; it brought the idea that your life can be audited. You should have achieved X by age Y. You should have become “somebody.” (As if being a body wasn’t already sufficient work.) Macaulay gave us an education designed to create clerks; we kept the clerk-soul and swapped the Empire for newer logos. Now the clerk in my head stands before the mirror and files a complaint: why has the product aged? why is the output not matching the brochure?

I’m aware, before anyone sends me a moral lecture disguised as concern, that this is not unique to Bengali men. But Bengali men do have a particular talent for turning private disappointments into public theories, preferably over tea, preferably with footnotes. We can’t just be sad; we have to be sad with citations. We can’t just be aging; we have to be aging *correctly*, with a properly articulated resentment about the decline of standards. The old North Calcutta archetype—the bhadralok with his books and his bruised dignity—has a whole mythology of self-respect, and if you don’t fit the mythology, you compensate by sharpening your tongue until it could shave.

*Crusty*, I called myself. It’s a good word because it’s honest about texture. Middle age is not just an age; it’s a layer. You accumulate little shells: habits, disappointments, the faint mineral deposits of all the times you had to swallow something you didn’t believe. Some people become smooth with age—those lucky creatures who forgive or forget or monetize their pain into motivational podcasts. Others become crusty, and not even in a charming sourdough way, more like the kettle in a Calcutta kitchen that has seen too much hard water and not enough descaling.

There’s a strange hypocrisy in my own disgust, because I despise performative intellectualism while performing it with Olympic enthusiasm. I can hear myself—listen to this fellow, he’s doing etymology in the bathroom—yet I keep going, because the alternative is silence, and silence is when the mirror wins. I’m a rationalist, an atheist, a man allergic to spiritual branding, and yet I understand the appeal: religion offers you a flattering narrative about your inner youth. The soul never ages. The essence is eternal. The body is just a temporary rental. Very convenient, like a cosmic return policy. My version of that comfort is science, which offers no comfort at all, only explanations—beautiful, pitiless explanations that do not care about my nostalgia.

Sometimes, if I’m in a slightly hypomanic mood, the mirror becomes a lab instrument. I start thinking about it like an interferometer: two waves overlap—what I feel I am and what I appear to be—and the pattern of bright and dark bands is my mood. When the phases align, I can almost laugh: yes, this is me, this worn face, this stubborn brain, this odd little life cobbled together from books and setbacks and tea. When they don’t align, it’s a kind of private vertigo. I feel “young” in the way a software program feels “new”—the core logic unchanged—while the hardware has been dropped too many times.

Then the depressive clarity arrives, not dramatic, not poetic, just plain: nobody is coming to validate this. There is no grand reveal. The self is not a hidden treasure. It’s a maintenance problem. You keep the system running, you patch bugs, you manage energy. You try not to let the whole thing crash.

Outside, the neighborhood wakes up with its usual noisy conviction. A vendor calls out, a scooter coughs, someone argues loudly about something that will never be resolved. Calcutta, eternal in its confidence that volume is a form of truth. I look again, and the mirror shows me not an archetype or a tragedy or a failed prodigy, but a man standing in a small room with bad lighting, alive, unglamorous, still capable of noticing things.

I wipe the glass with the corner of my towel, leaving a smear that makes my face look briefly like an impressionist painting, kinder than realism, and in that blur I find the only defiance I can reliably afford: to keep looking without pretending it’s noble.

My breath fogs the mirror again, a soft white bloom, and for a second I disappear completely—finally improved by subtraction—then the glass clears, and there I am, back to being an unpaid clerk of my own existence. And then I remember Shyam in Shirshendu Mukhopadhyay’s *Ghunpoka*—that depressed man returning again and again to his little shaving mirror, as if repetition could coax out a different fate, as if the glass might one day confess a loophole. I find myself drifting into his terrified shape, the same small ritual, the same compulsive checking, the same grim bargaining with reflection—going slowly sadder and mad, not with fireworks but with the quiet, steady efficiency of a worm in wood.
 


# File: src/lib/posts/moments-of-soft-fucking-delusion.md

---
title: "Musical Moments"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20260104-WA0008.jpg"
date: 2026-01-14
description: "Nostalgia as erectile dysfunction, memory as piss-soaked regret, and YouTube songs as little time-traveling turds in a life that smells of burnt rice, desperation, and faint BPL-brand soap."
category: 'videos'
published: true
color: "orange"
---

<Yc />

<Pi src="IMG-20260104-WA0008.jpg" />




The day starts with my tea pan screaming like it’s being exorcised, metal on flame, water threatening to mutiny, while my head does that familiar pre-dawn thing where it inventories every mistake I’ve ever made and a few I haven’t gotten around to yet, and I’m standing there scratching the inside of my elbow like a nervous chimp, thinking not about sex or love or any of the usual pornographic lies we sell ourselves, but about whether the song I’m about to play will shut this fucking noise off for five minutes or just rearrange it into a more melodic form of suffering.

<Yt src="https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLGAT_DYBcNKAqWUYLBg8HtqFZmHHtceys&si=xyPkFWD343cnfRT6" />

The songs some of them generations before I happened, I return to—because I always return, like a loyal dog or a moron—aren’t really about romance, not in the way people think when they hear me muttering along to some soft Hindi nonsense from the late nineties. They’re not postcards from failed affairs or ghosted women or beds that went cold. They’re older than that. Pre-sexual. Pre-disaster. They belong to a time when my brain hadn’t yet declared war on itself, when bipolarity was still a rumor, a distant thunderclap, not the full fucking monsoon dumping depression straight into my skull with no drainage plan.

These songs are about childhood, or at least about a slice of life when I wasn’t constantly negotiating with my own chemistry like a hostage-taker with mood swings. Back when the worst thing I worried about was homework and whether my socks matched, not whether today would be a “can’t get out of bed” day or a “pace the room like a deranged cocksucker” day. When I listen now, it’s not nostalgia for a person; it’s nostalgia for neurological quiet. For the absence of static.

Sometimes it works. That’s the maddening part. Sometimes a familiar intro—three notes, a breath of tanpura, a voice slightly off-key in a way that feels human—lands just right and my mind takes a break. Not a cure. Not enlightenment. Just a pause. Like someone hit mute on the inner narrator who keeps yelling that I’m a useless turd wasting oxygen. For a few minutes I can sit there, tea cooling, balls sticking to my thigh, and feel almost ordinary. Almost unbroken. Almost like a man instead of a walking DSM footnote.

Other times it does fuck-all. Worse than fuck-all. The music plays and my brain folds inward like a cheap lawn chair, and all I want to do is curl into the familiar discomfort, knees pulled up, eyes shut, marinating in that dense, syrupy sadness that feels perversely safe because at least it’s predictable. Depression, for all its cruelty, is consistent. It shows up on time. It doesn’t improvise. It’s the most reliable relationship I’ve ever had.

But when I reach for music—when I decide, against evidence, that sound might help—I don’t experiment. I don’t go hunting for new artists or fresh experiences like some wellness influencer with a beard and a podcast. I knock on the same doors. Again. And again. And again. The same playlists. The same songs. The same emotional furniture arranged just so. Because novelty requires energy, and energy is a luxury item I haven’t been able to afford since my brain decided to become a hostile foreign power.

There’s something almost pathological about it. Like a rat pressing the same lever even after the cheese is gone, hoping muscle memory might summon a miracle. I know exactly which songs might work, which ones sometimes work, which ones absolutely won’t but I play them anyway out of spite or boredom or masochism. These tracks aren’t memories; they’re tools. Blunt ones. Worn down. Handles slick with years of use. I grip them anyway because what else is there—mindfulness? Prayer? A brisk walk while chanting affirmations like “I am not a useless sack of shit”? Please.

People like to talk about music as transcendence. As healing. As art lifting us above the mess. That’s horseshit. For me, music is more like a dirty rag you press against a bleeding wound—not to cure it, just to keep the blood off the floor for a while. It’s chemical. Pavlovian. Sound waves nudging neurotransmitters like a bored technician poking malfunctioning equipment with a stick. Sometimes the machine hums. Sometimes it sparks and dies.

The science types will tell you about the hippocampus, about memory encoding, about how music bypasses certain cognitive checkpoints and plugs straight into emotional circuits like an illegal cable connection. Fine. Whatever. All I know is that these songs smell like old classrooms and bus rides and afternoons when time didn’t feel like a loaded gun pressed to my temple. They smell like dust and pencil shavings and the specific quiet of being young enough not to know what’s coming.

And I keep them close because the present is a crumbling façade held together with habit and low expectations. I still don’t know who the fuck I am. I’m not becoming anything. I’m not evolving. I’m maintaining. Barely. The music doesn’t remind me of who I was with—it reminds me of who I was before my own mind turned into a bureaucratic nightmare, requiring forms and approvals and apologies just to feel okay for an hour.

There’s no growth here. No arc. Just repetition. Same doors. Same knocks. Same hope that one of them will open onto that brief, ridiculous silence where the internal shouting stops and I can sit with my tea and my tired body and not actively hate the fact that I exist.

And when it doesn’t work, when the song fades and the noise rushes back in like a tide full of broken glass, I just sit there anyway, staring at the wall, humming the tune under my breath, because even failure is better when it’s familiar, and at this age, familiarity is the closest thing I have to comfort, even if it smells faintly of old socks, regret, and reheated rice.


# File: src/lib/posts/mousefuckers-mickey-to-mengele.md

That’s the thing about us and mice.

On one hand: Mickey. Stuart Little. That French cocksucker Remy who sautéed onions with the eloquence of an autistic sommelier possessed by Julia Child’s ghost. We project our every scrap of human whimsy onto those squeaking lint-queefs, making them drive tiny cars, wear waistcoats, fuck lady mice in romantic gondolas under crescent moons. We *adore* these little farting shits. We write bedtime stories about them. We slap their ears on diapers and sell them to toddlers marinated in their own piss. We defend their fictional dignity like they’re divine messengers of innocence who shat out cartoons into our childhood.

And on the other hand?  
We genetically engineer them to be *born wrong*.

Not just slightly off. Not just a little nearsighted. No. We engineer mouse fetuses with no fucking cerebellum. With spinal cords like overcooked vermicelli. With brains designed to seize and piss involuntarily when exposed to blue light, or develop Alzheimer’s faster than your auntie after Diwali.  
We break them, cripple them, then inject them with mystery goop. We slice open their backs, drip dopamine inhibitors into their shitty little amygdalas, and then *watch them scream*.  
We *need* them to scream.

Because screaming means it’s working.

We call it *preclinical* research, because calling it “ritualized rodent rape with grant funding” makes the HR people at Stanford sad. But that’s what it is, isn’t it? Ghastly, sadomasochistic ballet in lab coats, where the twat doing the real torturing is some Polish postdoc who hasn’t fucked in six months and thinks mouse empathy is for pussies and vegans.

Sometimes we give them hope. We create mazes. Add cheese. Let them live three extra weeks after inducing colorectal cancer just to see if the Ayurvedic nutmeg extract from Sikkim made a fucking dent.

Sometimes they get a name.  
And that is the saddest fucking part.

The moment you name a mouse, you’re fucked.

Because then it’s not just specimen B6J-Fvbn/NJ-arcof/Valium-Injected.  
It’s Bholu. Or Paplu. Or Ramesh.  
And Bholu, the adorable balding mouse with the congenital rectal prolapse, now lives in your subconscious, curled up in a ball of sawdust and betrayal. And when he dies—which he *will*—from liver hemorrhage or nerve damage or just quiet resignation that he was bred to be a retarded lab ornament—you’ll cry. Or worse, write a fucking paper.

Let me tell you: I saw a technician in Austin once, some white guy named Brett, huge calves, smelled like Cheetos and despair, get drunk and confess that he used to masturbate before euthanizing the mice. He said it made him feel “balanced.”  
And no one stopped him.

Because deep down we all get it.  
The mouse is a receptacle.  
Of our curiosity. Our cruelty. Our cowardice. Our cum.  
Like every goddamn relationship I’ve ever been in.

I used to think the worst thing was the death. But it's not. It’s the *setup*.  
The controlled temperature. The sterile bedding. The faux empathy.  
It’s like we’re fucking Nazi decorators for a rodent-themed episode of *The Good Place*.  
“Here, here’s a nice cage. Here’s some corn starch pellets. Now I’m going to carve your hippocampus out with a scalpel fashioned from recycled menstrual cups and whisper ‘good boy’ while I pump radioactive dye into your nostrils.”

And you *can’t stop it*.  
Because it's in the grant.  
Because someone at the NIH thinks your theory about serotonin and compulsive nail-biting needs another five years of mousemurder to prove what any depressed Bengali mother with a WhatsApp group could have told you: sadness is hereditary and sometimes you just want to eat soap.

Also, did you know the mouse genome is 85% similar to ours?  
Which means, statistically, your uncle who failed the SSC twice and sells pirated condoms under a Howrah flyover has less in common with you than Mickey Mouse does.

No wonder India’s so fucked.  
We worship Ganesh, half-elephant. We worship Hanuman, half-monkey. We name kids after lions, tigers, snakes.  
But mice? We only love them when they’re cartoons or victims.

And *that* is the real horror:  
We’ve turned our own cognitive dissonance into a form of lab equipment.  
We are the pipette, the centrifuge, the guilt microscope.

We’ll tell ourselves the research is important.  
That human lives depend on it.  
That without these experiments, there’d be no Prozac, no Viagra, no COVID vaccine, no fucking eczema cream for your cousin’s idiot son with skin like a loofah.  
And maybe that’s true.  
But we didn’t *have* to enjoy it.  
We didn’t have to make it so goddamn *theatrical*.  
Like a fucked-up play where the mice die and we clap.

Sometimes when I shit—which is to say, daily, violently, in fear—I imagine there’s a mouse under the pot, watching. One I didn't kill.  
One that remembers.

Most of the people I’ve sketched on this blog—and I say this with the full knowledge that some of them might still be alive and capable of accessing WiFi—are, frankly, homely as fuck.  
We’re talking busted. Misshapen. Anatomically confusing. Not just a little asymmetry here and there, not just endearing imperfections like a mole shaped like a doomed continent or a lazy eye that occasionally syncs up during eclipses—no, I mean full-on bodily monstrosities.  

We’re talking areolas the size of tea coasters.  
Knees that look like they’re planning something.  
Elbows with texture.  
Skin with memories.  
Hair where evolution forgot to turn off the faucet.  
One bloke had toes like tiny thumbs and a scrotum that looked like it had seen trench warfare.

Just *naked*.  
As in: raw chicken skin, belly folds, armpit stubble, tan lines, stray lint, semi-flaccid but deeply opinionated penises, droopy breasts with moods of their own.

Naked like birth and death, not like romance.

Because under that mess, behind the stretch marks and bulbous joints and suspicious moles, there's a thing humming.

But symmetry is not personality.  
Prettiness is not honesty.  
And fuckability is not fucking *value*.  

I’ve seen the neural net fire beneath a half-toothless tea seller’s twitching eyelid.  
I’ve seen cognitive elegance trapped in bodies that looked like they were drawn by a drunk god in a hurry.  
I’ve seen shameful, beautiful thoughts writ large in the shrug of a dislocated shoulder, in a finger permanently bent by labor and not corrected because hospitals are for rich people and cowards.

We are so goddamn trained—**so cock-whipped by symmetry and skin tone**—that we forget the whole machine is running upstairs.  
In that sludgy meat sponge.  
In the cortex loops and thalamus clatter.  
In predictive coding so fragile that a single sugar crash can make you sob during toothpaste ads.  
But do we see it?  
Do we fuck.  

We see jawlines.  
We see eye color.

The synaptic drift.  
The priors.

# File: src/lib/posts/next-door-unicorns.md

---
title: "Next-Door Unicorns"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251030-WA0003(1).jpg"
date: "2026-01-12"

<Pi src="IMG-20251030-WA0003(1).jpg" />  

The first time I pitched, really *pitched*, as in stood under a tubelight halo in a room that smelled like wet socks and stale Domino’s, sweating through my ass and shirt at the same time, I was showing off a working HIE prototype written in real code with real data from real clinics—not demo bullshit, not lorem ipsum dashboards, not some Harvard dropout’s fever dream about democratizing diagnostics via WhatsApp chatbots and goat farts.

It was *real*. I had spent years in that shit—years. Wrestling with HL7 like it was a wounded street dog that kept biting back, trying to make sense of blood panel structures from Bihar, doctor notes written in SMS shorthand, prescription handwriting that looked like post-stroke Sanskrit. Built adapters, studied standards, wrote Python and SQL until my fingers cracked. I’d worked in the systems. I knew where the bodies were buried—digitally and literally. Half the EHRs in this country are duct tape over COBOL with a JPEG stapled to it.

And when I finally, finally had something that could move records, clean data, expose APIs, show goddamn meaning from the rubble of Indian health infrastructure—

They stared at me like I’d shat on their pitch decks.

The investor—some sweaty fucker in a FabIndia kurta who’d read *Zero to One* exactly once and was now pretending to be allergic to SQL—asked me if I could “pivot to blockchain.” Said it’d be easier to raise funds if I slapped an AI sticker on it. Maybe put a woman on the team for diversity optics. Maybe get an “NRI advisor.”

Motherfucker.

This wasn’t some idea I cooked up between TEDx talks and Tinder dates. It wasn’t a glorified PDF. It was built from the floorboards of public hospitals, from the thick moldy breath of ward boys and the biro scratches of overworked Bengali general physicians who still call fever “viral.” It was ugly, usable, minimal. And dead on arrival.

Because here’s the thing no one tells you:

In India, every startup pitch room is a theater production. You dress up in your best LinkedIn drag. You pretend you’re building the next E=mc² when in fact you’re squatting in a ₹5,000/month Sealdah mess with someone else’s Aadhaar card, quoting Naval Ravikant while your bank account has ₹12.50 and a bounced electricity bill. Your cofounder has a fake IIM degree, your website is made on Canva, your traction is two bots and your cousin in Gurgaon.

And the money men?

Oh, the money men.

They’re even worse.

They’re not VCs. They’re not angels. They’re not even devils. They’re just horny chartered accountants in disguise, wearing Ray-Bans and faking term sheets, looking for the next victim to gaslight with words like “synergy,” “unit economics,” and “market capture.” Half of them couldn’t tell HL7 from HIV. One told me I should rename the product to something more “Indian emotional.” What the fuck does that even mean?

But I kept going. 

Pitched in tech parks, malls, sweaty offices in Madhapur where the fan doesn’t work and the receptionist doubles as the pitch jury. Shared rides with kids whose only credential was a fake MIT email. Saw pitch decks with spelling mistakes in *“innovation.”* Watched the same five fake incubators recycle the same five fake success stories about an app that sends reminders to drink water but is now "valued at 20 crore."

All around me: the cosplay.

This was 2014 to 2016. UPA was still farting into the wind, Aadhaar was metastasizing like a tumour with no data rights, and every second cockroach in a shared flat had become a “founder.” People building “Uber for Pharmacies,” “Tinder for Pathology Labs,” “AI-enabled cancer risk via tongue selfies.” And me—idiot me—trying to solve real problems like referral loops and district hospital handovers, trying to convince Andhra Pradesh IT department that interoperability isn’t a fucking yoga pose.

I should’ve just made a skin-lightening filter app and faked my way into Y Combinator.

Instead, I watched my own work die like a lonely dog under a car. No obituary. No closure. Just silence, unpaid bills, and a bunch of unread follow-up emails bouncing in some bureaucrat’s junk folder.

I came back to Calcutta.

And that’s when I saw it.

One of the assholes I’d met in Hyderabad, who used to crash on someone’s floor and couldn’t code to save his life, was now giving LinkedIn sermons about “vision-driven impact.” Said he’d “successfully exited” his last startup—which I *know* was just a Facebook page for blood donation. He lives near Sealdah. Still. Under a fake company name. Probably wears a suit in his own bathroom.

Another one, who once asked me what an API *stood for*, is now an “AI founder-in-residence” for some American accelerator whose website looks like it was made in Microsoft FrontPage by a drunk goat. He keeps tweeting about grit.

And here I am.

Fifty. Bitter. Awake at 3:17 AM with acid reflux and a resentment rash, scrolling through these fuckers’ VC daydreams while I reheat daal in a rice cooker and wonder if my resume should just say "Failure, but eloquent."

This ecosystem is not a garden. It's a sewage pipe with glitter.

And we, the genuine, the stubborn, the assholes who actually *built*, are just floating turds being passed over for shinier shit. And maybe that’s the real bitch of it—not that my startup died (everything dies, even kidneys), but that this whole pantomime we call a startup *ecosystem* is just that: a stage built on cow dung and TEDx banners, where actual experience—the slow, grinding, boring-as-fuck work of figuring out how hospitals *actually* operate, what doctors *actually* need, how blood reports move, how APIs break when the nurse enters a comma in the wrong place—isn’t just ignored, it’s actively *repelled* like it’s a bad smell. Because to build something that really works, you need layers: one fucker who understands pathology lab workflows, another who’s waded through HL7 schemas like toilet paper after a Vindaloo, another who’s dealt with Indian state procurement bureaucracy without losing their hair or soul, and maybe another who knows how to write code that doesn’t crash when you get 5000 concurrent users during dengue season. You need *specialization*, depth, patience, collaboration, humility, and maybe a little sadness. Which of course means it’s completely unfundable in India, where the VCs want one founder with a cocky smile and a Canva pitch saying “AI-powered preventive bhakti analytics” or “FaaS but for Karma,” and a PowerPoint slide with logos of fake pilot partners. Because our financiers have the intellectual volume of a spermatozoon and the ethical standards of a used condom, and because our culture rewards lies, speed, glitter, and vibes over reality, logistics, or working code. And because we’ve euthanized education and curiosity in this country—stabbed it repeatedly and pissed on the corpse—except in those few tightly compressed export factories like Jadavpur University or the IITs, where kids are still allowed to want to know, sort of in a pressure cooker style, how a thing works before being crushed by TCS or Deloitte. So the public, the audience, the ones who might actually benefit from a real health exchange or energy grid or agri-data layer—they don’t even *know* what the real thing should look like. They’ve never seen it. They’re not tuned to it. They think “modern” means an app with a gradient and a prayer wheel. They think “working” means funded.
 


# File: src/lib/posts/not-dead-checkin-app.md

---
title: "If I'm Not Dead, I'm Just Taking a Very Long Shit"  
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251021-WA0064(1).jpg"  
date: 2026-01-16  
description: "Ruminations on the Chinese 'I'm alive' check-in app, familial indifference, corpse decomposition, and the way death smells slightly better than life in South Calcutta."
