<Pi src="IMG-20251021-WA0064(1).jpg" />



The first time I smelled a rotting human—probably human, might’ve been a goat, or one of those Calcutta dogs that looks like it gave up halfway through evolution and just decided to be both dead and alive until entropy sorted it out—was on the eastern bypass, not far from the flyover that’s always under construction like some ancient mythological punishment for believing in infrastructure.  

And I wasn’t even looking for it. I was just trying to piss in the bushes without getting spotted by the perennially masturbating uncle-class men of this concrete diarrhoea of a city, and *bam*, this wind came—hot, humid, full of bacteria and regrets—and it was like somebody had boiled liver and piss and then forgotten about it for three weeks and then stirred in some molten plastic and burnt hair and served it on a bed of shame. That smell, that hot dead sweet fuck-you stench, is the only notification anyone would get if I died here.  

Because apparently there’s a Chinese app now, a sort of "Hey, I’m not a corpse yet" social media for the unclaimed, the unkissed, the unmissed. A daily check-in to prove you're not yet liquefying into mattress soup.  

And the moment I saw it, I thought—finally, software for me.

Except if I used it, and it said *Add Emergency Contact*, who would I even put? My kith and kin, who’ve already ghosted my broke ass harder than any corpse? The old fuckers in this lane who already assume I’m an antisocial masturbation monk with BO and possibly a fridge full of severed genitalia? Any relative I still have would react to my death like people react to a piece of spam in their inbox: slight annoyance, immediate deletion, maybe a moment of vague moral farting about whether to feel sad. But definitely no action. Maybe not even a phone call.  

If the stench gets bad enough, somebody might throw a torn mosquito net over me and inform the local councillor. And the councillor will send some municipal halfwit in plastic sandals and leftover COVID gloves, who’ll call a “van,” which will be a hollowed-out Mahindra Bolero from 1998 with a single rusted stretcher, and they'll dump me next to vegetable peels, condom clusters, puja flowers, and the occasional Ganesh idol that failed to make it into the Ganga, all into the grand unified theory of Calcutta waste—the landfill.  

That's my retirement plan.  

And don't get me wrong, I don’t even hate the app. I love it. It’s honest. It’s more honest than all these vomitous Instagram reels with their turmeric lighting and smug life advice. This Chinese app says: we know no one gives a shit about you. You know no one gives a shit about you. So let’s make it a game: tap once a day or people will assume you're rotting in your boxers next to an uneaten half-mango and a dried-up puddle of tea.  

And you know what, in this current state of decay we call life, that’s progress.  

Because let’s face it, nobody wants the reality of death. They want it dressed up in ceremony—cremation slots booked by a cousin who last saw you when Nokia was still king, priests who mispronounce your name between belches, and some socially mandated WhatsApp status mourning you in passive-voice platitudes like “He is no more,” as if I was once a fucking state of matter.  

I’m not “no more.” I’m still here. I just smell like reheated sweat and failure.  

And I check my own pulse sometimes, because I’ve stopped feeling pain in certain parts of my body—not out of enlightenment but because I think the nerves themselves gave up and emigrated.  

My tea pan—yes, not a kettle, not a proper respectable British-fuck's gurgling heirloom but a dented aluminum shallow pan I use because kettles require *hope*—makes a sound now when the water boils. Not a whistle. A *sigh*. I swear. The pan exhales. As if it too has accepted that this is the last boiling it’ll do before someone uses it to piss in during a diarrhea night.  

My rice cooker, which doubles as oven, pan, and accidental foot warmer in winter, has a smell that is 10% basmati, 40% desolation, and the rest unclassified. I’ve lived alone so long that the fucker’s developed moods. It cooks better when I talk to it. I talk to it. Because who the fuck else would reply?

This isn’t a cry for help. This is documentation.

Science says the human body begins decomposition within minutes of death. Enzymes liquefy cells. Bacteria bloom like porn tabs on a teenager’s browser. Gases build. A fart that never ends. Swelling. Skin slippage. And then the fluids. Fluids you didn’t even know existed, leaking out of holes you never wanted to think about.  

That’s the real notification system.  

The nose knows. If someone doesn’t check in on the app, and they live in a city like this, and the neighbours notice a scent more repugnant than the usual open-drain fragrance bouquet of Calcutta, that’s when death gets discovered. Not by love. Not by memory. By stench.

I could automate the app with some script that checks in daily so no one ever has to actually care. A bot performing the last rites of loneliness. A ghost coded in Python. Press F to not be forgotten.  

The fucking irony of a society that needs an *app* to notice you’re not rotting is that it says more about the living than the dead. We’re all corpses-in-training. Some are just better at putting on deodorant.  

And people talk about community, about social fabric, but I live in a fucking jute bag of a neighborhood, full of snot-nosed little shits who scream because their mothers are too busy scrolling, old fuckers who think WhatsApp forwards are a religious canon, and some uncle-shaped methane sack next door who plays Bhojpuri remixes like it’s a sonic weapon system.  

And me? I’m a boxers-wearing turd-ghost who smells like an old hostel mattress fucked a latrine.

I tried once to wave at someone on the lane just to see if I still existed. They flinched like I was trying to sell them Amway.  

I’ve started keeping track of how long it takes for ants to find a dropped grain of sugar. It’s down to seven minutes. I feel weirdly jealous. At least the ants have purpose. And backup.

There’s a little mold patch near my bathroom drain that I’ve started calling Bappa. It grows, shrinks, comes back in new patterns. More loyal than my family.  

I swear to fuck, the only way I’d get discovered if I died is if the rats found my scrotum too chewy and gave up halfway through.

The point is I hadn't bathed in three days. Or maybe four. Somewhere between existential inertia and that greasy blank scroll of time you forget to swipe, like when your screen freezes but it’s your life, and there’s a slight twitch in your boxer’s waistband like your dick wanted to participate in the plot but the story’s already dead, the narration stalled, and the protagonist—you—is a middle-aged brown skinbag with scalp dandruff, parched toenails, and a double chin that jiggles when he’s crying over cold rice in his electric fucking oven.

No, I’m not dead. But I *get* why people assume I might be. Because depression is a sneaky motherfucker. It doesn’t throw dramatic tantrums. No, it just sits there like a smug fart trapped inside an airplane seat, slowly poisoning your will to live while the smiling airhostess asks if you want masala peanuts or not. Depression, unlike death, needs constant management. Death at least ends the subscriptions.

And yet, like a fool with leftover erections and unanswered WhatsApp messages from former classmates turned startup crypto-gurus, I persist.

Now let me say something scientific before I drown in my own fucking bile.

See, in cryogenics, there’s this charming little thing called vitrification. It’s what they hope happens when they freeze dead rich cunts in tanks, hoping to preserve the cellular structures without forming the sharp ice crystals that rip through the membranes like a thousand tiny bayonets screaming “fuck your afterlife!” Depression, my darling, is emotional vitrification. You don’t rot. You just... suspend. Not dead, but also not alive. No warmth. No cell activity worth noting. Just frozen regret in viscous cerebrospinal syrup.

And much like those frozen dickhead billionaires, I too lie horizontal most of the day, only instead of a sci-fi preservation chamber I have a peeling floor mat that smells of Dettol, damp boxer sweat, and the ghost of my mother's cooking.

The worst part?

I *know* I’m not dead. My nose still works. And there’s no mistaking the rotting onion that’s been mating with a dead potato under the sink for 9 days. Which I still haven’t thrown out. I don’t throw *anything* out. There’s a curry from last week that’s developed a pellicle so thick I swear it winked at me once. My stomach turned, but I also got hard, which says more about the state of my dopamine receptors than I care to admit.

Let me also confess: I am a man who has masturbated to grainy 240p phone-captured videos of women coughing. Not sexy coughing. Just real ones. Tuberculosis-chic. Probably because it reminds me of home. Or of love. Who the fuck knows anymore. Point is: whatever the signal, the wiring's crossed, and the motor twitches inappropriately. The body remembers long after the brain’s declared bankruptcy.

Memory.

A few decades ago, I was a promising little twat. My teachers said I was going to *do* something. And I did. I left the country. Got a degree. Came back with a used rice cooker, a history of meaningless sex, and an American accent so diluted now it sounds like a Bangladeshi used car dealer trying to sell a Hyundai Santro by saying "it have all working, bhai."

I also came back with bipolar disorder, a mild porn addiction, an unhealthy relationship with the sound of my own piss stream (louder = healthier, don’t @ me), and an unplaceable sadness that sits somewhere between my kidneys and the last unread novel on my shelf. I reread page 17 of every book. Never finish.

Here’s the science again. The anterior cingulate cortex is partially responsible for decision-making, empathy, and the motivation to move your fucking legs. In MRIs of severely depressed individuals, this region glows like a dead Christmas light bulb at a government office. Nobody replaces it. It just blinks once in a while out of habit.

I am powered by blinking dead bulbs and a tea pan that squeals like a molested banshee when it boils.

That pan is older than my last orgasm. Possibly more meaningful too. Because that whistle, fuck me, it’s the only thing around here that screams when it’s hurt. I just fart silently and scroll.

What do I scroll? Everything. Nothing. Tweets. Threads. Diagrams of serotonin pathways. Pictures of women I once thought I might have loved. A YouTube video about the urachus, which is a remnant duct between your bladder and navel that sometimes doesn’t close properly in men and causes piss to leak from your belly button. You think you’re depressed? Imagine leaking piss from your stomach. I’d at least *feel* something.

Now, death. Death would simplify shit.

No passwords. No backups. No awkward attempts to explain my final Google search (“is it possible to overdose on saffron?”). No fucking to-do list with “Buy curd. Don’t die. Update CV.”

But unlike death, depression lets you *simmer.* You sit in your own stock, turning into a consommé of guilt and flatulence. Nobody buries you. You just recede. Like my hairline. Or democracy. Or foreplay.

People call. You don’t pick up.

People stop calling. You feel abandoned.

You want love. But if someone shows up, you panic and pretend you’re fasting for spiritual reasons and can't meet today, even though you're literally eating leftover bhindi with your fingers while scratching your crotch with the other hand.

People tell you to go outside. Walk. Touch grass.

Grass? The only thing green around here is the fungal patch under my pillow.

And outside? Outside is men with loud voices who think YouTube counts as a degree, women who clutch handbags like they contain the last vial of human decency, and scooters ridden by screaming toddlers who will one day be adults with voting rights and erectile dysfunction.

I used to read. I used to fuck. I used to think things mattered. Now I mostly nap.

The other day I tried to jerk off but fell asleep midway and woke up four hours later with a semi, a numb left leg, and an ad for cremation services playing on autoplay.

I am sitting on the toilet at six in the morning, knees apart, belly hanging like a defeated sack of wet cement, waiting for the shit to decide whether it wants to be solid or philosophical, when it hits me—not the shit, the other thing—that there is absolutely nobody I want to tell this to, not the toilet part obviously, but the part where the body becomes the only audience left, the asshole its own confessional, the tiled bathroom a church with no god and excellent acoustics for farts.

The shit comes out half-formed, embarrassed, like it knows it shouldn’t exist in public, and I sweat in that sour winter way Calcutta does, cold air outside, sticky armpits inside, the body unable to agree with itself, which feels like a pretty accurate metaphor for my entire fucking life, fifty years of internal committee meetings ending in nothing, no resolution, just a smell.

My mother would worry if I told her this, my sister would try to fix it with logistics and tone, so I keep them wrapped in distance like old crockery you don’t want to chip, and everyone says family is everything but they never tell you that “everything” often means silence, a polite refusal to contaminate each other with the real textures of living, the skid marks of thought. I flush, the toilet roars like a small angry river, and that’s the loudest conversation I’ve had all week.

There is one friend, technically, a work friend, a man who runs on ambition like a cheap generator, loud, erratic, full of smoke, dreaming of Bugattis and billionaire spreadsheets, always hustling some new shortcut to infinite rupees and relevance. He talks in IPOs and Instagram Reels, as if luxury were a birthright stolen by bad timing, and I listen, mostly because arguing with superlative ambition is like trying to fistfight a mirror. He’s always winning in his own story—net worth going up, enemies vanquished, destiny beckoning—and I nod like a neutered consultant at a crypto seminar, because explaining to him that I’ve never really given a fuck about money or power or the LinkedIn food chain feels like a losing proposition. His dreams gallop; mine sleep standing up.

I dry myself with a towel that smells faintly of mildew and regret, catch my reflection in the mirror, the belly, the droop, the eyes that look like they’ve been waiting in a government office since 1998, and I think: this is the face of nothing. Not tragic nothing, not heroic nothing, just administrative nothing, a file mislaid between departments. I masturbated last night out of boredom, not desire, scrolling porn the way one scrolls news during a riot—too much, too fast, everyone screaming, nobody touching me—and came with a sigh that sounded like a bus braking, afterward lying there with the damp patch cooling and the thought that if I died right then, the room wouldn’t notice until the smell changed.

Loneliness is supposed to be dramatic, violins and rain and longing glances, but mostly it’s just logistics: who do you text when your stomach hurts, who do you tell that the dream you had involved a woman from twenty years ago who wouldn’t look at you and a classroom full of people laughing while you tried to hide a hard-on behind a schoolbag like a guilty child. I woke up sweaty, ashamed, hard for no reason that could survive daylight, the body still insisting on rehearsals for a play that closed decades ago.

I have read too many books for this to be interesting. I know the evolutionary arguments, the primate grooming, the colonial loneliness of cities designed for extraction not comfort, the neuroscience of social pain lighting up the same circuits as physical pain, and none of that stops me from eating leftover rice standing at the counter, fingers greasy, thinking about how my blog has become a kind of latrine wall where I scratch messages to nobody in particular, proof of existence like a turd left unflushed: someone was here, briefly, and it was unpleasant.

The city outside coughs and groans, buses farting diesel, construction hammering at yesterday’s mistakes, and I imagine Calcutta itself as a giant aging body, arteries clogged, joints creaking, everyone pretending vitality while leaking, and maybe that’s why I fit so well here now, an exile within an exile, old North Calcutta’s ghosts shaking their heads at me from cracked verandas, Satyajit Ray’s calm faces watching this shitshow and politely declining to comment.

Politics used to give me erections, or at least a sense of purpose, slogans and marches and the warm press of bodies, but that dried up too, the way arousal does when you’ve seen the trick too many times. Now nationalism feels like erectile dysfunction for a whole country, all bluster and no blood flow, and spirituality feels like porn with the sound off, everyone pretending transcendence while rubbing themselves raw on metaphors.

I try to pee and it comes out in two streams, disagreeing, splashing the rim, and I laugh because even my piss can’t commit to a direction. The abstract idea of “nothing” lives in the gut like gas, invisible but insistent, a pressure that makes you shift in your seat, and when philosophers talk about the void I want to tell them it smells faintly of shit and cheap soap and old cum, it sounds like silence punctured by neighbors’ televisions, it feels like a phone that never vibrates.

There are inappropriate memories that surface like pimples when I’m alone too long: a woman on a bus brushing my arm thirty years ago, a teacher’s blouse straining, a hand held too briefly, all of them useless now, museum pieces of desire that still manage to make my dick twitch like it’s remembering a password the brain has forgotten. Erotic shame is mostly archival, the body hoarding moments the mind would rather delete, and every time I scroll porn I’m just rearranging the archive, dusting the same dead exhibits.

I eat, I shit, I sweat, I scroll, I sleep badly, and in between I tell myself stories about being a rationalist, an atheist, a man of thought, when really I am a mammal with Wi‑Fi, a sack of fluids convinced it has opinions. The blog exists because talking requires a listener and writing only requires gravity and time, words falling out like dandruff, accumulating until someone might notice the flakes.

Sometimes I imagine dying and the problem isn’t fear, it’s administration: who calls whom, what happens to the browser tabs, who explains the smell. That’s when I realize the body is the only thing consistently present, the asshole the most honest orifice, always telling the truth about what’s been passing through.

I lie on the bed in the afternoon, half-hard for no one, scratching my balls while some old Ray film plays on mute, the actors noble and composed while I adjust my dick so it doesn’t point accusingly at the ceiling fan, and I think about how this is the sum total: a man alone with culture, history, pornography, and a digestive system that never shuts up. Nothing, yes—but nothing with a body, which is worse, because bodies insist, they keep producing evidence.

I fall asleep briefly and wake to the sound of my own fart, sharp and wet, echoing in the room like applause from a very small audience, and for a moment I consider clapping back, acknowledging the only response I’m likely to get.



# File: src/lib/posts/pigeon-god-of-the-gaps.md

title: "Pigeon God of the Gaps"

<Pi src="IMG-20251204-WA0002.jpg" />



The pigeon shat on my rice while I was still chewing.  
I hadn’t even fucking started the second bite—lukewarm rice, cold dal, that tragic purgatory meal of a man who’s lost both money and meaning and yet persists in warming the fucking food like it’s not the third day of the same shit in the same aluminium bowl.  

And there it was. Mid-mastication. Plop. Yellow-greyish-black diarrheic punctuation on top of my parboiled sadness. A Calcutta pigeon, sacred-feathered sidewalk deity of bacteria and bloat, had declared its divine intervention by uncoiling its cloacal enlightenment onto my tiffin.  

Now I know this cocksucker. This exact bird. Probably born on the same oxidizing windowsill where it now worships the sun with the same kind of slack-jawed awe I once reserved for the tits on Monica Bellucci in *Malèna*—except that dumb feathery fuck does it every single day, and gets rewarded with leftover puffed rice and that unmistakable reverence Bengalis reserve for anything fluttering, confused, and entirely unfit for survival.  

You’ll see them—old sagging nipples of the city tossing mustard grains on the temple steps like that’ll bring them a miraculous hernia cure or an erection they don’t deserve.  
And the pigeons? The bastards have been *trained*. Skinner would have fucking loved this city. Operant conditioning in full fuckin’ form.  

Every twitch of their underdeveloped little velociraptor brains is a divine guess. Peck this ledge: food falls. Fly in circle: bell rings. Shit on brown man’s rice: achieve moksha.  

Superstition isn’t a glitch in the software. It’s the goddamn bootloader.  
A safety net for brains too slow to compute causality in real-time, too cowardly to admit randomness, too constipated to accept death.  

And it ain’t just humans doing it, no. I mean these pigeons aren’t just pooping priests in some feathered archdiocese—they are *theologians*.

He tossed some poor dumb birds in a box, fed them pellets at regular intervals, and sat back watching them turn into psychotic ballet dancers. One bird spun counter-clockwise every 15 seconds, thinking its little pirouette summoned the snack. Another did head-bobs like it was in a fucking Punjabi wedding. They invented *rituals* out of dumb luck.  

They thought the random reward was a result of *their* actions.  
And before you say “aww cute,” let me slap you with the mirror.  

You’re the same.  
You bought that fucking crystal. You prayed before your ICSE results. You wore lucky boxers for your prostate exam. You sent your resume after fasting on a Monday.  

You’re the pigeon, my friend. A big-balled, bipedal, Bengali version, jerked off not by the promise of food but by the fantasy that the universe might be listening—when all it’s doing is taking a galactic shit on your rice.

And I know the brain’s in on this racket. We’ve got whole clusters lighting up like Diwali when a “pattern” emerges—even if it’s made of farts and coincidences. Some evolutionary hangover from when seeing a predator *maybe* meant you *maybe* lived one more day to fuck or ferment in your own fear.  

So the amygdala screeches, and the cortex backfills. It’s like one of those half-sober WhatsApp uncles forwarding *“proof of Ram Setu”* images. The emotional trigger hits first. The rationalization arrives later with a fake beard and a WhatsApp degree in ancient aeronautics.  

Now extrapolate this pattern across species.  

A rat hits a lever. Sometimes it gets a shock. Sometimes cheese. It still keeps trying.  
A dog gets fed when the bell rings. Soon it salivates for bells like a pubescent boy salivates for cleavage-shaped clouds.  

So what is God, then, if not the Great Cheese Dispenser of Unpredictable Timing?

Every species has a gap.  
A terror of not-knowing.  
Of chaos.  
Of the yawning cunt of uncertainty.  

So we invent the *filler*. The god. The story.  
The gap gets spackled with semen and psalms and planetary positions and spilled mustard seeds and weird dreams that somehow mean your neighbor’s going to die.  

Pigeons shit on us. We still feed them.  
We shit on each other. Still pray together.  
The whole fucking biosphere’s a circlejerk of magical thinking.  

And you’d think higher IQ might vaccinate you, right?  
That if you studied biology or logic or that you once jerked off to Carl Sagan documentaries, you’d escape this bullshit.

You say “emergent properties.”

You say “simulated multiverse.”  

Same pigeon, different turd.  

And it’s always funny until it's personal.  

Like when you’ve been alone too long and your dead mother’s old scarf drops off a shelf on a windless day and you feel—deep in your chest, between the ribs and where your anxiety nests—that *maybe* it’s a sign.  
And then you laugh. Because you know it’s not.

It just gets older.  
And more tired.

Not flying. Just perched. Observing.

And I preen.

Just in case she was watching.  



# File: src/lib/posts/pigeonhole-principle.md

---
title: "The Pigeonhole Principle"
date: "2025-12-25"
description: "It’s so obvious you think it can’t possibly do anything… and then it strolls into a proof like a bored uncle at a wedding and solves the whole problem."
thumbnail: "/Photos/IMG-20251225-WA0003.jpg"
category: "math"
color: "green"
published: true
---

<Pi
    src="/Photos/IMG-20251225-WA0003.jpg" 
    caption="The drawer principle: fewer nests than birds means someone has to share."
/>

<Yc />
<Yt src="https://youtu.be/Z1zgrgstVAw?si=gz19kVM8dgze4btY" />

The pigeonhole principle is one of those bits of mathematics that feels like it should be illegal: it’s so obvious you think it can’t possibly *do* anything… and then it strolls into a proof like a bored uncle at a wedding and solves the whole problem with one sentence.

## “What” it says (in plain human)

If you put more objects than containers into the containers, at least one container must end up with more than one object.

That’s it. That’s the whole thing. The entire principle fits on the back of a tea packet.

* If you have 11 socks and only 10 drawers, some drawer has at least 2 socks.
* If 367 people are in a room, at least two share a birthday (because there are only 366 possible birthdays if you include Feb 29).
* More magically if 13 people are in a room then at least two have the same birth month according to our 12 month calendar. 

## A simple proof by contradiction (The "Uh-Oh" method)

The contradiction-style proof is basically: assume the principle is false, then watch arithmetic reality punch that assumption in the face. If your brain refuses to accept this as an absolute law of the universe, here is the logic broken down:

Imagine 5 boxes. You try to put 6 balls in them.

1. **Pretend** you can do it with *no* box getting two balls.
2. Then each box can take only one ball.
3. So 5 boxes can take only 5 balls.
4. But you have 6 balls.
5. So where does the 6th ball go?

It has to go into a box that already has a ball.
**Meaning:** some box *must* have two.

## The “why” (why anyone should care)

Because this tiny idea is a crowbar. It pries open problems where you can’t see any structure. You don’t need to know *which* drawer has two socks. The power is: it guarantees *existence* without telling you where to look.

Pattern appears because you’re forcing lots of things to share a small set of “types.” You first decide what “type” means (month of birthday, remainder after dividing by 5, drawer number, weekday, etc.). If there are only, say, 5 types available, then the first 5 items could each take a different type, but the 6th item has no new type left to claim, so it must repeat a type already used. The moment two items share the same type, you’ve got a guaranteed match—a pattern. The cleverness is choosing types so that “same type” automatically implies something interesting (same remainder means their difference is divisible by 5; same month means shared birthday month; same drawer means a collision).

The pigeonholes-and-pigeons story is a cartoon with good intentions, like a school poster about vitamins: it’s not wrong, it’s just omitting the awkward parts where life behaves like life—yes, in our photo, a perfectly competent pigeon can loiter on the parapet and refuse to participate in our tidy bureaucracy of holes, and letters can miss the slot and sulk on the floor like dropped exam papers; mathematics handles this not by arguing with pigeons, but by tightening the rules of the game into a definition: the pigeonhole principle is a theorem about a mapping (an assignment function) from objects to boxes, meaning the premise silently includes “every object is placed into exactly one box,” and if that isn’t true, the theorem simply doesn’t apply until you model the extra reality—so you add an additional “box” called outside/on-the-wall/on-the-floor, or you allow a partial function (some objects unassigned) and then the conclusion weakens to something like “among the objects that actually got assigned, a collision occurs if assigned-objects > boxes,” which is mathematicians’ way of saying: metaphors are for getting your boots on, but proofs require you to specify whether the wall counts as a container and whether the floor is, regrettably, a box.

That’s a recurring theme in modern math and computer science: proving something must happen even if you can’t point to it directly. Pigeonhole is the baby version of that instinct, and it shows up everywhere:

* **In number theory:** proving patterns in remainders and divisibility.
* **In combinatorics:** proving “some pair must share something.”
* **In computer science:** hashing and collisions—if more keys than hash slots, collisions are inevitable.
* **In cryptography:** why perfect “collision-free” hash functions can’t exist if outputs are fixed-size.
* **In geometry and data:** guarantees about clustering, nearest neighbors, and overlaps.

## “Who / when / where” (the little history tour)

The principle is most famously associated with **Peter Gustav Lejeune Dirichlet** (1805–1859), a German mathematician who worked in places like **Berlin** and **Göttingen**, and who used it in the 19th century while doing what number theorists love most: forcing integers to confess patterns they didn’t want to reveal.

Dirichlet used it in results about **Diophantine approximation**—that is, how well real numbers can be approximated by rationals. The core move is “there are more attempts than outcomes, so two attempts must land in the same outcome,” which sounds like a bureaucratic complaint but becomes deep mathematics.

The name “pigeonhole” came later as a friendly metaphor: Victorian-era desks often had little cubbyholes for letters—like literal pigeonholes. The French sometimes call it the **“principe des tiroirs”** (the drawer principle), which is frankly more elegant: fewer birds, more furniture.

## The basic statement

**First form:**
If you have $(n+1)$ objects and $n$ boxes, then some box contains at least 2 objects.

**A slightly more powerful version (the one mathematicians actually use):**
If you place $N$ objects into $k$ boxes, then some box contains at least:

$$
\left\lceil \frac{N}{k} \right\rceil
$$

objects. That ceiling symbol $\lceil \cdot \rceil$ just means “round up.”

Example: 100 people, 12 months $\rightarrow$ some month has at least $\lceil 100/12\rceil = \lceil 8.33…\rceil = 9$ birthdays.

## A “dot product style” example

**Main idea:** pigeonhole is about **forced overlap**. When possibilities are fewer than attempts, duplicates must occur.

**Example:** Pick any 6 integers. Show that two of them differ by a multiple of 5.

**How:** Every integer has a remainder when divided by 5. The possible remainders are:
$$
0, 1, 2, 3, 4
$$
That’s 5 “boxes” (remainder classes).

Your 6 integers are the “objects.”

With 6 objects and only 5 boxes, pigeonhole says: at least two integers land in the same remainder box. Suppose two integers $a$ and $b$ have the same remainder mod 5. Then:

$$
a \equiv b \pmod{5}
$$

Subtract:

$$
a - b \equiv 0 \pmod{5}
$$

So $(a-b)$ is divisible by 5. Done.

Notice the vibe: we never needed the actual integers. We forced a property to exist by counting possibilities.

## A couple of “this is why it’s sneaky” applications

1. **The handshakes in a party trick** In any group of people, two people have shaken hands the same number of times (assuming no one shakes their own hand, and handshake counts are between 0 and $n-1$).  
   *Why it works:* You can’t simultaneously have someone with 0 handshakes and someone with $n-1$ handshakes in the same group (if someone shook hands with everyone, nobody can have 0). That leaves only $n-1$ possible handshake counts for $n$ people $\rightarrow$ overlap.

2. **Hashing in computing** If a hash function outputs 256-bit values, there are only $2^{256}$ possible outputs. Feed it more than $2^{256}$ different inputs and collisions are guaranteed. Pigeonhole doesn’t tell you *which* collision, just that the universe cannot avoid one.

3. **Geometry / “crowded room” thinking** Put 13 points inside a unit square. Then two points are within distance $\le \frac{\sqrt{2}}{3}$.  
   *Why:* Divide the square into 9 smaller squares of side $1/3$. With 13 points and 9 squares, some small square gets at least 2 points. The farthest two points inside a small square are its diagonal:
   
   $$
   \sqrt{(1/3)^2+(1/3)^2}=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{3}
   $$

   That’s pigeonhole wearing a geometry costume.

## The deeper philosophical point

Physics often runs on conservation laws: energy can’t vanish, charge can’t disappear, entropy has opinions. Pigeonhole is a conservation law for *possibilities*. When outcomes are limited, repetition isn’t a surprise—it’s a necessity.

And that’s why it’s such a staple in proofs: it’s a way to turn “life is messy” into “life is cornered.”


# File: src/lib/posts/pinworms-in-the-ruins.md

---

title: "Pinworms on my Anus"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251016-WA0002(1).jpg"
date: '2026-01-09'
description: "A middle-aged Bengali man, alone in South Calcutta, losing a nightly war to pinworms, shame, heat, aging, and a libido that keeps arriving late, drunk, and uninvited."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "orange"

<Pi
 src="IMG-20251016-WA0002(1).jpg"
 caption="Night falls, dignity follows, then something microscopic starts a protest march."
/>


At 2:17 a.m. my body makes a small, humiliating announcement, not with a trumpet but with an itch, a specific itch, the kind that has a street address, the kind that doesn’t politely knock on your shoulder but grabs you by the ass and says, wake up, baba, there’s a tiny white committee meeting happening at your anus and they have a full agenda. But no, it's not Trump and his white MAGA sycophantic stooges, these have much less avarice and won't fuck up the world order. 

South Calcutta in winter is supposed to be tender. The air turns crisp like a biscuit, the ceiling fan can be lowered from cyclone to gentle gossip, the mosquitos retreat like defeated generals. But my body doesn’t do seasons the way sane bodies do; my body is a leaking government office. There is always some department on strike. One night it’s acidity, one night it’s sweat, one night it’s the knees complaining like old party workers, and now—pinworms. Bengali pinworms. Local boys. They know the lanes. They know the shortcuts. They wait until night, until the mind is already thin and sad, until you’ve had one too many cups of tea and one too many thoughts about your life, and then they crawl out like small pale punctuation marks to leave eggs around the rim of your dignity.

I lie there in the dark, scratching carefully, because even in disgrace a man tries to maintain some technique, and the room smells of old bedsheet, old books, old disappointment, and a faint ghost of last evening’s alur dom, which I ate straight from the steel bowl like a widower who has given up on plates. My phone is face-down on the pillow, glowing faintly like a guilty conscience. The walls have that winter dampness that makes everything feel like it’s been stored in someone else’s mouth. Outside, a dog barks at nothing, and I envy him because at least his problems are large enough to bite.

Pinworms are comedy written by a biologist who hates you personally. They’re not dramatic, like cancer; not cinematic, like tuberculosis; not even poetic, like cholera with its colonial history and watery horror. Pinworms are petty. Pinworms are the universe saying, you wanted meaning? Here: a millimeter-long worm with the nightlife habits of a pickpocket, coming out after you fall asleep to glue little eggs around your anus like a sickly rangoli.

And because the body is a shameless gossip, the itch drags everything with it. Memory, politics, sex, the whole rotting kitchen of the mind. You scratch and suddenly you’re eight years old again, standing in a government clinic with a line of children, each holding a crumpled slip of paper, the nurse handing out those chalky deworming tablets like communion. We swallowed them with tap water that tasted faintly of iron and municipal despair. The adults called it “kira dawa,” said it with the casualness of sweeping dust under a bed. Worms were normal. Worms were a fact of Bengal, like humidity and corruption and Tagore on calendars. Nobody made a drama. Nobody said, how are you feeling about the fact that your body is a hotel for parasites. They just said, open your mouth.

Now I’m fifty-something and still opening my mouth, but to what? To tea, to self-pity, to stale jokes, to the occasional late-night snack eaten like a thief. The worms, meanwhile, have upgraded. They’re not just worms; they are my biography in larval form. Overeducated, undersexed, living in a decaying structure, surviving on scraps, doing their work at night.

People think shame is a mental thing, but shame is physical. Shame is the sweat that comes even when it’s cold. Shame is the sudden tightening in the belly when you remember something you did in 2003 and your body flinches like it expects a slap. Shame is the way the hand hesitates before scratching, not because scratching is wrong, but because you can’t bear the fact that you’ve become the sort of man who has to scratch there at 2:17 a.m. like a mangy street dog.

And then, like the universe adding garnish to an already disgusting plate, libido wanders in. Not the glamorous libido of film heroes with oiled torsos and moral clarity, but my libido: a confused, late, poorly dressed creature that shows up when it’s least helpful, like a drunk uncle arriving at a funeral and asking where the snacks are. I’m lying in bed, scratching, thinking about microscopic eggs, and some part of the brain—some ancient lizard department—tries to start a different conversation, a horny conversation, as if arousal is an appropriate response to intestinal parasites. This is what I mean when I say the mind is not a cathedral. It’s a public toilet with a philosophy section.

I don’t want to get into details because even I have limits and I live inside this body, but let’s just say modern solitude has a way of turning desire into paperwork. You don’t have sex; you process sex. You browse. You regret. You close tabs like you’re erasing evidence. The next day you remember nothing except a vague sense of having eaten too much sugar. There is no glow. There is only the faint nausea of having collaborated with your own emptiness.

They say “libido” comes from Latin for desire, but I read somewhere—completely unreliable, probably invented by a bored priest—that it actually comes from a phrase meaning “to embarrass your ancestors.” Total bullshit, obviously. Latin doesn’t work like that. But it feels true in the only way that matters, the way your gut knows a thing before your brain can dress it up. My ancestors, those thin, stern men in sepia photographs, would look at me now: a middle-aged Bengali man in an unflattering lungi, scratching his ass in the dark, the room smelling like damp concrete and half-dead dreams, my browser history a crime scene, my muscles soft as overcooked rice. They would not be proud. They would cough politely and change the subject.

Nationalism, in this context, feels like a particularly stupid joke. All that chest-thumping talk of “strength” and “purity” and “culture,” while I can’t even keep my own ass uncolonized. That’s the thing: masculinity is sold to men here like a cheap tonic, like some ayurvedic bottle promising virility, stamina, dominance, and what it actually delivers is a paunch, a temper, and an inability to admit you’re miserable. Nationalism is like trying to come while constipated—lots of effort, lots of grunting rhetoric, no real release, and afterwards you just feel sore and lied to.

My father’s generation had a different kind of shame. They were ashamed of hunger, of poverty, of not having enough. My generation has the luxury of being ashamed of nonsense: of our bodies misfiring, of our desires turning absurd, of our brains being crowded with images we didn’t earn. The British left, yes, the flag changed, yes, but the intimate humiliations remain stubbornly local. The drains still smell. The walls still sweat. The body still does what it does. Somewhere, a municipal officer signs a file; somewhere, a worm lays an egg.

Pinworms have a science, of course, because everything has a science, even humiliation. The female comes out at night, lays eggs around the anus, and the itching encourages scratching, which spreads the eggs to fingers, to bedsheets, to doorknobs, to the whole domestic ecosystem. The life cycle is efficient in a way my own life has never been. The pinworm is a capitalist. The pinworm understands distribution.

I try to be rational about it. I tell myself: it’s common. It’s treatable. It’s not a moral failing. It doesn’t mean you’re dirty in the cosmic sense. But the body doesn’t listen to speeches. The body believes in sensation. The body believes in itch. The body believes in the cheap horror of knowing that something is living inside you and doesn’t care about your opinions.

I get up and go to the bathroom, because the bathroom is where a Bengali man goes to negotiate with reality. The tiles are cold. The light is unforgiving. The mirror is a cruel academic examiner. I look like someone who has read too many books and digested too few joys. My belly has that soft deflation of a man who once had ambition and now has only habits. My eyes look like they’ve been left in rain.

I wash my hands too long. I wash like I’m trying to erase a decade. Soap, water, soap again. I remember childhood instructions: don’t bite nails, wash hands, keep sheets clean. As if hygiene is a kind of virtue. As if virtue can protect you from biology. In Bengal we grow up believing that the body is a nuisance you endure while the mind does the important work. But the mind is just the body’s secretary, typing letters while the real boss makes noises in the gut.

Back in bed, the itch returns, because of course it does. The worms have no respect for my schedule. I shift around, trying to find a position that doesn’t make me aware of my own rear end. That’s another insult: pinworms force intimacy with parts of yourself you’ve spent a lifetime pretending don’t exist. You can ignore your ass when you’re young and busy and distracted. You can treat it as plumbing. But now, in the dark, it becomes the center of consciousness, a small cursed planet.

And because the brain is a traitor, the itch drags up old scenes like a perverted archivist. A crush from college. A woman’s laugh in a corridor. A moment on a bus when someone’s shoulder brushed mine and my whole nervous system reacted as if touched by electricity. Those were clean desires, almost sweet, almost innocent. Now desire is sticky and tired, like chewing gum stuck under a chair. Now desire comes with failure attached, like a product with a known defect.

Sometimes I think my libido isn’t even libido; it’s loneliness wearing a cheap costume. Loneliness doesn’t know how to speak, so it borrows the language of sex. It says: want, want, want, when what it means is: please, just, some warmth, some proof that you’re not completely unnecessary. But then the body chimes in with its own commentary: sweat, itch, bowel sounds, the faint ache in the hip. The romance collapses. The animal facts remain.

Somewhere in the mind, a Sanskrit line surfaces, not as wisdom but as mockery: अहं ब्रह्मास्मि. I am Brahman. Sure. Brahman with pinworms. Brahman with a belly. Brahman with a hand hovering near his ass at 2:17 a.m. like a thief. The Upanishads didn’t cover this part, did they. They skipped the itching.

I fall asleep in patches. Half-dreams. Little dips into unconsciousness like a man trying to escape through a series of tiny doors. In one dream I’m back in North Calcutta, the old lane, the smell of frying oil and damp brick, and my mother is calling me in for dinner and everything is warm and normal. Then I wake up and I’m here, exiled in concrete, with a body that feels like a badly maintained apartment: something always leaking, something always crawling.

In the morning, the sunlight arrives like an accusation. The bedsheet is rumpled. The air is cold enough to feel clean, which is a lie. I sit up slowly, feeling the weight of my own flesh, and I think: this is the real autobiography, not the degrees, not the books, not the political opinions, not the clever rants—just the body and its ridiculous rebellions. A man can call himself rational, atheist, leftist, skeptic, whatever. Then a pinworm scratches its tiny signature into your night and you remember who’s really in charge.

I shuffle to the kitchen, make tea, stand there in my old T-shirt, stirring sugar like I’m dissolving evidence, and I feel, for one brief second, the absurd urge to be dignified. To be above it. To be the kind of man who has “principles.” Then my body gives a small warning itch—just a hint, a reminder, a wink from the microscopic underworld—and I stand there, alone with my tea, thinking of all the great speeches men make about nation and honor and purity, while my own private flagpole can’t even stay upright reliably, and my ass is basically an egg-laying beachfront property.

The smell hits first, always, a hot metallic piss tang with a note of wet cement and fried oil and something dead-but-not-committed-to-being-dead, the way a public stairwell smells at dawn when the city hasn’t decided yet whether it’s going to wake up or just lie there twitching, and I’m standing ankle-deep in a puddle that is neither rain nor sewage but some cuntish third thing invented by committee, watching a rebar skeleton poke through flaking concrete like bones through the ass of a starving cow, and my bladder does that traitorous clench where it wants to join the puddle out of solidarity, a worker’s strike in my own pelvis, because this is what solidarity looks like here: everyone leaks.

There’s a building—no, a promise of a building—leaning slightly like it heard a joke years ago and never recovered, wrapped in green netting that pretends to be safety the way prayer pretends to be engineering, and someone once cut a ribbon here, I swear to god they did, some motherfucker in a crisp shirt with a borrowed smile and a microphone that smelled like spit and disinfectant, and now the ribbon is gone but the spit remains, fossilized in spirit, and the concrete is already shedding its skin like a reptile with a thyroid problem.

I think about load-bearing capacity while holding in a fart, which feels right, because both are exercises in faith, and the fart wins, a small wet betrayal, because of course it does, and the building loses, because of course it does, and somewhere in the middle there’s a pamphlet explaining why none of this is anyone’s fault except time, weather, and vague enemies who live far away and are very jealous of our potential, which is a word we use the way drunks use tomorrow.

You can build a bridge out of math, that’s the thing they don’t tell you loudly enough, actual equations that don’t give a shit about elections or slogans or whether your uncle got the contract because he knows a guy who knows a guy who once shared a bidi with a minister’s cousin’s driver, and the equations will hold if you feed them honestly, if you give them good steel and patience and testing and a willingness to fail in small humiliating ways before the big humiliating collapse, but we skip the small humiliations because they’re boring and unphotogenic, and we go straight for the big ribbon and the bigger hoarding with a smiling family that does not live here and will never cross this bridge except in Photoshop.

I learned once—no, overheard, learned implies effort—that concrete cures slowly, that it is not dry when it looks dry, that water is not the enemy but the midwife, and I remember this while watching a contractor hose down a slab like he’s baptizing a reluctant baby, too fast, too much, because the schedule says today is curing day and tomorrow is inauguration day and the day after that is denial day, and I want to explain hydration curves and capillary action and microcracks but my mouth is busy tasting last night’s cheap liquor and the ghost of a cigarette I didn’t smoke but wanted to, and anyway nobody wants to hear about capillaries unless they’re bursting in someone else’s brain.

Colonial engineers wrote manuals, thick boring manuals full of tables and cautions and footnotes, and yes they were bastards and thieves and racists and the whole fucking parade, but they were meticulous bastards, and they built drains that still work because water does not respect your feelings, and somewhere along the line we kept the arrogance and lost the manuals, which is an impressive trick, like keeping the erection and losing the dick, and now we build drains that slope the wrong way because slope is a suggestion, and then we blame the monsoon like it’s a bad tenant who refuses to leave.

There is a particular confidence that comes from never having to fix what you broke, a confidence that swells like a hemorrhoid and hurts when you sit on it but you sit anyway because standing would require admitting you have a problem, and that confidence is everywhere, strutting in steel-toed boots over blueprints no one read, talking about scale and vision while the screws are counterfeit and the sand has more clay than a kindergarten art class, and the language gets weird, words like “world-class” and “global” and “next-generation” flung around like condoms at a fertility rally, because saying the word is cheaper than doing the thing.

I piss behind a half-finished wall because there is no finished wall anywhere nearby, and the piss arcs beautifully, physics still works, thank god, gravity still pulls, parabolic and honest, and it splashes onto a base that was supposed to anchor something permanent, and I think about entropy not as a cosmic abstraction but as a local sport, a neighborhood hobby, something you can watch with a cup of tea while your building sheds another tile like dandruff, and entropy wins not because it’s clever but because it shows up every day, which is more than can be said for maintenance.

Maintenance is the least sexy word in any language, it doesn’t get you laid, it doesn’t get you elected, it doesn’t get you a plaque, and it smells like grease and sweat and the humility of checking your own work, and so we avoid it, we fetishize creation and ignore custody, and then we act surprised when the baby grows up feral and bites us, and the metaphors pile up like illegal floors on an illegal building, each one worse than the last, but still cheaper than admitting we needed to spend money on boring people with clipboards.

There’s a science to failure too, a taxonomy of fuckups, and we specialize in the early bloomers, the ones that look impressive right before they rot, like fruit sprayed with shine and poison, and you can chart it: underestimate complexity, overestimate control, confuse velocity with direction, declare victory while the concrete is still warm, and then institutionalize forgetting so no one remembers the last time this exact cuntish sequence happened, which was, let me check my watch, five minutes ago.

I get horny at the wrong times, like now, because the body is an idiot savant that associates danger with blood flow, and there’s a billboard of a smiling couple promising luxury living above a site where a man is shitting into a plastic bag because the toilet block was inaugurated but never plumbed, and my body thinks this is erotic because it is stupid and alive, and I have to tuck the thought away like a bribe in a file, because public transport does not forgive.

Politics leaks into the cracks the way piss leaks into stairwells, not as ideology but as scheduling, the tyranny of the next date circled in red, and you can feel it in the materials, the way corners are cut with a knife that’s already dull, the way audits happen after the fact like autopsies that declare the patient died of being poor, and somewhere a committee will conclude that lessons were learned, which is a phrase that means nothing was learned and everyone got paid.

I once watched a fly land on wet cement and struggle, a tiny tragedy, its legs stuck, its wings buzzing uselessly, and for a moment I felt kinship, which is not flattering to either of us, and then someone stepped on it, mercy or negligence, hard to tell, and the cement kept curing, indifferent, because materials don’t care about metaphors, only ratios, and that fly is now part of the structure, load-bearing in a way no one planned.

The city hums, a constant electrical fart, and my stomach answers back, and I think about how systems fail not with a bang but with a shrug, with everyone assuming someone else checked the bolts, and how that shrug becomes culture, becomes a way of standing, a slouch that looks like confidence if you squint, and how exhausting it is to hold yourself upright when everything around you is leaning on you like a drunk friend who promises he’s fine.

By the time I leave, my shoes are sticky with someone else’s history, my bladder is empty, my head is full, and the building is still not a building, just a rumor held together with hope and rust and the certainty that no one will be punished because punishment requires clarity and clarity requires looking, and looking requires time, and time is expensive.

On the bus home, packed tight, I realize I’ve misjudged my body again, a small swelling of blood where it shouldn’t be, reacting to nothing in particular, and I angle my bag like a shield, pressed against strangers who smell like sweat and resignation, and through the window I see another skeleton rising, wrapped in green netting, already flaking, already leaning, already smiling for a camera that hasn’t arrived yet, and I think, not for the first time, that this whole place is held together by piss, rebar, and the unkillable belief that tomorrow will be different, which is funny, because tomorrow is already cracking.


# File: src/lib/posts/piss-in-a-propaganda-pool.md

title: "Piss in a Propaganda Pool"
