# File: src/lib/posts/ruminative-piss.md

---
title: "Ruminative Piss"
date: "2025-12-14"
description: "Depressive rumination is me doing the opposite of alchemy: taking the raw effluent of a sick mood and swallowing it, unfiltered, and then acting surprised when it poisons my perception."
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251214-WA0002.jpg"
category: "personal"
color: "black"
published: true
---

<script>
    // Context: Bipolar rumination and the alchemy of waste
</script> 

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251214-WA0002.jpg" 
    caption="The liquor of certainty"
/>

I have the picture open on my phone like a talisman I don’t trust, a little black-and-white man with a belly like a punctuation mark and a grin like a lie, tilting his head back to swallow something that is colored an indecent, almost cheerful yellow, the kind of yellow that belongs on a child’s plastic toy or the warning sticker on a pesticide bottle, not in the mouth of a grown man who already knows what his mind does when it wants to be cruel. You can see the metaphor I hope.

The room is doing its usual North Calcutta winter performance: air that looks innocent and smells like a committee decision, ceiling fan chopping lazily at nothing, a glass of water that tastes faintly of metal because everything tastes faintly of metal when you live in a city built from exhaust and resignation.

On the table sits a blister pack of pills—each tablet sealed like a tiny hostage negotiation, each one a choice between two embarrassing faiths: the faith that chemistry can patch a brain, and the faith that my brain is even patchable.

I pick one out. The foil gives that little crackle like it’s snickering. The yellow tablet sits on my fingertip, absurdly small for something that can rearrange the furniture of your inner universe. I swallow it, and for a second it sticks to my tongue like a rude guest who won’t leave, and my mind—being the considerate host that it is—immediately serves it a full meal of thoughts: 

> You’re pathetic. You’re late. You’re wasting your life. You’re a burden. You’re a joke. This pill is a joke. Your entire biography is a joke with footnotes.

That’s the snare. Not sadness itself. Sadness is honest. Sadness says: *something hurts*. Sadness is a bruise you can point to.

Depressive rumination is a different species. It’s my brain brewing a rancid little drink from old disappointments, future catastrophes, and the fermented sludge of comparison—and then insisting, with the confidence of a drunk uncle at a wedding, that what it’s serving is truth.

And I, in bipolar II depression, am perfectly capable of drinking it like it’s spring water.

# The Liquor of Certainty

People use the word “rumination” as if it’s a thoughtful thing, like a philosopher in a library stroking his chin, or a gentle cow in a field contemplating the metaphysics of grass.

The word is much more vulgar than that. It comes from Latin *ruminare*, to chew over; and behind that is the rumen, the first stomach of a ruminant—cows, goats, deer—those animals that swallow, then bring it back up, then chew it again, as if the universe might cough up a better flavor the second time.

*Bos taurus* does this with grass because grass is an engineering problem. Cellulose is stubborn. You need multiple passes, enzymes, microbial assistants, an entire internal factory to wring nutrition from something that is, to begin with, basically green cardboard.

Humans do it with thoughts because… because we can.

That’s the humiliating part. The cow has a reason. I do it because my nervous system is a gossip columnist with a chemistry set. In depression, the cud is always the same: a sentence I said wrong, a friendship I didn’t maintain, a door I didn’t knock on hard enough, a phone call I didn’t make, a version of myself that existed in some alternate timeline where I was less frightened and more disciplined and didn’t turn every ambition into a half-finished notebook.

The mental process feels productive because it has the shape of thinking—there’s motion, there’s repetition, there’s the little click-clack of logic pretending to be a train heading somewhere. But what it is, most of the time, is my brain chewing the same dead leaf until it’s convinced it has found the leaf’s hidden moral message: *You are the problem.*

And here’s the trick that makes it a snare rather than a habit: the conclusions arrive with the flavor of fact. Not “I feel like a failure.” Too honest, too provisional. No—depression prefers the courtroom voice. “You are a failure.” Full stop. Case closed. Court adjourned. Everyone go home.

I have been inside that court. I have been the judge, the prosecutor, the incompetent defense attorney who falls asleep during cross-examination, the stenographer typing “pathetic” for the fiftieth time, and the accused sitting there thinking, *Yes, yes, that’s fair.*

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251207-WA0008.jpg" 
    layout="iR"
    caption="The court adjourned"
    size={0.6}
/>

# How My Mood Becomes a Measurement Device

Somewhere in the back of my bookish skull there’s a little mathematician who wants to model everything, because models are clean and life is a public toilet. So I try to imagine what depression is doing in technical terms, not to “solve” it (nothing makes an illness laugh harder than being treated like a puzzle), but to keep my dignity by describing it accurately.

Here’s one version. The brain is a prediction machine. It’s constantly making guesses about the world—what will happen next, what people mean, what a sensation implies—and updating those guesses based on incoming data. If you want a nerdy picture, think of a kind of Bayesian update: prior beliefs plus evidence yields a posterior belief. You start with some expectation, you see something, you adjust.

In a well-behaved system, the confidence you assign to evidence matters. Noisy data gets downweighted. Reliable signals get honored. You don’t let one bad measurement convince you the planet has changed shape.

Depression, at least the depression I know, behaves like a sensor that has lost calibration and refuses to admit it. It doesn’t just deliver “negative thoughts.” It delivers them with high precision—as if the measurement error has dropped to zero. As if the instrument is perfectly trustworthy.

The thought arrives: *No one cares about you.* And the brain stamps it with the seal: **CERTIFIED TRUE**.
The thought arrives: *You will never fix this.* Stamp: **TRUE**.
The thought arrives: *Your best years are behind you.* Stamp: **TRUE**, with a flourish, as if the stamp itself is enjoying the performance.

Meanwhile, the actual evidence—people being kind, small accomplishments, the mere fact that moods change—gets treated as noise. Anomalies. Statistical outliers. “Doesn’t count.”

So I end up with a grotesque inversion of scientific method: my worst state becomes my most “accurate” state. Which is idiotic. It’s like insisting that a microscope is most reliable when someone has smeared Vaseline on the lens.

# Piss, Alchemy, and the Seduction of Extracting Meaning

The phrase I used—drinking ruminative piss—sounds like the kind of line that should get me banned from polite dinner parties, which is fine because I don’t go to polite dinner parties. But it’s also weirdly scientific.

Human beings have a long, proud history of doing disgusting things in the name of discovery. We have boiled corpses, dissected cadavers in candlelight, scraped mold off bread to make antibiotics, and—here’s my favorite—made light out of urine.

In the 1600s, a German alchemist named Hennig Brand tried to isolate the Philosopher’s Stone, because of course he did, and he decided urine was the right starting material, because urine contains “essence” and other words that mean “I have no idea what I’m doing but I’m committed.”

He collected buckets of it—imagine the smell, imagine the neighbors—and boiled it down, fermented it, heated it, distilled it, until he got a waxy substance that glowed in the dark. Phosphorus. From piss. Literal light from waste.

If that doesn’t summarize *Homo sapiens*, I don’t know what does: we are capable of turning the most humiliating bodily byproduct into something that can set ships on fire and also help plants grow.

So the problem isn’t that the mind generates waste. The mind generates waste the way the body does: constantly, inevitably, with a kind of bored competence. The problem is what I do with it.

Brand didn’t drink the urine. He processed it. He subjected it to heat and transformation. He treated it as raw material, not as a beverage. Depressive rumination is me doing the opposite: taking the raw effluent of a sick mood and swallowing it, unfiltered, and then acting surprised when it poisons my perception.

The snare is not merely pessimism. The snare is credulity. I become an alchemist who confuses his starting sludge for his final product.

# The Two Americas in My Head

When I was in America—those years between 1998 and 2014—there was an ambient faith in systems that I didn’t fully share but could at least recognize as a real cultural weather pattern.

The airport lines moved with a kind of stern efficiency. The forms were annoying, but they were legible. The shelves were stocked. The roads had rules that mostly worked. Even the nonsense had a disciplined, bureaucratic geometry to it, like a well-designed machine that occasionally pinches your finger.

I’m not romanticizing it. I saw poverty. I saw loneliness. I saw the quiet brutality of “meritocracy,” that lovely word people use when they want to believe their luck is virtue. But there was still a baseline belief that if you measured something, if you recorded it, if you argued about it, reality would eventually submit to some shared accounting.

Now, observing America from afar—the news clips, the algorithmic tantrums, the way every topic becomes a blood sport—I see something else: a nation caught in its own version of rumination, chewing the same fear until it tastes like prophecy.

The mechanism is identical to my depressive snare. A mood becomes a worldview. A feeling becomes a “fact.” A narrative becomes immune to counterexample. Everyone is certain. Everyone is furious. Everyone has a stamp.

And the funniest, saddest part is that this is happening in a country that gave the world so much of its modern infrastructure for truth-making: peer review, statistical literacy (in pockets), scientific institutions, investigative journalism, the whole Enlightenment apparatus with its powdered wigs and its beautiful, doomed optimism.

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251207-WA0009.jpg" 
    caption="Powdered wigs and doomed optimism"
/>

# Indian Education and the Cult of the Wrong Certainties

India, meanwhile, has its own specialty: teaching certainty without teaching the method by which certainty is earned. We cram. We memorize. We recite. We learn to perform answers the way a parrot performs devotion.

We are trained, from childhood, to treat authority as epistemology. If it’s in the book, it’s true. If it’s said by a teacher, it’s true. If it’s said by a loud man on a stage, it’s true. If it’s said with enough conviction and a microphone that squeals, it becomes truer. And then we grow up and wonder why fraud flourishes like algae.

My depression loves that cultural training. It uses the same template. A thought appears with authority—because it is loud, because it is repetitive, because it has the tone of certainty—and I accept it the way I accepted textbook definitions as a child: obediently, fearfully, as if disagreement is a moral defect.

Depression is an internal authoritarian regime. It doesn’t debate. It declares.

The irony is that I’m an atheist, a skeptic, allergic to grandstanding, the kind of person who will argue about the misuse of a word in a newspaper headline—yet the loudest tyrant in my life is a mood state, and I still hand it the keys.

# The Mechanical Snare

Rumination is seductive because it has the moral aesthetic of effort. If I lie in bed doing nothing, I feel guilty. If I lie in bed thinking miserable thoughts, I feel… industrious. As if I’m paying rent for my existence by suffering.

This is the puritanical accountant in my skull: misery as proof of seriousness.

So I pace mentally, revisiting old scenes like a director reshooting the same bad movie, convinced that if I find the right angle—if I replay the moment with enough precision—I will discover the secret lever that makes the story different. But the past is not a machine with a hidden gear. The past is a dead animal. Chewing it does not resurrect it. It just gives you the taste of rot.

In bipolar II depression there’s also a special cruelty: the memory that I have been other versions of myself. I have had days when my mind is quick, when connections sparkle, when I can write with that slightly manic electricity where everything is linked—history to math, etymology to politics, the smell of winter air to the concept of entropy.

And then the depression arrives and says: *That was an illusion. That was you being delusional. This—this heaviness, this contempt, this certainty of doom—is the real you.*

# A Brief Zoology of My Thoughts

Some thoughts are like mosquitoes. Annoying, high-pitched, easily slapped away if you’re awake enough.
Some thoughts are like stray dogs: persistent, hungry, capable of following you for miles, not evil, just desperate.

Depressive ruminations are like feral pigs that have discovered the pantry. They don’t just intrude. They rearrange the house. They knock over chairs. They root around in every corner until you can’t remember what the room looked like before they arrived.

And the worst ones have costumes.
They dress up as philosophy: *Life is meaningless; everything decays; all effort is vanity.*
They dress up as economics: *The system is rigged; you have no leverage; you will always lose.*
They dress up as morality: *You are selfish; you are weak; you don’t deserve care.*
They dress up as “realism,” that fashionable word people use when they want to confuse cynicism with accuracy.

Sometimes they even dress up as compassion: *You should withdraw so you don’t bother anyone.*

That’s a particularly vile disguise, because it makes self-erasure feel like virtue. I have to remind myself—often in the most blunt, unpoetic language possible—that a thought being elaborate does not make it true. The brain can produce nonsense at any IQ level. In fact, high IQ nonsense is the most dangerous nonsense, because it comes with citations.

# The Small Counterspell

There is a modest practice I return to, not as salvation, not as cure, but as a way to keep my head above the swamp. I try to treat thoughts the way I treat weather.

When it is humid and polluted outside, I do not conclude: *The universe is made of poison.* I conclude: *The air is bad today.* Then I close the window, run the fan, drink water, wait.

Similarly, when my mind is producing the bleak, contemptuous, ruminative piss of depression, I try—try, imperfectly, sometimes with theatrical failure—to say: **This is a mood. This is chemistry. This is weather inside the skull.**

Not “fake.” Not “invalid.” Weather is real. It just isn’t the whole climate. Depression wants me to confuse a storm for the planet.

So I do something that feels childish but is, for me, a form of scientific hygiene: I write the thought down and label it. Not with poetry. With tags.

* “Mood-generated.”
* “High certainty, low evidence.”
* “Old tape.”
* “Not actionable.”

It’s like putting a hazardous material sticker on a container. It doesn’t make the container disappear, but it does prevent me from sipping it absentmindedly while pretending it’s tea.

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251207-WA0023.jpg" 
    layout="iL"
    caption="Hazardous materials"
/>

# The Bitter Joke

The most ridiculous part of the whole affair—the part that would be funny if it weren’t my daily furniture—is how quickly I grant authority to my ugliest mental state.

If I’m slightly hopeful, I interrogate it like a suspicious customs officer. *What are you doing here? Show your documents. Prove you’re not delusion.*
If I’m miserable, I hand it a chair and offer it snacks. *Welcome, sir. Please, take the microphone.*

Why? Because misery aligns with my fears, and fears always feel like wisdom. Fear is ancient. Fear kept our ancestors alive long enough to reproduce. Fear has the atavistic prestige of survival. Hope feels like a luxury item, like imported cheese: probably fake, probably adulterated, probably too expensive for my constitution.

So I accept the cheap local brew—my own ruminative piss—because it is familiar, because it is bitter in the way I’ve been trained to believe truth must be bitter.

That’s the snare in one sentence: I equate pain with accuracy. And then I wonder why I live like a man who keeps licking a cracked battery to “check” if it still works.

# A Small Defiance, Quietly Embarrassed

Tonight the room will do its usual thing again. The winter air will press itself against the walls. The fan will turn. The phone will offer me a buffet of things to be outraged by. My brain will attempt, with its familiar zeal, to build a cathedral out of my shortcomings and then kneel before it.

I will not win some heroic victory over it. That kind of story is for motivational speakers and people selling courses.

But I can do one small defiant act: I can refuse to confuse the drink with the truth. I can look at the thought—*You are finished*—and say, in my most tired, unromantic voice, *You are a symptom, not a prophecy.*

I can take the picture of the grinning man swallowing yellow certainty and see it for what it is: a cartoon of my own gullibility. And then I can do something almost insultingly ordinary, something that doesn’t flatter my misery with attention.

I can close the blister pack.
I can put the glass in the sink.
I can open a book and let someone else’s sentences borrow my nervous system for a while.

Or—because I am exactly the kind of person who does this—I can delete a paragraph I just wrote, not because it’s “bad,” but because I can feel the ruminative tone trying to turn itself into doctrine, and I don’t want to publish doctrine; I want to publish evidence of a mind wrestling with itself and occasionally refusing to drink what it produces.

The light goes off with a soft click. In the dark, my brain will still try to hand me that cup. In the dark, I can still decide—quietly, without drama, without holiness—not to raise it to my mouth.

# File: src/lib/posts/shitting-on-a-cramped-asian-toilet.md

---
title: Calcutta Toilet
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20260113-WA0001.jpg"
description: "A graphic, foul, funny and depressingly accurate depiction of the absurd daily humiliation of squatting over a filthy pan while the tap runs dry mid-wipe."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "black"
---

<Pi src="IMG-20260113-WA0001.jpg" />



The shit came out sideways.

Not metaphorically, not as some sly turn of phrase for moral collapse or the political climate or the nation’s collective constipation—no, I mean it *literally* exited my ass with a velocity and angular deviation that made me think my sphincter had developed its own gravitational field and was now participating in astrophysics without my consent.

This was inside a public toilet in north-central Calcutta, or maybe Dum Dum, or Behala, or Burrabazar, or anywhere else the smell of humanity’s digestive regret hits you like a gut punch from God with IBS. One of those "pay and use" models of hygiene theater where the entry costs 2 rupees and the exit costs your fucking will to live.

The floor was a mosaic of old piss, recent piss, confused spit, and something green that moved when I didn’t look directly at it.

And the door didn’t lock.

And the lightbulb didn’t work.

And the fan spun like a dying ceiling angel who hated you.

And the mug had teeth marks.

Teeth. Fucking. Marks.

And I had to squat like a demented ape being punished for existing, right foot barely resting on the slippery edge of a pan that seemed designed for someone with the body mass of a feral cat and the thigh strength of a gymnast. My knees pressed against my chest. My balls stuck to my thigh. My back ached. My spine whimpered. And then, the pièce de merde—*the tap coughed and died.*

One last droplet, like a stingy pension from a dead bureaucracy, fell with theatrical delay onto the dry aluminum mug—mocking me, announcing: “This is all you get, bitch.”

Why, in the name of Euclid and all that’s geometrically holy, are Indian public toilets designed like punishment cells in a Soviet sex cult? Why the narrow width? Why the crumbling cement alcoves that are too small for even a rat to turn around in, and yet still contain one (who is also shitting, but more gracefully)? Why the slanted floors that guarantee your own shit will chase you like a determined duckling?

The science of it makes no sense. See, squat toilets are biomechanically superior—yeah yeah, your anorectal angle opens up, puborectalis relaxes, the poop flows—but what good is that when you’re being dripped on by a ceiling leak that smells like fermented leg sweat, and the water source below your ass has tapped out like a drunk uncle at a wedding?

You think I’m exaggerating?

Picture this: the mug is there, but there’s no water. The tap gives nothing. The wall has graffiti—some scratched sex hotline, some political slogan now half-washed off by decades of despair—and the only thing even *remotely* absorbent is a torn poster for a tantric baba who guarantees longer erections and visa approval in 30 days.

There is no dignity.

There is only the reality of your own body’s betrayal. Of the chap from the roadside stall you shouldn’t have eaten. Of the pakoda that tasted just a little *too* tangy. Of the chai with milk that may or may not have been boiled this century. And all of it has now conspired into a digestive protest rally marching out of your rectum with slogans and banners and fucking drums.

No one knocks.

No one interrupts.

No one *needs* to.

Because the building itself is a performance. The walls tremble when someone next door sneezes. The flush from a different stall echoes through the concrete like a ghost moaning into a bucket. You hear it all—the endless chorus of squats and spits and sighs and farts and the occasional grunt of someone whose soul is trying to exit their body via their colon.

A man walks past the open top half of your stall wall. You see his eyes. He sees yours. You both pretend nothing happened. You both die a little inside.

And then there’s the final insult: *wiping.*

You check your pockets like a man searching for redemption in a wallet of expired train tickets and gut bacteria. You find nothing but the edge of a grocery receipt and a piece of tissue folded so many times it’s now denser than neutronium and just as cruel. 

You look at the door.

You look at the crack in the floor where something just skittered.

You look at your hand.

You consider your options.

And you realize the real genius of Indian culture isn’t zero, or surgery, or nonviolence—it’s managing to maintain national cohesion while every citizen has, at some point, wiped their ass with newspaper and shame in a 40-degree cement chamber that smells like an exorcism gone wrong.

Eventually, you shuffle out.

Half-washed. Humiliated. Hollow.

You walk out into the sunlight blinking like a man reborn, but not really. You will carry this scent for hours. You will not talk about it. You will pretend your soul is intact.

You will go to work.

And yes, the erection came later.

Don’t ask why.


# File: src/lib/posts/simpsons-fucking-paradox-in-garia.md

---
title: "Simpson’s Fucking Paradox"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20260113-WA0005.jpg"
date: 2026-01-16
description: "A gas-leaking meditation on statistical illusions, half-dead erections, and why the suburbs of South Calcutta feel like quantum traps of piss and regret."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "orange"
---

<Pi src="IMG-20260113-WA0005.jpg" />



My stomach made that sound again.

You know the one I mean—like a whale getting punched in the gut underwater by a slightly confused but well-meaning kraken. Followed by a low, accusatory *glorp* that echoes through your asshole like a municipal drainpipe regurgitating tea shop leftovers. I was squatting in my miniature bathroom—the one where the plastic water bucket and the commode have a toxic relationship—and I was calculating whether I had time to run the geyser before the next splashdown, but alas, South Calcutta had already decided. The inverter had conked out. And this bastard part of the city, once a proud dumping ground of post-liberalisation optimism and broken concrete socialist dreams, now sat squelching under its own armpit sweat, too far from everything, too close to itself.

Now, here's the thing: I’m not dumb.

I know what paradox means. I know what averages do. I once scored 100 in math. I know that your average fuck doesn’t mean every thrust was worthwhile. But *Simpson’s Paradox* is a cocksucker. Not the charming kind that buys you tea and rubs your shoulder while you confess your soft dick never quite recovered from 2008. No. This is the one that says you’re improving—in every subgroup—yet still somehow you’re getting fucked harder in the total. It’s the statistical equivalent of Calcutta real estate logic: every flat is selling better than last year, every block says sales are rising, but the whole goddamn sector has collapsed like my left testicle in winter.

I live in a neighbourhood where time bends backwards.

Not in a sexy Nolan way with violins and reversed explosions, but in a saggy, existentially constipated loop. The grocery shop has had the same fly inside the jar of *chanachur* since Diwali. The postman delivers letters from the 90s. The plumber wears pants so tight the very crack of dawn peeks out when he bends. Nothing dies here. Even the pigeons look depressed but immortal. You can walk for forty-five minutes and see only two things: temples being repainted in blood-red and teenage boys playing cricket in drainage water like they’re training for a mutant IPL team.

So when I try to explain Simpson’s Paradox to someone—say, the gas delivery boy with suspiciously well-groomed armpits—I use this neighbourhood.

See, I say, imagine two apartment buildings. Both are showing more electricity uptime than last year. Their maintenance costs are lower. Less rats, more lights. Great. But when you add their data together for the whole area, *total* uptime is lower than last year. Why? Because the bigger building got a lot worse and had more tenants. It weighs the average down, like my fucking beer belly weighs down my dreams of ever buttoning a shirt without sweating. Everything looks better inside, but shittier outside.

That’s South Calcutta.

Every house has a small victory—a new LED bulb, a child not addicted to PUBG, a grandmother who only mildly praises Hitler—but the neighbourhood as a whole is disintegrating into a fungal nostalgia pit of sewage, tuition fees, and delayed marriages. That’s Simpson’s Paradox with bidi smoke. The illusion of progress depends on how you slice the groups. Grouped one way, you're surviving. Grouped another, you're face down in pisswater pretending it’s therapy.

And speaking of slicing groups—I sometimes wish I could statistically segment my life.

Take the two me’s. The one who reads PDF copies of philosophical essays about urine symbolism in Beckett, and the one who scratches his balls on the balcony at 2:17 a.m. thinking about whether any of his exes ever masturbated to the memory of his left nipple. Both those me’s are improving. One has grown intellectually. The other now knows which bakery uses expired flour. But aggregate me? Oh, that motherfucker is falling apart. Lying to himself with clean Excel sheets while jerking off to Instagram reels of people making sandwiches with cleavage.

My local doctor, the guy who still uses a mercury sphygmomanometer like it’s 1962 and radio is king, told me I was showing signs of “urban deflation.”

Not depression. Deflation. Like my soul was an old tire on Gariahat flyover, slowly leaking air but still pretending it could go another mile if the traffic cop wasn’t looking. He told me to walk in the mornings. I tried. But walking in Garia is a full-contact sport. You either dodge a feral scooter, a vegetable seller’s scream, or a retired uncle whose farts have gravitational pull. And the moment your brain tries to meditate, your asshole remembers you had milk tea with roadside muri last night and decides to initiate Operation Mudslide.

Let’s talk about that tea.

Tea here is made by people who hate existence but love overboiling. There’s this little corner shop—paint peeling off like postmenopausal dandruff—that serves tea in plastic cups so thin they melt before you’re done. One sip and you know three things: you will fart, you will regret, and you will come back. Because even regret is routine in this city. Even bad decisions become part of your gut biome. And this—this—is where Simpson’s Paradox becomes a gastrointestinal metaphor: each cup is better than the last, but your body still collapses into acidic rebellion.

I miss the kind of statistical clarity we had as children.

Did you poop? Yes or no. Was the fish tasty? Yes or no. Did that boy touch your dick behind the library? Yes or no. But adulthood is averages, and averages are lies. Like when my mother tells people I’m doing "well" now. What she means is I’m not in jail, not dead, and not married. That's the holy trinity of mediocrity here. By subgroup? Sure, I’m thriving. I’ve got books, lube, a rice cooker, and mild porn-induced wrist strain. But in aggregate? I'm a declining trendline no amount of data smoothing can save.

Sometimes I think this whole area is one giant statistical error margin.

The milk is always “almost” fresh. The plumber is “nearly” coming. The metro is “about” to be completed. And every woman I’ve ever liked is “not entirely” unavailable. You can’t even properly fail here. You just asymptote toward irrelevance like a limp dick in a cold bathroom trying to reach an orgasm that’s already archived.

People ask me why I don’t move.

I tell them: I am the moving. I am the entropy. If I leave, the rats will miss me, the pigeons will unionize, and the local paan-stained walls will forget how to listen. I am statistically insignificant, but topologically trapped. And besides, where would I go? North Calcutta hates me for leaving. South Calcutta laughs while fingering its bellybutton and offering me another glass of lukewarm boredom. And Salt Lake? Fuck Salt Lake. It’s like a failed Dubai cosplay run by retired engineers who think they invented water.

The paradox isn’t just in the stats. It’s in the body.

My knees hurt less than last year. My blood pressure’s better. I drink more water. But I also cry in the kitchen while microwaving dal for one. I cum less. Dream less. My mother no longer knocks on the door to ask if I’m okay. She just assumes I’m alive because the electricity bill still arrives.

And that, I suppose, is how life works here.

Statistically improving. Experientially rotting. 

Just like my underarms, which now smell like detergent-covered despair and hint of onions from a lunch I didn’t even eat.

Today, I tried to jerk off while watching an ASMR video of a woman whispering math facts. 

I stopped halfway—not from guilt, but because she said “confidence intervals” and I remembered I had to pay my internet bill.

Then my phone buzzed with a Swiggy notification for discounted *rajma chawal*.

And I came anyway.

# File: src/lib/posts/sporefuckers.md

---
title: "Sporefuckers"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20260113-WA0002.jpg"
date: 2026-01-13
description: "Two faces. One rage. An hourglass womb of ideological herpes. Or maybe just a fucked-up sketch of every relationship I’ve had with a government, a lover, or myself."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "orange"
---

<Pi src="IMG-20260113-WA0002.jpg" />


Two faces—both moustached, both masculine, both farcical reflections of each other like government and opposition humping in sync while pretending to swordfight. One smug in his smugness, the other furious in his fury, like two versions of constipation: the clenching and the denial. They glare across a shared womb of spores—those stippled black bursts that look like the kind of thing you find on a corpse when you dig it up too late for an autopsy but too early for forgiveness.

This isn’t just a standoff.

This is theatre. This is the pointless, masturbatory debate culture of the subcontinent. This is Times Now and its five-paneled orgy of sound. This is two sides of the same coin trying to scratch each other’s eyes out, unaware that the coin is melting in acid. And I’m stuck in the middle, not as a referee but as collateral damage. Fungally impregnated by the sheer dumbness of it all.

Because here’s the real twist of the knife: when you suppress nuance, when truth becomes this moist, contaminated afterthought, the quarrel becomes the main dish. The performance becomes policy. The spore-field in the middle, the symbolic womb of their shared idiocy, isn’t a battleground. It’s a **breeding ground**.

Every time they face off, something new and more diseased is born.

The new sedition bill.
The new god.
The new enemy.
The new show.

And I, unfortunate observer, am reduced to piss-stream epistemology—trying to decode national collapse while my urethra burns slightly from too much black tea and not enough dignity.

There’s no balance here.
No opposition.
Only **mirrored ego**.
Only loudness.

The kind that drowns out my bowel movements and my better judgment. The kind that spackles over history with patriotic glitter and wipes its ass with the constitution, all while claiming moral victory in the debate you didn’t ask for.

I used to think both-sides-ism was cowardice.

Now I know it’s a kindness.
Because neither side deserves a full endorsement
and both are violently committed
to losing me.

So I boil my tea till it tastes like ash.
Burn my tongue.
Sip again.
Watch them argue with each other’s reflections
as the fungus in the middle multiplies.
And I laugh.

Because one day, the spores will eat them
and I won’t even have to flush.


# File: src/lib/posts/starry-eyed-shitfuckery.md

---
title: "Starry-Eyed Shitfuckery"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20260115-WA0002.jpg"

description: "A foaming, furious, foul-mouthed rant on India's star-promise political theatre, the willing gullibility of its electorate, and the stomach-churning cycles of empty hope, set against the visual absurdity of leaders who point at stars like they’re ripe mangoes."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "orange"
---

<Pi src="IMG-20260115-WA0002.jpg" />



There was once this cockfaced municipal candidate, khadi-shirted, Gandhi-topi tilted like an erection after an accidental thigh brush, sweat rings under his armpits shaped like the map of Greater Bengal if you squinted and held in a fart, standing on a broken dais in front of a borrowed mic (which smelled like fermented curry spit and rusted dreams), pointing up to the sky with the same hand he had absolutely scratched his ass with, proclaiming: **"Vote for me, and I will give you that star."**

Yes. That actual flaming fuckball in the sky. That thermonuclear bindi of false hope.

The crowd clapped. Some farted. One motherfucker fainted from spiritual excitement or dehydration or both. One old constipated skeleton in a gamchha cried actual tears, either because of blind devotion or because he thought the promise involved free adult diapers. No one laughed. Not a single bastard laughed. They believed it.

Not metaphorically. Literally. They *actually* thought—if they voted for this moustache-sporting maniac with onion breath and a violent twitch—that somehow, by some celestial reacharound, the motherfucker would lasso that flaming nuclear tit in the sky and hang it from a lamppost in Howrah like a Durga Puja chandelier.

And here’s the really dangerous thing: they *wanted* to believe it. Needed to. Like how you need to believe that the fucking woman on Tinder with a pout and filter and “sapiosexual” in her bio is not a bored BTech dropout trying to scam you out of 800 rupees and your semen.

Because the truth is: life here is so fucking humiliating, so chronically bowel-gnawing, so filled with piss-streaked government stairwells and diesel coughs and erections of pointless bureaucracy—*that you’d rather believe the lie.*

You’d rather die clutching a fake star in your hand than live staring at a real pothole in your lane that nobody has fixed since Indira Gandhi’s left tit started sagging.

And this isn’t just one time. No, motherfucker, this is every five years. Like seasonal herpes. The lies get recycled like temple prasad. Same shit, different turban.

"I will build a bridge to Pakistan."

"I will make India a 5 trillion dollar economy."

"I will give free electricity, free petrol, free pussy, free Wi-Fi, free rainbows, free immortality."

All shouted with veins popping, arms flailing, moustaches flapping like dying rats in a blender. Behind them, always—*always*—a fucking banner with one sad, flickering, five-pointed yellow star. Like some cosmic sticker of approval granted by the Universe’s dumbest intern.

But the bastards *eat it up*.

This entire country is like a man who keeps going back to the same STD clinic and every time the doctor tells him, “Stop fucking goats,” he says “This time it’ll be different. I wore a condom made of banana leaf.” And then scratches his burning urethra while humming the national anthem.

Hope is the most overrated drug.

Even heroin has the dignity of withdrawal.

Hope just makes you stupid *on loop*.

And it’s not just the poor. Oh no, don’t you dare think it’s just the rice-packet voters and chapati-hungry schoolchildren waving tricolor flags outside the ration shop. No. The educated are worse. More insidious. They read policy PDFs. They quote GDP forecasts. They masturbate to "infrastructure growth" charts. But the second some slick-haired prick in a kurta says, “We will touch the stars together,” they start weeping like they just heard Lata Mangeshkar sing through a seashell.

It’s like this whole country is stuck in a *collective religious orgasm*, 24x7, where logic goes to die like a flatulent goat in a temple fire.

And speaking of goats: why the fuck do we elect the same bleating shitbags over and over? Same families. Same slogans. Same ritualistic touching of the air in front of statues like they’re giving invisible handjobs to ghosts of failed freedom fighters.

Because it’s not about governance. No, you prick. It’s *theatre*.

India is not a democracy. It’s a 1.4 billion–strong improv play where every actor shits their pants and still gets a standing ovation because “at least he’s not that other guy.”

The only thing more dangerous than a lying politician is a population that gets a hard-on from the lie.

And I know this because I’ve seen it happen since I was five years old.

Same slogans. Same bastard promises.

They promised my father a job.

They promised my mother clean water.

They promised me internet and dignity and at least one fucking moment of truth in public life that didn’t make me want to rip my own nipples off and mail them to Rashtrapati Bhavan.

Instead?

Brown tap water. Broken job market. And an internet so full of cockroach-brained influencers that I feel like strangling myself with my LAN cable every morning.

The last time someone promised to "give me a star", they were a party worker with halitosis handing out stickers that had glitter glue on them and made my shirt smell like fevicol and sad childhood.

You know what that star is?

It’s constipation.

That’s what it is. It’s a tight, throbbing, unreachable thing lodged so far up the national rectum, we’ve mistaken the pain for destiny.

We point to it.

We elect it.

We worship it.

We name our babies after it.

And we never, ever fucking ask why it keeps disappearing the moment the rally ends and the lights go off and the diesel generator dies with a cough that sounds suspiciously like a resigned “fuck you.”

And I?

I sit here in my dim rented room in this dying Calcutta para, surrounded by mosquitoes that vote more wisely than humans, my feet crusted with old skin flakes, watching my broken rice cooker bubble like a fart in a bathtub, and I try—*really try*—to imagine what it must feel like to believe again.

To be part of that idiot choir that looks at a man pointing to a celestial gas ball and thinks “Yes. He loves me.”

But all I can think about is the last time I trusted someone, I ended up with my dick in one hand and a ration card in the other, wondering which one would be more useful when the world burns.


# File: src/lib/posts/static-equilibrium.md

---
title: "Static Equilibrium"
date: "2025-12-25"
description: "I live, increasingly, as one who has stepped aside from the main current of time, not in protest but in fatigue, inhabiting a private margin where days resemble one another too closely to require naming."
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251207-WA0013.jpg"
category: "personal"
color: "black"
published: true
---



<Pi
    src="IMG-20251207-WA0013.jpg" 
    caption="where a gecko remains perfectly still"
/>

There is a line from **L. P. Hartley**. It opens his 1953 novel **The Go-Between**:

> **“The past is a foreign country; they do things differently there.”**

A single sentence that manages to feel like a passport stamp, a warning label, and an ache all at once. It’s often misquoted, but that’s the canonical wording—the quiet, devastating kind that keeps being true the longer you live. I remember it as I wake before the fan has finished one of its weary wintry revolutions on Christmas night, already aware—through the thin, damp cotton of the sheet—of that particular sweat which is not the product of heat but of memory itself, as though telescoped to my past, having found no other outlet, had chosen the skin as its medium of return, ignoring the time of day, the calendar month or the air circulation from the fan blades. 

The room, still half-submerged in night, smells faintly of soap, old fabric, and the indefinable residue of days that have been lived too similarly, and in that smell, inseparable from the present moment yet belonging to no single time, there rises the figure of my mother—not as she is now, seated somewhere far away beneath another ceiling fan, but as a persistent principle, a living archive in whom my earlier selves continue to exist with a coherence that I myself no longer possess.

# The Architecture of Cowardice 

It is perhaps this knowledge—that she remembers me intact—that makes her at once indispensable and unbearable. For when I think of her, I do not think merely of a person but of an entire apartment, with its mosaic floor chilled in winter mornings, its light filtered through curtains browned by decades of Calcutta dust, its cupboards preserving the odors of camphor, paper, and meals long digested. 

To visit her would be to submit myself to that space where memory is not speculative but architectural, where the walls themselves seem to insist that I once occupied them with purpose, movement, and an expectation of continuity. And so I visit my old apartment in North Calcutta infrequently as the walls that prop me up are vulnerable to collapse in conversations—I fear it will come out I am made out of thin air, so I choose distance from all that was once familiar, friend or family, not from indifference, but from a kind of self-preservation that resembles cowardice only because it lacks a nobler name.

Lying there, listening to the fan’s uneven rhythm—slightly off-balance, as though one blade had accumulated more history than the others—I become acutely conscious of how reduced my inner life has grown, how many dimensions have quietly collapsed without ceremony. Once, thought branched outward, seeking objects, problems, explanations; now it circles, like air in a closed room, conserving energy rather than spending it. 

The sciences I once trusted for their clarity return to me only as metaphors: damping without oscillation, systems settling into low-energy states, equilibrium mistaken for rest. I recognize these ideas not intellectually but bodily, in the heaviness of my limbs, in the reluctance of breath to complete itself with confidence.

# Treacherous Sparks

At moments—treacherous moments—I feel a sudden quickening, a sensation like the striking of a match in darkness, and for an instant the world appears once more connected, actionable, almost hospitable. I think, absurdly, that I am better than this, that I might yet re-enter life as one steps back into a conversation left unfinished. 

But even as the thought forms, I sense its fragility, its dependence on borrowed oxygen, and before it can reach the dignity of a full sentence, it extinguishes itself, leaving behind only the faint odor of disappointment. What remains is not despair exactly, but an alert resignation, the knowledge that such sparks, though vivid, are not durable enough to be trusted.

Language itself seems complicit in this erosion. Words like “depression,” learned first as abstractions, now press down with a literal weight; terms like “withdrawal” describe not a gesture but a habitat. I live, increasingly, as one who has stepped aside from the main current of time, not in protest but in fatigue, inhabiting a private margin where days resemble one another too closely to require naming. I tell myself this is clarity, that illusions have simply been stripped away, yet I know there is a cruelty in such lucidity, a narrowing of possibility disguised as wisdom.

# Morning

When morning finally intrudes—grey, tentative, without promise—I sit up and observe the room as though it belonged to someone else: the books that have ceased to instruct and now merely witness, the glass of water left untouched overnight, the pale wall where a gecko remains perfectly still yet animated, animated in a scientific fiction I imagine, naughty and irresistible flights of fancy I afford, but in reality it is motionless, surviving by a mastery of stillness perhaps only I can imitate. 

Somewhere, my mother's nurse will be making tea for my mother, repeating gestures perfected over habit and instructions, and my mother will be sipping that tea, believing—perhaps correctly—that continuity itself is a form of care. I do not move toward her, nor away. I remain where I am, suspended in the present, which is neither painful nor consoling, but simply there, like the fan above me, turning, imperfectly, again.


# File: src/lib/posts/substances-simples.md

---
title: "Substances Simples"
date: "2025-12-07"
description: "Lavoisier’s basic Lego set of the universe: an official list of what counted as indivisible building blocks. Except, being human, he got it partly right and partly gloriously wrong."
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251203-WA0006.jpg"
category: "science"
color: "blue"
published: true
---

Somewhere between my school diarrhea and my adult bipolar doomscrolling there was, of course, chemistry class, that noble enterprise where a bored teacher with halitosis pointed to a laminated blue-and-pink periodic table and told us, with all the gravitas of a government notification on onion prices, that Antoine Lavoisier was the “Father of Modern Chemistry.” What she did not tell us was that this particular father of chemistry was also a father of taxes, a part-owner of a delightful exploitative racket called the Ferme Générale, and that his head eventually parted ways with the rest of his person because the French revolutionaries were not very keen on nuanced performance reviews.

Our textbook had the usual bullet point:

* Lavoisier discovered oxygen.
* Lavoisier disproved phlogiston.
* Lavoisier was guillotined.

As if that last line was a casual HR exit: “Left company in 1794 for personal reasons,” instead of “had neck forcibly uninstalled by nation-state using sharpened steel and gravity.”

What fascinated me, much later—not in that farts-and-fenugreek classroom—was that Lavoisier didn’t work alone. There was Marie-Anne, his wife, who is introduced in most Indian textbooks, when she appears at all, like a side salad: “His wife helped by drawing diagrams.” As if she were some 18th-century Canva plugin. The reality was that she was translating English papers, annotating Priestley’s misadventures with “dephlogisticated air,” drawing meticulous apparatus that, frankly, would put most modern “figures” in Indian journals (those pixelated MS-Paint tragedies) to shame, and cheerfully helping dismantle the great invisible fart of phlogiston that had wafted over European chemistry for a century.

Picture the scene: a Parisian lab, copper kettles and glassware that looked like fragile alien intestines, Lavoisier measuring mass like a tax accountant of atoms, and Marie-Anne quietly sketching and annotating, doing with pen and ink what your brain wishes it could do with reality—track every tube, every flame, every bubble. While outside, the same city was sharpening the very blade that would later separate his careful head from the rest of the experimental apparatus.

Now, the part I really love—the sort of thing that would have made my Bengali schoolboy self sit up in class, instead of counting ceiling fans—is his Table des Substances Simples, the precursor to the periodic table we memorized without understanding. This was Lavoisier’s “basic Lego set” of the universe: an official list of what counted as indivisible building blocks. Except, being human, he got it partly right and partly gloriously wrong.

In the “right” column: familiar characters like oxygen, hydrogen, sulfur, phosphorus, iron, silver, carbon. Things that do, in fact, behave like elements, stubbornly refusing to be broken by the chemistry of that time. These were the kids who really existed in the classroom.

In the “wrong-but-charmingly-hopeful” column:

* **Caloric** – a sort of invisible, imponderable fluid of heat, like a ghost curry that flowed from hot to cold.
* **Light** – treated as a substance you could, in principle, pour into the universe like mustard oil.
* **Various “earths”** – lime, magnesia, and other crumbly powders that they hadn’t yet bullied into admitting they were compounds hiding metals.

To my Indian exam-conditioned brain, this was heresy. How could the Father of Modern Anything be wrong? In our system, once you are fathered into something, you are permanently correct, embalmed in multiple-choice questions and photocopied notes with fungus. Yet here was Lavoisier, in his own printed table, solemnly listing heat and light alongside oxygen and sulfur, mixing what we now consider concepts with what we now consider entities—like printing a class roll where half the entries are actual students and the rest are “discipline,” “sunlight,” and “tiffin.”

But that’s exactly the point, isn’t it? At any given moment, Homo sapiens’s proud “table of substances simples” is a desk full of mislabeled jars. You think you’ve separated the elements from the fantasies, and it turns out some of the jars are full of mythology, some of the labels are nationalistic bullshit, and one or two are just warm air from a bearded guru on primetime TV.

In my childhood, the Indian equivalent of caloric and light were things like “meritocracy,” “ancient Indian science,” “Vedic aviation,” and the notion that coaching-center ranks are a measure of intelligence. These were our substances simples—not to be challenged, only to be inhaled. Lavoisier, at least, measured masses and wrote equations. We just write slogans and exam questions.

Lavoisier’s head rolled because his second job—tax farming—was more visible to the mob than his first job—mass balance and careful thinking. The revolutionaries basically said, “The Republic has no need of scientists or tax farmers,” then proceeded to invent a century of science they absolutely did need, but using other people’s heads stuck more delicately to their necks. Marie-Anne, widowed, carried on preserving his notebooks, editing his papers, keeping the intellectual corpse warm long after the biological one had cooled. In any sane textbook, she’d be co-author of the whole enterprise; in ours, she is an optional first-line mention, like “also starring…”

This is the part that hooks into my present, sitting in Calcutta with particulate matter wedged in my already enfeebled lungs. I look around and see our updated local table des substances simples:

* **“Growth”** – regardless of what grows: GDP, tumors, or shopping malls.
* **“Development”** – defined as concrete per square foot and LED strips per balcony.
* **“Heritage”** – a grab-bag of unverified myths laminated with saffron or tricolor.
* **“Content”** – the new caloric, an invisible fluid that flows endlessly from phones and is somehow supposed to nourish us though it mostly causes intellectual rickets.

All of these are treated as basic, indivisible, beyond question. Yet, like caloric, they are probably doomed to be reclassified one day as incredibly elaborate fiction. Some future bipolar kid may scroll through our remains and say, “Wait, they thought this was real?”

I find comfort, perversely, in Lavoisier’s mistakes. The man who carved “nothing is lost, nothing is created, everything is transformed” into the woodwork of science still filled his own table with ghosts—heat fluids, light stuff, earthy clumps. He got beheaded not for those errors, but for participating in a predatory system that made peasants bleed so the elite could powder their wigs. The chemistry was the honest part; the finance was the phlogiston.

If I ever draw him—and I probably will—it will be with Marie-Anne standing beside him, holding the notebook, both of them looking faintly puzzled, as if trying to decide whether “faith,” “nation,” “merit,” or “market” belong on our modern substances simples list or in the dustbin with caloric. The guillotine will be in the background, a reminder that societies generally prefer to cut off the heads that measure things, while keeping the heads that hallucinate things very much attached and in charge.

In that sense, this blog is my own shabby little table des substances simples—what I think is real, what I only feel is real, what I know is wrong but can’t stop listing because it has shaped me. Some entries are as solid as oxygen; others are caloric-level nonsense stinking of nostalgia and bowel memories. The best I can do is keep rewriting the labels, scratching out the fictions when I catch them, and acknowledging that, historically speaking, human beings have always been very confident and very wrong at the same time, even when they are weighing oxygen in a Paris laboratory—right up until the moment the blade drops.

# File: src/lib/posts/sucking-democracy-through-an-arsehole.md

---
title: "Sucking Democracy Through an Arsehole"

<Pi src="IMG-20260116-WA0003.jpg" />



It begins with me on the toilet, of course, where all democracy ends up anyway. A dry, constipated morning shit that refuses to come out like it’s negotiating a Rajya Sabha seat—bloated, theatrical, and stinking of dead promises. I’m hunched on the commode, bare-assed, boxer elastic digging into my thigh like the Indian Penal Code into free speech, sweating from the back of my neck like a brown bureaucrat’s taint on election day. My tea has gone cold. My intestines, however, have not. They’ve gone full Bhagat Singh: rebellious, noisy, and mostly misunderstood.

And in that exquisite moment of anal indecision, somewhere between a fart and a prayer, it hit me like a lathi charge in my colon: we are not citizens. We are prostate-massaging suck-holes with opinions so limp, so fungus-covered, they make a flaccid dick in a sauna look assertive. We don’t vote. We don’t revolt. We fucking *worship*. Our ballots are just fetish objects shoved lovingly into the ballot box's tight little democratic hole, praying it moans back development.

You see a man in power and your first instinct, whether you're a chaiwala in Begusarai or a CXO doing yoga with a soft-on in Powai, is not to ask "What are you doing for me?"—it is to *fucking bow*, mentally suck that man’s chappal till the rubber patterns are tattooed on your tongue, and then giggle as he steps on your nuts with the other foot. We are a nation of givers, alright. Givers of rim jobs.

Every Bengali I know becomes a revolutionary only while drunk or post-defecation. In both states the body is relaxed and philosophical. But never while queuing outside a ration shop in forty-three degrees, or when that asswipe MP shows up grinning like a goat with a hard-on. Then everyone claps. Women ululate. Men raise hands. Children piss themselves with joy. Someone faints. And the actual public toilet, which smells like Gandhi’s broken dreams and cheap phenyl, remains locked. Because why not. The VIP is here. Time to suck dick and forget you're poor.

It’s not that our leaders are bad. No. That would be manageable. I can understand bad. What we have are *useless*, *shameless*, *oil-slicked motherfuckers* whose primary skill is staying unpunished. They are gristle. They are the burnt bits of rice stuck at the bottom of the degchi of democracy. And we, we are licking that degchi clean, tongue first, eyes wide, like it’s goddamn prasad.

In science terms, the Indian electorate behaves like colon bacteria: mindless, clumpy, and thriving best in darkness. Feed it sugar-coated lies, watch it ferment, then wait for it to explode in a gaseous burst of temple-building, WhatsApp farts, and barefoot pilgrimages to the nearest scam.

Oh and education doesn’t help. In fact, it makes it worse. The PhDs and IITians I’ve met in my sagging, saggy life are more likely to quote Chanakya and share Adani memes than ask "Where the fuck did my taxes go?" If they do ask, it’s only rhetorically—because they still think GST is a protein supplement. Most Indian engineers have the moral courage of a fungus and the spine of a used condom. If nationalism gave them a boner, they’d fuck the map.

Let me put it in digestive terms. You’re at the mercy of a body that doesn’t always obey. Some days it's diarrhea, other days it’s nothing but wind and shame. Governance is the same. You expect firm delivery, strong fibre, clean exit—but what you get is constipation with sideburns, wrapped in saffron or starched white or whatever new shade of fecal you’re currently worshipping.

Democracy should be about control. Choice. Participatory poop, if you will. But ours is a sort of reverse enema, where the leaders squat above us, dump policies, and we take it with prayer hands and a Facebook reel.

And don’t give me that tired-ass excuse about colonial trauma. Yes, we were ruled. Yes, they starved us. Yes, they drew borders with dick-shaped pens while smoking cigars rolled with our future. But that ended. At least on paper. Now? Now we volunteer for the same spanking, bend over in HD, and share it proudly on social media with hashtags like #FeelingBlessed and #ModijiKiLeela.

You want progress? Stop voting with your rectum. Use your fucking brain. Demand things. Ask for drainage systems that don’t breed dengue. Ask for hospitals where the doctor doesn’t smell like despair and expired Dettol. Ask for air you don’t have to chew.

Ask for *work*, not words. And if the fucker in charge doesn’t deliver, *stop clapping* and start spitting. You’re not a cheerleader. You’re a goddamn taxpaying meat sack. Act like it.

But no. Instead, what do we do?

We decorate the very arsehole that shits on us.

We call it culture.

We light a diya next to it.

We name our kids after it.

We call it “bhaavnaa” when we mean brain-rot.

We smear cow piss on our face and chant GDP figures like a cult that forgot it’s broke.

I went to get groceries yesterday, and the man at the counter had a massive poster of that dead-eyed fuckhead MLA right behind his head like a pimple saint halo. I asked him, "Why do you have this here?" and he said, I swear to Kali, “Dada, shomporko bhalo rakhte hobe. Ki jani kon dine ki lagte pare.”

Translation: keep the rat happy. Who knows when you’ll need his teeth.

That, right there, is India.

A thousand years of rat diplomacy. Waving at the boot that steps on your face because, hey, maybe tomorrow, it’ll step on your neighbour instead and give you a ministerial blowjob while you wait for onions to reach a price you can pronounce without crying.

I didn’t shit that morning. The feeling passed. Like freedom. And maybe, just maybe, deep down in our national gut—which, mind you, is already bloated with bad dal, caste guilt, and three centuries of colonial IBS—we *like* the smell of arbitrary power, we *like* watching the fucker on top wave his dick around like a flaming sword of apathy, because it grants us, the ass-scratching plebs, the divine right to be lazy, petty, conniving little turds in our own shitty spheres—skip the line, bribe the clerk, ignore the law, slap a junior, dump garbage where grandma prays, half-ass the project, ghost the client, and call it jugaad. It's a fucked barter economy of corruption and indifference: you let them shit on you from above, and in return you get to shit on someone smaller. That’s the real democracy here. Not one man one vote. One turd, many toilets. No matter what flag you raise or anthem you belch, the fruit this democracy bears will always come from the same sack of decomposing, gas-bloated, maggot-slicked fuckfruit we’ve been hoarding in the name of tradition, pride, or just the comforting weight of rot.


# File: src/lib/posts/sycophancy-is-the-only-lube.md

The first thing I notice is the mouth, not my own—though mine is always involved—but the mouth in the drawing, puckered and obedient, the kind that says uff so holy to power or promise, the kind that leans forward with its tongue already wet, and my fingers smell of cheap tea and yesterday’s rice cooker steam as I stare at it in this fucking room with its peeling paint and fan that sounds like a dying mosquito, and I think yes, this is the country, this is the job market, this is the ladder, rung by rung made of lips and spit and a practiced nod that says sir sir sir as if saying sir enough times will turn piss into promotion.

I live in South Calcutta now, poor suburban shanty with concrete dreams cracked like old teeth, old North Calcutta still clinging to my bones like a smell—fish, ink, arguments—and I cook most days because restaurants cost money and dignity, so I bake shit in an electric oven that smells faintly of burnt plastic and hope, rice cooker humming like a bureaucrat processing files slowly on purpose, tea pan blackened from years of boiling the same leaves into submission, and while the water comes up I scroll jobs that promise meritocracy in bullet points like a fucking religion, and every bullet is a lie, every point is a cunt, and the only thing they don’t list is the oral exam where you kneel and praise the manager’s mediocre ideas like they fell from the sky fully formed.

The sketch sits there, obscene but accurate, the hand grabbing the shaft of authority with the confidence of someone who’s practiced this move in elevators and conference rooms, and I remember the first time I learned the trick wasn’t to be right but to be agreeable, that correctness without deference is just masturbation—feels good alone, useless in public—and some HR woman with a smile like laminated paper told me I was “abrasive,” which is a polite word for didn’t lick enough ass, didn’t laugh at the right jokes, didn’t nod while someone explained my own work back to me with the confidence of a TED talk.

Sycophancy isn’t a moral failing here; it’s an infrastructure project, poured early, reinforced with caste and cash and the colonial hangover that taught us the shortest path to safety is obedience dressed as enthusiasm, and they’ll tell you it’s networking, they’ll say culture fit, they’ll say soft skills as if the skill isn’t being soft where it counts and hard only in private fantasies that end with you alone on the toilet scrolling and thinking of a life that didn’t involve this much bending.

Science, bless its filthy little heart, has words for this, because everything gets words eventually, even bullshit: status signaling, dominance hierarchies, grooming behaviors—primates pick ticks; we pick assholes—and somewhere a paper explains how flattery lights up reward circuits like sugar, how power enjoys mirrors that smile back, and I imagine the neurons in some boss’s head firing as a junior says brilliant sir, just brilliant, and the dopamine flows like chai, and I’m back at my tea pan, stirring leaves until they surrender color, thinking about Pavlov and Skinner and how we trained ourselves into this kennel.

Meritocracy is a bedtime story told to children who can afford books, a fairy tale with a LinkedIn profile, and in India it wears a kurta and speaks English with an accent imported in 1857, the British taught us the exam, the ranking, the list, and we perfected the workaround, because if the test can’t be passed, the examiner can be pleased, and pleasing is easier than thinking, easier than doing, easier than saying no when the no is correct but lonely.

The body knows this before the brain admits it. My stomach tightens in meetings even when I’m alone now, phantom rooms full of nodding heads, my asshole clenches like it’s anticipating a request, and the abstract idea of “career” becomes a bodily thing, a posture, a tilt of the neck, a smile held too long until the jaw aches, and you go home and piss and the piss smells of swallowed words.

I’ve watched it up close, the ritual, the way a room rearranges itself around power like furniture fleeing a fire, the way jokes land only when aimed upward, the way dissent gets coughed into a handkerchief and pocketed for later, and I’ve been the idiot in the corner thinking facts matter, thinking if I explain the mechanism—how systems fail when feedback is flattered into silence—someone will care, but the room wants comfort, not truth, wants the lullaby of agreement, and truth is a fart that clears the space.

Colonial history again, sorry, it always comes back like acid reflux. The babu learned to bow, the clerk learned to wait, the empire learned to rule by paperwork and permission, and we inherited the filing cabinet of the soul, where every impulse must be stamped approved by someone who enjoys being asked, and now the startup founder is the new sahib, hoodie replacing pith helmet, but the posture is the same, the mouth ready, the compliment rehearsed, the LinkedIn post praising “vision” that looks suspiciously like copying whatever Silicon Valley sneezed last quarter.

I draw because talking gets me in trouble, and the drawing is rude enough to say what I won’t at a dinner where everyone’s chewing loudly and praising someone who arrived in a German car, and the dick-nose in the sketch points the way upward, anatomically impossible but socially precise, and someone once told me art is subjective, but this isn’t art, it’s a map, and the map says here be tongues.

There’s sex in this only as absence. 

As failure, as a ghost with bad skin rubbing itself against ambition. Desire rerouted becomes praise; libido redirected becomes loyalty; the energy that should make you fuck becomes the energy that makes you flatter, and Freud would have a field day if he weren’t busy being wrong about everything else, but the metaphor holds: you can’t cum in a system like this, you can only nod until you chafe.

Politics, obviously. Leftist turned numb because the slogans sound like ads now, because every party discovered the same trick corporations did: flatter the base, lick the mood, tell people they’re great while fucking them sideways, and upward mobility becomes a raffle ticket sold by someone who insists everyone can win while pocketing the box, and if you complain you’re told to be positive, which is code for shut up and smile.

I think about merit like a muscle that atrophied because nobody used it, like reading on screens until the eyes forget depth, like cooking on gas until electric feels wrong—skills decay when the environment rewards something else, and we built an environment that rewards the ass-kisser, the yes-man, the chuckle fuck who laughs before the punchline lands, and then we’re shocked when nothing works, when bridges fall, when policies rot, when every meeting produces applause and zero outcome. But I recognize the sycophant in myself in ugly moments, the reflex to soften, to agree, to survive, because hunger teaches lessons faster than philosophy, and sometimes you nod because rent exists, because rice costs money, because the tea pan doesn’t fill itself with dignity, and I don’t pretend purity, I’ve bent, I’ve smiled, I’ve swallowed, and it tastes like shit every time.

The room smells now of overboiled tea and damp walls, and my phone buzzes with a message that begins Dear Sir, and my body responds before my brain, a little tightening, a readiness to be nice, to be useful, to be liked, and I hate that this is true, hate that the drawing isn’t just satire but autobiography, hate that upward mobility has an odor and it’s not ambition, it’s breath.

At night the fan clicks and I think about neurons again, about reinforcement schedules, how intermittent rewards hook harder than steady ones, how a compliment once in a while keeps you licking forever, and the system is elegant in its cruelty, a Skinner box with salaries, a maze where the cheese whispers your name, and somewhere a boss sleeps well convinced he earned it all on merit. I end where I started, staring at the mouth in the sketch, obedient and hopeful, and I feel a small, stupid stirring—not arousal, not quite despair—just the urge to piss, the body reminding me it still has needs that don’t care about ladders, and I shuffle to the bathroom in the dark, careful not to wake the neighbors, and as I aim and sigh I think of all the mouths aimed upward, all the praise flowing like urine toward power, and I miss the bowl slightly, which feels about right.
 


# File: src/lib/posts/synchronized-constipation.md

---
title: "Synchronized Constipation"
date: "2025-12-18"
description: "Wisdom and diarrhea have always marched side by side. A reflection on humanity's tragicomic inability to synchronize even the most basic bodily functions."
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251216-WA0007.jpg"
category: "personal"
color: "red"
published: true
---



<Pi
    src="IMG-20251216-WA0007.jpg" 
    caption="Rodin's Thinker, if he were honest about the struggle."
    layout="block"
/>

Try as we might, no amount of synchronized ass-clenching, grimacing, or existential constipation has ever convinced humanity to shit simultaneously. Nope, we're hopelessly unsynchronized in all things—happiness, sadness, bowel movements, even the damned philosophical profundities we crap out at 3 a.m. after too much chili vodka. You see, while some schmuck in Brussels may be wiping his ass clean with a monogrammed silk tissue at the zenith of his morning glory, a hapless Calcutta sucker (yours truly) is clenching tighter than Scrooge's purse strings, choking on the constipated misery of unfulfilled dreams and partially digested lentils.

Think about it (or don’t—what’s it to me?): When Socrates waxed philosophical, downing hemlock shots like a cocky college kid challenging mortality to beer pong, somewhere a Neanderthal ancestor was probably crouched behind a rock, furrowing a low unibrow, trying to decipher why eating berries made the back exit so goddamned fiery. Wisdom and diarrhea, my friends, have always marched side by side, like obnoxious Siamese twins joined at the sphincter.

This cosmic unsynchronization—this unfathomably irritating reality that not everyone is blissfully orgasmic or abjectly depressed at precisely the same nanosecond—is life's greatest punchline and cruelest hemorrhoid rolled into one grotesque paradox. And yet, like pathetic monkeys we clap, clap, clap our fleshy paws together, pretending society is a grand unified ballet of coordinated assholes. Bollocks. Pure, unmitigated bollocks. Life's not a choreographed dance; it's an epileptic seizure in a porcelain shop—bulls and china and shards everywhere.


Consider happiness: elusive, slippery, insidious, like that one fart you gamble won't come loaded (and tragically discover it did). Happiness—from "hap," Old Norse for "luck" or "chance"—literally screams, "Dude, don't count on me! I'm the cosmic fart that sometimes comes clean, sometimes soils your Armani briefs!" And misery—oh misery—the magnificent perennial hemorrhoid, derived from Latin "miser," meaning wretched. Wretched—now there’s a word as poetically satisfying as it is physically accurate.

But we persist, humanity does, in forcing fake synchronicity. Holidays and mandatory joyous celebrations punctuate the calendar, marking enforced smiles and pre-scheduled happiness, social enemas violently administered to cleanse us of reality's grim residue. "Be happy! Eat cake!" bellows society; "Now feel sad, dammit!" commands tragedy. What if I’m busy? What if I feel like shitting right now instead of celebrating your goddamn wedding vows or birthday cake or funeral tears? I want freedom—no, I demand freedom—to be sad, euphoric, existentially panicked, or explosively diarrheal when the whim overtakes me.

And let’s face it: history has proved time and again that the monumental endeavors of mankind—the pyramids, calculus, the Sistine Chapel—are merely grandiose attempts at distracting ourselves from our humiliating inability to synchronize even the most basic bodily functions. You think Michelangelo painted God touching Adam’s limp digit out of some divine inspiration? Bullshit. He was compensating, folks—overcompensating for the grotesque, humiliating, unsynchronized reality of his own digestive tract. Renaissance humanism? Merely desperate cultural constipation.

So next time you witness humanity's tragicomic inability to collectively experience any goddamned emotion or bodily function simultaneously—be it the orgasmic cheer of World Cup goals or the unified horror at election results—just remember: we're all alone, grotesquely unsynchronized, and perpetually shitting our pants at our own individual pace. And perhaps, just perhaps, that's the true glory of the human condition—billions of assholes marching resolutely out of sync, toward no goal, to no rhythm, desperately clinging to the toilet paper roll of life that never quite tears where it should.


# File: src/lib/posts/tea-shop-metaphysics.md

---
title: "Tea-Shop Metaphysics"
date: "2025-12-17"
description: "Calcutta is not a mind. Calcutta is a digestive tract... taking in raw material and producing output that nobody wants to claim as their own."
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251217-WA0001.jpg"
category: "personal"
color: "black"
published: true
---

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251217-WA0001.jpg"
    caption="exhausted concentric commentary on my existence"
/>

The plastic chair outside the tea-stall has a hairline crack that opens like a tiny mouth whenever I shift my weight, as if the chair itself is doing a small, exhausted concentric commentary on my existence—*tsk, tsk, another middle-aged Bengali man applying pressure where he has no business applying pressure*—and the stall-owner, in a vest that used to be white in some earlier geological era, is stirring my tea with the devotion of a priest and the hygiene of an archaeologist. Beside his foot, an open drain performs its endless wet throat-clearing, a gurgle that isn’t quite water and isn’t quite air and is definitely not a metaphor but also, maddeningly, is nothing *but* metaphor if you have the curse of being the kind of person who sees symbols everywhere, even in sewage.

This is South Calcutta’s boondocks, which is a phrase that should not exist—boondocks are supposed to be rural, and Calcutta is supposed to be a city, and yet here we are, an urban organism that keeps trying to grow new limbs while the old ones are infected, a metropolis that has learned to do *simultaneous arithmetic*: one part colonial boudoir, one part IT brochure, one part crumbling communist mural, one part religious loudspeaker, and eight parts “please don’t look closely at the plumbing,” like a family that bought a chandelier before paying the rent.

A mosquito—*Aedes aegypti*, my tiny airborne loan shark—lands on my forearm with the calm entitlement of a landlord; I slap it, miss, feel the sting begin anyway (the universe loves a good sequel), and in that small moment I remember, as the tea arrives in a glass that burns my fingertips, that Calcutta is not merely a location but an instruction manual for disappointment: step one, desire; step two, delay; step three, infection; step four, poetry.

# The City As A Digestive Tract

People want cities to be minds. “The city thinks,” they say. “The city dreams.” “The city has a soul.” This is what you say when you’re trying to sell real estate or justify suffering or both. Calcutta is not a mind. Calcutta is a digestive tract—vast, noisy, peristaltic, prone to spasms—taking in raw material (people, ambition, ideology, fish, slogans, limestone, lies), breaking it down with acids (bureaucracy, class, heat, habit), and producing output that nobody wants to claim as their own.

And because I’m me—bookish, underpaid by the cosmos, living in a shanty background with a brain that has too many books and not enough serotonin—I can’t sit in front of an open drain without thinking about entropy, that grand, indifferent accountant of the universe. Order is expensive. Disorder is on discount. Disorder is practically free. Disorder will, given enough time, crawl into your kitchen through a gap in the window, breed in the stagnant water behind your fridge, and then run for office.

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251207-WA0010.jpg"
    layout="iR"
    caption="Order is expensive. Disorder is on discount."
    size={0.6}
/>

The drain bubbles. A bubble pops. A smell rises—phenyl failing heroically against a tide of biology—and I have the sudden ridiculous urge to bow to it, not out of devotion but recognition: *yes, yes, this is what we are, this is what our institutions produce when the speeches end.* We are *Homo sapiens*, the wise apes, turning starch into opinion and opinion into sewage and sewage into yet another reason to blame somebody else.

My phone vibrates with a news notification—some fresh outrage, some ancient scam with a modern font—and I feel the familiar bipolar toggling: the hypomanic part of my mind wants to connect everything to everything (quantum entanglement and Hilsa prices and the pothole that has outlived three administrations), while the depressive part says, flatly, *it’s all the same sludge, stop pretending your metaphors are salvation*.

The tea tastes like sugar and smoke and the ghost of cardamom.

Calcutta tastes like that too.

# Names, Lies, And Other Municipal Services

“Kolkata,” “Calcutta,” “Kalikata”—pick your syllables like you pick your poison. People love folk etymologies the way they love horoscopes: because it feels good to pretend the world is legible. I’ve heard the whole menu: derived from Kali, derived from shells, derived from some ancient village name, derived from destiny itself. The truth, as far as I can tell, is both boring and fascinating: it’s probably a tangle of local toponyms and colonial ears and administrative paperwork, which is to say, the city began as a misunderstanding and has remained loyal to its origins.
