The British arrived, misheard, renamed, extracted, and then left behind the architectural equivalent of a half-eaten sandwich—Victorian buildings like grand dentures in a mouth that can no longer chew. Now we rename again, not because renaming fixes anything but because it’s cheaper than drainage. A new signboard costs less than a new system. A new slogan costs less than clean water. We are a civilization of paint.

And I say “we,” which is always the first lie. The rich don’t live in my drain-scented boondocks. The powerful don’t need to step around garbage like it’s a landmine field of shame. They inhabit the city the way a god inhabits a myth: above consequence, immune to smell. They get Calcutta as romance. I get Calcutta as mildew.

But I’m not innocent. I’m never innocent. I have my own small hypocrisies—my own private empires built on denial. I complain about the system while using the system; I despise grandstanding while writing paragraphs that are basically a one-man parade; I mock superstition while checking my own mood like a priest checks auspicious timings. Even my atheism sometimes has the smugness of faith. *Look at me, Ma, I don’t believe in anything*—as if disbelief is a personality and not merely the absence of a coping mechanism.

The Upanishads mutter, like an ancient neighbor who has seen too much: **असतो मा सद्गमय, तमसो मा ज्योतिर्गमय, मृत्योर्मा अमृतं गमय**—lead me from the unreal to the real, from darkness to light, from death to immortality—and I can’t tell whether the line is a lantern or a joke, because the unreal is often better furnished than the real, and darkness at least hides the stains.

# Tea-Shop Metaphysics (And Other Cheap Drugs)

At the tea-stall, two men argue about politics with the confidence of Nobel laureates and the evidentiary standards of toddlers. One says the country is doomed. The other says the country is glorious. Neither has a budget spreadsheet. Neither has a sanitation plan. Both have very loud lungs. The stall-owner ignores them the way the universe ignores all of us: with a practiced neutrality.

I listen, half-amused, half-tired, and my mind does the thing it always does—starts building a theory of everything out of street noise. Somewhere in a CERN tunnel, protons are being whipped into near-light-speed collisions so we can understand the fundamental particles, the quarks and leptons and bosons, the tiny alphabet of reality; here, in my lane, two uncles are colliding opinions at near-light-speed so they can understand absolutely nothing. Both collisions produce heat. Only one produces publishable data.

If I were a better person, I would join them. If I were a wiser person, I would leave. Instead I sip my tea and become the third kind of Calcutta man: the observer with a superiority complex, hiding behind skepticism like it’s a shield, as if not believing in anyone’s story exempts me from the need to live in one.

The thing about tea-shops is that they are small parliaments without consequences. Everyone gets to speak; nobody has to implement. In that sense, they are the purest form of democracy: noise without plumbing, rights without responsibility, freedom without maintenance. It’s intoxicating. It’s also why we remain, generation after generation, in love with our own commentary and indifferent to our own infrastructure.

I think about how in physics, the most powerful truths are often symmetry statements: the laws of nature don’t care where you are, or when you are, or how you rotate your coordinate system. The universe is, in a cold way, fair. Calcutta is not symmetrical. Calcutta cares very much where you are—north, south, gated, slum, “posh,” “busti”—and it cares what your father did, what your accent does, what your skin suggests, what your address implies, what your shoes confess.

Yet we still demand metaphysics from it, like children demanding a bedtime story from a broken fan.

Rigveda whispers another line I can’t unhear: **एकं सद्विप्रा बहुधा वदन्ति**—truth is one, the wise speak of it in many ways. Beautiful. Dangerous too. Because in the wrong hands, it becomes license for bullshit: *everything is one, therefore my nonsense is also wisdom.* Calcutta is full of people who confuse many ways of speaking with many versions of reality.

I include myself. Of course I do.

# Bipolar Weather Report

There are mornings when the city feels almost tender. Sunlight hits a wet wall and turns it into gold. A crow caws like an old comedian. A child runs with a schoolbag that’s too big, carrying the future like a poorly packed suitcase. On those mornings, my hypomania arrives like a caffeinated professor: *Look, Suvro, see how everything connects—drainage to empire, tea to labor economics, mosquitoes to climate, shame to caste, your loneliness to algorithms.* I scribble notes. I draft sentences. I feel briefly like a person with purpose, which is the most intoxicating drug I have ever taken, and I have taken some stupid drugs—doomscrolling, nostalgia, self-pity, the fantasy of being understood.

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251207-WA0020.jpg"
    layout="iL"
    caption="The familiar bipolar toggling"
/>

Then the mood shifts, as it does, with no cosmic decency to announce itself.

Suddenly the same wall is just wet. The same crow is just noise. The child is not the future but an overburdened body in a failing system. My notes look pretentious. My sentences look like fraud. The drain smell is not metaphor but evidence. In depression, my mind becomes brutally literal: the city is broken, you are broken, and your cleverness is merely decorative ruin.

I delete drafts obsessively. I rewrite. I rewrite the rewrite. Sometimes I delete the whole thing with a petty, righteous pleasure—*there, take that, universe; I refused to produce content.* Then, an hour later, I open a blank page again like an addict returning to the dealer, because writing is the only way I know to turn mental noise into something shaped, even if the shape is a mess.

People romanticize bipolarity, as if it’s a creative superpower, as if suffering is a quirky accessory. It’s not. It’s an electrical fault in the house wiring, occasionally producing pretty sparks, often producing smoke, always leaving you suspicious of the light switch. I don’t glamorize it because I can’t. I live inside it. I pay rent to it.

Calcutta doesn’t help. Calcutta is mood-congruent. When you’re up, it gives you stories. When you’re down, it gives you receipts.

# Colonial Aftertaste, Capitalist Hangover

Sometimes I imagine the city as a palimpsest—the old text scraped off, new text written on top, old text still bleeding through—except the scraping was done with a dull knife by people who didn’t care if the parchment survived. The colonial period left behind rail lines and institutions and a particular flavor of contempt; the postcolonial period added bureaucracy and slogans and a talent for rearranging poverty into different shapes; the neoliberal period slapped on glossy ads for luxury apartments that stare down at the slum like a smug moral lesson: *if you worked harder, you too could escape the smell.*

The education system—my old frenemy—taught me to worship marks and English and obedience, to treat curiosity as a side hobby and conformity as a career. It also gave me books, and books are the only reason I’m not fully dead inside. So I’m caught in that classic Bengali contradiction: I despise the machinery that produced me, and I can’t deny I am its product, like a man who hates cigarettes while still smelling faintly of smoke.

Capitalism, in this city, is not the clean, efficient market of textbook fantasy. It’s a bazaar with a dress code. It’s rent-seeking with better fonts. It’s the same old hierarchy wearing a new shirt, insisting it’s modern now because it has an app. And technology—the great promised liberator—often arrives here as a way to monetize helplessness: food delivery because walking is unsafe, ride-hailing because public transport is exhausted, online learning because schools are broken, digital payments because cash was always a leak. Progress is sometimes just a new layer of coping.

I look at my phone again, that glowing rectangle of manufactured anxiety, and I think: we have built a machine that can deliver dopamine on demand and information without context and outrage without cost. No wonder the tea-shop uncles sound like angry prophets. No wonder I sound like one too. We are being trained—conditioned, like lab animals—to react, react, react, until reaction replaces thought.

And still, I keep the phone. Because I’m not a monk. I’m a man in a shanty background with a taste for knowledge and a weakness for distraction, which is just a fancy way of saying: I’m ordinary.

# The Myth Of Glorious Anything

There’s a genre of story Indians love, across classes and ideologies: the “we used to be great” story. It comes in many costumes—civilizational supremacy, religious nostalgia, nationalist fever, sometimes even scientific name-dropping—but it always delivers the same emotional product: pride without work, identity without responsibility, a warm blanket over a cold reality.

I have no patience for it. Not because the past wasn’t complex or impressive—history is messy and full of human genius—but because the “glory” narrative is usually a substitute for plumbing. It’s a way to feel tall while standing in sewage. It’s a way to avoid the humiliating truth that greatness is maintenance: roads, drains, schools, hospitals, public trust, boring competence.

Yes, ancient texts are fascinating. Yes, old architecture is astonishing. Yes, human beings have always been clever. But if your response to a broken present is to chant about a shining past, you are not honoring your ancestors; you’re using them as emotional blackmail.

And here I catch myself, because I too have my own “we used to be great” story, only mine is personal. I was bookish. I was promising. I was going to do something. I was going to be the kind of man whose name appears on things that matter. Now I’m fifty-ish, living in the south Calcutta boondocks, writing long essays like a stranded radio station broadcasting to the fog.

My superiority narratives are smaller, but they are still narratives. My ego wears intellectualism the way some men wear gold chains. It jingles when I move.

Somewhere in the background, the old line floats up again—**कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते**—you have a right to action, not to the fruits (yes, I know, not a Purana line; the point is the humiliation embedded in it), and I resent it because it’s true in the way gravity is true: unfair, impersonal, non-negotiable.

# A Small Inventory Of My Complicity

I want to blame the politicians, the bureaucrats, the colonial hangover, the capitalist vultures, the neighbor who throws garbage into the drain like it’s a sacred offering.

I do blame them.

Then I remember: I also throw things away mentally. I outsource responsibility to mood. I postpone. I fantasize. I choose comfort over discipline and then pretend my failure is purely structural. I use sarcasm as armor. I use erudition as camouflage. I talk about entropy while letting my own room become entropic. I am, in miniature, the same problem I accuse the city of being in macro: too much talk, not enough maintenance.

Some days I even enjoy the decay, because it justifies my bitterness. If the world is a septic tank, then my despair is reasonable. My nihilism becomes a kind of moral cleanliness: *I don’t participate in illusions,* I tell myself, as if cynicism is the same as clarity. It isn’t. Cynicism is often just depression with better vocabulary.

The tea-stall argument has moved on. Now they’re discussing the price of fish, which is the most honest economics seminar in the city. One of them says Hilsa has become a luxury for the poor. The other says everything is luxury now. They laugh. The laugh is real. That’s what gets me. Even knee-deep in problems, *Homo sapiens* will find a way to make a joke, because laughter is our last remaining public utility.

For a moment, I feel something like tenderness for these men, for the stall-owner, for myself—this whole ridiculous species, trying to negotiate meaning in a universe that doesn’t issue refunds.

Then the drain gurgles again, and the spell breaks, and I’m back inside my head, where the lights flicker.

# The Only Defiance I Can Afford

I finish the tea. The glass leaves a sticky ring on the wooden counter, a small mandala of sugar and dust. I pay with coins that have passed through countless palms, carrying microbes and history like a tiny circulating library. The stall-owner nods without looking at me; he has seen my type, and he has also seen far worse.

I stand, stretch my back, feel the chair’s cracked mouth close in relief.

Walking home, I pass a small shrine wedged into a wall—marigolds, incense, a smudged image—someone has asked the universe for mercy in the only language they trust. I don’t believe. I still pause, not out of worship but out of respect for the human need to plead. I continue past, stepping over a puddle that reflects the sky like an accidental philosophy: above us, vast indifferent blue; below us, street water of uncertain parentage pretending to be a mirror.

At home, I open my laptop, stare at the blank page, and feel the familiar urge to either write everything or delete everything.

I type anyway.

Not because I think it will fix Calcutta, or fix me, or purify the drain, or shame the powerful into competence.

I type because this is the one small gesture of defiance I can afford: to look at the septic tank honestly, to refuse the romance without surrendering to pure rot, to admit that I am ridiculous and complicit and frightened and occasionally lucid, and to leave behind, for whoever stumbles upon it, a smear of language on the wall that says—without neat morals, without self-help perfume, without holy conclusions—

I was here. I noticed. I laughed, a little. I kept my irony. I kept the light on for another minute.

Then I save the draft, consider deleting it, and instead—almost shyly—turn off the screen.


# File: src/lib/posts/the-age-of-beautiful-nonsense.md

---
title: "The Age of Beautiful Nonsense"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20260103-WA0010.jpg"
date: '2026-01-04'
description: "The crack in my Android screen..."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "orange" 
---


<Pi
    src="IMG-20260103-WA0010.jpg" 
    caption="The Age of Beautiful Nonsense"
/>

The crack in my Android screen has its own weather system now—tiny white fault-lines that catch the tea-stall light and refract it into a nervous, glittering map, like the Ganges delta if the Ganges were made of tempered glass and human negligence. There’s thumb oil smeared across the lower half where my scrolling finger lives, and under that smear a man is speaking—calmly, confidently, with the tonal assurance of someone who has never had to argue with an electricity bill—announcing a policy, a threat, a promise, a rupture, a new dawn, a nation-in-peril, the usual buffet. Behind him the background is the sort of patriotic blur that can be manufactured in any country with three flags and a bored graphic designer.

The tea stall TV is barking at a different truth, louder, uglier, more analog. A kettle hisses. Someone’s scooter refuses to start and the kick lever is taking a beating. My downstairs neighbor's pet cat "Taklu Babu", considers the philosophical question of whether my slipper's plastic is a recommended nail sharpener. The man on my phone continues speaking, and for a brief moment my brain does the old lazy thing it learned from living in India: it tries to decide truth by vibe. He *sounds* like him. His pauses are familiar. The cadence is right. The consonants land where they should. The vowels have that particular rounded confidence that comes from never taking a tram.

Then someone forwards it on WhatsApp with the caption: “see! finally someone is saying it.” And WhatsApp adds that small grey tag—“forwarded many times”—like a priest sprinkling a drop of disinfectant into a municipal water tank.

This is where we are now: authenticity as a rumor with UI.

They tell us we will have labels. They say the label should cover ten percent—ten percent of the visual, ten percent of the audio, ten percent of the lie. Ten percent is a wonderful bureaucratic number. It’s large enough to feel moral and small enough to be ignored, like the “service charge” on a restaurant bill. Ten percent is also, coincidentally, about how much of my daily attention I can spare for anything that isn’t survival, deadlines, or the low-grade existential nausea of living among people who treat superstition like a pension plan.

But the problem is not the label. The problem is the human animal, that melodramatic primate who will happily accept a forged voice note if it confirms what he already suspects about his neighbor, his party, his nation, his wife, his own importance. Give him a stamp—“AI GENERATED”—and he will treat it as either a badge of modernity (*look, even the machine agrees with me*) or as proof of conspiracy (*they labeled it to silence the truth*). Labels, in India, do not create trust. They create new genres of argument.

This is the Age of Beautiful Nonsense, and beauty is the worst part, because ugly propaganda at least has the decency to look like propaganda. Ugly lies give off a smell. Beautiful lies arrive perfumed, in HD, with perfect lighting and a face that holds still like an obedient idol.

I keep thinking about the word “document,” which everyone now chants with the reverence once reserved for “scripture.” Document, from the Latin *docere*, to teach. A document is supposed to teach you something—show you a trail, a source, an origin, a lineage. In practice, in modern life, a document teaches you mostly about power: who can demand it, who can produce it, and who gets humiliated in the queue when the ink is slightly smudged and the clerk feels bored.

Now they want machines to be documented too. Models, training data, safety processes, transparency rituals. Paperwork for the gods we built. There is something almost touching about it—humans facing a new ocean and bringing out their little measuring cups.

The Europeans, in their way, are trying to treat synthetic gibberish as a “security surface,” which is an excellent phrase because it sounds like a corporate mattress. A security surface: the place where bad things can land. They look at a viral clip and see attack vectors, systemic risk, platform obligations, audits, codes, compliance. They speak in the language of levers and duties.

India, in its way, wants quantifiable labeling because India understands quantification. We are a civilization of forms. We do not trust a person’s face, but we trust a stamp. We trust a stamp so much we will accept a stamp even when it is obviously fake, because the stamp is the ritual and rituals calm us. *দেখুন, কাগজ আছে তো*—look, there is paper, no?

But the planet we live on is not a court file. It is a forwarding machine.

The dumbest step destroys truth first. Not the clever adversary. Not the state actor with a budget. Not the shadowy lab. The dumbest step: someone screen-records, someone screenshots, someone compresses, someone reposts, someone forwards it with their own caption, someone crops out the watermark because it “spoils the view,” someone sends it as a WhatsApp video because it’s “easier,” and the provenance trail—those signed manifests, those credentials, those carefully embedded metadata prayers—evaporates like a puddle on a May footpath.

Truth dies not in fire, but in re-encoding.

People in clean offices are building provenance systems—Content Credentials, signatures, manifests—like little birth certificates for images. I can see the appeal. It’s the same old human longing: to pin identity down so it stops slipping through your fingers. When my father dealt with a bank account, he trusted the ledger. When I deal with the internet, I’m being asked to trust a torrent.

But provenance works best where ordinary people least live: inside the sleek, polite corridors of platforms that preserve metadata, respect standards, and don’t treat your content like a chicken to be plucked and sold in parts. Meanwhile, the real India—the India of family groups and voice notes and forwarded folklore—lives in the screenshot. We live in the copy-of-a-copy-of-a-copy, the third-generation JPEG where the pixels have become little anxious ghosts.

So you get this absurdity: “Prove where it came from” becomes a product feature, a neat toggle, a ribbon on a gift box—while the everyday flow of information, the *actual bloodstream*, is a series of amputations.

If I sound bitter, it’s because bitterness is one of the few renewable resources we have. It requires no import license and survives power cuts beautifully.

In Sector V—our glassy little office park where dreams go to become spreadsheets—you can already imagine a new job category: “labeling reality.” A fluorescent cubicle, an employee badge, a quota. You sit all day with two windows open—one showing a piece of content, the other showing a drop-down menu of compliance categories—and you decide whether something is synthetic, manipulated, misleading, satirical, harmful, political, violent, medical, financial, impersonation, “other.” It’s like grading essays, except the essays are lies and your red pen is a legal risk mitigation tool.

The strangest part is that this labor will be sold as progress. A new industry! New jobs! Trust & safety! Meanwhile it’s still a kind of piecework: invisible, exhausting, and morally degrading. You are not building anything; you are shoveling. The flood rises, you shovel.

They will tell you, with straight faces, that users can report content. Users can block. Users can fact-check. Users can educate themselves. Users can be “responsible digital citizens.” This is the modern platform bargain: we will extract attention rents and sell ads against your eyeballs, and you will do unpaid moderation to keep the system vaguely habitable. It’s like being charged rent for a building and then asked to sweep the staircase because “community.”

Every era has its sacred object. In my childhood it was the textbook, heavy and authoritative, smelling of cheap paper and punishment. Now the sacred object is the clip: a 17-second rectangle that arrives already carrying its own mood, its own implied conclusion, its own pre-chewed outrage. The clip doesn’t argue; it performs. It doesn’t persuade; it infects.

And because we are performing monkeys with smartphones, the clip wins.

The geostrategic people will say: this is an authenticity arms race. Deepfake operations versus provenance tooling. State actors versus standards bodies. Elections versus disinformation. All very grand, all very chessboard.

But the supply chain that matters is not only chips. It’s transformers, permits, water, and diesel.

Somewhere behind a shiny “AI-ready” building—those glass fortresses that look like they were designed by a committee of smug rectangles—there’s a generator coughing like an old smoker who refuses to die. The building will have a sustainability banner. There will be a press release. There will be a “net-zero roadmap,” which is the modern equivalent of “my ancestors were kings.” Behind it, the generator will burn fuel because the grid is fragile, because transformers have lead times, because interconnection queues are long, because the unsexy hardware of civilization is always the bottleneck.

So the Age of Beautiful Nonsense is not only a cognitive crisis. It’s physical. It has a footprint. Every extra stream of AI slop is a little tug on the electrical system. Every “talking head” video is heat somewhere. Noise you can measure in megawatts. The internet used to feel weightless; now it’s starting to feel like a factory you can smell.

Kolkata, of course, will pay in the usual way: in humidity and inconvenience and resentment. A load-shedding here, a voltage dip there, an inverter battery groaning in the corner like a sick animal. The rich will sit inside cooled rooms and complain about “connectivity issues” while the rest of us listen to the ceiling fan slow down and speed up like a drunk philosopher.

And then, because a society cannot tolerate uncertainty without reaching for a stick, we will solve the “deepfake problem” the way we solve many problems: with surveillance.

This is the part that makes my skin crawl, not in a dramatic way, but in that small domestic way—like realizing your pillow smells faintly of mold. Anti-disinformation easily becomes pro-surveillance, because “verify identity” is such a tempting phrase. Face ID, CCTV analytics, SIM/KYC, biometric “liveness tests,” mandatory declarations. The state will say it’s to protect you from fraud and fake content. It will be true, in the way a lion is truly interested in your safety when it corrals you.

Enforcement capacity is always the rate-limiter, not the text of the rule. You can write a beautiful law. You can publish a code of practice. You can announce obligations with the seriousness of a judge. Then you need courts, regulators, labs, expertise, budgets, and a political culture that isn’t allergic to accountability. Without that, the rule becomes theater. Compliance becomes a performance. Everyone learns the moves. The underlying incentives—the attention rents, the ad-tech machinery, the platform gatekeeping—keep humming.

The result is a world where disbelief is formalized.

I keep thinking about dignity. Not in a lofty way. In a small, humiliating way. Your auntie hears a voice note that sounds like her nephew asking for money, and she’s torn between love and skepticism. Love used to be a shortcut—*I recognize you, therefore I trust you*. Now love becomes a vulnerability surface. She has to doubt her own ears. She has to become a forensic analyst in a cotton saree. She has to remember “reasonable technical measures.” She has to ask for a code word like spies. This is what it means when sincerity becomes a luxury good: only the people with time, education, and spare attention can afford to verify. Everyone else lives in probabilistic fog.

The fog isn’t evenly distributed, either. Deepfakes get extra cover in Bengali and other Indian languages because we live in a world of accents, code-switching, clipped consonants, and affectionate distortions. “Sounds like him” does half the work. The other half is the social structure: a culture that already runs on hearsay and hierarchy and fear of embarrassment. No one wants to be the person who asks too many questions in the family group. You’ll be labeled “negative.” In India, skepticism is often treated as a personality defect.

So the flood comes, and we meet it with what we always meet things with: superstition, bureaucracy, and resignation, in some unstable mixture.

There’s a debunk that arrives later, of course. Debunks always arrive later, like ambulance sirens in a traffic jam. The debunk is itself a clip—slicker, sharper, with a confident narrator explaining that the original was fake. Under it someone comments: “this is also fake.” Under that someone posts a third clip, “proof” that the debunk is part of a cover-up. The system has learned a new trick: it can generate not only lies, but counter-lies, and meta-lies, and lies about lies, until your brain gives up and chooses a team.

This is the truly modern horror: not that we can’t know what’s true, but that we get tired of trying.

At College Street, a student buys a secondhand textbook—pages damp at the edges, margins filled with someone else’s underlining, someone else’s anxieties—and writes an essay with a model. The professor knows. The student knows the professor knows. The professor uses AI to grade it because the workload is insane and salaries are insulting and the institution is rotting in slow motion. Both feel oddly relieved. Authenticity becomes a negotiated truce. Education turns into an arms race, then into fatigue, then into theater.

In my darker moments—my more honest ones—I suspect that’s the destination for public life too: a kind of exhausted pantomime where everyone performs belief just enough to get through the day.

Still, my brain insists on taking the long way round, as if a digression could save me.

There’s a debunked folk etymology I always liked, even though it’s wrong, because it fits our current mood: people say “news” stands for “north east west south,” as if information is a compass. It isn’t. Real etymology is less romantic: “news” is just “new things.” That’s all. New things, happening. The compass story is nonsense, and it comforts because it suggests there’s direction.

We are living through the collapse of the compass story. “New things” arrive faster than meaning can be made. The feed is not a compass; it’s a slot machine. It dispenses outrage, cuteness, terror, patriotism, and scams in an optimized sequence. Attention engineering—autoplay, infinite scroll, notification lotteries—turns the mind into a twitching lab rat. Then we act surprised when the rat can’t write philosophy.

I look at my cracked screen again. The man’s face is still calm. The calmness is almost insulting. Synthetic faces look calmer than real citizens because they are not made of flesh and consequence. They don’t sweat. They don’t stammer. They don’t have that tiny panic in the eyes that comes from knowing you might be wrong.

A tram rattles past in my memory—North Calcutta, the old metallic groan, that improbable gentleness of public transport that asks nothing of you except patience. Now the modern tram is the reel-audio leaking from earbuds in the metro, a disembodied chorus of other people’s moods. Progress, as always, manufactures convenience; convenience manufactures credulity; credulity invites control.

Outside, the tea stall kettle whistles again. A cybercrime helpline poster curls at the corner, laminated optimism. A UPI QR board leans against the wall, its edges warped from damp, as if even the plastic is tired. Someone pays with a beep and feels modern for half a second.

My phone buzzes. Another forward. Another clip. Another voice that sounds like someone I know.

I wipe the thumb oil off my screen with the edge of my shirt, the way you wipe fog off a bathroom mirror, and the crack catches the light and turns it into a tiny constellation—proof, at least, that some kinds of distortion still come from honest physics.


# File: src/lib/posts/the-balcony-rail.md

---
title: "The Balcony Rail"
date: "2025-12-21"
description: "The balcony rail is cold enough in December to feel like it has opinions. Not grand opinions—nothing that would get a newspaper column—but small metallic judgments."
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251029-WA0013(1).jpg"
category: "personal"
published: true
color: "black"
---

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251029-WA0013(1).jpg"
    caption="The balcony rail is cold enough in December to feel like it has opinions."
/>

The balcony rail is cold enough in December to feel like it has opinions.

Not grand opinions—nothing that would get a newspaper column—but small metallic judgments that seep into the skin when I lean my forearms on it and stare down at the little strip of South Calcutta street that pretends to be a road, the one where a cycle-van rattles past like a skeleton in a tin can, where the air smells like damp concrete, yesterday’s frying oil, and that peculiar winter Kolkata odor: smoke plus fog plus the sweet rot of leaves that never quite become soil because the city is too impatient to let anything finish its life properly.

A man across the lane is already shouting into his phone. There’s always a man shouting into a phone. If the universe has a background radiation, in Bengal it’s middle-aged male outrage, broadband-enabled, tariff-plan-optimized. A stray dog—thin, philosophical, perpetually auditioning for the role of “metaphor”—does that slow, careful scratching that says, *I have fleas, but also I have principles.* Pigeons clatter on a parapet and I can hear, from somewhere inside the building, the domestic percussion of steel plates meeting a sink with the passive aggression of a small war.

I’m standing there doing what I’m best at: not moving.

And then, because my brain is a cursed librarian that reshelves misery under “interesting,” the phrase pops up again—*Wu Wei*—like a smug little bookmark inserted into my day.

It’s an elegant idea, is the problem. That’s how it gets you. *Wu Wei* sounds like a soft instrument. Two syllables that could be a lullaby. It does not sound like the thing it’s often used for, which is an intellectual permission slip to let your life fossilize while you narrate the fossilization in very sophisticated language.

The lower middle-class version of this is not even sophisticated. It’s just *kal theke korbo*—I’ll do it from tomorrow—said with the calm assurance of a man who has been promising tomorrow for twenty-five years and has never met the fellow.

And I’m not exempt. I’m the specimen jar too. I can dress it up in philosophy, I can garnish it with etymology and politics and the sorrowful beauty of “systems,” but at 6:40 a.m., in winter air that tastes like a public-health warning, I am still just a mammal leaning on a rail, waiting for motivation to fall from the sky like divine bird-droppings.

# A philosophy that gets misused because it’s too pretty

*Wu Wei* is usually translated as “non-action,” but that translation is the philosophical equivalent of labeling a tiger “large cat.” True, but you’ve missed the part where it eats you.

The Chinese characters are doing more work than the English. 無 (*wú*) is “without,” “lacking,” “not.” 爲 / 为 (*wéi*) is “doing,” “acting,” “making,” “contriving.” Put them together and you get something like “without contrivance,” “without forced effort,” “without that frantic, white-knuckled pushing that makes you sweat and still go nowhere.”

Which is not the same as lying on a mattress until your mattress develops its own weather system.

The Taoist classics—*Daodejing* (traditionally linked to Laozi), *Zhuangzi* (Zhuang Zhou, who wrote like a man sleepwalking through logic and laughing at it)—came out of a China that was chaotic in a way that makes modern chaos look like a spreadsheet. Warring states, rulers, schemes, ritual correctness, and the general human hobby of mistaking domination for meaning. In that world, “effortless action” was not a celebration of laziness; it was a rejection of *performative control*.

Taoism is what you get when someone watches the ambitious wreck themselves, over and over, and decides the universe might not be impressed by hustle.

But here’s the trap: anything that sounds like cosmic permission will be adopted by every small despair looking for a robe and a halo.

I can see it clearly because I’ve done it. I’ve read a line that says, in effect, “stop forcing things,” and heard it as, “stop trying.” I have taken “don’t strangle the river” and turned it into “don’t leave the bed.” I have misread “align with the grain of reality” as “become furniture.”

Part of this is depression. Depression is a con artist that sells you a fake philosophy: *Nothing matters, so why move?* It’s a thought that feels wise because it’s quiet and heavy, like old stone. Hypomania, on the other hand, sells the opposite fake philosophy: *Everything matters, so move in all directions at once.* Between the two I live like a pendulum that thinks it’s a philosopher.

So when *Wu Wei* shows up in my mind, I have to ask: is this Laozi speaking—or is this my nervous system, tired and underfed on hope, doing ventriloquism?

# Kolkata’s physics: friction everywhere, no traction anywhere

There’s a simple mechanical truth that explains a lot of lower middle-class paralysis, and it has nothing to do with “culture” and everything to do with energy.

In physics, to move a thing from rest you need to overcome static friction. Static friction is meaner than kinetic friction; it’s the bouncer at the club door. Once you’re moving, it’s easier to keep moving. But to start—especially if the surface is rough, uneven, and possibly on fire—you need a shove.

Now take that and build a life.

When you’re broke, when your neighborhood is a slow leak, when institutions feel like theater and jobs feel like lottery tickets sold by smug men, the friction is high. Every action has hidden costs: money, time, humiliation, paperwork, social signaling, the emotional labor of being treated like you’re asking for favors instead of trying to exist.

Even deciding to try carries a tax: you might fail, and failure in a precarious life is not a lesson, it’s a crater.

So inertia isn’t just “laziness.” It’s often the rational response of an organism in an environment where effort doesn’t reliably pay. This is not me romanticizing it. It’s me noticing that bodies and brains are accountants. They track cost and reward, not in tidy numbers, but in stress hormones, sleep, appetite, and that invisible metric called “how many times have I been disappointed recently.”

Psychologists call one flavor of this *learned helplessness*—a concept Martin Seligman studied in the 1960s and 70s. The crude summary: if an animal learns that its actions don’t change outcomes, it stops acting even when action would help. The elegant horror: the animal’s “giving up” is not moral failure; it’s a model of the world.

Depression can be that model calcified into identity.

And in a city like Kolkata—where the air itself teaches you that you are not the priority—there’s a collective version. A shared shrug. A local climate of resignation that people decorate with ideology, or nostalgia, or sarcasm, or the wonderfully Bengali habit of turning despair into performance art over tea.

Which is where *Wu Wei* gets invited in as a dignified foreign guest.

“Ah yes,” says the chai-stall philosopher, stirring sugar into his cup like he’s doing chemistry for the gods. “Why run after things? The Tao says don’t force it.”

But the Tao is not your auntie’s excuse for not taking medicine. Taoism is not a bureaucratic stamp that validates your stagnation.

It is, if anything, an attack on self-importance. And self-importance is exactly what we use to justify our despair: *My suffering is special. My failure is cosmically inevitable. My inaction is intellectual.*

I’m saying “we,” but I mean “me,” too. I have intellectualized myself into a corner often enough to know the furniture by name.

# What effortless action actually feels like (spoiler: it can look like work)

The most annoying thing about *Wu Wei* is that, when you finally glimpse it, it does not look like doing nothing. It looks like competence.

Watch a skilled carpenter. Not the poetic kind from advertisements—an actual one, with forearms like arguments. When he measures, cuts, joins, the action is smooth. Not because he is lazy, but because he is aligned with constraints. He respects wood grain, tool angle, leverage. He isn’t fighting reality; he’s cooperating with it. The “effortlessness” is what action looks like when it isn’t wasted.

This is true in sports, music, mathematics, even conversation. The best move often feels like *not forcing the move*. You let the system’s own dynamics do the heavy lifting.

There’s a neuroscience angle here, if you want to ruin the romance (I do). Brains are prediction machines. They minimize error between what they expect and what they sense. When you’re learning something, your prediction errors are huge, so everything feels effortful. As you get better, the brain compresses the skill into a more efficient model: fewer surprises, smoother execution, lower metabolic cost. “Flow” states—those periods where action seems to happen without a separate “you” narrating it—are arguably the nervous system running a well-trained loop with minimal internal conflict.

That’s a plausible modern cousin of *Wu Wei*: action without the ego’s constant micromanagement.

The ego, by the way, is often a terrible manager. It is anxious, status-obsessed, and convinced that the universe is grading it. It loves to *try hard* in ways that are theatrically visible and strategically useless.

So Taoism says: stop that. Stop the frantic, grasping, performative struggle. Do what fits.

But the lower middle-class tragedy is that “what fits” is often very narrow, and the environment punishes experiments. In that situation, “don’t force it” can mutate into “don’t attempt it,” and soon you’re not practicing *Wu Wei*; you’re practicing *slow self-erasure*.

I know because I can feel the seduction in my bones. On bad days, the bed is not a bed; it’s a philosophy. The phone scroll is not a vice; it’s an epistemology: I am “staying informed.” The procrastination is not fear; it’s “waiting for the right moment.” All of it sounds clean when translated into abstract nouns.

But bodies don’t live in nouns. Bodies live in minutes.

# The Indian cousin of Wu Wei that nobody uses as an excuse

We have our own old literature about action and restraint, but we cherry-pick it like crows.

From the Īśa Upaniṣad—part of the Vedic corpus, short and sharp enough to feel like it was written by someone who hates unnecessary decoration—there’s a line that I keep returning to when my brain tries to baptize inertia:

“कुर्वन्नेवेह कर्माणि जिजीविषेच्छतं समाः”
(*kurvann eveha karmāṇi jijīviṣec chataṃ samāḥ*)

Roughly: “Doing actions here, one should wish to live a hundred years.”

It’s not saying “be a workaholic.” It’s saying: *life is not lived by withdrawal alone.* It’s a reminder that the world is not solved by sulking at it from a safe distance.

And then, a few verses later, the same text tosses a grenade into the smug face of simplistic spirituality:

“विद्यां चाविद्यां च यस्तद्वेदोभयं सह”
He who knows both knowledge and ignorance together…

The point being: reality is mixed. You don’t get to pick only the parts that flatter your temperament. You have to hold opposites without collapsing into either mania (“only knowledge!”) or nihilism (“only ignorance!”). It’s almost rude how psychologically modern it sounds.

Taoism, in its better moments, is also about holding opposites. Not forcing, but not freezing. Yielding, but not rotting.

My problem—our problem, if I’m being generous—is that we prefer philosophies that give us a clean excuse. We like systems that let us say, “See? I’m not failing. I’m *transcending*.”

Transcendence is a beautiful word that has been used, historically, to cover an enormous amount of cowardice.

# Politics as mood stabilizer, mood as politics

It’s impossible to write about Bengali stagnation—sorry, *my stagnation in a Bengali setting*, because I am not going to turn an ethnicity into a punching bag—without mentioning politics, because politics is the city’s favorite religion after cricket and pessimism.

The Left taught a whole generation to talk in grand abstractions while life continued in small humiliations. Then the counter-reaction taught us to talk in different abstractions while the humiliations continued, now with extra noise. If you’re lower middle class, politics can become a way to feel involved without being effective, like yelling at the TV and calling it cardio.

Sometimes that involvement is genuine. Sometimes it’s an alibi.

I have watched smart people become museum guides of their own resentment, explaining, with great fluency, why everything is broken, who broke it, and why the fix is impossible—while they themselves remain strangely untouched by the concept of changing a habit.

The thing about ideology is that it can be a mood stabilizer. It converts personal failure into systemic critique. The critique may even be correct. Systems are brutal. Inequality is real. Corruption is not folklore; it’s infrastructure. But the psyche loves a story where responsibility is always located elsewhere.

I say this as someone who distrusts authority on principle. I’m not here to preach bootstraps. I’m here to admit a more embarrassing truth: I can be right about the system and still use that rightness as a sedative.

That’s the worst combination—accurate diagnosis plus comfortable paralysis.

On hypomanic days, my mind becomes a firework factory. Everything connects: Taoism to thermodynamics to the sociology of tea stalls to the geopolitics of supply chains to the neurochemistry of motivation. I feel like a prophet of patterns. It’s intoxicating. Then the next day I can’t answer a phone call. The same brain that mapped the cosmos can’t map the route to a simple task.

So I become, again, a balcony mammal.

# The quiet difference between surrender and acceptance

Here’s the distinction I keep trying to tattoo onto my own mind with a blunt instrument: surrender is not the same as acceptance.

Surrender is when you stop because you believe you are powerless.

Acceptance is when you stop fighting what is true so you can act on what is possible.

They look similar from the outside. Both can be quiet. Both can involve a person sitting still. But the inner texture is different. Surrender feels like collapse. Acceptance feels like unclenching.

*Wu Wei*, properly understood, is acceptance that moves.

It’s the martial arts idea: you don’t meet force with force; you redirect. You don’t stiffen; you align. It’s softness as strategy, not softness as self-abandonment.

My version, too often, is surrender dressed as a robe.

I tell myself I’m being “philosophical,” but I’m actually being afraid—afraid of trying and discovering that my best effort is still not enough, afraid of starting and finding out I have less stamina than I imagined, afraid of the banal truth that improvement is mostly repetition and boredom, not revelation.

Taoism is full of water metaphors because water is patient and strong and does not argue with rocks. But water also *moves*. It doesn’t sit in a corner congratulating itself on being moist.

If I’m honest, a lot of my inaction is not spiritual at all. It’s the simple, primitive avoidance of discomfort. Not even big discomfort. Small discomfort: the awkwardness of asking, the pain of being a beginner, the irritation of paperwork, the embarrassment of being seen wanting something.

My pride is pathetic. It’s a cheap pride, the kind that comes free with failure: “At least I’m not desperate.”

But I am desperate. I’m just performing nonchalance because it feels less humiliating than hope.

# A small experiment with the Tao, conducted in a Kolkata winter

This morning I did something radical. I did one thing.

Not a grand thing. Not a life-revolution thing. One thing that took less than ten minutes and required no moral transformation.

I washed a cup properly. Not the ceremonial rinse. The real one: soap, scrub, rinse, dry. I did it slowly, paying attention to the sensation of the sponge dragging across steel, the way water beads and then disappears, the tiny squeak that means clean.

This is so small it’s almost insulting to call it an “experiment,” but that’s kind of the point. If my life is stuck under static friction, I don’t need cosmic ambition; I need a tiny shove.

The Taoist move here is not to force a heroic reinvention. It’s to find the smallest action that fits the grain of the moment, the one that doesn’t trigger resistance, and to do it cleanly.

Effortless action, in my current condition, looks like lowering the bar until my nervous system stops panicking and agrees to participate.

I hate that this works. It feels undignified. My ego wants a dramatic narrative. My ego wants me to be the kind of man who changes his life in a montage.

But real change is usually just a dull accumulation of small, unromantic repetitions. It’s closer to erosion than to explosion.

So the cup gets washed. The balcony still exists. The phone still contains a thousand ways to avoid living. The city still smells like burnt leaves and old arguments.

But there’s a tiny pocket of order now, a clean surface where yesterday there was sticky residue. My brain registers, however faintly: *action can change a local reality.*

That is not enlightenment. That is not salvation. That is just evidence.

And evidence, unlike ideology, actually helps.

# A parting image that refuses to be a moral

By late morning the fog thins, the sun arrives with the mild reluctance of a government clerk, and the street below becomes louder, as if someone turned up the volume on human existence. I watch a boy—school uniform, too-big backpack—hop over a pothole with the casual athleticism of someone who hasn’t yet learned to expect disappointment. His shoes slap the road, he doesn’t look down, he doesn’t narrate his suffering, he just moves.

I envy him in the ugliest way, then immediately feel ashamed for envying a child because my mind is a petty, complicated animal.

Inside, on my table, there’s a book I’ve been meaning to read properly, the kind with underlines waiting like teeth. Next to it, my phone glows with fresh outrage and fresh distractions. Two gods, both hungry.

I don’t pick a grand philosophy. I pick a small action.

I put the phone face down—like turning a loud person toward the wall—and open the book. The page smells faintly of paper and dust and whatever optimism the publisher had when they thought readers still had attention spans.

Outside, the dog scratches again, solemnly, like an old monk with fleas.

I read a paragraph. Then another. Not because the universe demanded it, not because history will reward it, not because I have finally become a better man, but because for a few minutes, at least, I’m doing something that doesn’t feel like force and does n’t feel like surrender either—just a quiet alignment with the fact that I’m alive, I’m here, and the day will pass whether I move or not.

The balcony rail stays cold.

I stay, for once, less still.


# File: src/lib/posts/the-civilized-leaf-and-the-vibrating-bean.md

---
title: "Tea and Coffee"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251220-WA0020.jpg"
date: '2026-01-04'
description: "Tea and Coffee..." 
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "orange" 
---


<Pi
    src="IMG-20251220-WA0020.jpg" 
    caption="Tea and Coffee"
/>

The terracotta *bhar* is sweating again, the way Kolkata sweats—earnestly, without shame, as if humidity were a civic virtue—and the chai seller has set it on a steel saucer that has survived more governments than I have, and more washing than is philosophically advisable. The cup is warm enough to forgive, rough enough to remind you that “authentic” once meant “made by someone with hands,” not “validated by a task force with letterhead.” I cradle it anyway, because this is what a city does to you: it makes you sentimental about objects that would, in a more hygienic universe, be politely retired.

Across the road, a tram bell clinks like an old man clearing his throat before an opinion, and College Street is doing its daily business of selling secondhand certainty—textbooks with underlined sentences, political pamphlets with underfed conclusions, and the occasional earnest boy who thinks the universe is a solvable equation if he just buys the right guidebook. The tea is milky, aggressively sweet, designed not for subtlety but for survival. Somewhere in the steam is the whole infrastructure of Bengal: a beverage as a public utility, a cheap mood-stabilizer, a ritual handshake between strangers who do not trust their institutions but will, without thinking, trust boiling water and crushed leaf.

And then, because the modern world cannot leave a single quiet thing unmeasured, the cup becomes an interface to everything—climate, policy, labor, plastics, my brain’s unreliable wiring, your manager’s fetish for “focus culture,” and Europe’s magnificent habit of turning moral panic into a regulation with an appendix.

I used to believe—how charming, how naive—that tea was a kind of gentle superiority. Coffee was for the jittery, the hurried, the people who think speed is personality. Tea was for the civilized: a slow sip, a small pause, a leaf with manners. This is the sort of idea you acquire the way you acquire fungus: by living too long in the same damp cultural corner.

Now tea is being rebranded as a pharmacology product, and coffee is being rebranded as climate adaptation, and both are being sold in packaging that may or may not be shedding polymers into your bloodstream like tiny invisible confetti celebrating the triumph of convenience. The civilized leaf and the vibrating bean, locked in a global romance that increasingly resembles a labor contract.

You can feel the shift even at the stall. The chai seller doesn’t say “L-theanine,” of course. He says, *cha*, and that syllable carries more history than most parliaments. But somewhere, in an office pantry with a sad potted plant, someone is dunking a nylon pyramid teabag into boiling water and telling themselves they’re making a responsible choice—look, it’s “premium,” it’s “clean,” it’s “green,” it has geometry, it has the aesthetic of science. The bag is a tiny translucent tent, a designer sleeping bag for leaves, and the whole thing looks like it was engineered by a committee that has never met an actual leaf in the wild.

*Science as interior design*, that’s the new spiritual practice.

The internet, meanwhile, has learned to render molecules the way medieval scribes rendered angels: shimmering, symmetrical, holy with meaning. Caffeine gets its own glossy animation, rotating in sacred jewelry lighting, little bonds twinkling like a Bollywood star’s teeth. You can watch it on your cracked phone while a commodity chart—also glossy, also holy—tells you the bean is getting expensive because the planet is getting cranky. Drought, heat stress, shifting rainfall, pests that have read the memo and moved uphill. Robusta, once the “cheap filler,” is being elevated with the kind of reluctant respect we reserve for the cousin who was mocked for years and then bought a flat in Dubai.

Taste is not a private experience anymore; it’s negotiated geopolitics. What the world drinks follows weather maps and port schedules, and the romance of “notes of chocolate” is just a polite way of saying “supply chain didn’t collapse this week.”

I take a sip of chai and try to imagine explaining all this to my younger self—the North Calcutta boy who thought the world was mostly books and rules and the occasional riot. He would have liked the clean story: tea has caffeine plus a peculiar amino acid called L-theanine; caffeine is the rowdy friend banging pots; L-theanine is the sensible companion opening curtains gently; together they produce “calm alertness,” a kind of cognitive gentlemanliness. A chemical handshake. A tidy duet.

Except brains are never tidy. Brains are bureaucracies with electrical storms. Caffeine works by blocking adenosine receptors—adenosine being one of the body’s ways of saying *enough, go lie down, you primate*—and blocking it is like cutting the brake lines on fatigue. You can feel it: the sudden mental brightness, the slightly desperate clarity, the way your thoughts start behaving like commuters late for a train. L-theanine appears to modulate neurotransmission in ways that might increase alpha-band activity on EEG (alpha being that pleasingly poetic “relaxed wakefulness” rhythm), might nudge GABA and glutamate systems, might soften the edge. The literature says “promising” and “inconsistent” in that apologetic academic tone that means: *we tried, reality refused to cooperate, please fund us anyway.*

This is the part where a sensible person would stop and say, “So drink your tea, enjoy your life, don’t turn your nervous system into a spreadsheet.” I am not a sensible person. I am a man who has watched too many people turn their lives into spreadsheets without ever improving the math.

Because the real story isn’t caffeine. The real story is work.

“Calm alertness” has become a workplace norm the way fluorescent lighting became a workplace norm: not because it made humans happy, but because it made them *available*. Productivity culture has discovered that the ideal employee is not merely awake; he is awake with a smile, awake without complaints, awake and *pleasantly optimized*. The old factory demanded your muscles; the new office demands your attention, your mood, your emotional bandwidth. Your brain becomes a project. Calm becomes a KPI. Serenity becomes a subscription. Someone, somewhere, is monetizing your willingness to be less human in the name of being more employable.

So you get supplement stacks. L-theanine capsules in blister packs beside a mug of green tea, because nature is too slow and modernity has no patience. “Bioavailability,” “dose-response,” “pharmacokinetics”—the vocabulary of seriousness, pasted onto products whose greatest innovation is a label that looks like it belongs on a spacecraft. You become your own clinical trial, except without the good parts like oversight and honest statistics. Placebo design, control groups, blinding—these are treated as annoying obstacles instead of the only adult way to claim a thing is true.

And then, because we live in a world that cannot simply poison you in one straightforward way, the cup itself may be a chemical experiment.

The teabag is the quiet scandal. Those plastic mesh pyramid bags, the composites, the adhesives, the “biodegradable” marketing that often means “biodegradable in a hypothetical industrial compost facility located in the same dimension as honest politicians.” Boiling water is not a gentle medium. It is a tiny aggressive ocean. It pulls. It extracts. It persuades molecules to leave home. The tea leaf gives you polyphenols and caffeine and whatever else it was growing under the sun. The bag may give you microplastics and nanoplastics, a phrase that sounds like a science-fiction insult but is really just modernity’s way of saying “we put polymers in everything and now we’re surprised they show up in us.”

The rich world is responding, as it always does, with paperwork. Packaging rules, recyclability mandates, restrictions on intentionally added microplastics. A single big machine of regulation, humming with good intentions and terrifying footnotes. This is not useless—regulation is one of the few ways a society admits it has a shared body—but the irony is delicious: the West discovers sustainability only after it can be audited.

Meanwhile, here at the chai stall, the “reusable” economy is not a virtue signal; it’s poverty doing the correct thing for the wrong reasons. The clay cup is technically single-use too, smashed and discarded, returning to earth in the way our promises never do. The steel kettle is used because you cannot afford to throw it away. The glass is washed because you must. Survival economics accidentally impersonating environmental ethics, and being congratulated only when it gets translated into a policy framework in Brussels.

I catch myself feeling smug—*see, we’ve been sustainable all along*—and I immediately distrust the feeling. Kolkata teaches you this: any emotion that arrives too neatly is probably propaganda.

Because our “authenticity” is also a mess.

Darjeeling, that tiny strip of hills with a global reputation and local fragility, has become a battlefield over what counts as “real.” GI labels, logos, policing, labs, task forces—dignity enforced by chemical assays. There’s something tragic and comic about it: a leaf needing a bureaucracy to remain itself. Counterfeit flows, blending rumors, cheap inflows, and the blunt economic fact that markets often reward the blend, not the truth. In a world of climate volatility—erratic rains, hotter seasons, timing shifts that make “second flush” gossip sound like meteorology—purity becomes a luxury, and luxury becomes a weapon.

The plantation worker doesn’t get paid in authenticity. He gets paid in heat and piece-rate. The “calm cup” comes with intergenerational labor, welfare dependency, and bodies bent over bushes in weather that is getting less polite every year. I think about “heat stress productivity loss,” a phrase so bloodless it could be a corporate memo, and then I think about actual heat—the kind that makes your skin feel like it’s wearing a damp shirt you cannot remove—and suddenly the romance of “tea culture” feels like a perfume sprayed over a sweat-stained shirt.

This is the point where the essay could become a sermon. I can feel the temptation: the noble worker, the evil consumer, the wicked corporation, the righteous regulation. It’s a classic structure, ready-made, like a cheap packet of instant coffee. So I swerve. Deliberately. I refuse to pretend I am above the system simply because I can name its parts.

I am complicit. I like convenience. I like the quick teabag on days when my mind is a collapsed tent and I cannot manage the ceremony of leaf and strainer. I have watched molecule-videos late at night, seduced by their clean geometry, as if understanding were a visual effect. I have read labels with that paranoid Indian fatigue—*is this real, is this fake, is this adulterated, is the “pure” thing a lie wrapped in plastic?*—and then bought the thing anyway because living entirely on suspicion is a form of starvation.

In India, the regulator’s labeling instinct is both comforting and absurd. Comforting because somebody, somewhere, is pretending there is a rule. Absurd because the market has the agility of a thief. Wellness claims breed like mosquitoes. “Functional beverages” appear with their confident fonts, colliding with the slow grinding machinery of standards. The label becomes a battlefield where truth either becomes honest or dies. Often it does neither; it just becomes ambiguous enough to sell.

And in the middle of this, we have the personal myth: tea as calm-focus, tea as civilized, tea as the better drug with better branding.

My old Bengali reflex is to turn that myth into an identity—*we are tea people, therefore we are refined*—which is just coffee snobbery in a quieter sari. The leaf does not make you wise. The leaf is a plant. It wants sunlight, water, and to reproduce. It did not evolve to help you survive your Monday meeting.

Still, the cup in my hand is doing something. Not just chemically—though yes, the caffeine is sliding into my receptors and the sugar is bribing my bloodstream—but socially. The chai stall is a tiny republic. A public square with steam. A place where the price is known, the ritual is shared, the conversation is democratic in the only way Kolkata still manages: loud, intimate, unlicensed. Tea is infrastructure. It survives even when institutions don’t. The stall is open when the office is closed. The kettle works when the grid sulks. The vendor remembers you when the bank forgets you.

So perhaps the civilized leaf isn’t about calm-focus at all. Perhaps it’s about continuity—the stubborn persistence of small systems that function in a country where large systems often perform. The chai seller doesn’t need a packaging regulation to understand waste; he understands it because waste costs money. He doesn’t need a neuroscience paper to understand attention; he understands it because a distracted customer spills tea.

I look down at the *bhar* and imagine, absurdly, a Brussels bureaucrat trying to classify it—single-use? recyclable? compostable? culturally significant?—and the thought makes me laugh into my tea like a fool.

A boy walks past with a phone playing some “study with me” stream—soft music, a timer, the aesthetic of discipline—and I can’t decide whether to admire him or pity him. The internet has turned concentration into a genre. Calm is now something you watch someone else perform. We outsource serenity the way we outsource manufacturing.

My tea is almost finished. The leaves, somewhere, have already been paid for in a chain of transactions that includes weather, wages, branding, and a thousand tiny compromises. The cup will be tossed. The saucer will be wiped with a rag that has seen things.

The tram bell clinks again. The air smells like damp paper and boiled milk and ambition.

I drain the last sip, feel the familiar lift—the vibrating bean’s cousin, the civilized leaf’s little betrayal—and think: in 2026, even a humble cup of tea is a policy document with steam.

And steam, as always, rises beautifully and vanishes, like our best intentions.


# File: src/lib/posts/the-elephant-in-the-skull.md

---
title: "The Elephant in the Skull"
date: "2025-12-21"
description: "A meditation on the chronic diseases of a civilization: inflated self-esteem, overconfidence, and the elephant in the room that is actually inside our heads."
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251221-WA0072.jpg"
category: "personal"
published: true
color: "red"
---

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251221-WA0072.jpg"
    caption="A map of India pretending to be an elephant, carrying history and a personality disorder."
/>

The drawing is a map of India pretending to be a patient suffering from severe elephantiasis, which is already a very Indian sort of metaphor—cartography as disease, nationalism as pet animal—except this man is not majestic. He’s lumpy in his balls where it hurts the most, semi-bored, vaguely constipated, like he has been asked to carry history on its back and has responded by developing a personality disorder.

I drew him with the kind of impatient tenderness you reserve for your own worst habits. Not hatred, not pride—more like that exhausted, familiar disgust you feel when you catch yourself doing the same idiotic thing again, the brain reaching automatically for the same cheap comfort, the same inflated narrative, the same little lie that keeps you warm but makes you stupid. My hand did the outline first, that confident stroke that always arrives before the confidence is deserved, and then I had to go back and dirty it up—stippling, shading, giving him that swollen, lived-in misery—because even caricature needs biology. Even satire needs flesh.

And there’s something deliciously obscene about using a medical condition as a national allegory, because India is the sort of place where metaphors are always bodily if you look long enough. We don’t just have corruption; we have rot. We don’t just have inequality; we have infestation. We don’t just have ideology; we have fever dreams. We speak in stomach and skin and blood and purity and pollution, even when we pretend we’re talking about GDP.

Also I’m fifty-ish, stuck in the south Calcutta boondocks with a mind that behaves like a miswired electrical panel—sparks of hypomanic pattern-making, long brownouts of depressive realism—so my metaphors tend to arrive wearing sandals and dragging a bag of groceries: ordinary, physical, faintly pathetic.

# A Quick Science Detour, Because I Can’t Resist

Elephantiasis—real elephantiasis—isn’t a moral failing. It’s a physiological tragedy. Lymphatic filariasis, parasites, mosquitoes, a quiet war happening under skin; a drainage system clogged until the body swells grotesquely, not because the body is arrogant, but because the plumbing is broken. The lymph system is one of those unglamorous miracles: it hauls away waste, moves immune cells, keeps tissues from becoming soggy ruined sponges. When it fails, the body doesn’t politely malfunction. It balloons. It announces the failure.

That’s why it’s such a cruelly perfect metaphor for societies.

Because societies also have drainage systems. Not literal ones—though India, famously, struggles with those too—but conceptual ones: institutions that remove waste ideas, that filter nonsense, that prevent the same toxic myths from recirculating until they become culture. The scientific method is one. Journalism, at its best, is another. Courts, when they’re not asleep. Education, when it teaches thinking rather than obedience. A functioning civil service. A social norm that says: *you don’t get to claim anything you like just because you said it loudly*.

When those systems clog—when superstition becomes identity, when propaganda becomes patriotism, when caste becomes “heritage,” when religion becomes a political weapon—the social body swells. Not with strength. With edema. With trapped fluid.

And then the swelling itself becomes proof. Look how big we are, the swollen nation says. Look how powerful. Look how ancient. Look how *special*.

A tumor also grows. That doesn’t mean it’s winning.

# Why I Drew His Balls First

It’s vulgar, sure, but it’s honest. The groin is where insecurity lives. Not poetry-insecurity—actual, sweaty, trembling insecurity. The place where evolution stored the fear of being laughed at by the tribe, rejected, made irrelevant. We dress it up as honor, pride, tradition, culture; underneath, it’s the same mammalian panic: *am I safe, am I respected, am I desired, am I allowed to exist without being crushed*.

India’s public mood often feels like a man constantly protecting his crotch while shouting about greatness.

And I’m not outside this. God knows I’m not. The part of me that wants India to be “great” is not the part that cares about justice or science or dignity; it’s the part that wants my own life to retroactively matter, my own disappointments to be reframed as merely temporary setbacks in the grand civilizational arc. If the tribe is glorious, then my smallness feels less humiliating. If the nation is special, then my mediocrity becomes a rounding error.

This is the psychological engine of supremacy narratives everywhere—national, religious, racial, whatever. The ego is a hungry little bureaucrat. It wants a stamp. It wants certification. It wants a letterhead that says: IMPORTANT PERSON, BELONGS TO IMPORTANT GROUP.

So I drew the swelling where it hurts most, because that’s where the lie lives.

# Inflated Self-Esteem: The Inflatable Raft of the Poor

The cartoon labels it like a symptom: inflated self-esteem, overconfidence, shallow knowledge. People might read that and think it’s pure insult—Indians are arrogant and dumb, ha ha. That’s the cheap reading. The satisfying reading. The reading that lets you feel smarter than a billion people without doing any work.

But when I wrote “inflated self-esteem,” I wasn’t thinking of strength. I was thinking of an inflatable raft.

You don’t inflate a raft because you’re proud. You inflate it because you’re drowning.

A lot of India’s chest-thumping is not confidence; it’s compensation for humiliation—colonial humiliation, poverty humiliation, the daily humiliation of being treated like a replaceable insect by systems that don’t have to care. And when a society has been humiliated for a long time, it develops a weird reflex: it starts building myths the way a body builds scar tissue.

Some scars are protective. Some scars make you stiff.

The trouble is that scar tissue doesn’t feel like weakness. It feels like armor. And armor, once you’re wearing it, starts making you behave like a soldier even when you’re just buying potatoes.

# Overconfidence: The National Sport Nobody Admits They Play

Overconfidence is not just a personality trait. It’s a social reward structure.

In India, certainty is applause-worthy. Nuance is suspicious. Doubt is treated like treason or softness or—my favorite accusation—“confusion,” as if being confused in a complex world is a personal failure rather than an accurate perception.

So people learn to speak like gods even when they know like toddlers.

I’ve watched men who can’t explain how interest rates work explain geopolitics with the confidence of a CIA director. I’ve watched family WhatsApp groups transform a badly edited video into a worldview in ten minutes. I’ve watched religion become a substitute for curiosity: why learn when you can chant?

And yes, of course, this happens everywhere. Humans are credulous animals with smartphones. But India adds particular accelerants: a brittle status hierarchy, a schooling system that often trains memory more than reasoning, and a political culture that thrives on spectacle. Overconfidence becomes not just common but *functional*. It gets you jobs. It gets you followers. It gets you power.

Meanwhile the quiet person who says “I don’t know” gets treated like a malfunction.

This is why I’m suspicious of any society that treats humility as weakness. Humility is not self-hatred. Humility is epistemic hygiene. It’s washing your hands before you touch reality.

# Shallow Knowledge: The Coaching-Class Epistemology

Shallow knowledge is not “knowing little.” It’s knowing things that haven’t been metabolized—facts as ornaments, concepts as trophies, vocabulary as camouflage.

India is brilliant at producing the appearance of knowledge. We are the homeland of the exam guide, the shortcut, the “important questions,” the last-minute crash course, the coaching-industrial complex that treats learning like a military drill: memorize, reproduce, rank, repeat.

The tragedy is that this system can produce high scorers who are intellectually malnourished.

It can also produce the worst kind of semi-educated arrogance: the man who has just enough jargon to bully other people, and just enough ignorance to never suspect he’s wrong. The Dunning–Kruger creature—though I hate invoking that phrase because it has become another shallow meme, another way to dunk on others while pretending to do psychology.

But the phenomenon is real. The less you know, the easier it is to feel certain.

Knowledge, actual knowledge, comes with discomfort. The more you learn, the more you see the edges of what you don’t know. The world grows teeth.

So shallow knowledge is seductive because it gives you the warm feeling of understanding without the cold price of humility.

# Caste and Religion: The Old Plumbing That Keeps Clogging Everything

I drew “caste” and “religion” near the lower body not because I’m trying to be edgy, but because these systems are deeply bodily in India. They are obsessed with touch, with food, with purity, with contamination, with who can be near whom, who can marry whom, who can enter which space, who can do which work. They are social biology pretending to be spiritual order.

Caste is not merely prejudice. It is infrastructure. It is networks, marriage markets, informal references, the invisible hand that is not a hand but a very old fist.

Religion, in its everyday politicized form, becomes a technology for organizing crowds—identity, belonging, moral permission, enemy-making. It can also be beauty and community, yes, but I’m allergic to the grandstanding version, the version that talks like God hired a PR agency.

The cartoon doesn’t say “religion = bad.” It says religion becomes a chronic disease when it is used to justify supremacist fantasies and to keep people from asking questions that would threaten the hierarchy.

This is where the elephantiasis metaphor bites again: when the drainage system fails, waste accumulates. And social waste is not only corruption money; it’s dead ideas that refuse to die. It’s myths that keep reproducing because they flatter the ego and stabilize power.

# The Worst Part: I’m in the Drawing Too

Here’s the part I hate admitting, because it spoils the righteous pleasure of satire.

I drew this cartoon, and then I caught myself feeling superior to the people I was criticizing, and that—right there—is the disease doing push-ups in my own head.

My depression tells me I’m irrelevant. My hypomania tells me I’m a prophet. Both are forms of narcissism, just dressed differently: one says, “I am uniquely doomed,” the other says, “I am uniquely insightful.” Either way, I’m the main character in a cosmic drama that reality didn’t agree to produce.

And because I’m bookish, my arrogance often wears a sweater vest. It quotes history. It name-drops science. It pretends that reading is a moral virtue. I can become the kind of man who thinks that because he has *language*, he has *wisdom*, which is like thinking that owning a map makes you a good traveler.

So when I label “inflated self-esteem” on the cartoon, I have to ask: whose self-esteem is inflated?

Mine, too.

When I label “shallow knowledge,” I have to stare at my own shelves—my half-read books, my hoarded PDFs, my concepts collected like stamps—and ask how much of it is actually lived understanding and how much is intellectual cosplay.

This is the humiliating thing about satire: it’s supposed to be a weapon, but it keeps turning into a mirror.

# Methods, Not Myths

If the cartoon is more than a cynical doodle, it has to point toward something other than contempt, because contempt is the laziest emotion—cheap, instant, endlessly recyclable, like plastic bags.

What it points toward, for me, is method. Not ideology. Not slogans. Methods.

The scientific method is one: you propose, you test, you try to falsify your own idea, you let evidence humiliate you, you update. Statistics is another: you quantify uncertainty, you resist the brain’s addiction to stories, you learn to live with probability instead of craving certainty. Philosophy—actual philosophy, not motivational posters—teaches you to define terms, examine assumptions, follow arguments until they either hold or collapse.

And it’s funny—darkly funny—that even the ancient Indian texts people weaponize as supremacy proof often contain warnings against certainty.

One of the Upanishads, in a line that feels like it was written specifically to ruin a WhatsApp forward, basically says: the person who thinks he knows doesn’t know. That’s not anti-knowledge. That’s anti-arrogance. That’s epistemic humility dressed as poetry.

Which is the opposite of how we use “tradition” today. We use it as a shield: don’t question, don’t examine, don’t test—just revere. But reverence without inquiry is how you end up worshipping your own ignorance, like a man polishing a locked box and calling it treasure.

# The Bitter Little Punchline

The elephantiasis patient in my cartoon is not India as a place—the smells of frying oil, wet dust, old books, the sudden sweetness of jasmine near a roadside shrine, the chaos that sometimes feels like a jazz solo and sometimes like a riot. I love the place even when I can’t stand the people, including myself.

The patient is India as an idea: swollen with stories it cannot metabolize, dragging around ancient hierarchies that keep rebranding themselves, mistaking noise for knowledge, mistaking pride for strength, mistaking supremacy for dignity.

And because I drew him, I have to admit something even more irritating: I drew him as a warning, but also as a confession. The cartoon is me trying to drain some of my own trapped fluid—my own resentment, my own disappointed love, my own itch to feel superior—onto paper, where it can at least be looked at under a harsh light.

Later, when the house is quiet and the ceiling fan does its tired helicopter impression, I’ll probably open a new document and start rewriting this, deleting sentences, adding clauses, trying to make the prose sound less like a man arguing with himself in the dark.

I’ll fail, of course. That’s part of the condition.

Then I’ll close the laptop, and somewhere in the corner of my mind that swollen cartoon-man will sit, lumpy and constipated and absurdly familiar, reminding me that the real chronic disease isn’t India.

It’s certainty.

And the only modest cure I know—the one I can practice even from my small, shabby corner of Calcutta—is the embarrassing habit of checking whether the story in my head is true before I start worshipping it.


# File: src/lib/posts/the-feigenbaum-bum-fucking-constant.md

---

title: "the feigenbaum bum fucking constant"  
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251023-WA0012(1).jpg"  
date: 2026-01-11  
description: "A spiraling, piss-soaked, math-and-masturbation tangent about chaos, constants, calcified cocks, and the unprovable slope of human stupidity."  
category: 'personal'  
published: true
