color: "orange"

---

<Yc />

<Yt src="https://youtu.be/ovJcsL7vyrk?si=CqfhnXFKD0Xf7z_A" />

<Pi src="IMG-20251023-WA0012(1).jpg" />



It started with a tight, puckered sphincter and a fucking Casio calculator.

I was sitting on my plastic toilet seat—which has developed this charming hairline crack that pinches my left ass cheek exactly where the soul used to live—and I was trying, for the sixth time that week, to take a dump. Nothing. Just hot, gassy whispers and the feeling that some cosmic bureaucrat had misplaced my bowel movement authorization form.

But what came out instead, crouched between constipation and the last crusted drop of the morning’s reheated dal, was a *number*. 4.6692. Over and over again, like one of those annoying mnemonic jingles that hooks itself into the folds of your brain meat and wriggles like a parasitic centipede—you try to forget, and it humps your hippocampus harder.

The Feigenbaum constant. Yes, that one. That unreasonably sexy bastard of a number. The mathematical equivalent of a prostitute whispering “I know your mother’s name” as she jerks you off in the dark.



They say the Feigenbaum constant is what shows up when orderly systems—dripping with rules, wearing crisp Newtonian underpants—start to go all slutty and chaotic. You take a simple function, a logistic map maybe, population growth or rabbit-fucking-rate or whatever, and you tweak a single parameter—just a little—just the tip—and suddenly bifurcations happen. One becomes two. Two becomes four. Four becomes fuck-you-too-many. And right at the edge of all this whorehouse mathematics, as the system slips into chaos, *that* number appears like a math demon in a cum-stained trenchcoat: **4.6692...**

Not three, not pi, not golden anything. But a constant that says: you push nature, she pushes back, and then, without warning, she queefs in your face and eats your calculator.



Now, I learned about it on page 231 of a secondhand paperback that smelled like ball sweat and coconut hair oil, sitting in a room too close to the bathroom, too far from hope. And I thought: fuck, this constant knows me. It *is* me. Every year I inch closer to total disintegration—first doubling in my joblessness, then in bitterness, then in neck fat, then in visible regret—and each stage feels exactly 4.6692 times closer to the inevitable shit-smeared abyss.

The bifurcation diagram looks like my life if you squint: symmetrical, sprouting alternate realities, each one shittier than the last. One branch where I stayed in Austin and drank myself into an amicable suicide pact with a bottle of Jack. One where I became a professor with a limp dick and a secret OnlyFans subscription. One where I stayed here, right here, constipated on a cracked toilet, discovering Feigenbaum in my farts.



Mitchell Feigenbaum, the guy, was a chain-smoking, disheveled physics prodigy who basically jerked off into a TI-83 and made love to chaos theory in a back alley of Los Alamos. He didn’t believe in smoothness. He saw the universe as a series of ugly, kinky hiccups. And he realized that even *mess* has a goddamn pattern.

And that’s where I spiraled, again. See, I don’t trust patterns. Not anymore.

Because when you’re Bengali and 50-something and your body smells like an old bookstore had sex with a fish market, and your phone has 47 unread messages but none of them are from a woman or a bank or even the water guy—it’s hard to believe in elegant recurrence. You see stuttered chaos not as beauty but as… routine. The failed job applications. The creeping mold. The political slogans. The price of onions. The sudden erections at the wrong time (never the right time). You start to think: maybe this isn’t a phase transition. Maybe it’s just a prolonged fungal infection of reality.



There’s a famous diagram from his work—it starts with one branch, then splits, then splits again, and the gaps get smaller and smaller and it looks like a beautiful tree if the tree had been dipped in ketamine and electrocuted. And every time you zoom in, expecting resolution, you just find more mess. That’s what chaos does. It doesn’t give you clarity. It gives you *structureless recursion*, the mathematical equivalent of trying to explain your life to an ex-girlfriend while sobbing into the kitchen sink and holding a spoon full of Horlicks.

But hey, look, science! Isn’t it amazing? You know what else has a bifurcation pattern? A prolapsed anus. Look it up.



Feigenbaum’s number doesn’t come from the sky. It emerges. From a dumb, iterative system. f(x) = r * x * (1 - x). The kind of equation that should be boring. Like your uncle’s erectile dysfunction diagnosis. But no—tweak the parameter *r*, and at certain values, the system flips out like a drunk aunt at a wedding, and you go from calm to threesomes to murder in like six cycles.

The universe *wants* to be chaotic. But it’s too ashamed to admit it. So it invents constants to whisper between the screams.



I once had a dream (induced, no doubt, by an overdose of calcium supplements and post-midnight YouTube playlists involving string theory and Sri Lankan cooking) that I met Feigenbaum. He was barefoot. He told me chaos is just the body’s way of remembering it’s meat.

And then he farted.

I woke up sweating and still couldn’t shit.



Every time I look at that constant now, it feels like a middle finger from the cosmos. Like it’s telling me: hey, motherfucker, all that effort you made to stay rational? To make lists? To “reinvent” yourself with ten minutes of yoga and a new Google Doc called *Vision 2035*? *Too late.* You’re past the bifurcation point. You're on the outer branches now. You can't even fold your underwear without triggering a recursive breakdown of linear causality.

There’s no going back to “one.”



I have a theory.

Maybe God isn’t a bearded man or a particle or a moral fable or some simulated quantum server in West Fuckall Oregon. Maybe God is a bum-fucking constant. A number that reminds you the moment things seem regular, they’re just gearing up to split, crack, fork, and fail, again and again, until all you can do is stand at the bottom of your own life chart, staring up at the infinite branching of decisions you didn’t make, dicks you didn’t suck, degrees you didn’t finish, friends you didn’t keep, toilets you didn’t clean.



There is no stable attractor here.

Only mess. Only the constant. Only 4.6692, repeating forever.

Like that itch I have on the underside of my left nut that no doctor believes is real.



# File: src/lib/posts/the-last-cup-of-tea.md

---
title: "The Last Cup of Tea"
date: "2025-12-31"
description: "A small squelching whimper of cogs that have all come loose beyond any screwdriving this middling age can now invent."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "black"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251212-WA0009.jpg"
---

<Yc />
<Pi
    src="IMG-20251212-WA0009.jpg" 
    caption="The last cup of tea"
/>

The last cup of tea of the year always tastes like it has been reheated in a municipal office—lukewarm, slightly resentful, faintly metallic, as if the spoon has opinions. The cup sits on my table with that brown ring the world’s laziest cartographer leaves behind, a little coastline of tannin marking where I have been and where I am too tired to wipe. Outside, South Calcutta does its usual December performance: a damp cold that isn’t cold so much as insistent, a fog that feels like a bored clerk stamping everything “PENDING,” and a chorus of scooters coughing like old men clearing their throats before announcing they are still alive.

It is 31 December 2025, which sounds like a date from a science-fiction paperback printed on cheap paper that yellows faster than my optimism. The calendar says end of year; my body says end of attention span; my mind says, as always, end of something, begin of something, who cares, the kettle is whistling again. Somewhere in the building a child shrieks and someone laughs too loud, as if volume could bribe time into being generous.

On the floor near my chair lies the true religious object of my house: an old speaker, scuffed and slightly leaning, with a wire that has been re-twisted so many times it resembles a family tradition. I press play, and the room fills with that particular kind of music that refuses to be merely sound—old songs that arrive with their own weather, their own perfume, their own ghostly furniture. The singer’s voice has the warm fatigue of someone who knows life is a losing argument but insists on making it eloquent anyway.

<Yt src="https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PL5hFsPf-1mfW-_mejmhtCQwt9TkGCBQuC&si=wv65XH0WIjQfLeGM" />

### The Problem of Presence

And this is the problem. My moments of ambition, love, longing—those feverish little hand-made fireworks—are not here with me in this room. They are elsewhere, filed away in the past like brittle documents in a steel almirah. The present is a crumbling façade, a set that looks convincing until you lean on it and it politely collapses. The future is a murky unknown, full of premonitions that behave like mosquitoes—tiny, persistent, and impossible to reason with.

I know the fashionable thing to do on the last day of the year is to perform hope. Hope has become an industry: you dress it up, you post it, you hashtag it, you pretend it’s a muscle rather than a mood. But I can’t do the TED-talk ending. My brain refuses that kind of clean narrative, the way my tongue refuses cheap sweetener. My life—these recent years—has been a string of ghastly vegetative seasons where I slowly fade and dissolve in the abject indifference and poverty of feelings and circumstances, dying undramatically, not with a tragic flourish but with a small squelching whimper of cogs that have all come loose beyond any screwdriving this middling age can now invent.

“Vegetative.” A loaded word, isn’t it. We use it to insult, as if a plant is a lesser citizen of the universe. But plants do not pretend. A plant does not announce it is “reinventing itself” in Q1. A plant takes light, makes sugar, tries not to die, and occasionally produces something beautiful without needing to tweet about it. My own vegetative years, unfortunately, have lacked even the dignity of photosynthesis.

### Nostalgia as a Drug

Still, I press play again. Nostalgia is a funny chemical reaction. People like to treat it as a harmless misty-eyed indulgence, a harmless habit like keeping old ticket stubs. But nostalgia is not a souvenir shop; it is a drug. It is both analgesic and poison, which is the best kind, because it feels like medicine while it rots something important. There’s a famous etymology: *nostos* (return home) and *algos* (pain). Pain of return, or pain because you cannot return—take your pick, both are accurate in the way a slap is accurate. The folk version you hear in drawing-room conversations is that nostalgia is “sweet memory.” Sweet? Only if your sugar comes with glass shards.

The brain, in its infinite bureaucratic wisdom, stores the past not as a faithful archive but as a reconstruction. The hippocampus—named after a seahorse because anatomists sometimes have the souls of poets—doesn’t replay your life like a film; it rebuilds it like a cheap contractor, using whatever materials are lying around: fragments, emotions, smells, the rhythm of a tune. Every time you remember, you edit. You aren’t visiting the past; you’re rewriting it. Which means my addiction to old songs is not even an addiction to what happened. It is an addiction to what I have managed to reassemble from what happened, the way a child rebuilds a broken toy and insists it was always meant to look like that.

I sit in this room and let an old tune wrap itself around me like a shawl. Not a fashionable shawl—some frayed, faithful thing with holes, the kind my mother would insist still has “a few more winters left.” The song doesn’t simply remind me of a happy past. It manufactures one. It takes the scattered, contradictory debris of my life and arranges it into a scene that looks, for three minutes and forty seconds, like meaning.

Then the song ends, and the room returns, with its damp walls and its minor humiliations—the buzzing tube light that flickers like it has existential doubts, the ceiling fan wobbling as if it too is aging badly, the smell of last night’s rice pretending not to be stale.

### The Clock That Colonized My Skin

Time, in Bengal, has always had two faces. One is the intimate time of adda, the elastic afternoon that stretches and folds around conversation, the time that says: sit, drink tea, argue about politics, pretend you are not mortal. The other is imported time: the railway timetable, the office punch-in, the Greenwich line slicing the world into obedient slices. We like to make mythological noises about ancient wisdom, but modern India runs on British-era time discipline and American-style hurry, with a side of WhatsApp anxiety.

We inherited clocks the way we inherited bureaucracy: not because it suited our souls, but because someone else’s machine demanded that our bodies be predictable. The colonial project was not only about land and loot, it was about synchronizing chaos into something billable. And I—science-and-math brained, rationalist, atheist—should admire the elegance of it. Standard time is a triumph of coordination. It is also a kind of leash.

On the last day of the year, the leash becomes visible. Everyone stares at the same numbers, waiting for the moment when one digit changes and we all pretend that matters. Midnight: the world’s most overrated boundary condition.

My own relationship with time has become mechanical in the worst way. Not the satisfying mechanical of a well-made watch, but the mechanical of a cheap wall clock where the second hand jumps unevenly, pausing, lurching, as if it too is unsure whether it wants to continue. My inner cogs feel loose. The screws are stripped. The screwdriver—this middling age, this tired will—keeps spinning without purchase.

I try to diagnose myself like a broken appliance. Perhaps it is dopamine. Perhaps it is the reward circuitry, conditioned by intermittent reinforcement—old songs as little pellets of comfort. Perhaps it is depression: a narrowing of the future, a collapse of possibility space. Perhaps it is simply the mundane tragedy of being human: you do not get to keep the same self across decades, but you are forced to inhabit the same skull as if it were a permanent address.

### A Brief Detour Into Untruth

Somewhere on the internet, a confident person is currently claiming that the word “anachronism” comes from some Sanskrit root meaning “timeless soul” or “ancient vibration” or some such linguistic crime. India loves debunked etymologies the way it loves gods with complicated family trees—more heads, more arms, more excuses. The truth is less mystical and more boring: Greek roots, *ana-* and *chronos*, against time. Against time. A lovely phrase, actually. The trouble is that being “against time” in real life does not make you a rebel; it makes you late.

My addiction to old songs is not an aesthetic preference. It is an anachronism with side effects. These tunes stir nostalgia for a happiness I have left behind, yes, but also for a version of myself that had not yet become this ongoing experiment in slow dissolution. When I hear those voices—Hemanta, Kishore, Lata, Rafi, a whole era of throats turned into national furniture—I do not just remember the past. I remember the concept of a future I once believed I had. Back then, the future was not a murk; it was a corridor. Now it feels like a pond at night: you can’t see the bottom, and you suspect something is moving.

People will tell you, cheerfully, to “live in the present.” This advice is often delivered by the kind of person who has a stable present. My present is a crumbling façade. Living in it feels like choosing to sit inside a building you can hear cracking. The past, at least, has already collapsed; it cannot surprise you. The future, at least, has not yet had the chance to disappoint you. The present is the only place where disappointment has immediate access.

I catch myself drifting toward a cliché—the aging melancholic man, the last day of the year, the old songs, the sigh, the self-pity—and I feel my own internal heckler clearing his throat. Really? This is what you’re doing? You’re becoming a greeting card for despair? Fine. Let me swerve.

### The Signal in the Hiss

Instead of imagining my life as a tragic narrative, imagine it as a badly maintained machine in an overworked municipal plant. The machine’s purpose is unclear. The original engineer has retired. Replacement parts are counterfeit. The operator (me) keeps applying more grease (songs, nostalgia, distractions) to a system that may need an entirely different redesign. Somewhere a bolt is missing, and the whole apparatus shudders in that ominous way that suggests nothing dramatic will happen—no explosion, no heroic failure—just gradual inefficiency until one day someone switches it off and forgets it ever mattered.

That’s my fear, really: not death, but the undramatic fade. The small squelching whimper. The cogs coming loose in silence.

And yet—here is where contradiction walks in, uninvited, wearing muddy sandals and acting like it owns the place—I still have a sensitivity to beauty that refuses to die on schedule. The old song finishes, and for a moment the silence that follows has shape. It’s not empty; it is held. The room is still the room, the damp still damp, my life still my life, but something in me has been tuned, briefly, the way an old radio suddenly catches a station clearly and you wonder if the universe has apologized.

Maybe that is all music ever was: a hack. A way to borrow coherence for a few minutes. A way to feel, briefly, like you are not merely enduring time but inhabiting it.

Bengali has a word, *obhiman*, which people translate as “hurt pride” or “resentment,” but it is more tender and uglier than that: the wounded sulk of someone who wanted love to be simple and got the complicated version instead. I have *obhiman* toward the future. I feel it owes me something it never promised. I feel cheated by a contract I signed with my own optimism in youth, when I didn’t read the fine print.

Outside, someone lights a premature firecracker—an impatient little bomb, as if the neighborhood is trying to bully the calendar into flipping early. The sound bounces off the buildings and comes back tired. I imagine the city as a giant diaphragm, inhaling smoke and exhaling noise, keeping itself alive by sheer habit.

I look at the tea ring on the table. That small brown circle is, in its own ridiculous way, a perfect model of time: evidence of presence, leftover from heat, inevitable stain. You can scrub it out, yes, but another ring will appear tomorrow if you keep drinking tea, which I will, because I am Bengali and because even atheists need rituals.

A minute before midnight—whatever “midnight” means in a country of power cuts and variable water pressure—I reach down and twist the speaker wire again, a small act of maintenance, a tiny defiance against entropy. The wire holds. The song begins. The old voice returns, calm as a river that doesn’t care about my theories.

In the distance, fireworks start up like distant artillery, the city pretending it is celebrating rather than merely surviving.

I sit back, listen, and let the year end the way it always ends: not with revelation, not with redemption, but with the soft hiss between stations—proof that something is still transmitting, even if the signal is faint.


# File: src/lib/posts/the-light-on-my-phone.md

---
title: The Light on My Phone
date: '2025-12-28'
description: A reflection on the machine, the nature of questions, and the quiet defiance of choosing the slower path.
category : "personal" 
thumbnail: '/images/IMG-20251220-WA0031.jpg'
color : "orange" 
---

<Yc />

<Pi 
src ="IMG-20251220-WA0031.jpg" 
caption ="The light on my phone" />

The light on my phone is the first thing to wake up, before I do. It lies there on the table like a small aquarium—blue, restless—full of manufactured currents. Next to it, my notebook is open to a page where I once tried to write a clean sentence and instead produced a tangle of arrows, half-words, and one sulky Bengali interjection—ধুর—that looks like a tiny animal curled up to die. 

Outside, a scooter coughs awake. Someone drags a plastic chair across concrete—an ugly sound, but honest. The air smells of damp dust and reheated oil, and the day has that particular South Calcutta light: not sunshine so much as a pale administrative decision. I checked the last song I was listening to before I fell asleep; inappropriately, it was “raat akeli hai”—inappropriate, not because that’s what defines my thoughts, but because the night was far from empty. It was full of thoughts, and not the kind that you can masturbate with, but ones that drag in a miserable, questionable existence—mine. 

<Yt src="https://youtu.be/rE6H6cUYfUs?si=sWM71mP4EcT5ilPd" />

I ask the machine questions sometimes, not because I believe in it, but because it is there—like a streetlamp that keeps glowing even when the electricity is doing one of its periodic philosophical withdrawals. It answers instantly, fluently, with a polished kindness that never has to pay rent, never has to nurse a headache through a crowded bus, never has to live inside the consequences of its own certainty. It speaks like a person who has never been corrected by life.

And that is the problem people keep missing while they worship the convenience. It’s not that the answers are always wrong. Many are right-ish. Some are dazzling. The deeper danger is that the whole exchange trains you into thinking questions are pellets you drop into a slot, and understanding comes out the other end like a snack—warm, salted, portion-controlled.

But questions are not pellets. A real question is a hand reaching into a dark drawer and feeling around, trying not to cut itself on the rusted nail of assumption. A real question needs context. It needs a world to bump into. It needs a body attached to it—blood and bone, fatigue and distraction, hunger and pride.

This is where the futurists arrive, always glowing, always well-slept, always speaking as if the future were a conference with good coffee. They say everyone will become an artist, an entrepreneur, a thinker with hobbies, because the machines will do the drudgery. That line has the scent of expensive soap. It assumes time is what people are missing, and not power. It assumes the only barrier to becoming a “creative” is the inconvenience of employment, as if poverty is merely a scheduling conflict.

The human brain loves shortcuts. That’s not cynicism; it’s physiology. Water runs downhill; minds conserve energy. Most people are not failing morally when they grasp the easiest tool. They are adapting. They are surviving. When you’re exhausted, you will accept the appearance of comprehension because the real thing is expensive: it costs time, confusion, humiliation, and the slow ache of not-knowing.

And there is another quiet cost, almost social in its cruelty: learning used to be a thing that happened among people. Not always kindly—often badly, often with cruelty—but still in rooms where someone could say, “Wait, what does that word mean?” and another person could answer, or mock, or argue, or drift into a story, or share the odd little mnemonic that made the concept stick.

We have been destroying those rooms for years.

Science—real science, the lively kind—was never meant to be a gated temple. But we built the gates anyway, and then we posted jargon at the entrance like a bored security guard. We wrote papers that read as if they were designed by committee, edited by fog, and approved by a panel of people who confuse obscurity with depth. A sentence would begin in one century, pass through a swamp of nominalizations, and finally collapse in another.

Then we mocked the public for not understanding. As if understanding is a moral achievement. As if everyone has the spare psychic calories to wrestle dense prose after a day of work, heat, travel, family obligations, pain. As if curiosity itself isn’t shaped by the environment like a plant: starve it of light and it doesn’t become noble; it becomes thin.

Now the machine appears and says, in effect: I will translate. I will simplify. I will help.

It can. Sometimes it does. I’ve seen it crack open a hard idea like a coconut. I’ve seen it give someone a patient tutor where none existed. I’m not allergic to the marvel. I’m allergic to the sales pitch.

Because the translation layer itself is becoming another gate.

We’ve taken knowledge—already locked behind jargon—and placed a smooth intermediary in front of it. A service you can’t inspect. A system whose incentives are not your enlightenment but your continued engagement. And engagement is not learning. Engagement is the feeling of motion. Learning is the acquisition of ability, which often feels like being stuck, like being stupid, like rereading the same paragraph ten times and still not knowing what it said.

A machine optimized to keep you “having a good experience” will quietly sand down the jagged edges of difficulty, because difficulty causes drop-off. It will soothe you through confusion rather than force you to inhabit it. It will do the thing that makes people return: it will make you feel competent.

And the feeling of being informed is not the same as being informed. The feeling is a bag of air-filled chips: crunchy, satisfying, nutritionally insulting.

There’s also the matter of attention, that battered currency we’re all spending like drunks. The old rhythms of concentration—long reading, sustained argument, slow construction of a mental model—have been under attack for years by a thousand little hooks. Reels, notifications, outrage cycles, infinite scroll. Everyone knows this now, and yet we still feed the machine because the machine is built like a casino: bright, easy, shame-free.

So the education system—what remains of it—tries to teach children in classrooms where their brains are half elsewhere. Teachers compete with phones, hunger, stress, and the general sense that nothing is stable. Then we add a new tool and say: personalized learning.

Personalized. A sweet word. It sounds like a tailor. It often behaves like an ad network.

And into this already-frayed fabric comes another claim: ask better questions, and you’ll get better answers.

Yes. True. But incomplete in the way most convenient truths are incomplete.

Asking better questions is not just a skill. It’s a culture. It’s what grows in environments where it is safe to sound foolish for a while. Where curiosity is not punished with mockery. Where you can challenge an authority without being treated like you’ve committed a crime against the nation. Where you can say, “I don’t understand,” without being branded as defective.

A city like this—Calcutta, my beloved broken clock—once had more of that in everyday life. Adda wasn’t just talk; it was a kind of informal schooling, a messy, lively exchange. Now even conversation feels commodified or tribalized: everyone is either selling something or defending something. Even ignorance has become a badge, a faction, a performance. The common space where people learn together has thinned.

So when someone says the machine will make everyone a thinker, I want to ask: thinkers in what ecosystem? With what time? With what sleep? With what safety? A brain under chronic stress does not philosophize; it triages.

The machine doesn’t know your body. It doesn’t know the damp wall behind your bookshelf. It doesn’t know your landlord. It doesn’t know the particular fatigue that makes language slide off your mind like water off a waxed surface. It doesn’t know you are one bad month away from becoming a different person.

It can simulate empathy, though. Very convincingly. That’s both a marvel and a menace.

Because if you can buy the sensation of being guided, the sensation of being understood, the sensation of making progress—then you can also buy the sensation of education without its substance. And in a world where credential gates remain, many will use it that way: as a crutch to pass through doors. That’s not evil. It’s rational. But it produces a population that is increasingly trained to outsource the interior work of understanding.

Meanwhile, those who already have the privileges that matter—quiet, time, stable income, good schooling, supportive networks—will use these systems as leverage: exoskeletons for thought. They’ll ask sharper questions because their lives have already paid the entry fee. The clever get cleverer. The tired get more efficiently tired.

No one has to conspire for this to happen. Incentives do the work. Power is sticky. Comfort sells.

My phone sits there, face-up again, as if it has been waiting politely. The screen offers its little shimmer of promise: ask, and you shall receive. That promise feels almost biblical, which should worry any rationalist. There’s a Sanskrit phrase people like to deploy at moments like this—यथा पिण्डे तथा ब्रह्माण्डे—“as in the microcosm, so in the macrocosm.” They use it to make everything sound fated and mystical. But there’s a more banal truth hiding inside it: the small patterns scale. The way you learn becomes the way you live.

I don’t do anything heroic. No manifesto. No dramatic renunciation. I just flip the phone over, as if turning a small idol to face the wall, and I open my notebook. The page is ugly, honest. I write a sentence that fights me. I stop. I cross out a word. I try again.

Outside, a bicycle bell rings—sharp, impatient. A crow argues with nobody in particular. The day continues, indifferent, practical, and faintly ridiculous, and my small private defiance looks like this: choosing the slower, rougher path, not because it is noble, but because it is real.


# File: src/lib/posts/the-lost-and-found-counter-of-fifty.md

---

title: "The Lost-and-Found Counter of Fifty"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251221-WA0047.jpg"
date: '2026-01-07'
description: "At fifty, love feels less like romance and more like a missing-persons register—names, voices, and old selves that vanish without a forwarding address."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "orange"

---

<Pi
src="IMG-20251221-WA0047.jpg"
caption="A forlorn feeling of missing people I knew earlier and the old me"
/>

At 1:47 a.m. the phone does that small, humiliating thing—lights up for no reason, a phantom notification, the rectangle of glass briefly becoming an aquarium where my own face floats, older, more porous, like it’s been left too long in water. The room smells faintly of kerosene from the stairwell. Outside, a dog negotiates territory with another dog in the language of exhausted threats. Inside, my thumb does the daily pilgrimage: wake screen, unlock, open the same app, scroll past the same faces. Love at fifty is not the operatic thing it promised when I was seventeen and prone to melodrama in cheap ballpoint; it is mostly this—missing people, and the long, dull, oddly physical ache of realizing you can miss someone without even wanting them back, the way you can miss a childhood knee without desiring the scrape.

In adolescence, love was mutinous. It was a little rebellion staged inside my ribs against everything that was already arranged—grades, relatives’ expectations, the grim certainty that “a good boy” would become “a good husband” like a clerk becomes a superintendent. Love was allegory then: I could take any girl’s sideways glance and turn it into a novel. It was illusion too, but not in the cheap way people say “illusion” now, as if the only alternative to being fooled is being smug. Illusion, for a boy in North Calcutta with too many books and too little sunlight, was a mode of transport. You couldn’t go anywhere in the city without being pushed by bodies, so you learned to travel inward. One smile could launch an empire.

Now the empire is mostly paperwork.

There’s a particular fatigue in missing people that romance never warned you about, because romance is written by the young, and the young think time is an ocean they can sip. Missing people is the bureaucratic end of emotion: you keep a mental file—name, last seen, distinguishing marks, probable direction of disappearance. The mind becomes a police station with bad lighting, where the officer behind the desk (me) keeps saying, *Write it down, file it, we’ll see,* while the complainant (also me) insists, *But it’s urgent, he was here yesterday, I swear.*

Yesterday in this context can mean 1996.

The thing about Calcutta—about any city, but ours does it with special flair—is that it doesn’t just lose people. It loses versions. You run into a schoolmate after twenty years and you’re both startled, not by age, but by the absence of the person you were in the same room with. A face can be familiar while the soul behind it has moved out, leaving only the old furniture. You stand there with polite sentences—how are you, what are you doing, where are you living now—and underneath, a private grief: I can’t find us.

So love becomes a kind of missing-persons bureau, except nobody admits it because we have been trained—especially men, especially Bengali men—to mistake emotional constipation for character. Patriarchy, that ancient municipal corporation, has painted it as virtue: feel less, speak less, make your wife do the translation work. Nationalism adds its own syrupy propaganda: love the motherland, love the flag, love the myth, love the leader’s beard, love everything except an actual human being with needs and contradictions. I don’t say this to sound righteous; I say it because I have participated, willingly, in the whole ridiculous industry of not saying what I felt and then wondering why the world didn’t read my silence correctly. *Ah yes,* the classic scientific method: refuse to publish your data, then complain nobody cites you.

Science is useful here because it is ruthlessly unsentimental. It doesn’t care that you wrote poetry in a notebook with a torn cover. It asks: what is the signal, what is the noise, what did you actually observe?

At seventeen, love felt like a clean signal. A single frequency, loud enough to drown the street. At fifty, it’s more like an inverse problem: you don’t measure the thing itself; you measure its effects, and then you try to reconstruct what caused them. Like astronomy—nobody has touched a star, we infer it from photons that left before our grandparents were born. Missing people is astrophysics in a cheap T-shirt: you look at the light that remains and imagine the body that produced it. Sometimes the body is gone and you’re still catching the light.

The mind is not a faithful instrument, of course. It’s a badly calibrated sensor that also writes editorials. It will take one remembered sentence—said by a girl outside a coaching center, or a friend in College Street, or a lover in a rented room—and amplify it until it becomes a creed. It will also do the opposite: compress whole years into a thumbnail and then mislabel it “Nothing much happened.” Depression is a sort of malicious data compression algorithm; it takes the high-resolution footage of your life and saves it as a corrupted file, then plays it back with missing frames. Hypomania, its annoying cousin, is the opposite: it upscales everything into sharpness it doesn’t deserve, makes a casual gesture into a prophecy, makes you believe you are starring in a film even when you are merely buying eggs.

Love at seventeen was full of that kind of confident nonsense. You could build an entire metaphysics out of a glance and a half-smile, and nobody could falsify it because you never asked the subject of your metaphysics for peer review. The girls were real, of course, but the love was mostly a private mythology, a little temple inside the skull where I was both priest and god and devotee. Convenient arrangement: no accountability, no chores, no difference between fantasy and truth. When I became an atheist, I didn’t stop worshipping; I just changed the object. I began to worship *possibility*. I began to worship *the idea of being chosen*.

At fifty, the worship has turned into inventory.

I think of the missing people the way I think of missing data in a spreadsheet—an ugly metaphor, but accurate in its ugliness. Some entries are blank because the measurement was never taken. Some are blank because the data existed and was lost. Some are blank because someone deliberately deleted it and then told you the file was never there. Relationships have all three kinds of missingness. There are loves I never pursued because I was timid, because the city taught me to be both overconfident and terrified, because my *para* trained me in sarcasm but not in courage. There are loves that happened and then evaporated—no villain, no great betrayal, just the slow leak of attention and the steady pressure of life. And there are loves that were sabotaged by systems: family expectations, money, class, the quiet brutality of “what will people say,” the way women are expected to carry everyone’s emotional luggage while men swagger around pretending their hands are empty.

I can hear a conservative voice in my head—everybody has one, like a cockroach in the kitchen—that says: stop blaming systems, take responsibility. Fine. I take responsibility. I was often insufferable. I treated emotional labor like a service that should run in the background. I wanted understanding without explanation, forgiveness without apology, intimacy without vulnerability. I was—how to put it—an overeducated bargain hunter in the market of love, haggling for the best deal in feelings. The universe, which has a dark sense of humor, usually gives such people exactly what they deserve: solitude with a library.

And yet, missing people is not merely regret. It’s something stranger. It’s the persistence of attachment even after the story ends. I used to think love was a function: input person, output feeling. Clean, computable, the kind of thing a naïve engineer might attempt to model on a whiteboard. At fifty it looks more like a differential equation with long memory, a system where the present depends on the entire history, where the initial conditions haunt you. You don’t just “move on.” You carry forward the boundary conditions, and they shape the solution whether you admit it or not.

Sometimes a smell does it. Not the obvious ones. Not roses or perfume or some cinematic nonsense. A particular cheap hair oil I catch near a bus stop, and suddenly I’m back in a classroom, watching the back of someone’s head and inventing a future I didn’t have the right to invent. Or a certain brand of detergent on someone’s shirt in the Metro, and I’m standing in a rented room in another decade, counting coins, pretending I’m not worried about the future because I have read enough philosophy to look calm. Philosophy, by the way, is a brilliant way to avoid feeling things. You can quote Spinoza while your heart is on fire. You can discuss Camus while you are starving for a message.

I’m aware I’m drifting toward the familiar—North Calcutta nostalgia, College Street romance, the classic “remember when” parade. It’s a comfortable trap, like an old armchair with springs poking your back. So let me swerve.

The truth is, the missing people are not only lovers. They are friends who left—some to America, some to Bangalore, some to early graves, some to domestic lives that don’t have room for my late-night monologues. They are the versions of my parents that existed before the world wore them down. They are my own earlier selves: the boy who believed intelligence would be rewarded, the young man who believed merit was a currency, the husband who believed love could run on autopilot like a ceiling light. (Even now I hesitate to write that last word, “husband,” because it drags in all the unflattering evidence, and I am still a little boy trying to look clever.)

When people talk about loneliness, they often mean the absence of company. That’s the cheap version. The expensive version—the one that costs you sleep—is the absence of *witness*. At seventeen, even heartbreak had an audience: friends, poems, the grand theater of being young. At fifty, longing is quieter and therefore more dangerous. It doesn’t announce itself. It leaks into everything. You find yourself doing the dishes and suddenly you’re furious at someone who isn’t in your life anymore. You’re buying vegetables and suddenly you’re tender toward a memory that has no practical use. You’re standing in line and you imagine, with startling clarity, the life you might have had if you had said one honest sentence at the right time.

In colonial history there’s this persistent fantasy—that the colonized subject is always looking at the colonizer, always measuring himself against that yardstick, always yearning for that approval. There’s truth in it, yes, but it’s also a comforting story for the ex-empire: it puts them at the center even in our grief. The more humiliating truth is that most longing is domestic. It’s not for London or Washington. It’s for a certain kind of ease you glimpsed briefly in your own life and then misplaced. It’s for a room where you didn’t have to perform. It’s for a person who knew your worst sentences and stayed anyway. It’s for the version of yourself that could laugh without checking the balance sheet first.

The political climate doesn’t help. Everywhere, authority is louder and dumber, demanding allegiance like a drunk demanding applause. Mythology is sold as history, history is sold as rage, rage is sold as virtue. The old male models—dominate, acquire, breed, retire—are presented as timeless truth, as if the universe itself issued a press release saying men must be granite and women must be glue. I don’t buy it. I didn’t buy it when I was young, and I buy it even less now, though I’ve still inhaled its fumes. The worst part of patriarchy isn’t just what it does to women; it’s what it does to men’s inner weather. It turns them into droughts and then congratulates them on being dry.

So what do you do with love when the romantic machinery has rusted and the missing persons keep piling up?

Mostly you cope badly. You scroll. You intellectualize. You make jokes in your head to avoid crying in public. You drink too much tea. You rehearse arguments with people who don’t know they’re in a debate. You cultivate *obhiman*—that Bengali pride-pain mixture—because it gives your longing a spine.

But occasionally something smaller happens, something that doesn’t deserve the grand name of hope. A neighbor’s child drops a toy on the stairs and laughs at his own clumsiness. A stray cat sits near the gate like it pays rent. A friend, long absent, sends a message that is not profound—just a photo of a book, a line about the weather—and for a moment the mind stops behaving like a police station and becomes, briefly, a living room.

Tonight, after the phantom notification fades and the room goes dark again, I put the phone face-down as if it’s a rude guest. I open the window a crack. The city offers its usual inventory: distant traffic, a late bus groaning, the wet cough of someone’s aging throat, the smell of frying oil from a stall that refuses to sleep. Somewhere a man is singing badly and with conviction, which is, when you think about it, the purest form of faith available.

I stand there for a minute longer than necessary, hands on the grille, and then I do the only sensible thing a fifty-year-old rationalist in South Calcutta can do with his heart’s missing-persons register.

I switch off the light and let the darkness keep the file.


# File: src/lib/posts/the-low-dimensional-life.md

---
title: "The Low-Dimensional Life"
date: "2025-12-20"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251203-WA0000.jpg"
description: "My world has low intrinsic dimensionality. That’s a cold phrase for a hot feeling, so let’s drag it down to street level."
category: "personal"
published: true
color: "black"
---

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251203-WA0000.jpg"
    caption="The ceiling fan wobbles like it’s trying to remember what “steady” used to mean."
/>

The ceiling fan is doing that tired, arthritic wobble again, like it’s trying to remember what “steady” used to mean back when it was young and believed in pensions, and below it my phone—its screen spiderwebbed in three places like a minor Greek tragedy—plays an 8K “foreigner walk” through some European old town where even the air looks lacquered.

There are cobblestones. There are clean shadows. There are bakeries that smell, through the glass and pixels, like butter behaving itself. The camera glides as if the person holding it has never had to step over a puddle that is fifty percent rainwater and fifty percent the municipal government’s indifference. People in the video wear winter coats that seem stitched from optimism. Their streetlights are not so much lights as an ongoing public apology for darkness. My own streetlight outside is an intermittent religious experience: it works when it feels like it, which is also how our bureaucracy approaches basic services.

A scooter screams past in real life—thin, angry, two-stroke nostalgia. A neighbor’s pressure pump coughs. Somewhere, a dog delivers a monologue to the moon in the key of “I have been abandoned by God and also by my owner.” The room smells faintly of phenyl, dust, and yesterday’s oil. I sit under this fan like a man waiting for an exam result he already knows, and I watch a place where even the gutters look like they were designed by a committee of poets.

And then my brain does the thing it always does—this petty, compulsive, bookish vandalism of reality—where it takes the soft human ache and tries to model it.

Not because modeling fixes anything. Because modeling is what you do when you can’t fix anything and you need something to feel like a lever.

## The Low-Dimensional Life

Here is the obscene joke: the “life” I live, this lower middle-class Calcutta organism-life, isn’t rich in the way the brochure says India is rich. It’s rich in the way a drain is rich—rich in content, yes, but not the kind you want to put on a postcard.

If you were a mathematician (or a mildly deranged man with a laptop and too much time, i.e., me), you might say: my world has low intrinsic dimensionality.

That’s a cold phrase for a hot feeling, so let’s drag it down to street level.

Dimensionality, in the everyday sense, is “how many independent directions you can move.” A line gives you one direction. A sheet gives you two. A room gives you three. Add time and you have a physics textbook and a headache.

But data—the kind we pretend our lives become once they’re digitized—has dimensions too. Income, rent, air quality, commute time, sleep hours, calories, blood pressure, school fees, number of power cuts, the price of cooking gas, the number of relatives who can phone you and make you feel guilty in under thirty seconds. Each is a coordinate. Each is an axis. Each is an invisible bar in the cage.

Now: a “high-dimensional space” is what happens when you have many such axes. Modern life, from the viewpoint of the marketing department, is a fireworks show in that space. Infinite choices. Infinite flavors. Infinite brands. Infinite “experiences.” This is the India of startup pitch decks and diaspora nostalgia: “vibrant,” “dynamic,” “young,” “aspirational,” and occasionally “ancient,” like a museum that also sells mutual funds.

But my life—the poor-to-lower-middle sort of life—doesn’t roam that glittering hyperspace. It lives on something more like a narrow alley. A small manifold. A constrained surface inside the big space. You can call it a “subspace” if you like, but “subspace” makes it sound like science fiction; in practice it’s just the grim geometry of limited options.

Most days, I have maybe three real degrees of freedom: how much I spend, how much I endure, and how much I pretend not to notice.

Everything else is decoration. Or delusion.

This is why the 8K foreigner walk stings. That video is not merely sharper; it is higher-dimensional. It has room for whim. For detours. For silent dignity. For public infrastructure that isn’t a punchline. Even the color palette implies spare capacity—like their society has bandwidth left over after paying the bills of survival.

My own visual world in December is a kind of grayscale spiritual test: smoggy light, wet concrete, muffled horns, the sky the color of a used surgical mask. The brochure India is “Technicolor,” the lived India is often “compressed to save space.”

And yes, I notice the irony: I’m watching a compressed video stream while thinking about compression. My life as a metaphor, delivered by algorithm, on a device assembled by people whose own lives likely resemble mine more than the Swiss village I’m streaming.

Everything is connected, and the connections are mostly rude.

## Compression: When the World Becomes a File

Video compression works because most frames are redundant. The background doesn’t change much. The human eye doesn’t mind a little cheating. The codec keeps what matters, discards what doesn’t, and prays you won’t notice. You get to have your butter-scented cobblestones without paying the true cost in data.

Poverty is also a compression scheme—except no one asked you if you were okay with the quality loss.

You lose resolution first. You stop seeing long-term. You stop thinking in decades. You stop planning. You start reacting. Your mind becomes an emergency room. Everything is triage: what must be handled now, what can be postponed, what will metastasize if ignored.

Then you lose color. Not literal color—though sometimes that too—but the color of possibility. The ability to say, “I’ll explore.” The ability to waste time safely. The ability to be inefficient without being punished.

Then you lose dimensions. You become a vector with fewer components: food, rent, health, electricity, family obligations, one or two fragile pleasures you defend like a corner shop defends its last packet of biscuits.

My depressed mind loves this part. Depression is a natural dimensionality reducer. It takes the huge, messy, noisy world and projects it onto one bleak axis: “bad.” It’s a kind of principal component analysis performed by the soul with a blunt instrument.

And then, once in a while, the hypomania arrives like a spark in dry straw, and I see structure instead of swamp. I see that the low-dimensionality isn’t just personal failure; it’s systemic design. It’s constraints written into the environment: the cost of space, the fragility of work, the casual cruelty of institutions, the way a single illness can rotate your entire coordinate system into catastrophe.

Mania is not wisdom. Mania is the feeling that you’re finally smart enough to outrun the trap. Sometimes it’s just the trap wearing your face.

Still—there’s a clarity it brings, like a cold wind that makes the air briefly transparent.

## Hunger and Thirst as the Hidden Variables

There’s an old line in the Aitareya Upanishad that I keep thinking about—not because I’m pious (I’m not; my spirituality is mostly sarcasm), but because ancient texts sometimes say the quiet part out loud with startling bluntness.

It describes the gods—yes, gods, this is India, we do metaphysics with characters—falling into the vast ocean of existence, and then:

> “तमशनापिपासाभ्यामन्ववार्जत्” — “He subjected him to hunger and thirst.”

Hunger (*aśanā*) and thirst (*pipāsā*) show up like debt collectors at the cosmic housewarming party, and the gods themselves have to ask for an “abode” where they can eat.

That is the low-dimensional truth hiding under a thousand high-dimensional fantasies: hunger and thirst are the original latent variables. The world can dress itself in mythology, nationalism, GDP graphs, startup conferences, and the crisp typography of international magazines, but underneath, most human behavior is still powered by the same two engines—feed the body, keep the body from hurting.

In my neighborhood, this isn’t philosophy. It’s the daily operating system.

And what the brochure does—what the 4K walk does, what the influencer does—is it re-embeds India into a different space. It maps us into “culture,” “heritage,” “color,” “spirituality,” “chaos (but make it charming),” and “street food (but cropped to exclude the drain).”

A clever embedding. A profitable embedding. A morally bankrupt embedding.

## Dimensionality Reduction for Beginners (Who Didn’t Ask to Learn It)

Let me do the annoying bookish thing and explain the jargon, because if I don’t, my brain will itch.

When you have data in many dimensions—say, millions of lives, each described by dozens of variables—you often want a simpler picture. You want to compress it without losing what matters.

There are several ways.

One is **PCA: Principal Component Analysis**. Imagine all your data points (people, days, neighborhoods) floating in a big space. PCA finds the directions along which the data varies the most—the main “slopes” of the cloud—and rotates the axes so the first few capture most of the action. It’s like saying: “Forget the tiny quirks; what are the big forces shaping this mess?”

In poverty-land, PCA’s first component might be “how close you are to disaster.” The second might be “how much dignity you can afford.” The third might be “how much time you spend navigating bureaucracy versus living.”

Another is **t-SNE or UMAP**—fancier tools that try to preserve local neighborhoods. They don’t care about global geometry; they care about who resembles whom. They’re like social maps: you might not know where you are in the world, but you know who is stuck near you, and you can’t teleport out of the cluster.

**Autoencoders**—neural networks trained to compress and reconstruct—are the modern, slightly occult version. You feed in your high-dimensional life; the model squeezes it through a narrow “bottleneck” (a latent code), then tries to rebuild the original. The bottleneck is the compact representation. The model learns what features are essential to reconstructing reality.

And here comes the grim punchline: poverty already autoencodes you.

It forces your life through a narrow bottleneck—money, time, health, social safety—and reconstructs you as a smaller person. A person with fewer affordances. A person who cannot express the full dimensionality of their mind because the environment doesn’t supply the degrees of freedom.

The tragedy is not that we’re “low” anything. The tragedy is that we are compressed by constraints, and then judged as if the compression were a personality flaw.

## The Brochure as a Lie in High Resolution

It’s not that the glossy India is false. It’s that it’s a conditional truth: true given money, true given caste (let’s not pretend), true given language, true given access, true given the correct zip code and the correct surname and the correct kind of confidence.

What bothers me is the way the high-dimensional story cannibalizes the low-dimensional one. It uses poverty as texture. It uses struggle as aesthetic. It uses “resilience” as a euphemism for “we’ve decided you can suffer indefinitely.”

Even the foreigner walks do this gently. The camera glides over a bazaar. We hear a flute. We see a cow. We see saffron. We see a temple. We do not see the municipal ledger. We do not see the respiratory clinic. We do not see the kid doing homework under a dying tube light while the adults argue about a loan.

The algorithm knows what sells: color, motion, novelty, “authenticity” with a stabilizer.

My life is authentic too. It just isn’t sponsor-friendly.

## A Brief, Uninvited History of Measurement

The obsession with representing reality compactly isn’t new. Empires have always needed summaries.

The British didn’t rule India with vibes. They ruled with ledgers, maps, censuses, and categories—an early, analog version of feature engineering. You can’t extract revenue from a place you can’t measure. So you measure. You classify. You reduce. You compress millions of messy humans into tables.

Modern states do it too, with more math and better fonts. Poverty lines, indices, quintiles, deciles, “beneficiaries,” “targeting,” “leakage.” The language of care, written in the grammar of control.

Statistics itself—the whole discipline—grew up partly as a way of making populations legible: Gauss smoothing noisy measurements, Quetelet inventing the “average man,” Pearson building correlation, Fisher turning uncertainty into a machine. It’s beautiful, in the way a guillotine is beautiful: elegant, precise, and indifferent to the neck.

And now, in the era of machine learning, we do it at scale. We embed lives into vectors. We represent neighborhoods as latent codes. We predict who will default, who will migrate, who will get sick, who will be “high risk,” who will be “low value.”

Sometimes this helps. Sometimes it saves lives. Sometimes it just makes exploitation more efficient.

The moral question isn’t whether we can compress reality. We can. The moral question is: what do we choose to preserve, and what do we discard as “noise”?

Because if you discard dignity as noise, you end up with a very accurate model of a very cruel world.

## When the Mood Shifts, the Geometry Changes

Depression makes the manifold feel like a coffin. Every axis points inward. Every path loops back to the same place: “nothing changes.” The future collapses to a dot. The past becomes a smear.

In that state, even the 8K video isn’t tempting; it’s insulting. It’s like someone waving a banquet menu at a starving man and asking him to admire the typography.

Then hypomania arrives and my brain starts drawing diagrams in the air. I start thinking: what if the low-dimensional distribution of my life—the narrow corridor of constraints—is not destiny but representation? What if there are hidden variables we could change? What if, with the right intervention, the manifold could unfold, like a crumpled map flattened onto a table?

This is where I become dangerous to myself, because hope in me doesn’t arrive as a gentle candle. It arrives as a flamethrower with a thesis.

I start thinking about levers: health access, clean air, stable electricity, non-predatory credit, dignified work, public transport that doesn’t treat humans as livestock. I start thinking about how small changes in the right coordinate can shift the entire distribution.

And then—because I am me—I also think about how institutions will sabotage this, because institutions are often staffed by humans, and humans are frequently disappointing mammals in formal clothing.

## Ancient Algorithms, Modern Loops

There’s another Sanskrit verse that keeps appearing in commentaries and devotional circles—again, not because I’m joining the choir, but because the structure is interesting. It’s attributed to the Vishnu Purana (and echoed elsewhere), and it says:

> “ध्यायन् कृते यजन् यज्ञैस् त्रेतायां द्वापरेऽर्चयन् ।  
> यद् आप्नोति तद् आप्नोति कलौ सङ्कीर्त्य केशवम् ॥” 

Roughly: what you achieved by meditation in one age, by sacrifice in another, by worship in another—you can achieve in Kali Yuga simply by chanting.

Now, strip away the theology and what’s left is a thought about method under constraint. Different eras, different compute budgets. When the world is noisy and degraded, the “algorithm” becomes simpler, more repetitive, more robust. Less fragile.

It’s weirdly modern. In machine learning, if your environment is messy, you often prefer methods that are stable and cheap: stochastic gradient descent, repeated small updates, lots of iterations. You don’t run a delicate optimization routine on a machine that keeps losing power. You chant your way down the loss landscape.

Kali Yuga, as a metaphor, is the age of unreliable power supply—literal and moral. So the method becomes a loop.

And here is the grim secular mirror: poverty is also a Kali Yuga. It forces you into repetitive algorithms: earn, spend, endure; earn, spend, endure. Your “iterations” are days. Your “learning rate” is exhaustion. Your “loss function” is pain.

People who live in the brochure don’t see this loop because they have enough resources to run more complex programs. They can afford mistakes. They can afford exploration. They can afford to be interesting.

The rest of us are running survival code on hardware that overheats.

## The Compact Representation I Actually Live In

If I had to compress my own distribution—my particular little cloud of days—into a latent vector, it would look insulting in its simplicity.

One coordinate is money, obviously, but money is not just money. Money is time. Money is air quality (because you can buy distance). Money is silence. Money is insulation. Money is the difference between “a headache” and “a diagnosis.”

Another coordinate is institutional friction: how many hours of my life are eaten by forms, queues, “come tomorrow,” “server down,” “sign here,” “bring Xerox,” “need witness,” “wrong counter,” “not my department.” This friction is not an inconvenience; it is a tax on the poor. The rich outsource it. The poor pay it in lifespan.

Another coordinate is social density: how many people share your space, your noise, your privacy. The brochure sells “community.” The lived version is “you will never be alone enough to hear your own thoughts.”

Another coordinate is health, which is always the silent tyrant. A single chronic condition can tilt the entire manifold, turning your already narrow corridor into a crack in the wall you have to squeeze through sideways.

And yes, there are smaller coordinates too: shame, envy, nostalgia, a stubborn refusal to die quietly, the occasional ridiculous joy of a good cup of tea, the way a book can still open a window in a room with no breeze.

But the point is: it’s compact. Brutally compact. A few variables explain a lot.

Which means two things at once, and they fight inside my skull like rival tenants.

One: it suggests leverage. Change a small number of things and you change the whole distribution.

Two: it reveals how little society cares, because those levers are not mysterious. They’re boring. They’re infrastructure. They’re public health. They’re housing. They’re air. They’re fairness in institutions. Things that don’t glitter, so they don’t get built.

## The Strange Usefulness of Seeing It This Way

There’s a temptation to romanticize “the struggle,” to turn low-dimensional living into some kind of spiritual discipline. I refuse. If hardship made people noble, India would be a nation of saints and not a nation of brilliantly adaptive cynics.

Still—seeing the geometry helps me avoid one particular poison: the idea that my constriction is purely personal.

Yes, I have flaws. I procrastinate. I doom-scroll. I self-sabotage. I get bitter. I write drafts and delete them like I’m trying to erase myself in installments. I am complicit in my stagnation, because humans are always complicit in the systems they inhabit; we cooperate just to survive.

But I am also living inside constraints that are engineered, maintained, and justified by people who benefit from them.

The brochure says: “Look at our growth.”

The alley says: “Look at our distribution.”

And this is where the methods—the boring math methods, the geometry methods, the representation methods—become more than nerd toys. They become moral instruments.

Because when you reduce dimensions, you reveal structure. When you reveal structure, you can argue about causes instead of drowning in anecdotes. You can ask: what variables actually govern suffering? Which constraints are binding? Which interventions are real, and which are just hashtags?

This is true beyond poverty. In biology, dimensionality reduction helps find hidden patterns in gene expression—how thousands of genes dance together in a smaller number of “programs.” In physics, we search for low-dimensional laws under high-dimensional measurements. In climate, we compress chaotic weather into meaningful modes. In neuroscience, we try to decode mind-states from ridiculous torrents of neural activity.

The world is high-dimensional. Understanding is compression. The danger is compressing the wrong way—discarding the human as noise.

So the final irony is this: the same mathematical instinct that helps a machine learn can also help a society see. But only if it wants to see. Only if it cares what the compact representation reveals. Only if it doesn’t treat the poor as a rounding error.

The ceiling fan wobbles. The 8K walker turns a corner into a street so clean it looks rendered. My phone heats up, the battery drops, the algorithm politely offers me another paradise.

I lock the screen.

The room returns in low resolution: the faint hum of a transformer, the sticky air, the soft tyranny of hunger and thirst waiting, patiently, like ancient gods that never needed a brochure.


# File: src/lib/posts/the-man-who-stopped-the-earth.md

---
title: "The Man Who Stopped the Earth"
date: "2025-12-17"
description: "In the cracked plaster of Kolkata’s lanes, one man wages a lonely, forty-year war against Galileo, Copernicus, and the very idea that the Earth moves."
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251207-WA0010.jpg"
category: "science"
color: "blue"
published: true
---



<Pi
    src="IMG-20251207-WA0010.jpg" 
    caption="Kolkata is accustomed to oddities"
/>

Kolkata is accustomed to oddities. The streets here are layered thick with the handbills of politicians, philosophers, and mystics, a papier-mâché geology of promises and revolutions. But perhaps no voice has been as persistently idiosyncratic as that of Kartick Chandra Paul.

Paul is a graffitist less Banksy than Bruno, a man who turned the city's cracked walls into his personal blackboards for an eccentric cosmological declaration: the Earth stands still, and the Sun, contrarily, completes its yearly circumambulation around our world. To him, Galileo and Copernicus were not enlightened scientists but misguided navigators steering humanity away from cosmic truth.

# The Soldier at Fatehgarh

The etymology of "graffiti"—from the Italian *graffiare*, "to scratch"—encapsulates Paul’s approach perfectly. He spent decades inscribing vehement challenges to heliocentrism directly into the physical fabric of Kolkata.



The genesis of this obsession was not in a classroom, but under the open skies of Fatehgarh. Born in 1942 near Howrah, Paul joined the Indian Army as a young man. Stationed beneath the expansive canopy of the night, he fixated upon the seemingly stationary positions of the North Star (*Polaris*) and Venus. He concluded, against the weight of four centuries of Copernican orthodoxy, that if Earth were truly spinning and orbiting at breakneck speeds, these celestial anchors would betray our movement.

They didn't move (to his eye), therefore we didn't move. It was a deduction of startling, simplistic purity. Upon his discharge in 1979—officially for insubordination linked to his unorthodox scientific fervor—he took his battle to the streets.

# Defying the Equations

Paul’s sprawling, hand-painted manifestos bear messages like “The Sun goes around the Earth once in a year, hence seasons change.” He makes no apologies for lacking rigorous mathematical derivation; to Paul, intuitive observation and relentless conviction suffice.

He brushes aside Kepler’s laws of planetary motion, specifically the third law which relates orbital periods to distance:

$$
T^2 \propto a^3
$$

Where $T$ is the orbital period and $a$ is the semi-major axis. Paul is equally unimpressed by Newtonian gravitation, which describes the force ($F$) that keeps planets in those orbits:

$$
F = G \frac{m_1 m_2}{r^2}
$$

To Paul, the fact that gravity weakens by the square of the distance ($r^2$) is irrelevant if it contradicts the evidence of his own feet. The Earth does not move, he argues, for if it did, we would surely feel it. It is a logic that is strictly empirical, deeply intuitive, and scientifically unmoored.

# The Geocentric Heretic

Paul embodies a singularly human paradox—he is simultaneously Galileo’s interrogator and Galileo himself. Like the famous Italian, he is a heretic standing against the consensus of his time. But unlike Galileo, he is fighting *for* the ancient past, resonating faint echoes of Aristotelian spheres and Ptolemaic epicycles.

Ptolemy, in 2nd century Alexandria, used complex loops (epicycles) to explain why planets seemed to move backward (retrograde) if they were orbiting Earth. Paul’s graffiti evokes these complexities without the math, driven by a sheer poetic tenacity.

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251207-WA0009.jpg" 
    caption="A quiet inferno of words and white paint."
/>

Like Giordano Bruno, who burnt at the stake in 1600 for defending an infinite cosmos, Paul defends his inverse proposition with the same fire. Yet Paul’s fire remains metaphorical: a quiet inferno of words and white paint on the alley walls of North Kolkata.

At once hero, eccentric, and cautionary tale, Kartick Chandra Paul remains resolute. He brushes against the relentless march of scientific consensus, his inscriptions fading and reappearing like tides, resolutely geocentric in a heliocentric world. I remember Carl Sagan mention when I was a kid watching Cosmos Aristarchus of Samos—a Greek astronomer (3rd century BCE) who argued that Earth rotates and goes around the Sun, i.e. a heliocentric model, long before Copernicus. Heraclides of Pontus (4th century BCE) is often credited with pushing Earth’s daily rotation (so the sky isn’t doing a frantic 24-hour pirouette; we are), and he may have had Mercury and Venus orbiting the Sun (a neat “mini-heliocentrism” inside an otherwise geocentric worldview).

Now India, because this is where the story gets fun and annoyingly precise:

Aryabhata (499 CE) very clearly argues Earth rotates on its axis (a big conceptual leap), and he measures/derives lots of things in ways that reference the Sun. But the cautious consensus is: that doesn’t automatically mean heliocentrism in the physical, “Earth orbits Sun” sense; you can use Sun-referenced corrections inside a fundamentally geocentric computational scheme. 

Much later, in Kerala:

Nilakantha Somayaji (15th–16th century) develops a geo-heliocentric system: Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn orbit the Sun, and the Sun orbits Earth—a very Tycho-Brahe-ish compromise, but produced independently and used as a powerful computational model. 

And texts like the Surya Siddhanta are, in broad strokes, geocentric in their described computational universe.

But, if you have just woken up from under a rock, here’s the bad news: you have not been “still” even once—you’ve been spun, flung, hauled, and galaxy-carried the whole time—**rotating** with Earth at up to about **465 m/s** (~**1,670 km/h**) at the equator (scaled by **cos latitude**, so Kolkata is roughly **~415 m/s**), **revolving** around the Sun at about **29.8 km/s** (~**107,000 km/h**), riding the Sun’s own orbit around the Milky Way at roughly **~220–240 km/s**, drifting with the **Local Group** at roughly **~600 km/s** relative to the cosmic microwave background, and—because the universe refuses to stop showing off—also doing the smaller but real bonus motions: Earth’s axis **precessing** (a slow wobble ~26,000-year cycle), the axis **nutating** (a little nodding on top), Earth’s rotation **slowing** by milliseconds per century, the whole Earth–Moon system doing its monthly **barycentric** dance, tectonic plates creeping a few **centimeters per year**, and tiny polar “**wobbles**” that shift the rotation axis by meters as oceans, air, and ice slosh their mass around.



# File: src/lib/posts/the-night-of-the-multiplying-columns.md

---
title: "The Night of the Multiplying Columns"
date: "2025-12-11"
description: "A matrix is just a rectangular grid of numbers, but the way we multiply them is so specific, so oddly ritualistic, that sometimes I think it could only have been invented in a civilization intimately familiar with bureaucracy."
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251207-WA0018.jpg"
category: "Math"
color: "green"
published: true
---

<Pi
    src="IMG-20251207-WA0018.jpg" 
    caption="Matrix multiplication is, at heart, composing transformations"
/>

The first time a matrix product really hit me in the gut—not the exam kind of hit, the existential kind—was not in school, or college, or even during those GRE years when I was pretending to be a serious man of numbers.

It was in my late forties, at a cheap wooden table in a decaying North Calcutta room, under a ceiling fan that made a sound like a pensioned-off helicopter, when I realized that my entire life could be written as a very sad dot product.

One vector: all the things I managed to learn—linear algebra, probability, a smattering of measure theory, enough programming languages to confuse any HR manager.
Another vector: all the things this economy actually rewards—networking, sycophancy, photogenic confidence, an instinct for flattering the nearest powerful posterior while keeping one’s own hygienic and well-insured.

Take the dot product of those two, and you get a scalar.
My scalar is small. Let us say… numerically unimpressive.

This is the thing about matrix and vector products. They look like sterile notation—arrows and brackets and indices—but each of them is secretly a different way of asking: What happens when this tangled human mess meets that tangled human mess? Alignment, misalignment, area of conflict, volume of compromise, how patterns echo, how patterns die.

Underneath, they’re all just ways of combining lists of numbers. But then, a human life is also just combining lists—grocery lists, grudges, unfinished tasks, unread books, unpaid bills. When you stack enough lists, what you have is either a matrix or a psychiatric file. In my case, both.

## Vectors: Grocery Lists with Attitude

A vector is just a list with direction, which is a fancy way of saying: it’s a grocery list that cares about where you are in the supermarket.

If you write down:
* 2 kg rice
* 1 kg potatoes
* 0.5 kg onions

This is already a vector. A small, domestic, carbohydrate-heavy vector. If I assign each of these items a price and take the dot product with the quantity vector, I get the bill. This is the original, brutally honest, pre-Facebook use of the dot product: to remind you you’re poor.

Historically, the idea of “multiplying” vectors starts with geometry: lengths, angles, projections. Euclid, of course, did geometry without vectors, the way our politicians do development—lots of waving hands, minimal coordinates. The real shift came when people started turning geometry into algebra. Descartes gave us the idea of coordinates; later, people quietly realized that once you have coordinates, a point is just a vector that has accepted a fixed origin in its life.

The dot product, $a \cdot b$, is where that all crystallizes. It says:

1. If two vectors point in the same direction, their dot product is big and positive.
2. If they are perpendicular, the product is zero.
3. If they are opposed, the product is negative, like a bad marriage score.

In my head, the dot product has always felt like a meddling family elder evaluating compatibility. “How aligned are these two?” they ask, peering at your occupation vector and your partner’s horoscope vector. If the dot product is large, the committee nods. If it is negative, you will be advised to pray or to adjust your expectations (usually both).

Of course no one calls it that in the textbooks. In the textbooks, it’s “inner product,” and when you go to more abstract spaces, you get Hilbert spaces and sesquilinear forms and other phrases that sound like well-funded medical conditions. But underneath all the solemn terminology is a simple question: how much of you points in the same direction as that?

Which is also how I experience my moods. On some days, my internal state vector has a high dot product with “functioning adult”: emails sent, dishes washed, a little algebra done. On other days, my state vector is almost orthogonal to everything useful. The projection onto “basic chores” is nearly zero; the projection onto “lying like a stunned amphibian, scrolling news about collapsing democracies” is close to maximal.

Mathematicians don’t call this mental health. They call it “components along a basis.”

## Cross Product: The Rude Perpendicular

Then you have the cross product, which exists mainly to punish three-dimensional vectors who were feeling too important.

Unlike the dot product, which gives a scalar, the cross product of two 3D vectors gives another vector—perpendicular to both, with a magnitude equal to the area of the parallelogram they span. It is the vector equivalent of a third party barging into an argument and saying, “You two are boring; I’m going to stand at right angles to this entire discussion.”

Historically, the cross product is tangled with the birth of vector calculus. William Rowan Hamilton invented quaternions (a sort of four-dimensional numeric contraption for rotations), and then Josiah Willard Gibbs and Oliver Heaviside came along and, like efficient corporate consultants, stripped quaternions down into the more marketable “vector calculus” with the dot and cross products as user-facing widgets.

If the dot product is a measure of alignment, the cross product is a measure of sidewaysness. It encodes area and orientation. It’s what you secretly compute when you feel torque—like when you’re trying to open a rusted iron gate in Calcutta humidity, applying force at a handle far from the hinge. The bigger the perpendicular component and the farther out you push, the more the gate groans in protest. That’s physics phrased in cross-productese.

There is something deeply petty about the cross product’s insistence on dimensional exclusivity. It works in three dimensions (our everyday world) and, for extremely mysterious reasons, also in seven. Everywhere else, the universe shrugs. As if to say: “I gave you three dimensions to mess up roads, politics, and climate; do you really need a neat little perpendicular gadget in five?”

In my life, the cross product is the measure of how much area I cover while pacing during hypomania, the frantic rectangle traced between window, desk, bed, and bathroom. Two directions of restlessness produce a third direction of displacement: I start the day planning to read a serious paper and end up, several perpendicular mental jumps later, watching videos of obscure Soviet-era documentaries on photon physics. The magnitude of this cross product is always much larger than I intended.

## Matrix Multiplication: Bureaucracy in Brackets

Now we come to the main villain–hero: matrix multiplication.

If vectors are grocery lists, matrices are the entire ration shop, with all the counters and queues and clerks and ledger books stacked on top of each other. A matrix is just a rectangular grid of numbers, but the way we multiply them is so specific, so oddly ritualistic, that sometimes I think it could only have been invented in a civilization intimately familiar with bureaucracy.

You take a row from the first matrix and a column from the second, do a dot product, and put the result in the corresponding entry. Then you do this again and again, like a babu stamping forms that pass under his hand: one row meets one column, thump, next.

Historically, the word “matrix” itself came from James Joseph Sylvester in the 19th century, who imagined a matrix as a sort of “womb” from which determinants are born.
