# Delhi AQI

I am watching Gul Saxena singing "Raat ke Humsafar" on YouTube not because she’s Lata Mangeshkar (though she sings well), but because she’s an eerily close look-alike of my ex-wife—who, the last time I can hold her face still in memory, looked like a young Runa Laila.

<Yt src="https://youtu.be/ugeXVmC6H4Y?si=DdXcieiVsE5WFCTX" />

That memory is pinned to Delhi, to our honeymoon in 2001: a city that felt like a step up from Calcutta—cleaner angles, wider roads, a slightly more confident electricity—though still nowhere near the league of American cities like Austin, where I was living then and where even the blandness had an odd competence to it.

Now I’m a divorced, fifty-year-old, crusty scrote, an asshole really, and I can’t tell whether it’s the AQI inside my head or the one outside that’s the real problem. The first thing I notice—before thought, before politics, before the day has put on its trousers and started lying to itself—is the taste.

It arrives the way bad news does in India: politely, persistently, and already inside your mouth.

I’m on my little South Calcutta fringe, the unfashionable outskirts where the city ends not with a grand boulevard but with a tired shrug, and the morning air, which used to be a kind of invisible mercy, has acquired texture. Not *weather*, exactly. More like an unasked-for condiment. You can almost chew it. The tea—my one stable relationship—goes from aromatic to metallic if I leave the window open, as if the leaves have begun to remember they were once dust themselves.

<Yt src="https://youtube.com/shorts/oBBhUd0azeQ?si=T2AFVk5uRxCyXzJ5" />

Some video says Delhi’s AQI is 402 today. I ask in the comments if it isn’t 420, because of course I do as a responsible Bengali smartass fuckface, because we are a nation that loves numbers the way a child loves firecrackers: loud, meaningless, and vaguely patriotic. 420, the little numeric wink—*charso bees*—the folk code for “cheat,” that sweet Indian invention where the crime is always individual and never structural, as if corruption were a personality trait and not a climate.

I hear myself replying—Are you sure it’s not 420?—and immediately I want to slap myself, because even my sarcasm has become a coping mechanism with air holes. Still, the joke works the way jokes work in a sinking boat: it doesn’t stop the water, but it gives everyone something to do with their hands besides panic.

# Kaisi paheli hein ye AQI? 

<Yt src="https://youtu.be/9pYmkbILGHo?si=vJzYdvZ9O5PF0pr3" />

AQI is a funny acronym. It sounds like a new private engineering college—“A.Q.I. Advanced Quality Institute” (and not the actual simpleton expansion *Air Quality Index*) where the brochure is glossy, the lab equipment is imaginary, and the placement officer is a cousin. And yet, the concept behind it is almost heartbreakingly simple: take a mess of pollutants—PM2.5, PM10, ozone, nitrogen dioxide, sulfur dioxide, carbon monoxide—squash the chaos into a single index, and tell people, in a childproof number, how poisoned their lungs are today. A domesticated apocalypse, alphabetized and converted into a score you can scroll past while buying into the smorgasbord of everyday bullshit and deceit that surround an Indian today. 

My brain, in its tiresome science-and-math brained way, keeps wanting to translate: PM2.5 is particulate matter smaller than 2.5 micrometers, fine enough to sneak past the body’s bouncers—nose hairs, mucus, those pathetic little defenses we pretend are modern infrastructure—and lodge deep in the lungs, sometimes wandering further like an uninvited relative who discovers the guest room and decides to stay. A micrometer is one-millionth of a meter, which is a wonderfully crisp fact until you remember that “one-millionth” is exactly the scale at which our political accountability also operates.

There’s a folk etymology I once heard (and immediately distrusted, which is my only real talent): that “smog” comes from *smoke* plus the Hindi *maug* or *mog* or some other invented syllable allegedly meaning “fog.” मोग (mog) in the Hindwi dictionary is a noun meaning anger / irritation / inner resentment — “गुस्सा, नाराज़गी, मन ही मन की कुढ़न”. This is nonsense, of course; “smog” is just smoke + fog, a portmanteau coined in early 20th century England, the kind of neat little linguistic mash-up that suggests the problem was once quaint enough to name with wordplay. We love these fake derivations because they flatter us: if the word is ours, the phenomenon is ours, which means we own it, which means we can transcend it by chanting something about ancient wisdom. Meanwhile, the actual particles are busy doing chemistry in your alveoli.

I think of my childhood in North Calcutta, when “pollution” meant two-stroke scooters coughing blue ghosts, and the solution was to wave your hand theatrically in front of your face like a Bengali auntie shooing a fly. The air was bad then too, but it was still, in a crude way, *legible*. You could point to the culprit. You could scold it. You could blame a bus. Now the danger has become statistical, diffuse, everywhere, the perfect Indian form: no single villain, only a thousand “small” exceptions adding up to a national condition. The street vendor burns plastic because the municipal bin is missing; the bin is missing because the contractor is absent; the contractor is absent because the tender was a ritual offering to a politician’s nephew; the politician’s nephew is a patriot on television.

The number 402 (or 420, if we’re doing numerology for cynics) is not just a measurement. It’s a mirror held up to a society that has learned to live with slow violence the way we live with potholes: adjust your gait, blame your luck, move on.

And the laity—what a lovely word, laity, like lace—are anesthetized, complicit, victims, accomplices, the whole contradictory circus. I include myself, obviously. I’m sitting here, lecturing into the void, using my vocabulary like a mask, as if a good sentence can filter PM2.5. *Dekho, dekho,* the educated man says, while ordering takeout in plastic.

Nationalism, in this context, becomes a kind of respiratory hallucination. “Indian supremacy” (the phrase itself wheezes) requires a certain kind of air: not the oxygen kind, the narrative kind. It needs the haze of myth, the thick fog of “we were vishwaguru,” the comforting exhaust of ancient greatness pumped into the present to keep the engine of self-regard running. When the literal air becomes unbreathable, the metaphorical air gets even thicker—because people who are suffocating do not want to be told they are suffocating; they want to be told they are heroic divers in a sacred ocean.

There’s a grim comedy here that even Mencken would have enjoyed, if he weren’t busy coughing: the more measurable the disaster becomes, the more mystical the response. Numbers should sober us. Instead they become talismans. 200, 300, 400—like cricket scores. Like marks in an exam. Like GDP targets. Like the number of years our civilization allegedly predates everyone else’s. We are addicts of magnitude.

# In 5 years... 

Give it five more years, I add another comment, and there’ll be haze inside your house and you won’t be able to see your pisser when pissing.

This is grotesque, yes, but it’s also the kind of domestic prophecy that hits harder than any policy paper because it drags the abstract down to the humiliating human level where all truth lives: the bathroom, the throat, the eyes that sting, the child who coughs at night and is told it’s “just allergy,” as if the air itself were a seasonal flower. The body doesn’t care about ideology. The lungs are famously non-partisan. They are equal-opportunity sufferers—though the poor, as usual, get more of the “opportunity.”

In my more manic moments—those little bursts of mental overclocking where everything connects too neatly—I imagine the future Indian home as a terrarium. Sealed windows, humming purifiers, a family sitting inside like rare orchids, scrolling reels about “proud heritage,” while outside the city conducts its daily sacrifice of diesel, dust, crop-burning residue, construction grit, and the sacred smoke of garbage fires. The child asks why the purifier is always on. The parent says, because we are modern. Nobody says, because the world outside has become a slow gas chamber and we’re pretending it’s progress.

Then the depressive clarity arrives, quiet and absolute: we have always done this. Not the purifier part—the denial part. We normalize what should revolt us. We live inside emergencies until they become furniture. We develop a genius for adaptation that is indistinguishable from surrender.

Somewhere in the middle, hope does its shy little Bengali thing—turns up late, doesn’t speak much, sits at the back with its hands folded. It whispers: this is not fate. This is not karma. This is not a cosmic test of national character. This is combustion, regulation failure, incentives, enforcement, urban planning, energy choices, agricultural practice, and the political economy of pretending everything is fine.

Which means, annoyingly, it can be changed.

Not by slogans, obviously. Slogans are air fresheners sprayed in a burning room. Changed by the unglamorous machinery of adulthood: standards that are enforced, transport that works, power that isn’t a coal-fed prayer, waste that isn’t set on fire like a ritual, farmers who aren’t forced into practices that make the sky cough, cities that stop treating construction dust as a natural element like wind or time.

And yet—*and yet*—I know what we will do first. We will argue about the number. We will debate 402 versus 420. We will make memes. We will accuse someone of defaming the nation. We will demand that the air apologize for being anti-national.

<Yt src="https://youtu.be/Nt5lzSUpBWE?si=lpRwsE6MGiAj5Rbx" />

I close the window dancing mentally to "Aaj ki raat hona hein kya." I might suffocate to death but given I have everything that's good in my past, I don't give a fuck anymore "hona hein jo ho jane do." The room smells briefly of old paper and tea leaves and my own stubborn carbon-based existence. Outside, the city continues, busy being itself. The light has that dull, filtered quality—like sunlight seen through a used handkerchief—and for a second the world looks almost cinematic, almost beautiful, the way disasters often do when they’re far enough away from the part of you that has to breathe.


# File: src/lib/posts/three-tits-up.md

---
title: "Three Tits Up"
date: "2026-01-11"

color: "black"

<Pi 
  src="IMG-20251015-WA0007(1).jpg"

It began with a wet fart that wasn’t a fart.

You know the kind—stealth missile, phantom squelch, the ghost of last night’s regretful cholar dal passing gaslit judgment on my foolhardy love of reheated parathas with mouldy mango pickle, all fermented nicely overnight in the dank belly pit I call an abdominal cavity. I shifted sideways on the ceramic throne, legs falling asleep like underpaid interns during Zoom calls, unsure whether what exited my body was biodegradable or actively treasonous.

And that, ladies and unwanted gentlemen, is exactly what it feels like to watch America post-Obama.

A swampy, morally ambiguous, low-pressure intestinal expulsion that starts out with relief and ends with a squirming suspicion that something inside you just gave up its will to persist.

Because let’s face it—this corpse-humping festival of fundamentalist fuckery that now calls itself a country has become so aggressively dumb, so fattened on its own delusional gas that it fancies itself chosen—yes, chosen, like some Old Testament's hairy-ass scrotal itch chosen—while turning the Earth into a warming, charring, wheezing perineum of despair. The three-titted mutant prostitute from *Total Recall* is the sanest metaphor I’ve got for it. A nation lactating idiocy from every hormonal extremity. One tit for Fox News. One for AR-15s. And one for Jesus, but only the white Republican version who hates Mexicans and loves capital gains.

The America I jerked off into at 27 in a dorm room in Texas, enchanted by ethernet porn and Einsteinian equations, that America is now six feet under, replaced by an orgy of opioid-slicked, ketamine-snorting, Christian crypto-fascist QAnon tit-suckers who couldn't tell the Bill of Rights from a Waffle House menu if you stapled it to their unvaccinated dicks.

And yet—and here’s where the bile chokes you mid-belch—it’s not even America’s collapse that’s interesting. It’s the theatrical shoddiness of it all. No Caesar, no Caligula, not even a fucking decent Judas to betray the whole charade with style. Just this endless, spite-lubed gangbang of slow learners humping the Constitution like it’s a sex doll filled with dogma and chewed-up Hot Pockets.

Meanwhile, I’m here, in Calcutta—or whatever pseudo-historic, piss-splattered rebranding they’re calling it now—staring out my concrete balcony at a view so depressing it could send a sugar-addled toddler into existential nihilism. Plastic bags flapping like suicide notes, dogs eating dogs, and the faint scent of sewage mixed with incense because of course God must enjoy the stench of a million fermenting bowels disguised as devotion.

Every day I wake up to the stink of mythological diarrhea—Ram and Sita and Shiva and that thunder-thighed blue prick Krishna and his flute of phallic promises. And Jesus, let’s not forget that Middle Eastern magician with six-pack abs and eternal mommy issues. All of them lined up like contestants in some cosmic cock-measuring contest for the privilege of shoving their doctrine deeper up my cracked philosophical sphincter.

There is no liberation. There is no progress. There is only involuntary clenching and the hope that this turd of a civilization doesn’t rupture the septic tank we call a biosphere before I die. Which I hope is soon. I’m not suicidal, I’m just... ready. Ready for the curtain call. The Final Flush.

But no, I must persist. I must fucking endure, because the universe decided to give me just enough stamina to survive but not enough serotonin to enjoy it. So I stew. I seethe. I scroll. I watch the American government turn into a poorly written sequel to *Idiocracy*, only now with nukes and TikTok diplomacy. I see Elon’s muskrat face tweet genocidal crypto-libertarian diarrhea while people call it genius. I watch Texas freeze while their senators flee to Cancun. I see drag queens treated like war criminals while billionaires build rocket dildos to escape the planet they helped destroy.

And India—oh fuck me sideways with a roti roller—India thinks it’s winning. Winning what? A turd polishing contest? A race to see who can package mythology as modernity faster? We are now a people who name Mars missions after gods who couldn’t navigate their own marriages. A country that bans beef but beats women. Builds statues, not sewage lines. And the ruling ideology? A stinking curry of prepuce-chafed masculinity, economic sleight-of-hand, and saffron-dyed derangement cooked up in WhatsApp kitchens by men whose idea of culture is a spreadsheet of enemies and a log of how many times they’ve jerked off to a female news anchor.

What’s left? Nothing.

Nothing but nervous shits and memories of better lies.

Once, I had hope. I believed in the Enlightenment. Not the woo-woo candle-sniffing wellness version but the cold, hard, Kantian ass-slap of reason. I believed in democracy, flawed but functional, in scientists with crooked teeth and dog-eared journals, in collective curiosity, in vaccines, in NASA, in books with spines, in libraries, in the silence between answers.

Now? I believe in bowel regularity. I believe in cheap rice. I believe in not shitting myself during power cuts. I believe in listening to the gecko in my ceiling more than I believe any elected representative.

And I believe—I really, truly believe—that hell is real.

It’s not fire and brimstone.

It’s a WhatsApp group of your extended family, a torn lungi, and the sound of a neighbor’s child learning to play the recorder at 6 a.m. on Republic Day. It’s the realization that the last time you got an erection was during a dream where you were applying for a voter ID. It’s the third tit of modern civilization—vestigial, obscene, and inexplicably sticky.

And I’ll be there. I’ll arrive with a half-flushed turd of hope still bobbing behind me. They’ll greet me with halal pork, Sanskrit hymns, and a thousand-page tax audit. And I’ll say—

“Take me. I’m ready. Just don’t make me listen to another speech about economic growth while the air smells like burning tires and cancer.”

Three tits up.

And no one’s lactating anything worth drinking.




# File: src/lib/posts/too-good-to-be-true-india.md

---
title: "Too Good To Be True? Welcome to India, You Fucking Moron"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20260112-WA0000.jpg"
date: 2026-01-12
description: "A slowly unraveling, foul-mouthed anatomical fuck-you to the idea that anything nice ever lasts in India. Involving clogged toilets, fake invoices, misplaced erections, and the physics of disappointment."
category: 'personal'
published: true
color: "orange"
---

<Pi src="IMG-20260112-WA0000.jpg" />



I was crouched over the plastic Western toilet that pretends to flush like a real one but gurgles like a drowning buffalo, peeling off the moist strip of toilet paper that had somehow fused into my ass crack like those laminated barcode stickers they put on LPG cylinders, wondering—not for the first time—if I had rectally absorbed yet another fungal infection from the last time the water tank wasn’t cleaned and the pipe brought in liquid diarrhea straight from the Hooghly.  

This is where hope lives in India. In the whorled ring of an asshole clenched against betrayal.

See, in India, the moment anything seems smooth, polished, even faintly competent—an app interface that works, a plumber who arrives on time, a government scheme with actual disbursal—you must recoil like a man who just found a boner in his own mouth during a dream. Because it will fall apart. It will implode. It will self-detonate like a pre-paid mobile plan caught in a neutron star’s gravitational reach. And when it does, you will find yourself, as I did, one leg raised like an arthritic flamingo, reaching for Dettol with the panicked flailing of a man trying to put out a fire using piss.  

Take the broadband guy, for instance. He came. Yes, came. Not like the verb in the adult films but the actual miracle: he *showed up*. With tools. Wires. A fucking tester. He even *smiled*—that soft, neutered corporate smile worn by those who've been forced to complete a “customer delight” training module made by a Canadian who’s never seen a power cut. He fixed the fiber line, ran a speed test, *explained* the jitter graph. It was *too good*. Too straight. Too fucking normal. So of course, twelve hours later, the whole line was rerouted to someone else’s goddamn account, and my connection now services the astrologer downstairs who believes the Wi-Fi interferes with his Vishuddha chakra.  

Physics has laws. India has punishments for expecting them to work.

This country operates like a turd floating in Schrödinger's toilet—both flushed and not flushed, depending on whether the municipality inspector is visiting your ward that day or attending the fifth cousin’s Ganesh puja opening ceremony of a new sweet shop that also sells SIM cards and does Aadhaar linking in the back.  

The middle class here, oh the motherfucking middle class, runs on denial the way diesel generators run in blackout zones. Denial and EMIs. When something works—say a footbridge doesn't collapse or a payment clears without a bribe—it’s taken as *auspicious*. Like a planetary alignment. Rahu got bored. Mercury didn't retrograde. Or the engineer didn’t drink Old Monk for breakfast.  

Because systems, here, are not *systems*. They are *gestures*. 

Which brings me to the tea kettle. My beloved fucking electric tea kettle. Bought online during one of those idiotic “Big Billion” sales where everything's supposedly 80% off but ships with the gravitational sadness of being repackaged by underpaid teens with an ear infection. It worked like a dream. For *four days*. Then it hissed like a snake with TB and tripped the entire house. Turns out, it wasn’t grounded. Not metaphorically. *Electrically*. I could've died making chai. Imagine the obituary: “Man found half-boiled, dick out, corpse smelling faintly of Lipton.”  

But nobody would investigate. They’d say, “Arrey, must have been his time.”  

You’d think, maybe, science would save us. But no. In India, even entropy has a bureaucracy. Everything decays *with supervision*. Government schools decay with a teacher who signs in but never shows. Flyovers decay with vendors frying pakoras on the expansion joints. Bodies decay in hospitals where the only refrigeration works in the canteen selling stale idlis for ₹80.  

Trust dies here. Not in flames, but in gurgles. Like the sound my geyser makes when it pretends to heat.  

Once I tried to get a water purifier repaired. Big brand. I called the helpline. Spoke to three voices that were definitely generated by some AI bot trained on English call center trauma. A guy arrived two weeks later. He looked fifteen. Wore no badge. Smelled like onion bhaji and Lynx body spray. Fixed something, took cash, and *vanished*. Turned out he wasn't from Aquaguard. He was from WhatsApp. Like, literally. A WhatsApp contact. The real company denied him. I had basically invited a teenage conman to fuck my filtration membrane.  

And I *paid* him.  

We’re a country where the false version of anything is easier to access than the real thing. Fake doctor? Every lane. Fake saffron robe? ₹100. Fake organic eggs? Why not. Fake nationalism? Oh boy. You can’t swing your dick without slapping a cow-worshipping loudmouth whose last brush with patriotism was downloading a Salman Khan biopic torrent.  

This is why in India the moment something is beautiful—honestly, staggeringly good—your instinct should not be gratitude but *panic*. 

That job offer? It’s got an HR clause hidden in the offer letter that says your salary will be performance-linked to the number of times you say “sir” in meetings.

That girl who laughed at your joke and touched your arm? She’s selling real estate or crypto or maybe her cousin needs a kidney. Yours.

That government app that seems to work? Don’t. It’s harvesting your location, contacts, Aadhaar, PAN, sexual fantasies, and your mother’s weight.  

This paranoia isn’t cynicism. It’s *hygiene*. Like washing your ass after using the toilet—which, ironically, also doesn’t happen in half the households here because people believe wiping with newspaper gives you character.

You know what character I’ve got now? Fungal.  

Every time I feel a twinge of optimism—like maybe, just maybe, the shipment will arrive on time, or the government portal won’t crash at 11:59 pm on the last day to file returns—I develop a rash. A literal one. Optimism manifests as hives on my lower back and occasionally an erection so ill-timed and limp it looks like a sock full of regret.  

Which is fair, because this country has taught me the *physics* of disappointment. Not the “oh, that's sad” kind. No, the Newtonian, gravitation-pulled, iron-ball-to-your-nutsack kind of disappointment. The energy conserved is always humiliation.  

Because nothing real works here without jugaad, grease, or groveling. Nothing. And the people who claim otherwise are either lying, NRI, or own shares in Paytm.  

I once tried to buy a decent pair of scissors. Ended up with a pair that cut at 37 degrees to the plane of intention. You try cutting paper and it tears diagonally into the shape of Kashmir. Maybe it was a metaphor. Or maybe some fucker in the assembly line was just high.  

Either way, the scissors don’t work.

And I still can’t find the original invoice.

I was watching Sharad Sharma—ex-NDTV, one of the few still stupid-brave enough to point a camera at reality without licking anyone’s boots—reporting from Delhi where laborers were getting slowly ass-fucked by pollution, contracts evaporating, lungs turning into damp ashtrays, their stories spoken cleanly and then dropped straight through the cracks like coins through a torn pocket. And it wasn’t him I was thinking about—he’s fine, he’s hustling, he’s built himself a little life raft out of bandwidth and backbone—but about everyone else watching silently, the ones without the entrepreneurial reflex, the branding gene, the stomach for YouTube thumbnails and daily outrage. The people whose lives were shaped narrow and sharp by higher education and specialization, trained like instruments for a society that no longer needs the music—researchers, engineers, archivists, domain experts, the overeducated and underutilized—now fucked just as thoroughly as the daily-wage laborer, only quieter, cleaner, and therefore easier to ignore. In this kakistocracy, joblessness isn’t a phase, it’s rabid, and it doesn’t care whether you know quantum mechanics or just how to carry bricks; if your skill doesn’t convert directly into spectacle or scale, your story dissolves, undocumented, unmonetized, and un-mourned.

<Yt src="https://youtu.be/BvhmIjpXT1s?si=NRZDJUSXUCiS8-fd" />

Because let’s get this out of the way: the myth that only rickshaw-pulling, paan-spitting, one-lunged proletariat fucks are drowning in this economy? Horseshit. Everybody’s drowning. The middle class is just better at holding its breath and updating its LinkedIn while floating face down.

And no, it’s not just the saffron dipshits or that man-child in a muffler who sells hopium laced with Excel graphs and rented tears. Every fucking party in India, once in power, slips into that old caste-lubed rhythm of loot-fuck-hide, jizzing onto the Constitution with the glee of a coaching center lecturer who just sniffed his first parcel of black money. Doesn’t matter if they chant in Sanskrit, Arabic, or broken Hinglish—once they’re sworn in, your vote becomes a mosquito buzz they swat away with barricades and black SUVs.

I live in a cement fart of a room with one plastic chair that sounds like arthritis when I sit, a fridge that smells of onion murder, and a mind full of borrowed books I can't afford to read without spiraling into existential defecation. And still—*still*—some fucks on TV have the saggy tits to say we’re a rising superpower.

We’re not rising. We’re rotting upwards.

What we have is not democracy. It’s not even oligarchy. It’s *murgimocracy*—a coop where the loudest rooster gets beheaded and the others are too stupid to remember tomorrow. The elections are WWE scripts ghostwritten by Ambanis, and each new administration is a fresh strain of syphilis wearing a Nehru jacket or a Ram Mandir selfie on its forehead like a fucking QR code for fascism.

Meanwhile, on ground zero, every second household has a daughter who’s suicidal, a father who’s bankrupt, a mother peddling turmeric as cancer cure, and a brother worshipping Andrew Tate while failing competitive exams like it’s a family tradition. I’ve seen men with MTechs eat banana peels out of hotel trash piles in Ballygunge because their startups failed and their wives left with the last working fan.

But Satya Meva Jayate, right? Truth triumphs. Except in real life it doesn’t. In real life, truth’s a broke-ass whore who’s been fucked raw by too many slogans and now walks funny. Truth, my dear, smells like leaking sewer gas and sounds like the resignation letter of an honest civil servant being quietly shredded at 2AM while the PM records a yoga video.

There’s a special breed of Bengali intellectual who still thinks we can *debate* our way out of this, sipping watery coffee and stroking their limp Marxist egos while pretending the world gives a fuck about Tagore quotes. I used to be one. Now I just smell like feet and microwave mutton.

And science? Hah. Science in India is like that ancient condom in your wallet—there for moral support but never used. Every minister with half a liver and zero IQ now spews cow urine as vaccine, Vedas as astrophysics, and builds statues so tall they can’t hear the cries of hungry kids in the shadow below.

Meanwhile, I wait four hours for water because my building tank is filled once a week by a man who smells like diesel and failure, and during those hours I write these invisible thoughts on a phone that heats up like my scalp under this paralyzed fan. My pubes are sticky with sweat and irony.

You want a bodily metaphor?

Being Indian today is like having hemorrhoids on a public bus—you can’t scream, you can’t sit, and every bump on the road is a fresh insult to your dignity.

You want history?

Let’s talk about how we inherited not just railways and bureaucracy from our colonizers, but also their most exquisite gift: **the ability to repress dissent with dignity**, to lie with straight backs and folded hands. Our leaders don’t silence opposition with jackboots—they do it with legalese and WhatsApp leaks, press raids and Pegasus cock-in-ear spyware. We've made Orwell look like a naïve optimist.

And the common man? Ah, that poor dickless bastard. Fed a diet of mythology, revenge porn, cricket highlights, and job scams. Ganja is illegal but rapists get parades. An influencer can sell you protein powder for 3000 bucks, but your anemia test costs a month’s wage and still comes stamped with errors.

I once had an idea for a health tech startup. Built a full EHR prototype. Scalable, localized, resilient. You know what I got?

A mouthful of spit from investors asking if I could "make it AI so Modi ji can talk to villagers in Hindi."

I told them I could also make the app fart and sing bhajans while jacking off to GDP charts.

Didn’t go well.

Anyway, here I am, eating cold bread with onion salt because I’m too broke to buy eggs, too old to beg, too proud to sell my ass, and too jaded to hope.

Hope.

Hope is like that last fart you trust before a long walk—you think it’s safe but it stains.

And me?

I’m a 50-year-old bipolar Bengali with a death wish for every politician. 

Last week I masturbated to a cooking video because the woman used mustard oil like a goddess and I hadn’t tasted mustard oil in a month.

The soul hungers in strange ways.

And now the bread's got mold.

But it’s democracy, so I eat it anyway. And the truth? It doesn't dance, it doesn't flirt, it doesn’t do Bollywood pelvic thrusts while waving tricolor condoms in the air. Truth does not the entertaining cut make. It drags, it itches, it mutters like an old man pissing in installments. My truth has that gritty, sandy, mouthful-of-ash texture, like the kind you taste after watching a Mrinal Sen film alone in the dark while your neighbour blasts Daler Mehndi next door. Or the kind Ray wrapped inside those quiet shots of rusted railings and hopeless eyes—no slow-mo hero, no punchline, just the slow rot of dignity. And like that, my posts—these disturbed, shit-slicked, cum-sour atheist spasms of bile—make the holy citizens of this chemically neutered republic flinch. Because nothing unsettles the faith-wanking majority more than someone who doesn’t kneel, doesn’t chant, doesn’t fake reverence, and still refuses to die quietly.
 


# File: src/lib/posts/unlike-rene-descartes-i-shit-therefore-i-am.md

---
title: "Unlike René Descartes, I Shit Therefore I Am"
thumbnail: "/images/IMG-20251015-WA0011(1).jpg"
date: 2026-01-12
